column7: b'The Top Dawg label\xe2\x80\x99s latest signee is Inglewood-bred crooner\xc2\xa0Sir Darryl Farris, aka SiR. His latest EP embraces restraint and subtlety\xe2\x80\x94a pure, 18-minute jolt\xc2\xa0of traditionalist R&B.'
column8: b'Since the early 2000s, the proprietors of the TDE label\xe2\x80\x94Anthony \xe2\x80\x9cTop Dawg\xe2\x80\x9d Tiffith, Dave \xe2\x80\x9cMiyatola\xe2\x80\x9d Free, and Terrence \xe2\x80\x9cPunch\xe2\x80\x9d Henderson\xe2\x80\x94have made\xc2\xa0a\xc2\xa0home for\xc2\xa0more critical darlings per capita than perhaps any other hip-hop-dominated outpost. Each of the last three acts signed to TDE (SZA, Lance Skiiiwalker, SiR) have been R&B artists, an indication that the moment\xe2\x80\x99s hottest rap label is perhaps looking to expand its palate.' b'The latest signee is Sir Darryl Farris, aka SiR, an Inglewood-born-and-bred crooner who has spent years following in the footsteps of his older brothers, the songwriters Daniel and Davion Farris (aka WoodWorks), writing for\xc2\xa0artists behind the scenes.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s uncanny for a mainstream R&B newcomer to have started out penning tracks for Jill Scott, Robert Glasper, Stevie Wonder, and Anita Hill\xc2\xa0rather than Drake or Rihanna, but this is central to SiR\xe2\x80\x99s ethos.' b'Her Too is an 18-minute jolt\xc2\xa0of pure, traditionalist R&B and neo-soul. SiR\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0successes lay in his polish and maturity. In this lane, his\xc2\xa0peers have recently focused\xc2\xa0on self-discovery, nostalgia ultra, and experiments in\xc2\xa0form, but\xc2\xa0SiR\xe2\x80\x99s concerns are\xc2\xa0in subtlety, restraint, and finesse.\xc2\xa0SiR\xe2\x80\x99s releases, then\xe2\x80\x942016\xe2\x80\x99s HER EP and 2015\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Seven Sundays among them\xe2\x80\x94have lacked a masterpiece like his labelmate\xc2\xa0Kendrick Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Art of Peer Pressure.\xe2\x80\x9d But\xc2\xa0Her Too contains fantastic analogues to Jay Rock\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cHood Gone Love It,\xe2\x80\x9d which are a purist\xe2\x80\x99s thrill.' b'Much of Her Too feels warm and leisurely. SiR has said he was aiming for something darker than his previous EP, but the project doesn\xe2\x80\x99t live up to that\xc2\xa0description, save for a few bars on the Anderson .Paak- and King Mez-assisted opener \xe2\x80\x9cNew LA.\xe2\x80\x9d King Mez raps, \xe2\x80\x9cMan why we take the murder route?/Shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t we be worried about niggas dying, niggas dying?/Or we could just not say shit and take the Cam Newton scary route.\xe2\x80\x9d As virtually the only patch of lyrics that aren\xe2\x80\x99t explicitly romantic, it\xe2\x80\x99s a bit\xc2\xa0discordant. On it\xe2\x80\x99s face, it\xe2\x80\x99s a whimsical and somewhat\xc2\xa0funny, topical sports reference. But it plays into the pathology that, no matter a black person\xe2\x80\x99s station in life\xe2\x80\x94and even if they\xe2\x80\x99re currently blinded by love and passion\xe2\x80\x94the threat of state-sanctioned violence lingers in the back of the mind, ready to punch itself into the foreground at a moment\xe2\x80\x99s notice.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cNew LA\xe2\x80\x9d is nonetheless the project\xe2\x80\x99s brightest and most buoyant moment. Cardiak samples Drake\xe2\x80\x99s overlooked \xe2\x80\x9cWith You,\xe2\x80\x9d crafting a saccharine trance of a beat. \xe2\x80\x9cOoh Nah Nah\xe2\x80\x9d is a smooth, sultry number featuring Masego\xe2\x80\x99s vocals and darting saxophone; it finds SiR bellowing in a tenor full of lust. Five of the six songs here\xc2\xa0embrace a degree of calm, but the closer \xe2\x80\x9cW$ Boi\xe2\x80\x9d possesses kinetic energy that explodes in\xc2\xa0the chorus, as SiR shouts that he\xe2\x80\x99s a \xe2\x80\x9cwestside boy.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s like SiR\xe2\x80\x99s version of \xe2\x80\x9cUptown Girl,\xe2\x80\x9d which is Billy Joel\xe2\x80\x99s Romeo and Juliet\xe2\x80\x94the template for an endless trove of tales about star-crossed lovers.' b"In his real life, Sir Darryl Farris is about\xc2\xa030, and he\xe2\x80\x99s been with his wife for the better part of a decade. About seven years ago, he was in Hollywood jobless, drug-addicted, and nearly homeless. The W$ Boi returned home and started writing songs in his mother\xe2\x80\x99s house, which eventually turned his life around. SiR proclaims, \xe2\x80\x9cI don't know if she knows/She don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I been through.\xe2\x80\x9d Even amid a song that could afford to be a bit\xc2\xa0more chaotic, the result is a contained personal anthem. SiR\xe2\x80\x99s debut album is slated to come out whenever Top Dawg chooses, but up to this point,\xc2\xa0his story is one of triumph."

column7: b'On his third proper\xc2\xa0Bing & Ruth album, and first for 4AD,\xc2\xa0David Moore\xe2\x80\x99s electroacoustic minimalism carries its strongest emotional tug. It\xe2\x80\x99s his earthiest and most distinctive record yet.'
column8: b'Bing & Ruth\xe2\x80\x99s music exists in the cracks between. Project leader David Moore has a degree in music and his earlier compositions, found on the 2010 album City Lake, can have the air of the conservatory. So it makes some sense to slot his work in with\xc2\xa0contemporary classical. But the era of classical music Moore\xc2\xa0most frequently evokes\xe2\x80\x94the trance-inducing minimalism of the 1960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s\xe2\x80\x94has at times been filed as new age. And divisions between *that *genre and the more critically acceptable sphere of \xe2\x80\x9cambient,\xe2\x80\x9d a word that sometimes describes Bing & Ruth, have always been porous. Beyond these labels, Bing & Ruth is also hard to pin functionally. Moore\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0pieces can feel formal, less like \xe2\x80\x9cenvironments\xe2\x80\x9d and more like compositions that need to be tracked carefully over their duration to be understood. Though he\xe2\x80\x99s made music for an ensemble that includes woodwinds and strings, Moore\xc2\xa0also includes processed tapes and production choices that smudge the lines between acoustic and electronic music.' b'On City Lake and 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Tomorrow Was the Golden Age, Moore\xe2\x80\x99s music evoked the best of what had come before him\xe2\x80\x94Philip Glass\xe2\x80\x99 repetition, the emotional shading of Max Richter, Eluvium\xe2\x80\x99s comfort with rock dynamics\xe2\x80\x94but he\xe2\x80\x99s steadily grown into a sound that feels all his own. No Home of the Mind, his third proper album and first for 4AD, is his most distinctive record yet. His working group is still here, but the arrangements on *No Home *feature Moore\xe2\x80\x99s piano much more prominently, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a more focused record. If City Lake and Tomorrow sometimes found him moving between established styles, demonstrating wide-ranging mastery because he can, the new album stays focused on wringing as much feeling as possible out of narrower terrain. And No Home of the Mind is the earthiest Bing & Ruth record yet.\xc2\xa0You can smell the sweat that went into it.' b'One of Moore\xe2\x80\x99s composition signatures is to turn the piano into a drone instrument. Using rapid clusters of repeating notes, Moore creates piano figures that hang in space like clouds of slowly shifting sound, not unlike passages of La Monte Young\xe2\x80\x99s The Well-Tuned Piano or the work of Young acolytes like Michael Harrison. Where the latter two artists are known for using the piano as a tool for overtones via specialized tuning, Moore creates piano-based drones that serve as the basis for his ensemble pieces. The other instruments\xe2\x80\x99 parts exist in relationship to what he\xe2\x80\x99s doing at the keyboard, offering contrasting textures and leading through varying shifts in mood and tone. It\xe2\x80\x99s almost as if all the separate parts come together into a single instrument, one that is \xe2\x80\x9cplayed\xe2\x80\x9d collectively by the Bing & Ruth ensemble.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cStarwood Choker\xe2\x80\x9d starts the album sounding like a continuation of the last Bing & Ruth record\xe2\x80\x99s criss-crossing tapestries of sound. But the record really begins\xc2\xa0to reveal itself on \xe2\x80\x9cAs Much as Possible,\xe2\x80\x9d which finds Moore in the realm of \xe2\x80\x9csolo piano with ambient treatments\xe2\x80\x9d \xc3\xa0 la Brian Eno and Harold Budd\xe2\x80\x99s *The Pearl. *Moore\xe2\x80\x99s chord voicings suggest both gospel music and the spare \xe2\x80\x9cfurniture music\xe2\x80\x9d of Satie. As he moves between modes, extremely subtle bits of tension are introduced, built, and then released, while yawning chasms of drone from the ensemble drift in and out beneath. \xe2\x80\x9cAs Much as Possible\xe2\x80\x9d is Moore\xe2\x80\x99s most tender and affecting piece yet, a filmic work that evokes haunting images on its own.' b'Throughout the rest of No Home, the piano moves between heavy drone (\xe2\x80\x9cForm Takes\xe2\x80\x9d), achingly spare and meditative ballads (\xe2\x80\x9cTo All It\xe2\x80\x9d), and pieces that explore how much can be done with simple repetition (\xe2\x80\x9cThe How of It Sped\xe2\x80\x9d). The tracks flow one into the next, which accentuates the connections between them and makes *No Home *feel like a single massive piece, carefully mapping every inch of its defined terrain. Moore is so gifted at teasing out emotion, it seems inevitable that there will be many film and television scores\xc2\xa0in his future, if he chooses to go that route. If that happens, *No Home of the Mind *will be remembered as his breakthrough, the place where all the pieces from earlier records snapped into place.'

column7: b'The latest LP from Moon Duo builds on\xc2\xa0their\xc2\xa0psychedelic formula\xe2\x80\x94corroded guitars, kraut rhythms, steely grit\xe2\x80\x94and\xc2\xa0allows them to\xc2\xa0indulge their most sinister tendencies.'
column8: b'Four albums deep, Moon Duo have grown somewhat predictable. The collaboration of Wooden Shijps\xe2\x80\x99 guitar-warlock Ripley Johnson and keyboardist Sanae Yamada has always been built on a steady but enjoyable mix of elements: corroded guitars, loopy keyboard lines, krautrock rhythms, and psychedelic strains conjuring\xc2\xa0both the whirling cosmos and droning abyss. Their new album Occult Architecture Vol. 1 does little to alter the formula, but the key to Moon Duo records has always been the strength of the compositions. And those\xc2\xa0already onboard with the band won\xe2\x80\x99t be disappointed by the seven tracks here.' b'Touted as representing the depths and changes of the seasons, Occult Architecture Vol. 1\xc2\xa0delves into the bleaker corners of winter and allows Moon Duo to indulge their most sinister tendencies. Like many a great Moon Duo song, opener \xe2\x80\x9cThe Death Set\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0is at once swaggering, sexy, and foreboding. Much of their\xc2\xa0music is low-key cinematic; it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to hear \xe2\x80\x9cThe Death Set\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0distorted, slow-motion whoosh or its bone-rattling beat and not imagine a character\xe2\x80\x99s dramatic entrance into an unnerving nightclub. Elsewhere, like on \xe2\x80\x9cCold Fear\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cWill of the Devil,\xe2\x80\x9d they use queasy electronic textures to flirt with gothier territory.' b'Well past the lower-fi nature of their earliest work, Moon Duo still don\xe2\x80\x99t operate with a ton\xc2\xa0of dynamic range. But they use those heart-palpitating rhythms and lacerating keyboard lines to build blown-out, end-times\xc2\xa0epics littered with subtle twists. Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s death-drive guitars propel \xe2\x80\x9cCult of Moloch\xe2\x80\x9d forward unwaveringly, but interjections of synth and a second, spiraling guitar part make the song feel like\xc2\xa0it\xe2\x80\x99s reaching for spiritual corners of nature. Closer \xe2\x80\x9cWhite Rose\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94one long synth ride\xe2\x80\x94has a similar effect, winding down a\xc2\xa0road into the distance. Moon Duo haven\xe2\x80\x99t gone full-on mystic, however; the new album maintains the steely grit of its predecessor, Shadow of the Sun**.\xc2\xa0Theirs is music still meant for barreling down desert highways in a stolen car, or for the grind and smog of a third-tier industrial city.' b"That said, Moon Duo isn\xe2\x80\x99t the kind of group to make albums with literal thematic angles. Their style has limits, but discernibility is maybe not the point. Moon Duo\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0precise mix of traditions and sounds conjures a\xc2\xa0nihilistic cool, an image of leather-jacketed outlaws chain-smoking in dark alleyways in seedy cities. Occult Architecture Vol. 1 is a good record that\xe2\x80\x99s at its best when Moon Duo fully give in to these seductive inklings, like on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Death Set\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cCreepin.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Sure, we\xe2\x80\x99ve heard the riff from \xe2\x80\x9cCreepin'\xe2\x80\x9d before, but it\xe2\x80\x99s nice to hear it again."

column7: b'The London DJ born\xc2\xa0Joseph Richmond Seaton crafts a set that channels Fabric\xe2\x80\x99s late-hours ambience, when things get weird and wooly.'
column8: b'At its best, a\xc2\xa0nightclub can be a scale model of utopia, a shared hallucination, an alternate reality that lasts as long as the house lights stay dark. The same holds true for mix CDs. Most merely operate as calling cards for the DJ making them, or flyers for the club promoting them. Occasionally, though, they aspire to be something more ambitious: a postcard from that imaginary place that the best club nights conjure into being out of sheer force of collective will.' b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the context in which Call Super\xe2\x80\x99s Fabric 92 comes to us. The London DJ, aka Joseph Richmond Seaton, says that he intended the release\xc2\xa0as a snapshot of the late hours of his sets, when consensus floor-fillers give way to stranger, more personal selections. That\xe2\x80\x99s one unusual thing about the mix; another is that it was born in the wild, but raised in captivity, as it were. His choice of theme and mood reflects a careful study of Fabric\xe2\x80\x99s mix series as much as it does his time in the booth at the London venue. Noticing that the late hours seemed \xe2\x80\x9cstrangely under represented\xe2\x80\x9d within the series, he writes, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought it would be good to start there instead of using this opportunity to add another peak-time chapter to the collection.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Commercial mix CDs have lost the central role in DJ culture that they enjoyed in the \xe2\x80\x9990s and \xe2\x80\x9900s; thanks to the internet, mixes are everywhere now, and free. But, perhaps precisely because no one has time to listen to even a fraction of them, Fabric\xe2\x80\x99s series is more of a canon-maker than ever. Fabric 92 is, above all, a testament to digging widely and without prejudice. Beneath house and techno\xe2\x80\x99s broad umbrella, it\xe2\x80\x99s as diverse a set as you\xe2\x80\x99ll find, spanning multiple eras, styles, and scenes, and boasting a final 14 minutes that veers way out into the deep end, from drone to country blues to polemical dancehall reggae.' b'Seaton\xe2\x80\x99s selections are spellbinding, as\xc2\xa0every track presents a self-contained world of its own. Some, like Don\xe2\x80\x99t DJ\xe2\x80\x99s polyrhythmic \xe2\x80\x9cPornoire,\xe2\x80\x9d are wildly complex; others, like the flickering electro of Shanti Celeste\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cStrung Up,\xe2\x80\x9d are relatively tidy. The cumulative effect of the way he layers and strings them all together is akin to moving through a series of wormholes, flashing from landscape to landscape while standing in place. His mixing is never ostentatious, but it generally emphasizes action. It\xe2\x80\x99s rare that a song is left to play out unaccompanied; far more often, he\xe2\x80\x99s got two and even three tracks running in parallel, resulting in a dynamic, shape-shifting fusion that\xe2\x80\x99s far more than the sum of its parts. Early on, he combines muted, shuffling cuts from Jan Jelinek and from Wolfgang Voigt\xe2\x80\x99s M:I:5 project to mossy\xc2\xa0effect, as though burrowing through underbrush, while using the doleful trumpet of Beatrice Dillon and Rupert Clervaux\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Same River Twice\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0to draw bright, silvery streaks overhead.' b'A few tracks later, following an early climax brought on by his friend Objekt\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Stitch-Up\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94whipcracks, shrapnel, a heart-in-mouth ostinato\xe2\x80\x94he turns to relatively obscure, mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s cuts from Photek and Two Full Minds to create a subaquatic atmosphere. That relative calm sets up the mix\xe2\x80\x99s most white-knuckled passage, in which Flanger\xe2\x80\x99s head-scratching \xe2\x80\x9cSpinner,\xe2\x80\x9d in 10/4 time, is teased in and out of Carl Craig\xe2\x80\x99s epic \xe2\x80\x9cA Wonderful Life\xe2\x80\x9d for three minutes of tug-of-war. At several points, it feels like it could all collapse into the mud at any moment, but it\xe2\x80\x99s precisely that sense of risk that\xe2\x80\x99s so exhilarating.' b"On the downhill slope, Seaton switches into a more sentimental gear, leaning heavily on melodic IDM and electro from Marco Bernardi, Jega, Shanti Celeste, and Bitstream; concluding with a fleet-footed Detroit techno skip from Convextion, this might be the set\xe2\x80\x99s most satisfying segment. But Seaton has one final trick up his sleeve. As Convextion\xe2\x80\x99s beats fade away, a pair of ambient drones from Karen Gwyer and Thomas Ankersmit & Valerio Tricoli shimmer brightly in the darkness, and a lilting, sing-song speaking voice rings out: \xe2\x80\x9cWell I\xe2\x80\x99m just walkin\xe2\x80\x99/I\xe2\x80\x99m trying to find the end/But every time I stop/Look like my trouble just begin.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s Walter Brown's \xe2\x80\x9cKeep on\xc2\xa0Walkin\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d an a cappella country blues recorded in Mississippi in 1981 by a pair of German ethnomusicologists." b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hardly the first time that archival blues has turned up in dance music\xe2\x80\x94Moby, you may recall, built his empire on wringing as much authenticity as he could out of vintage recordings of black Americans\xe2\x80\x99 voices. But Seaton\xe2\x80\x99s approach, which sets Brown\xe2\x80\x99s rueful blues in an imaginary summer night, lit only by stars and fireflies, is far stranger. And in the context of a club set, it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing short of audacious. Eventually, Yves Tumor\xe2\x80\x99s woozy, soulful \xe2\x80\x9cThe Feeling When You Walk Away\xe2\x80\x9d takes us by the hand and leads us back toward the light, and Speng Bond\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCutbacks,\xe2\x80\x9d a dancehall reggae tune about economic austerity policies, sends us home feeling righteous. But for just a moment there, at the tail end of the set\xe2\x80\x99s spellbinding denouement, everything falls silent as Walter Brown\xe2\x80\x99s plaintive voice carries on unaccompanied: \xe2\x80\x9cOn my knees, I\xe2\x80\x99m gonna just/Keep on walkin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d In a journey full of left turns and switchbacks, this calm, quiet testament to faith and fortitude speaks the loudest; it\xe2\x80\x99s a moment when absolutely anything feels possible.'

column7: b'The minimal dub-techno landscapes that Jacob Long makes as Earthen Sea carry a sense of refinement and grace. Each element of his Kranky debut is radiant.'
column8: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s rare to have any vocals appear on of the fog-enshrouded landscapes that Jacob Long devises as Earthen Sea. But earlier this month, Long cleared out his hard drive with A Serious Thing, a nine-track compilation of tracks recorded in the past three years (with all proceeds going to the International Refugee Assistance Project, American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, and the National Lawyers Guild). Less than a minute in, the voice of firebrand gay Harlem intellectual James Baldwin emerges from the mists and speaks of the crucial role of dreamers\xc2\xa0in their respective societies. \xe2\x80\x9cThe poets (by which I mean all artists) are finally the only people who know the truth about us,\xe2\x80\x9d Baldwin said. \xe2\x80\x9cSoldiers don\xe2\x80\x99t, statesmen don\xe2\x80\x99t, priests don\xe2\x80\x99t, union leaders don\xe2\x80\x99t. Only the poets.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'And while there are no words and no voices that appear on An Act of Love, Long\xe2\x80\x99s debut for Kranky, that poet\xe2\x80\x99s search for an undeniable truth powers the eight breathtaking tracks that appear here. A hardcore veteran who\xe2\x80\x99s played in D.C. bands like Amalgamation and Black Eyes, Long later played bass in the adventurous punk act Mi Ami. Over time, that trio mutated from art-rock towards the sounds of Chicago house and Jamaican dub, soon splintering into three separate electronic acts: drummer Damon Palermo became Magic Touch and guitarist Daniel Martin-McCormick became Ital.' b'Long himself took the foundations of dub as the starting point for his next iteration, Earthen Sea. Much like the godfathers of minimal techno\xe2\x80\x94Moritz von Oswald and Mark Ernestus, Vladislav Delay circa Multila,\xc2\xa0the entire Chain Reaction roster\xe2\x80\x94Long realized there was sublimity to be had in endless reverb, delay, and its sonic residue. And with 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Mirage, released on Martin-McCormick\xe2\x80\x99s Lovers Rock label, Earthen Sea\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic solidified. An Act of Love is a continuation of that effort, though there\xe2\x80\x99s a feeling\xc2\xa0of refinement and awareness that gives each element here a heightened radiance. Even in the buzzing static and air organ chords that comprise beatless opener \xe2\x80\x9cThe Present Mist,\xe2\x80\x9d there\xe2\x80\x99s a sense of grace, of deep breaths being drawn musically that makes it standout from other ambient noise of its ilk.' b'Earthen Sea makes\xc2\xa0minimal dub techno, but while Long\xe2\x80\x99s components are suggestive of dance music\xe2\x80\x94especially the 707 that drives most of the tracks\xe2\x80\x94the context for each programmed hit seems to not be a packed club. Rather, Earthen Sea could soundtrack\xc2\xa0a depopulated metropolis, each beat bouncing off of concrete. A squelchy kick drives \xe2\x80\x9cAbout That Time\xe2\x80\x9d and other elements wash in: a canned clap, a tapped ride cymbal, a piano line as contemplative and sonorous as that of Harold Budd. But underneath all of that is a gloriously slow swell of white noise, which rises and falls like an incoming tide and is mesmerizing in and of itself.' b'The muffled \xe2\x80\x9cApparent Lushness\xe2\x80\x9d sounds as if it was recorded four feet underwater, its pretty melody reminiscent of something off of J\xc3\xbcrgen M\xc3\xbcller\xe2\x80\x99s Science of the Sea, shining through the ripples. It segues into the centerpiece \xe2\x80\x9cExuberant Burning,\xe2\x80\x9d with Long taking a flare of feedback and making it arc across the sky like a vapor trail. A bass throbs along with the beat, and these elements all hover in place before Long adds live drums and cymbals, and moves the track forward again. A sound not unlike the distant roar of passing cars on a highway comes up, giving the track an uncanny sense of space.' b'After a brief interlude, the album peaks with the muscular kick of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Flats 1975,\xe2\x80\x9d breaking out of the noirish mood of the previous tracks and offering up a sense of much-needed physical release. In the press materials\xc2\xa0for the album, Long noted that the months leading up to the recording of An Act of Love were \xe2\x80\x9cthe most emotionally difficult and stressful year in my life,\xe2\x80\x9d which might be a sentiment shared by most people in the calendar year of 2016. But despite the darkness that intrudes in on the album\xe2\x80\x94from the inky cover to the gloaming sounds within to the despairing environment in which it now enters our present day\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s nevertheless a small kernel of hope to be gleaned. Long goes on to discuss the inspiration he got from empty city streets in the dead of night and the realization that regardless there are still people all around, as well as \xe2\x80\x9cthe openness and possibilities that [they] can bring.\xe2\x80\x9d While Long only uses a steady beat and some deeply resonant chords to convey this revelation, he nevertheless moves like a poet to unearth that heartening sense of truth here.'

column7: b'With her second album as Mozart\xe2\x80\x99s Sister, Montreal\xe2\x80\x99s Caila Thompson-Hannant uses aggressively bubbly synth-pop and unhinged vocals to explore the peculiarities of love.'
column8: b'A few years ago, a tow-truck driver in Texas asked Caila Thompson-Hannant a seemingly simple question: \xe2\x80\x9cDo you wanna be big in music?\xe2\x80\x9d But the D.I.Y.-bred Montreal artist was taken aback. \xe2\x80\x9cI honestly could not answer him,\xe2\x80\x9d she recalled in a recent interview. \xe2\x80\x9cIt kinda shook me, and I thought a lot about it mostly because I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t sure exactly what I wanted.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'After playing in offbeat art-rock bands like Shapes and Sizes and Think About Life, Thompson-Hannant went solo as Mozart\xe2\x80\x99s Sister in 2011. Ever since, the dance-pop project has been a conduit for her zany, freewheeling impulses as a songwriter and producer. And with her second album, more than ever, she\xe2\x80\x99s prioritizing her endearing peculiarity over any sort of run at stardom.' b'Field of Love is an obvious lurch forward from her debut, which at times had Thompson-Hannant coddling some of her quirks in appeasing, indistinct production. By contrast, the instrumentation on the new record is daring, aggressively bubbly, and sharp. As an extension of her love-buzzed lyrics, which can turn from schmoopy to demented in a single line, Thompson-Hannant\xe2\x80\x99s voice has always been unhinged: whooping, cooing breathily, even intoning baby sounds. The beats she\xe2\x80\x99s produced on Field of Love, meanwhile, flirt with unabashed garishness and fully match the whimsy of her vocal theatrics like never before.' b'The first several songs on *Field of Love *set a fizzy tone, with lead-off track \xe2\x80\x9cEternally Girl\xe2\x80\x9d pushing front-and-center synths that twinkle and plunk over tight, driving kicks. Here and throughout, Thompson-Hannant disarms with a suggestive charm, pre-ordaining an entire relationship from a pang of romance: \xe2\x80\x9cI could be the one that you love,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings in a soaring alto, before immediately promising, \xe2\x80\x9cI will be the one that you love.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a song about feeling like a little girl in love and embracing that excitement instead of qualifying or suppressing it.' b'Through Mozart\xe2\x80\x99s Sister, Thompson-Hannant has written about romance both fiercely and daintily\xe2\x80\x94at turns and at once\xe2\x80\x94often amplifying the heart\xe2\x80\x99s whims rather than trivializing them. \xe2\x80\x9cThe minute we sat down to dinner I knew,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings on \xe2\x80\x9cMoment 2\xc2\xa0Moment,\xe2\x80\x9d explaining how a new couple didn\xe2\x80\x99t even need to order drinks before adding, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know how rare that is.\xe2\x80\x9d For all her aggressive vulnerability, Thompson-Hannant sometimes drops the sentimentality for a colder edge. On \xe2\x80\x9cPlastic Memories,\xe2\x80\x9d a tweaked-out and pounding dance track, she compartmentalizes a breakup in order to leave it behind, hushing, \xe2\x80\x9cHappy goes away, so does the pain.\xe2\x80\x9d On the same song she leans in and chants savagely, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a death messenger, things that have happened are gone.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a jarring, fist-pump-worthy epiphany, a promise to live in the moment.' b'Toward the end of the album, \xe2\x80\x9cMy Heart Is Wild\xe2\x80\x9d reprises an originally stunted song called \xe2\x80\x9cMy House Is Wild\xe2\x80\x9d that first appeared on Thompson-Hannant\xe2\x80\x99s 2014 debut LP, Being. The original covered up a sincere invitation with clunky industrial production, but \xe2\x80\x9cMy Heart Is Wild\xe2\x80\x9d peels down to the core of the song\xe2\x80\x94Thompson-Hannant\xe2\x80\x99s voice, which she samples, triggers, and unleashes with giddy hope. The new version sounds less guarded, like she\xe2\x80\x99s singing and dancing manically about love at a wide-open sky instead of to a dark, throbbing dancefloor. It\xe2\x80\x99s the same effect she nurses throughout Field of Love, doubling down on her gut whims, newly confident. The record reads like a manifesto\xe2\x80\x94a pronouncement that anxiety and empowerment can dovetail, that vulnerability can be menacing, and, of course, that love can be infectiously weird.'

column7: b'Visible Cloaks\xe2\x80\x99 hard-to-classify ambient music is a fascinating mix of organic and synthetic, past and future.'
column8: b'So far, Spencer Doran\xe2\x80\x99s mixtapes have overshadowed his actual albums. In 2010, the Portland, Oregon, producer posted Fairlights, Mallets and Bamboo\xe2\x80\x94Fourth-World Japan, Years 1980\xe2\x80\x931986, a stunning collection of early-\xe2\x80\x9980s Japanese synthesizer music by artists like Yellow Magic Orchestra\xe2\x80\x99s Haruomi Hosono and Ryuichi Sakamoto. While not a party-starting DJ set, it was in its own meticulous, contemplative way, influential; you can hear its sensibility course through later works by the likes of Oneohtrix Point Never, Neon Indian, Motion Graphics, and the entire vaporwave contingency. A second volume followed, as did another series, Music Interiors, cementing Doran\xe2\x80\x99s status as an innovative curator of now-obscure sounds.' b'But despite the bubbling ambience and generally high quality of Doran and partner Ryan Carlile\xe2\x80\x99s 2015 debut album as Visible Cloaks, the initial full-length was overshadowed by the earlier mixes.\xc2\xa0On their second album, Reassemblage, however, the duo fully absorb these far-flung influences, weaving the strands into something delicate yet decidedly original. Lullaby-like though compositionally rigorous, serene but slightly unsettled, organic and synthetic, Reassemblage strikes an intriguing balance between extremes.' b'Like Daniel Lopatin, James Ferraro, and Laurel Halo did during the short reign of Hippos in Tanks at the start of the decade, Visible Cloaks scrutinize the once-novel digital sounds that now riddle modern pop and envelop us in our everyday lives. Just don\xe2\x80\x99t call Visible Cloaks \xe2\x80\x9cvaporwave\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94if anything, Reassemblage is the antithesis of that trend. While on the surface there is a shared obsession with the cleanliness of early digital music and the Japanese pop culture that helped usher it\xc2\xa0in the early \xe2\x80\x9880s, what Doran and Carlile do with the\xc2\xa0raw material stands apart.' b"Scroll through the Discogs page for vaporwave and almost any title bears either a visual wink or track title that mimics Japanese script. As an Esquire piece proclaiming that vaporwave was dead posited last year, the genre itself was a \xe2\x80\x9cmusical parody of pop consciousness\xe2\x80\xa6 [a] sarcastic take on the unachieved utopias of previous decades.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0But as Fairlights, Mallets, and Bamboo showed, there was a deeper investigation into the music beyond a mocking appropriation of a cool surface. The title itself comes from Vietnamese filmmaker/theorist Trinh T. Minh-ha's 1982 film Reassemblage, a documentary filmed in Senegal that doubles as a tacit admission that one can\xc2\xa0never fully decipher another culture. While never able to fully grasp the Japanese sounds they adore, Visible Cloaks nevertheless have created an album along the axis of Fennesz\xe2\x80\x99s Endless Summer and OPN\xe2\x80\x99s Replica, an abstract electronic album that\xe2\x80\x99s readily accessible and an immersive listen." b'Visible Cloaks specialize in blurring boundaries, as they collapse organic sounds into precisely machined new shapes. \xe2\x80\x9cMask\xe2\x80\x9d works from a palette closest to those Root Strata mixes, as gamelan bowls, bird calls, and vocodered hums are stretched and processed like a Fennesz track. \xe2\x80\x9cTerrazzo\xe2\x80\x9d has Doran and Carlile team up with Motion Graphics\xe2\x80\x99 Joe Williams, taking his flute and elongating it until it more closely resembles a shakuhachi bamboo version. Around this timbre, the duo stir a marsh of small blips, twinkling crystals, and koto strings, a strange sensation of natural ambience and glitching electronics blending into an alien landscape.' b'Even when working with thoroughly synthetic tones, Cloaks tease them out so that they clench and exhale, emerging as digital blips that seem as natural as breath. Water sounds gush out of \xe2\x80\x9cScreen,\xe2\x80\x9d but rather than replicate new age nature sounds, the frequencies become high and crinkled, like the baldly fake cellophane sea of Frederico Fellini\xe2\x80\x99s And the Ship Sails On. \xe2\x80\x9cValve\xe2\x80\x9d continues with that gentle pacing, this time featuring the crystalline vocals of Miyako Koda, one-half of Japanese elegant \xe2\x80\x9980s group Dip in the Pool. Curiously, the group didn\xe2\x80\x99t factor into any of Doran\xe2\x80\x99s mixes, but \xe2\x80\x9cValve\xe2\x80\x9d sounds like a lost Bamboo selection with its deliberate mallets and misty chords. Koda is the perfect fit here and the duo shadows her already gossamer voice with what might be puffs of steam on glass rods.' b'Water, glass, cellophane, crystals, glass\xe2\x80\x94these metaphors suggest sound that can at once seem transparent and featureless. But Visible Cloaks take pains to pivot their compositions every so often, so that light catches off the sleek edges and a full spectrum of color suddenly appears. And as the album glides along, Cloaks moves away from the easy Hosono and Sakamoto comparisons. \xe2\x80\x9cCircle\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94with its slivers of voices, strings, and woodwinds\xe2\x80\x94sounds exacting in its every gesture, bringing to mind modern composition rather than laptop mincing. \xe2\x80\x9cNeume\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94named for an early form of musical notation\xe2\x80\x94finds the Cloaks collaborating with fellow Portlander Matt Carlson. They Auto-Tune his voice, but also warp it until he starts to resemble the polyphonic chants of a medieval organum. It\xe2\x80\x99s one of Reassemblage\xe2\x80\x99s loveliest moments and reveals Visible Cloaks\xe2\x80\x99 essential appeal, not where\xc2\xa0East meets West so much as where ancient music anticipates\xc2\xa0its digital future.'

column7: b'Fat Joe and Remy Ma had\xc2\xa0their biggest hit together in 2004 before\xc2\xa0last year\xe2\x80\x99s comeback \xe2\x80\x9cAll the Way Up.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0On\xc2\xa0this collaborative LP, their hard styles are too\xc2\xa0similar\xc2\xa0to make for\xc2\xa0a compelling dynamic.'
column8: b'Fat Joe can no longer take hits for granted. While never a megastar, Joe has proved himself one of the most resilient rappers of all time, with a lengthy career spanning\xc2\xa0Big Punisher, Ja Rule, and DJ Khaled. At a point, he looked to be one of those old icons, like Snoop Dogg, whose stature seemingly grandfathered him into radio play for life. But then the hits dried up. Before his comeback single with Remy Ma \xe2\x80\x9cAll the Way Up\xe2\x80\x9d returned him to the charts last year and earned a pair of Grammy nominations, it had been nearly seven years since Joe released his last commercial album, and almost a full decade since his last Top 40 hit.' b'In truth, \xe2\x80\x9cAll the Way Up\xe2\x80\x9d would have been a hit with or without him. It\xe2\x80\x99s primarily a showcase for Cool & Dre\xe2\x80\x99s deliriously celebratory beat and a never-better feature from\xc2\xa0French Montana, which makes it a Fat Joe hit in the same way that \xe2\x80\x9cFuckin\xe2\x80\x99 Problems\xe2\x80\x9d was an A$AP Rocky hit. No matter the means, though, a smash on this scale is a major feat for any rapper. And so on Plata o Plomo, the belated follow-up to 2010\xe2\x80\x99s The Darkside, Vol. 1, Joe goes to almost superstitious extremes trying repeat that single\xe2\x80\x99s formula. He brings on Remy Ma as an equal partner, recruits Cool & Dre as primary producers, and invites\xc2\xa0back French Montana for its second single, \xe2\x80\x9cCookin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d Despite his best efforts, lightning does not strike twice.' b'Joe\xe2\x80\x99s great gambit is going halfsies with Remy Ma. Her own career was limping along before \xe2\x80\x9cAll the Way Up,\xe2\x80\x9d and the two had previously scored the biggest hit of their respective careers together\xe2\x80\x942004\xe2\x80\x99s inescapable \xe2\x80\x9cLean Back\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94so it figures they\xe2\x80\x99ve come to view each other as lucky rabbits\xe2\x80\x99 feet. And recently, other New York rap lifers have found second winds with these kinds of collab albums. Smoke DZA and Pete Rock just teamed for a widely praised record, and Joell Ortiz\xc2\xa0has rarely sounded more alive than he did on his Salaam Remi-produced album last year with No Panty, his group with neighbors Bodega Bamz and Nitty Scott.' b'Collaborations like this work best when there\xe2\x80\x99s some meaningful contrast between the performers, though, and Joe and Remy Ma are too similar to establish any kind of yin/yang dynamic. Both stem from a school of New York hip-hop that values presence over personality, and they both rap with meticulous enunciation, punctuating each bar with percussive emphasis. Their voices hit like rocks on concrete. That may be catnip for some diehard New York rap enthusiasts, but for younger listeners who came up with the nimble, free-form expression of modern Atlanta rap, that delivery can feel downright arthritic. What scans as hard for one generation of hip-hop fans just scans as stiff to another.' b'And while Joe can bend just enough to fit different styles\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s been doing it since he was biting Das EFX flows on his 1993 debut Represent, riggity-riggity-rather blatantly\xe2\x80\x94Remy is inflexible to a fault. She assumes a default battle stance even on songs that in no way call for it, like Ty Dolla $ign\xe2\x80\x99s smooth \xe2\x80\x9980s R&B homage \xe2\x80\x9cMoney Showers,\xe2\x80\x9d or the Sevyn Streeter-featuring DeBarge/Blackstreet flip \xe2\x80\x9cGo Crazy.\xe2\x80\x9d She still continues to rap about shitting on her enemies, too. She does it on two different tracks.' b'Plata o Plomo does feature one strong single candidate: the Caribbean-flavored the-Dream feature \xe2\x80\x9cHeartbreak.\xe2\x80\x9d Joe delivers his loosest performance in years, and for once even Remy Ma unwinds a bit and breaks out the suntan lotion. But more representative of the album\xe2\x80\x99s conservative approach is the mid-album champagne clink \xe2\x80\x9cHow Long.\xe2\x80\x9d The song\xe2\x80\x99s yawn of a chorus is supposed to be a boast about their veteran status\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHow long?/How long?/How long we been getting to the money?/How long?/How long we been gettin\xe2\x80\x99 it?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94yet through sheer repetition it becomes a kind of commentary on their songwriting: How long have we been rapping about this? How long have we been returning to these sounds? Without running the math, it sure feels like it\xe2\x80\x99s been ages.'

column7: b"Fatima Yamaha\xe2\x80\x99s 2004 song\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWhat's a Girl to Do?\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0made him a cult favorite. Here, on his second release since then, the Dutch producer offers future directions but none as captivating as his start."
column8: b'Fatima Yamaha\xe2\x80\x99s new Araya EP would not exist without persistent cheerleading from a few impressively dedicated followers. The Dutch producer Bas Bron released a record as Yamaha in 2004 and then appeared done with the name. He continued to put out records under other pseudonyms\xe2\x80\x94Bastian, Seymour Bits\xe2\x80\x94and run his Magnetron label. The results of the Yamaha experiment, a four-track EP titled A Girl Between Two Worlds, seemed like a one-off curio.' b"But over time, those who heard the EP became smitten. In particular, they swooned over \xe2\x80\x9cWhat's a Girl to Do?,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0with its sprightly synthesizers and existential-crisis dialog sampled from Lost In Translation. Two labels, D1 Recordings and Dekmantel, eventually released\xc2\xa0the song; another devotee, producer Hudson Mohawke, included Yamaha's tune in an Essential Mix for BBC Radio 1 in 2009 and used it as the basis for \xe2\x80\x9cResistance,\xe2\x80\x9d a new track featuring Jhen\xc3\xa9 Aiko, in 2015." b'This put Bron in a strange spot: a Def Jam vocalist with Top 40 cred was singing one of Yamaha\xe2\x80\x99s melodies, but Yamaha barely existed. So Bron pulled the moniker out of mothballs and released the LP Imaginary Lines in 2015. He could have done anything he wanted\xe2\x80\x94he was hardly constrained by precedent\xe2\x80\x94but he decided to stay faithful to his most hardcore fans. Imaginary Lines mostly picked up where *A Girl Between Two Worlds *left off, maintaining a handsome balance between fluffy and driving. Movie-score atmospheres sit easily next to songs like \xe2\x80\x9cLove Invaders,\xe2\x80\x9d with its resistance-is-futile grip recalling crackerjack pop songs.' b"In contrast, the three tracks on Araya represent a swivel away from the accessibility that earned Yamaha ardent admirers. Though \xe2\x80\x9cPiayes Beach Bar and Grill\xe2\x80\x9d has plenty of dinky electric snap, it avoids any head-rush moments: the synths never achieve peak friskiness, there\xe2\x80\x99s no sample lying in wait to ambush the listener and suddenly transform the song's final quarter. The track ends during the middle of a showy solo, so you get the annoyance of indulgence without the triumphant, ascend-the-scale payoff." b"\xe2\x80\x9cRomantic Bureaucracy\xe2\x80\x9d maintains distance in a different way; it has the exclusive feel of an inside joke. The song plays like a response to \xe2\x80\x9cLove's Got Me High,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9990s floor-wrecker produced by Detroit stalwart Terrence Parker. As one piano lays out a simple groove similar to the one that carried Parker\xe2\x80\x99s track, Bron adds criss-crossing clusters of keyboard notes\xe2\x80\x94sonic paperwork\xe2\x80\x94on top. A beat never arrives to cut through all the red tape." b"Still, Bron can't help but make something hard to shake\xe2\x80\x94that quality, after all, is what kept the Yamaha spark alive for all these years. In that vein, *Araya\xe2\x80\x99*s title track is crisp and chipper, with a commanding melody ricocheting playfully across a stern, \xe2\x80\x9980s-pop low-end. It's not much of a leap from here to the work of a more mainstream producer like Eric Prydz. There's a pair of especially pleasing moments around the song\xe2\x80\x99s four-minute mark: a light drum beats out a military rat-a-tat behind the primary melody just as it finishes one strafing run and prepares to begin another pass. This is a great trick for stakes-raising that you can also find in hits like Maxwell\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAscension (Don't Ever\xc2\xa0Wonder).\xe2\x80\x9d" b'Bron needs these overtly gratifying tracks\xe2\x80\x94without them, Yamaha wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have picked up boosters, and the project would have remained a quirky singularity. But even with \xe2\x80\x9cAraya,\xe2\x80\x9d this EP makes you wonder about Yamaha\xe2\x80\x99s status. First the persona inspired a minor cult; then it stormed back as a small-scale dancefloor hero. What is Yamaha now? Araya offers a few possibilities, but no answers.'

column7: b'Electronic music at the moment may not get more gurgling than Amnesia Scanner. The\xc2\xa0European duo keeps pushing the outer limits of noise and techno further on this excellent new collage of songs.'
column8: b'Berlin-based Finnish producers Ville Haimala and Martti Kalliala first made waves in 2011 as Renaissance Man, an impish electro duo equal parts quirky energy and bleary-eyed techno. The producers have since discarded that shell, reinventing themselves as Amnesia Scanner, a brutalist avant-club project whose music is engineered to alienate and provoke. In loose dialog with dance deconstructionists like Arca, Angel-Ho, and Lotic, Amnesia Scanner\xe2\x80\x99s violently kinetic club visions deal in the dissonant and the absurd, all the while glimpsing hellish dystopian wastelands and the disorientation of future shock.' b'Since 2014\xe2\x80\x99s AS LIVE [][][][][] and the following year\xe2\x80\x99s AS ANGELS RIG HOOK, Amnesia Scanner have been crumpling grime, trap, rave and various regional dance strains into one convulsive, machine-like knot. Last year\xe2\x80\x99s *AS *EP, Amnesia Scanner\xe2\x80\x99s first official physical release, dialed back on the aggression ever so slightly, distilling the duo\xe2\x80\x99s inclination for shrapnel textures and keening electronics into comparatively shorter, more accessible bursts. The duo\xe2\x80\x99s latest, the *AS TRUTH *mixtape, flips the script once again\xe2\x80\x94Amnesia Scanner has never sounded this abstract, this exceptionally unstable.' b'AS TRUTH\xe2\x80\x99s artwork depicts a lobotomy\xe2\x80\x94what looks like a forced lobotomy, to be specific. The victim appears resigned to his fate, looking confused, dejected, but also angry. In turn, the viewer is forced to share in that terrifying scene, in that discomfort, in that fear. Similarly, AS TRUTH feels like a music that\xe2\x80\x99s flung at you, forced on you\xe2\x80\x94something that not so much asks to be interpreted\xc2\xa0as reaches out and grabs at your attention, in thrilling, if deeply unnerving, ways.\xc2\xa0Throughout its 15 unbroken minutes, the mixtape hurls listeners into a bramble of juxtaposing textures and timbres. Hi-tech, high-gloss sounds clash up against coarse, serrated ones; needling dissonance rubs shoulders with creaky silences. Synths screech and squeal, bellow and gurgle. The percussion flits between skittering, frenzied beat-programming and concussive thunder. Shards of disembodied vocals are interspersed throughout the mixtape, reduced at turns to melting, pitch-shifted ooze and flinty cries. Seemingly brittle one moment, colossally impenetrable the next, AS TRUTH\xe2\x80\x99s angular shapes move in fits and starts, like some cybernetic albatross still searching for its sea legs.' b'AS TRUTH\xe2\x80\x99s tracklist outlines seven individual cuts, but simultaneously released on SoundCloud and Bandcamp as a single unsegmented stream, the mixtape functions as one long-form work without noticeable seams. Apart from the back-to-back midsection deluge of \xe2\x80\x9cAS TRUTH\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAS BRIETH\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94released as a two-sided single last December\xe2\x80\x94*AS TRUTH *consists of all new material. It starts with a wail\xe2\x80\x94part marine air horn, part digital leviathan stirring to life\xe2\x80\x94and closes with a throaty exhale. In between lives some of the most radical and ear-splitting electronic music you\xe2\x80\x99ll likely encounter all year. From opener \xe2\x80\x9cAS POWERLESS,\xe2\x80\x9d with its helicopter flicker and haunted rave theme, to outro \xe2\x80\x9cAS SANE\xe2\x80\x9d, which is of a piece with OPN\xe2\x80\x99s Garden of Delete, AS TRUTH never fails to confound. It\xe2\x80\x99s a release of ferocious intensity, constructed from an unwieldy set of moving, interconnected parts. Vestiges of melody and rhythm are teased here and there, but no sooner do they gain footing than they collapse in on themselves, receding back into the maelstrom.' b'Yet, for all its noise and frenzy, AS TRUTH also contains some of the slowest-paced and quiet music Amnesia Scanner has released so far. Take the funereal ambient of \xe2\x80\x9cAS WEEP\xe2\x80\x9d, which breeds tension in its gaping negative spaces. Gothic harpsichord, computerized plinks, slurred vocals,\xc2\xa0and muted drums are all that cut through the silences. However, this proves to be just another of Amnesia Scanner\xe2\x80\x99s clever devices: they lull you into a false sense of serenity, just so they can later spring a noisy trap.'

column7: b'Neil Young\xe2\x80\x99s polarizing\xc2\xa01982 album, influenced by new wave and heavy on the Vocoder,\xc2\xa0has long divided fans and critics. But beneath its cold\xc2\xa0exterior is a record with a lot of heart.'
column8: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s the end of the world. The sky is an ominous shade of red, and the air is thick with poisonous fumes. Some people are silhouetted with an eerie glow while others are dying of radiation poisoning. \xe2\x80\x9cIt shoulda been me that died,\xe2\x80\x9d Neil Young says, riding a bike alongside actor Russ Tamblyn. Tamblyn shrugs him off, and the two make plans for the evening. Tomorrow may never come, but tonight they\xe2\x80\x99ll take their dates to the drive-in, where Tamblyn begs Neil not to play his ukulele or to sing \xe2\x80\x9cin that high squeaky voice.\xe2\x80\x9d So goes the opening scene of the 1982 film Human Highway, an apocalyptic comedy written and directed by Neil Young under his long-standing nom de plume Bernard Shakey. It\xe2\x80\x99s a muddled and paranoid work, filled with forced slapstick humor and wild jams with Devo. In one scene, the members of the Ohio new wave group haul toxic waste in a flatbed truck down a lonesome highway. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in the world today,\xe2\x80\x9d Devo\xe2\x80\x99s Booji Boy says to himself as images of skulls flash across his bandmates\xe2\x80\x99 faces, \xe2\x80\x9cPeople don\xe2\x80\x99t seem to care about their fellow man.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'This is where Neil Young\xe2\x80\x99s head was at the top of the \xe2\x80\x9980s. Human Highway\xe2\x80\x94Young\xe2\x80\x99s third picture, following the psychedelic Journey Through the Past and his quasi-concert film Rust Never Sleeps\xe2\x80\x94shares a title with a song from 1978\xe2\x80\x99s Comes a Time. \xe2\x80\x9cTake my head, and change my mind,\xe2\x80\x9d he sang in its chorus, \xe2\x80\x9cHow could people get so unkind?.\xe2\x80\x9d With its gentle acoustic guitars and fantasies of misty mountains, \xe2\x80\x9cHuman Highway\xe2\x80\x9d plays like a eulogy to a specific type of Neil Young song. The Canadian hippie who sings in a high squeaky voice about packin\xe2\x80\x99 it in and buyin\xe2\x80\x99 a pick-up is only one side of Young. In fact, a decade into his solo career, Neil Young had developed a reputation more like an actor, someone remembered more for the parts he played than the unifying presence behind them all. After Comes a Time, he stepped away from his role as a \xe2\x80\x9970s folk singer, with 1979\xe2\x80\x99s Rust Never Sleeps introducing a decade of restless exploration. The world was getting meaner, and Neil Young was tired of being typecast as merely an observer: He wanted to take part in the madness.' b'Although they both speak to the increasingly uneasy state of Young\xe2\x80\x99s mind, \xe2\x80\x9cHuman Highway,\xe2\x80\x9d the song, never appears in Human Highway, the film. Instead, the movie is mostly soundtracked by a record called Trans, released that same year. In the film, Young gets into character by contorting his face, wearing a pair of dorky glasses, and slapping motor oil on his cheeks. On Trans, he transforms himself by setting his songs in a distant future and filtering his voice through a variety of synthesizers, most notably (and infamously) a vocoder. The warped new wave of Trans suits the movie\xe2\x80\x99s otherworldly (if endearingly chintzy) backdrops. You believe that this is the music that would play in the film\xe2\x80\x99s shoddy roadside diner, where Dennis Hopper cooks sausage patties and swats at radioactive, laser-pointer flies. In fact, the movie might be the best context to hear Trans\xe2\x80\x94an album that\xe2\x80\x99s often treated more like a symbol (for artistic reinvention, for failed experimentation, for creative self-sabotage) than an actual entry in a body of work characterized by prolificacy and versatility.' b"Part of what makes Neil Young\xe2\x80\x99s discography so rewarding for new listeners is that it\xe2\x80\x99s filled\xc2\xa0with great entry points: the classic rock radio staples with more depth than you imagined (After the Goldrush, Harvest); the intimate passages that, even after all these years, feel like uncovered secrets (Tonight\xe2\x80\x99s the Night, On the Beach); and the bizarre left-turns like Trans that inspire cult fandom just for existing. And while Trans sits comfortably along with Lou Reed\xe2\x80\x99s Metal Machine Music and Bob Dylan\xe2\x80\x99s Self Portrait in a lineage of puzzling-if-fascinating failures, its mythology is only part of the appeal. Reed and Dylan always felt like provocateurs\xe2\x80\x94for Dylan, even finding Jesus felt like a means of snapping back at critics. But Young\xe2\x80\x99s transformations have always felt less divisive, more natural and earnest and instinctual. Even when he followed\xc2\xa0Trans with Everybody\xe2\x80\x99s Rockin\xe2\x80\x99, a slight collection of anti-capitalist rockabilly songs, he held the latter record in high esteem: \xe2\x80\x9cAs good as Tonight's The Night, as far as I'm concerned,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99s said." b'Young has made similar claims about Trans. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is one of my favorites,\xe2\x80\x9d he said grimly, holding the album art to the camera during a 2012 interview, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you listen to this now, it makes a lot more sense than it did then.\xe2\x80\x9d Even if Trans is still confusing, it\xe2\x80\x99s a point well taken. In the context of Young\xe2\x80\x99s discography\xe2\x80\x94rich with remakes and sequels, major reunions and minor pet projects\xe2\x80\x94Trans has only grown more triumphant and singular as it\xe2\x80\x99s aged. He would do new wave again, he\xe2\x80\x99d mess with his voice some more, and he\xe2\x80\x99d even return to the idea of full-on concept albums. But he would never make anything quite so conceptually confrontational\xe2\x80\x94a challenge to even his most ardent followers\xe2\x80\x99 understanding of what a Neil Young album sounds like. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I build something up, I have to systematically tear it right down,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99s said, referring to his penchant for moving quickly from one project to another, carrying with him few traces of the previous work. It\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable, then, that Trans\xe2\x80\x94an album ostensibly designed to \xe2\x80\x9ctear down\xe2\x80\x9d a specific image of Neil Young\xe2\x80\x94ends up standing for exactly what\xe2\x80\x99s great about him.' b'Like so many of Neil Young\xe2\x80\x99s albums, Trans is filled with mysteries and unanswered questions (Why is his 1967 Buffalo Springfield song \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Soul\xe2\x80\x9d on here? Why is a track called \xe2\x80\x9cIf You Got Love\xe2\x80\x9d listed in the lyric sheet\xc2\xa0but not on the actual album?) It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to think of an artist with as many classic albums who has wrestled so constantly against the medium: even his canonized work has a raw, unfinished quality to it. \xe2\x80\x9cIf anything is wrong, then it\xe2\x80\x99s down to the mixing,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99s said about Trans, \xe2\x80\x9cWe had a lot of technical problems on that record.\xe2\x80\x9d Fittingly, much of Trans concerns man\xe2\x80\x99s fight against technology. A song called \xe2\x80\x9cComputer Cowboy (aka Syscrusher)\xe2\x80\x9d details a team of rogue computers robbing a bank, with Young\xe2\x80\x99s voice zapped down to a digital squelch. In \xe2\x80\x9cWe R in Control,\xe2\x80\x9d a choir of robots lists the aspects of daily life\xe2\x80\x94traffic lights, the FBI, even the flow of air\xe2\x80\x94in which humans no longer have a say. Thematically, these songs\xe2\x80\x94with their dystopian images of a world run by screens and numbers, where humans have everything at their fingertips but remain unhappy\xe2\x80\x94have aged pretty well.' b"It\xe2\x80\x99s the sound of the record that makes it more of an \xe2\x80\x9980s relic. No matter what format you listen to the album on (and it\xe2\x80\x99s still never been released on CD in the U.S.), you feel as though you\xe2\x80\x99re hearing it from the tape deck of a passing car. Even with longtime collaborators like producer David Briggs, guitarist Ben Keith, and drummer Ralph Molina, these songs sound very little like Young\xe2\x80\x99s timeless \xe2\x80\x9970s work. The goofier, beat-centric tracks from his previous release, 1981\xe2\x80\x99s shaky Re-ac-tor, certainly set a precedent. But despite its reputation for being aggressive and inscrutable, Trans is, at its heart, a pop record. It\xe2\x80\x99s filled with hooks and beats and synths informed equally by krautrock and MTV. In \xe2\x80\x9cSample and Hold,\xe2\x80\x9d guitarist Nils Lofgren\xe2\x80\x94whose solos added an element of bluesy desperation to Tonight\xe2\x80\x99s the Night but would soon light up football stadiums on Bruce Springsteen\xe2\x80\x99s Born in the U.S.A. tour\xe2\x80\x94points to future hits like Dire Straits\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cMoney for Nothing\xe2\x80\x9d and Oingo Boingo\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWeird Science.\xe2\x80\x9d When the Trans Band played \xe2\x80\x9cSample and Hold\xe2\x80\x9d during the album\xe2\x80\x99s comically over-the-top tour\xe2\x80\x94an endeavor that Young claims in Jimmy McDonough's authorized biography Shakey lost him $750,000 (\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we sold out every show,\xe2\x80\x9d he adds)\xe2\x80\x94Neil and Nils stalk the stage with rock star charisma, trading solos and bleating into their talkboxes. In the sweet, melodic \xe2\x80\x9cTransformer Man,\xe2\x80\x9d Neil\xe2\x80\x99s vocoder actually adds an element of purity to his voice, as layers of wordless choruses shower him. Listening to these songs, it\xe2\x80\x99s not impossible to imagine that Trans could have maybe, possibly, in another world, been a pop hit." b'But that world is in a\xc2\xa0galaxy far from this one. While the critical reception to Trans was not nearly as harsh as legend would have you think (Rolling Stone compared it to Bowie\xe2\x80\x99s Berlin Trilogy; Robert Christgau gave it a higher mark than Harvest), it was a commercial dud\xe2\x80\x94a rough start for the fledgling Geffen Records label, who also released\xc2\xa0Joni Mitchell\xe2\x80\x99s adult contemporary turn\xc2\xa0Wild Things Run Fast\xc2\xa0the same year. Trans wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the album that convinced David Geffen to sue Neil Young for making uncharacteristic records\xe2\x80\x94that would be its follow-ups *Everybody\xe2\x80\x99s Rockin\xe2\x80\x99 *and Old Ways, the country record that plays like a made-for-TV adaptation of Harvest. But the idea had to be floating through David Geffen\xe2\x80\x99s head when he first heard this record. At once Young\xe2\x80\x99s coldest sounding album and his most vulnerable, Trans makes its flaws immediately apparent as soon as you press play\xe2\x80\x94from the murky production to the mixed-bag tracklist.' b'When you listen to Trans, you\xe2\x80\x99re really only hearing two-thirds of it. Only six of the album\xe2\x80\x99s nine songs were intended for the actual project. The other three came from a different album entirely, one that concerned young love and ancient civilizations. It was to be titled Island in the Sun, and Geffen Records quickly steered him away from the concept. Album opener \xe2\x80\x9cLittle Thing Called Love\xe2\x80\x9d stems from those sessions, and it\xe2\x80\x99s the record\xe2\x80\x99s clearest connection to Young\xe2\x80\x99s more celebrated talents. Its chorus riffs on the title of one of his most beloved songs (\xe2\x80\x9cOnly love,\xe2\x80\x9d he barks in a chipper tone, \xe2\x80\x9cBrings you the blues\xe2\x80\x9d) and the ensuing chord progression would eventually find a new home in the title track of 1992\xe2\x80\x99s Harvest Moon. While demonstrating the fluidity of Neil\xe2\x80\x99s catalog, the song also makes for a striking introduction in its own right: a singalong before the apocalypse, when human connection would become as archaic as LaserDisc copies of the Solo Trans live show are today.' b'The Island songs also help highlight a major theme of Trans: it\xe2\x80\x99s an album about affection. At the start of the decade, Neil Young and his wife were enrolled in intensive therapy with their son Ben, who had been diagnosed with cerebral palsy. The program\xe2\x80\x99s long hours slowed Young\xe2\x80\x99s hectic work schedule and opened him up to writing about fatherhood. His struggles to communicate with his child and the technology that connected them inspired the lyrics of Trans and even informed the way he recorded his vocals: \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t understand the words, and I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand my son\xe2\x80\x99s words,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained in Shakey. In that context, Young\xe2\x80\x99s naked voice in respective side-openers \xe2\x80\x9cLittle Thing Called Love\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cHold on to Your Love\xe2\x80\x9d represents the catharsis of an emotional breakthrough. You understand the words he wants you to understand\xe2\x80\x94and most of them just say, \xe2\x80\x9cI love you.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"Even with Human Highway serving as a vehicle for the album, Trans was originally conceived with a different film project in mind. \xe2\x80\x9cI had a big concept,\xe2\x80\x9d Young said in Shakey, \xe2\x80\x9cAll of the electronic-voice people were working in a hospital, and the one thing they were trying to do is teach this little baby to push a button.\xe2\x80\x9d That metaphor pops up a few times throughout the record, most squarely in \xe2\x80\x9cTransformer Man,\xe2\x80\x9d a song Young's openly dedicated to his son. \xe2\x80\x9cYou run the show,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings to him, \xe2\x80\x9cDirect the action with the push of a button.\xe2\x80\x9d The Trans film might not have moved the album to the commercial heights Neil and Geffen imagined, but available evidence suggests that it would have at least made its digital world feel warmer, more grounded and productive\xe2\x80\x94the qualities fans had come to expect from Young\xe2\x80\x99s work. Instead, the songs would have to stand on their own, their meaning buried inside them, like a constellation of stars you have to connect based on your own perception." b'Near the end of Human Highway, a concussed Young enters a long, inscrutable dream sequence in which he, among other things, gets bathed in milk, attends a desert ritual, and becomes a world-renowned rock star. When Russ Tamblyn wakes him, they celebrate the mere fact that he\xe2\x80\x99s alive. For the film\xe2\x80\x99s final 10 minutes, Neil lives with a newfound sense of purpose and ambition (\xe2\x80\x9cWe could do it,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, \xe2\x80\x9cWe could be rhythm and bluesers, we could go on the road!\xe2\x80\x9d). Even with the fiery explosion on its way to squash his dreams and reduce the world to a pile of ash, it\xe2\x80\x99s a brighter\xc2\xa0ending than what Trans leaves us with. In the lost paradise of \xe2\x80\x9cLike an Inca,\xe2\x80\x9d Young envisions himself in the aftermath of a nuclear bomb, crossing the bridge to the afterlife, at once happy and sad and totally alone. It\xe2\x80\x99s a fitting finale for a heavy album, one whose only brief glimmers of hope come from our connection to one another. \xe2\x80\x9cI need you to let me know that there\xe2\x80\x99s a heartbeat/Let it pound and pound,\xe2\x80\x9d Young sings in \xe2\x80\x9cComputer Age.\xe2\x80\x9d His voice is masked beyond recognition, but the pulse\xe2\x80\x94steady and wild\xe2\x80\x94is unmistakably his own.'

column7: b'On their latest set, Mali\xe2\x80\x99s Tinariwen ensemble mix\xc2\xa0Western African styles, feverish group workouts, and\xc2\xa0world-weary lyrics, collaborating with Kurt Vile and Mark Lanegan in the process.'
column8: b'Since coming to the attention of Western listeners in the 2000s, the Tuareg artists in Tinariwen have managed to keep their \xe2\x80\x9cdesert blues\xe2\x80\x9d sound intact, while varying some elements of songwriting craft. The largely acoustic aesthetic of 2011\xe2\x80\x99s Tassili saw input from American indie talents, like TV on the Radio\xe2\x80\x99s Kyp Malone and Wilco\xe2\x80\x99s Nels Cline. On 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Emmaar, Tinariwen reveled in some funkier arrangements.' b'Elwan offers another solid collection of tunes that merge West African styles and guitar riffs inspired by American folk forms. The album can swing quickly across a wide range of moods, moving dramatically between feverish group workouts and more personal, acoustic laments. And the\xc2\xa0continued\xc2\xa0political turmoil in their native northern Mali\xe2\x80\x94including the targeting of the band\xe2\x80\x99s members by\xc2\xa0Islamist militants\xe2\x80\x94has provided these songwriters with no shortage of inspiration for world-weary lyrics.' b'This time around, Tinariwen\xe2\x80\x99s collaborations\xc2\xa0work\xc2\xa0more ideally than on previous outings.\xc2\xa0Sometime Queens of the Stone Age member Alain Johannes brings his \xe2\x80\x9ccigar box guitar\xe2\x80\x9d to the grooving, communal song\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cTalyat.\xe2\x80\x9d And on the uptempo opener, \xe2\x80\x9cTiw\xc3\xa0yyen,\xe2\x80\x9d guest guitarist Kurt Vile merges fully with the other members of the ensemble. During this first appearance, there\xe2\x80\x99s little sense that he\xe2\x80\x99s interested in calling attention to himself. (The song\xe2\x80\x99s real stars are the spirited backing vocalists, who swarm during the choruses.)' b'On bassist Eyadou Ag Leche\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cN\xc3\xa0nnufl\xc3\xa0y,\xe2\x80\x9d though, Vile\xe2\x80\x99s reverb-heavy guitar tone is more easily recognized. The romanticized sense of reverie in his playing\xe2\x80\x94familiar from albums like 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Wakin on a Pretty Daze\xe2\x80\x94seems to exert a strong influence over the entire band\xe2\x80\x99s performance, thereby giving Tinariwen a new vibe to inhabit. Ibrahim Ag Alhabib, one of the group\xe2\x80\x99s principal singer-guitarists, makes the most of this opportunity, turning in a chilled-out performance that is threaded with less vocal ornamentation than usual. The final minute\xe2\x80\x99s vocals are turned over to Mark Lanegan\xe2\x80\x99s coolheaded baritone: a choice that risks merely gilding the lily, but just plain works.' b'Naturally, this core group of players doesn\xe2\x80\x99t really need any help when it comes to fashioning sublime performances. On \xe2\x80\x9cAss\xc3\xa0wt,\xe2\x80\x9d acoustic arpeggios are sometimes joined by darts of electric-guitar filigree\xe2\x80\x94a mirroring of the way the song\xe2\x80\x99s solo vocalist routinely welcomes a chorus of companions by his side. Elsewhere, the propulsive rock energy of \xe2\x80\x9cSastan\xc3\xa0qq\xc3\xa0m\xe2\x80\x9d leavens the mood for a spell, while the mantra of \xe2\x80\x9cIttus\xe2\x80\x9d reflects a seriousness of intent. (The latter song\xe2\x80\x99s lyric reads, in its entirety: \xe2\x80\x9cI ask you, what is our goal/It is the unity of our nation/And to carry our standard high.\xe2\x80\x9d)' b'It can be tempting, at this point, to take all the strengths of Tinariwen for granted. Once again, all their music is crisply played, and smartly sequenced. Yet while Elwan may not herald any grand\xc2\xa0stylistic breakthrough, it does manage to synthesize some of the group\xe2\x80\x99s most recent experiments in a way that helps distinguish it within their overall catalog. English translations for the lyrics are available on their label\xe2\x80\x99s website, but the spirit of each song is generally discernible from the performance choices. The purpose of Tinariwen\xe2\x80\x99s music doesn\xe2\x80\x99t undergo radical redefinition\xe2\x80\x94and it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need to do so. From their beginnings in a refugee camp to their latest iteration as a world-touring entity, they can provide exultation\xc2\xa0and encouragement like few other ensembles, on any continent.'

column7: b'Australian improv trio the Necks have condensed their approach on this new double LP for\xc2\xa0Stephen O\xe2\x80\x99Malley\xe2\x80\x99s label. The experience\xc2\xa0feels like a ceaseless fever dream.'
column8: b'The Necks have never been much for tracklists. With some early and not always impressive exceptions near the dawn of the group\xe2\x80\x99s almost three-decade career, the improvisational Australian trio has preferred to go the distance in one, perhaps two extended takes. For an hour or so at a time, restless drummer Tony Buck, patient bassist Lloyd Swanton, and soulful pianist and organist Chris Abrahams would slip into sound worlds of their own design and slowly morph, as if on an evolutionary timeline. Their best records, like 2001\xe2\x80\x99s essential Aether or 2013\xe2\x80\x99s consummate Open, gradually subside and swell, drive and drift. By stretching pieces past the hour mark, they could change one\xe2\x80\x99s very sense of dynamics, where tiny shifts in volume or tone or speed suddenly felt revelatory. With the Necks, it seemed, anything could happen if you listened long enough.' b'But that approach ends abruptly on Unfold, the Necks\xe2\x80\x99 19th\xc2\xa0album and first for Ideologic Organ, the label of fellow slow-motion traveler Stephen O\xe2\x80\x99Malley, of Sunn O))) fame. For this double LP, the Necks devote each of four sides to one improvisation. With runtimes between 15 and 22\xc2\xa0minutes, they\xe2\x80\x99ve chopped the typical Necks tune into thirds or quarters. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, there\xe2\x80\x99s no intended sequence for these sides, meaning you could start with the hectic, gamelan-like rumble of \xe2\x80\x9cTimepiece\xe2\x80\x9d or end there, a move that makes the entire experience feel like a ceaseless fever dream. It\xe2\x80\x99s a surprisingly indeterminate decision\xc2\xa0for a group whose output has always felt, no matter how improvisational it was, meticulous, even hermetic. Since the mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s, the Necks\xe2\x80\x99 records have invariably offered micromanaged adventure; with Unfold, they let you shape your own tale by giving you tracks without a tracklist.' b'Still, all of the Necks hallmarks appear at some point during Unfold\xe2\x80\x94hyperactive drumming that expands and contracts any real sense of meter; piano lines that can summon a storm or conjure a presiding calm; bowed bass that rattles the room*.* And though the Necks look like a jazz trio, their swing is tempestuous and their approach nebulous, with touches of post-rock and soul and Stockhausen and gospel wrapped into their orchestrated mess.' b'But Unfold\xe2\x80\x99s unconventional format forces the Necks to condense its typical approach, to push and pull all the usual peaks, valleys, and arcs into more manageable spans. Everything speeds up just a bit. With\xc2\xa0that, by the end of the first two minutes of \xe2\x80\x9cBlue Mountain,\xe2\x80\x9d the bass, drums, piano, and organ are already intertwined and active. Buck\xe2\x80\x99s distended drum rolls ricochet between layers of blue piano fragments and organ peals. And\xc2\xa0during the tumultuous \xe2\x80\x9cRise,\xe2\x80\x9d which is so disorienting that the trio seems to be playing both meter and melody inside-out, the requisite moments of calm are fleeting. Here, the Necks make you gasp for air, never allowing for time or space to breathe very deeply.' b'Splintering the usual runtime of a Necks album into four largely disconnected pieces seems like it would fragment the experience\xe2\x80\x94that is, turning a Necks record on, then disappearing inside it. Is Unfold the trio\xe2\x80\x99s first album for our ever-shortening attention spans, at least since their salad days of placid bop in the late \xe2\x80\x9980s?' b'Turns out, not at all: The Necks\xe2\x80\x99 newfound density is intoxicating. The ideas fly by in a way they never have with this band. Each compressed piece simply pushes you along to the next, eager to witness how a quarter-century-old act can again reshape your perception of drums, piano, and upright bass. After the Necks answer the psychedelic, wildly melismatic organ runs of \xe2\x80\x9cOverhear\xe2\x80\x9d with the pensive, clinched gaze of \xe2\x80\x9cBlue Mountain,\xe2\x80\x9d hearing what else is possible becomes a compulsion. (And if you\xe2\x80\x99re new here, the quest can and should send you deep into a rich back catalog.) The relatively succinct tracks of Unfold aren\xe2\x80\x99t some cynical concession to an audience\xe2\x80\x99s fractured attention span or some attempt to become suddenly accessible. They are, instead, the result of a band that\xe2\x80\x99s always tested supposedly solid borders\xe2\x80\x94between jazz and rock, between acoustic and electric, between composition and improvisation. On Unfold, they\xe2\x80\x99ve wondered aloud if the spell of their long-form magic works when stunted by the limitations of physical media and shuffled by the will of the listener. It does.'

column3: b'A Pink Sunset For No One'
column7: b'This is Sarah Lipstate\xe2\x80\x99s biggest record as Noveller yet. Mixing genres to create\xc2\xa0her epic version of noise, what it loses in detail it makes up for in grandiosity.'
column8: b'With each successive release, the self-sustaining universe that is Sarah Lipstate\xe2\x80\x99s output as Noveller pushes outward. Her instrumental sound\xe2\x80\x94built from guitar loops run through pedals\xe2\x80\x94has evolved well past\xc2\xa0its drone-anchored early incarnation. That relied on layers of distortion to create meditative spaces that enveloped the listener; more recently, synths and percussion have entered her sprawling compositions. A Pink Sunset for No One is ruled by a newly epic sense of scale and narrative. For better or for worse, the album\xe2\x80\x99s more intricate details are at times overshadowed by its glimmering crescendos.' b'However, the tension between Noveller\xe2\x80\x99s roots as an intimate bedroom project and the outsize shape it takes here is compelling: even if her style has grown to fill the kind of rooms one might play opening for Iggy Pop, it still feels like a dreamworld Lipstate has built primarily for herself. Opener \xe2\x80\x9cDeep Shelter\xe2\x80\x9d begins with a low-pitched four-note phrase that repeats throughout, accumulating iterative details that begin to soar outward from the humble introduction. Four minutes in, these loops pull back to make way for a gently cinematic piano bridge: self-soothing, yes, but executed in a remarkably high-definition way.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s also a heightened sense of energy, Lipstate spending less time luxuriating in her guitar\xe2\x80\x99s textures and more on developing big-picture structure. \xe2\x80\x9cRituals,\xe2\x80\x9d which winks at Steve Reich, is anchored by soft, distant percussion and a small chorus of staccato riffing, punctuated by blasts of rippling sustained notes. On \xe2\x80\x9cTrials and Trails,\xe2\x80\x9d perhaps the album\xe2\x80\x99s most technically impressive track, Lipstate solos heroically over distorted passages, the juxtaposition throwing the liquidity of her playing into relief.' b'The variety of genres and sounds that emerge within her compositions give Lipstate\xe2\x80\x99s work a multitextured feel, but in moments I found myself wishing for more concision in the way such ideas are digested. Experimental forebears like Reich or Rhys Chatham (with whom she\xe2\x80\x99s performed, in his Guitar Army) are a natural influence, but on songs like \xe2\x80\x9cThe Unveiling\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCorridors,\xe2\x80\x9d Lipstate\xe2\x80\x99s usual spaciness takes on an almost-proggy feel; meanwhile, the title track feels like a crisp take on a Slowdive instrumental. Clearly, Lipstate has the technical prowess to pull off a near-infinite range of styles. As she shakes off the distortion that might have once smoothed over their messier intersections, the issue becomes, perhaps, how to tastefully marry them.' b'But that\xe2\x80\x99s not to say that there isn\xe2\x80\x99t a solid sense of self at this record\xe2\x80\x99s core. Its closer \xe2\x80\x9cEmergence\xe2\x80\x9d is slow but not sleepy, fluttering melodies dancing around its murky base. It\xe2\x80\x99s a pleasure to listen in to the small melodic details folded into its dominant humid texture, but it also feels, as a whole, reassuring: a sound that\xe2\x80\x99s big and confident without relying on excess to sway its listeners, or itself.'

column7: b'On her latest LP,\xc2\xa0Sallie Ford distills her retro rock sound and introduces a confessional lyrical approach. Soul Sick\xc2\xa0lands somewhere\xc2\xa0between between a \xe2\x80\x9950s sock hop and last call\xc2\xa0in a rockabilly bar.'
column8: b'A retro streak runs through most of\xc2\xa0the music of Sallie Ford, both solo and with her former Portland, Oregon band the Sound Outside. But it\xe2\x80\x99s never been quite as pronounced as on her latest album. Soul Sick is Ford\xe2\x80\x99s second LP since the Sound Outside split at the end of 2013, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a distillation in many ways, as if\xc2\xa0Ford ran her\xc2\xa0songs through a rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll evaporator to remove any extraneous elements.\xc2\xa0The result is a vintage sound that falls somewhere between a 1950s sock hop and last call\xc2\xa0in a disreputable rockabilly bar.' b'Soul Sick\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa011 lean tunes are full of raucous, trebly guitars and a toughness imparted by Ford\xe2\x80\x99s raw voice. Her vocals are a distinctive blend of rugged and plaintive, and\xc2\xa0something of a calling card, one of those attributes that draws listeners in or turns them off. Either way, Ford knows her strengths as a singer, and she maximizes them here. She lets\xc2\xa0her voice ring out on \xe2\x80\x9cScrew Up\xe2\x80\x9d over a thrumming Farfisa, or conveys an itchy sense of urgency on \xe2\x80\x9cGet Out,\xe2\x80\x9d or\xc2\xa0captures the anxiety of teen angst on \xe2\x80\x9cFailure.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Despite the jumped-up, hip-shaking music, Soul Sick is not a good-time album. Ford is deceptively self-lacerating, and she\xe2\x80\x99s by turns angry and forlorn throughout. Though she sings plenty about behaving badly, a classic rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll subject, Ford\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics are anachronistic. With their stark, personal tone, these songs amount to a latter-day form of confessional songwriting that simply wasn\xe2\x80\x99t done in the musical periods she draws from. Her dissatisfaction sometimes veers from restless exasperation, as on the full-throated \xe2\x80\x9cGet Out,\xe2\x80\x9d to something closer to wallowing in her anguish.' b'Ford sings with jumpy force on \xe2\x80\x9cLoneliness Is Power,\xe2\x80\x9d but the lyrics read as if she\xe2\x80\x99s trying to convince herself that the title is true. She beats herself up on \xe2\x80\x9cRomanticized Catastrophe\xe2\x80\x9d for letting negative emotions run rampant, a sentiment at odds with the doo-wop-esque backing vocals, which Dion and the Belmonts would have coveted.
