And she\xe2\x80\x99s on the verge of falling apart completely on \xe2\x80\x9cUnraveling,\xe2\x80\x9d a torchy slow-burner that Ford sings in a brawny falsetto over tremolo guitars and a subtle, muted horn section.' b'Though she rarely sounds at ease on Soul Sick, the blustery gusto with which Ford and her band tear through the songs turns her discomfort into catharsis. Even when her lyrics verge on self-pitying (\xe2\x80\x9cHurts So Bad,\xe2\x80\x9d say), Ford sounds like she is determined to exorcise her demons with a guitar and a tom-tom beat. Her energetic thrashing is infectious, like an open invitation to dance away your own pain. Loneliness may be power, but there\xe2\x80\x99s strength in numbers.'

column7: b'After\xc2\xa02016\xe2\x80\x99s loopy\xc2\xa0Painting With, Animal Collective return with a companion EP.'
column8: b'One way to think of a shape-shifting group like Animal Collective is that they\xe2\x80\x99re a different band with each album. Sometimes that\xe2\x80\x99s true in a literal sense, considering that Noah \xe2\x80\x9cPanda Bear\xe2\x80\x9d Lennox, David \xe2\x80\x9cAvey Tare\xe2\x80\x9d Portner, and Brian \xe2\x80\x9cGeologist\xe2\x80\x9d Weitz recorded without Josh \xe2\x80\x9cDeakin\xe2\x80\x9d Dibb on both 2009\xe2\x80\x99s luminously definitive Merriweather Post Pavilion\xc2\xa0and on last year\xe2\x80\x99s busily candy-coated Painting With. But one of the more intriguing observations from the Painting With\xc2\xa0press cycle was that Animal Collective had themselves toyed with switching band names, only to be dissuaded by practical concerns, like listeners being able to find their music.' b'It seems fitting that a previously suggested alternate name, the Painters, resurfaced during the demo process for Painting With. Like its predecessor, 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Centipede Hz, the last record is dense and ornamented with samples, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also brightly colored, synthetic, and dizzyingly hyperactive. After each Animal Collective album, the group has typically issued a related follow-up EP, including career highlights like 2005\xe2\x80\x99s Prospect Hummer\xc2\xa0and 2009\xe2\x80\x99s Fall Be Kind. The companion to Painting With is the four-song The Painters EP, and the records share a sensibility.' b'For however much Animal Collective have changed between each album, a juxtaposition between campfire primitivism and electronic experimentation has remained a near-constant. Painting With seemed to ball that up like never before into skewed, breakneck-paced pop miniatures.\xc2\xa0Generally speaking, more recent Animal Collective\xc2\xa0songs bang you on the head, lyrically and sonically, in a way the band didn\xe2\x80\x99t previously, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily get stuck in your head in the same way as a \xe2\x80\x9cMy Girls,\xe2\x80\x9d either.\xc2\xa0The Painters EP was mostly recorded around the same time as its companion album, and while it\xe2\x80\x99s a reasonably compelling elaboration on its predecessor\xe2\x80\x99s synth-splattering aesthetic, it\xe2\x80\x99s unlikely to change anyone\xe2\x80\x99s mind about this version of the group\xe2\x80\x99s sound.' b'The opener and first single, \xe2\x80\x9cKinda Bonkers,\xe2\x80\x9d resembles \xe2\x80\x9cFloriDada,\xe2\x80\x9d its counterpart from the last album: Both songs overcome their playful if obvious titles; both find Panda Bear and Avey Tare trading vocals in such a way that they\xe2\x80\x99re almost finishing each other\xe2\x80\x99s sentences; and both convey a utopian faith in transcending human differences. \xe2\x80\x9cKinda Bonkers\xe2\x80\x9d distinguishes itself, though, partly because its odd burbles and tribal pulse are at a statelier tempo. And where \xe2\x80\x9cFloriDada\xe2\x80\x9d plays its vision of \xe2\x80\x9ca future/connected by sutures\xe2\x80\x9d into wry \xe2\x80\x9cwhere\xe2\x80\x99s the bridge\xe2\x80\x9d puns, \xe2\x80\x9cKinda Bonkers\xe2\x80\x9d resolves into a communal mantra: \xe2\x80\x9cUnity of all kind, unity of all kind.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The middle of the EP passes pleasantly but less arrestingly. \xe2\x80\x9cPeacemaker\xe2\x80\x9d is more relaxed than almost anything on Painting With, and here the vocal exchanges tend to happen at the level of syllables, not half-sentences. At high volume in headphones, it offers enough squiggly nuances to hold interest, underpinned by glassy synth and a lurching rhythmic base. On the bouncier \xe2\x80\x9cGoalkeeper,\xe2\x80\x9d what precisely is being sung about this soccer savior\xc2\xa0gets largely buried in thuds and squelches.' b'Painters\xe2\x80\x99 most notable inclusion is a cover of Martha & the Vandellas\xe2\x80\x99 mid-\xe2\x80\x9960s classic \xe2\x80\x9cJimmy Mack,\xe2\x80\x9d done the Painters\xe2\x80\x99 way: delirious, yawpy, and belching with synth. As anyone familiar with the original song might hope, it\xe2\x80\x99s ecstatic with\xc2\xa0yearning, and it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise Animal Collective made a habit of working this into their 2016 tour stops. But the song doesn\xe2\x80\x99t lend itself to their current manic style, and it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine choosing this take\xc2\xa0over the Vandellas\xe2\x80\x94or any other version.' b"If hearing Animal Collective do \xe2\x80\x9cJimmy Mack\xe2\x80\x9d tells us anything, it's that writing a great song, like painting a modern-day\xc2\xa0masterpiece, is difficult. Animal Collective have done it\xc2\xa0before, and they\xe2\x80\x99ll hopefully do it again. Odds are, they\xe2\x80\x99ll be a different band then, and, as a wide-eyed Painters EP\xc2\xa0narrator might point out, their listeners will be different,\xc2\xa0too."

column3: b'Created in the Image of Suffering'
column7: b'On King Woman\xe2\x80\x99s debut LP, band mastermind Kristina Esfandiari finds her own path to redemption in doom\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s enough to inspire new believers outside of metal circles.'
column8: b'The response to Doubt stunned Kristina Esfandiari. In 2015, the San Francisco songwriter finally issued her proper, full-band debut as King Woman, a name she\xe2\x80\x99d toyed with for years while playing in other people\xe2\x80\x99s bands.\xc2\xa0Across the EP\xe2\x80\x99s four songs, Esfandiari used blown-out, country-kissed doom to reckon with and rage against a childhood spent in a Christian cult-like community.\xc2\xa0The unlikely mix\xe2\x80\x94where waves of distortion and wrecking-ball drums crashed against a voice that somehow drifted even as it raged\xe2\x80\x94found a sudden following. Conjuring Slowdive, Sleep, and maybe even Lucinda Williams, King Woman became one of the decade\xe2\x80\x99s most interesting new doom acts, loaded with crossover potential.' b'But Doubt courted a more unexpected audience, too\xe2\x80\x94the same religious clutches Esfandiari had castigated during those songs and in interviews with The Huffington Post\xc2\xa0and Rolling Stone. She soon started to clarify her positions publicly, but she didn\xe2\x80\x99t back down. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is my experience. This is my story, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t give a fuck about what any you think,\xe2\x80\x9d she said last year. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve had no voice for long enough, and there\xe2\x80\x99s so much that I need to say.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Esfandiari doesn\xe2\x80\x99t repent during Created in the Image of Suffering, King Woman\xe2\x80\x99s brazen and brilliant first LP, either. Instead, she redoubles her frustration and invective, not only impugning religious fervor but slyly subverting it as well, using its ecclesiastical language for very human conquests. Her writing is gripping and unapologetic, shrugging off the veils and cloaks of Doubt to address her grievances and express her regrets directly. \xe2\x80\x9cI wish somebody would have told me/\xe2\x80\x99Cause the past you can\xe2\x80\x99t get back,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings as \xe2\x80\x9cWorn\xe2\x80\x9d lifts to its grand chorus, \xe2\x80\x9cFeels like somebody wore me/There\xe2\x80\x99s a deliverance I lack.\xe2\x80\x9d Backed by a three-piece that seems now to share ownership of these songs, she seems to be finding her own path to redemption in doom\xe2\x80\x94and, in doing so, created one of the young year\xe2\x80\x99s most powerful rock records to date.' b'No one gets off easy here. Esfandiari scorns the self-medicating faithful during \xe2\x80\x9cDeny,\xe2\x80\x9d her soft but haunting voice riding a riff that feels as sharp as a reaper\xe2\x80\x99s scythe. \xe2\x80\x9cShame,\xe2\x80\x9d meanwhile, spotlights the existential dread of Esfandiari\xe2\x80\x99s former fellow adherents. She wonders how they find comfort in doomsday prophecies and punitive proclamations, why they seek shelter in something that feels so vengeful. She worries less about\xc2\xa0what people worship than how they worship\xe2\x80\x94specifically, how they use their beliefs to ensnare themselves and those around them, herself included. During Doubt, King Woman seemed to be learning how to communicate these concerns as a group; here, they preach together as a mighty team. The band pounds away behind her questions and observations, the bellicose rhythm section and snarling guitars demanding answers from a society of self-delusion.' b"The real strength of this still-new quartet becomes clear on \xe2\x80\x9cHierophant,\xe2\x80\x9d the centerpiece of these eight songs. Esfandiari funnels the language of the sacred into a series of profane come-ons: \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re a holy church, I wanna worship,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re a\xc2\xa0sacred script, I am the Hierophant.\xe2\x80\x9d She treats actual human lust with the same sort of obsessive, accidentally prurient language evangelicals sometimes use for God. It\xe2\x80\x99s funny, seductive, and coming from someone who has seen both sides, tragic. And with a chorus that hits like an electrified lullaby with a heretic\xe2\x80\x99s sense of mischief, it wouldn't be hard to imagine \xe2\x80\x9cHierophant\xe2\x80\x9d as a rock radio anthem. Now that would be a coveted fall from grace." b'Religious reckoning, of course, is nothing new to metal. For decades, the genre has subsisted on turning crosses and crowns upside down, self-identifying with the damned, and lampooning sources of self-proclaimed deliverance. But Esfandiari\xe2\x80\x99s rebuke on Created in the Image of Suffering is personal and real in a way that vaguely recalls the torment of the Delta blues or the spiritual keening of early American gospel music. Darkness is not just some metaphorical tool for expressing defiance or disillusionment\xe2\x80\x94Esfandiari has suffered and survived the horrors of which she sings. And yet there is an empowered spirit at the core of Created in the Image of Suffering, an understanding that goodness and light can crawl out of that dark, even if it takes a lifetime. With King Woman, Esfandiari has staked out her own salvation, and\xc2\xa0Created in the Image of Suffering is strong enough to inspire a lot of new believers.'

column7: b'Amsterdam DJ Young Marco Sterk mixes Buchla experiments with Nintendo-derived dance in his ambitious new mix.'
column8: b'In just a few years, Amsterdam\xe2\x80\x99s Dekmantel label has grown from throwing dance parties for 200 of their closest friends into a powerhouse label and a stellar annual festival. They recently leapt continents to throw their first festival in S\xc3\xa3o Paulo and last year, they spun off another mini-festival, Dekmantel Selectors, staged on a coastal resort in Croatia. As the name suggests, the latter festival emphasizes DJs with an ear bent towards the obscure and unheard. For those who didn\xe2\x80\x99t snap up tickets, as accompaniment, the label released compilations of such curious tunes from their favorite DJs. The first release in the series featured Motor City Drum Ensemble\xe2\x80\x99s Danilo Plessow balancing transporter-beam house, loft disco rarities, and raucous gospel-funk.' b'For the second entry in the series, Amsterdam\xe2\x80\x99s Young Marco\xc2\xa0takes a decidedly different path. Marco\xe2\x80\x99s mix hunts for tracks from outcasts and outliers, suggesting a bizarro world of not-dance dance music. Across 10 tracks, he finds Buchla experiments and a track made entirely from the old Nintendo game Mario Paint, cringeworthy Eighties Dutch rap, and a dewy jazz-funk delicacy from the lone legendary name on the comp, Larry Heard.' b'Along the way, Marco pays plenty of cheeky tributes to his Dutch roots. In the wake of Sugarhill Gang\xe2\x80\x99s chart success in the Netherlands, Jolyon Grevelt earned the humble title of being the first Dutch rapper, making\xc2\xa0a record\xc2\xa0as Danny Boy at the age of 13 in 1980. So leave it to Marco to find an even weirder B-side from the lad with which to open Selectors 002. Its rubber band-lite funk gets intercut every few minutes by cat meows, wikki-wikki scratches, vocoder chants, and what Jared Leto\xe2\x80\x99s Joker sneezing might sound like run through an Echoplex. Yet somehow, it all adds up into something that just escapes being an unlistenable oddity.' b'While EBM became a worldwide force thanks to the likes of Front 242 and Ministry, Sterk finds late \xe2\x80\x9980\xe2\x80\x99s Dutch examples that are peculiar mutations of that relentless electronic sound. Gerrit Hoekema\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cTelevisiewereld\xe2\x80\x9d sounds as whimsical as Aphex Twin\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cFingerbib,\xe2\x80\x9d with its circuitry curling up at the edges of the track. The Force Dimension\xe2\x80\x99s 1989 track \xe2\x80\x9c200 FA\xe2\x80\x9d trades the genre\xe2\x80\x99s distorted drum programming for what could be ethnographic tribal chants.' b'To Marco\xe2\x80\x99s ear, there\xe2\x80\x99s a connection to be made between the extremely rare and expensive Buchla Music Easel and a video game console. He digs up a 1981 track from Philly group Ghostwriters (an early duo featuring analog synth legend Charles Cohen) that deploys the Buchla on the joyous bubbling of \xe2\x80\x9cSwizzle\xe2\x80\x9d and then, a few tracks later, slots in Ray Tracing\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cMariopaint,\xe2\x80\x9d an anthemic bit of digital tiddlywinks from the mid-\xe2\x80\x9890s. That entry comes from Irdial Disc\xe2\x80\x99s peculiar \xe2\x80\x9995 comp that had as its only piece of gear the Nintendo Super Famicom, running the Mario Paint music sequencer as its only bit of software. Neither selection would scream \xe2\x80\x9cpeak hour,\xe2\x80\x9d but in Marco\xe2\x80\x99s hands, his gifts as a \xe2\x80\x9cselector\xe2\x80\x9d become clear. Like a packet of Sea-Monkeys, Marco knows just when to sprinkle in seemingly un-danceable tracks so as to make them wiggle to life in just the right setting.'

column7: b'Chad Ubovich is\xc2\xa0already a proven guitar hero, having played\xc2\xa0in Fuzz and with Mikal Cronin. His second Meatbodies album\xc2\xa0is a mellower, full-band effort with more psychedelic textures than before.'
column8: b'As California garage rock was\xc2\xa0recently enjoying a hot streak of sorts, Meatbodies emerged with a 2014 debut\xc2\xa0that asserted them as wreckers to be reckoned with. Songs like \xe2\x80\x9cDisorder,\xe2\x80\x9d with its fast, beefy, infectious hook, could hang with Ty Segall\xe2\x80\x99s most rabid material. (It helps, of course, that Segall himself played bass and drums on that track.) It was an album with layers\xe2\x80\x94one where earworm hooks and massive guitar solos wove together with gradual, acoustic psychedelia. Frontman and Meatbodies mastermind Chad Ubovich was already a proven guitar hero from his tenure in Fuzz and Mikal Cronin\xe2\x80\x99s live band. With Meatbodies, he showed that he was an artist who could craft a strong rock album all on his own.' b'On Alice, Meatbodies test the limits of their capabilities by wading into murkier waters: they made a concept album. The overarching story isn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly spelled out, but the album is filled with strange characters and over-the-top symbolism. Alice, from the title track, leaves men bloody and foaming on the ground. \xe2\x80\x9cDisciples\xe2\x80\x9d is sung from the perspective of a king who declares himself \xe2\x80\x9cthe idol,\xe2\x80\x9d relishes the fealty of his apostles, and demands his subjects keep their feelings to themselves. Sisyphus, Bethlehem, martyrs, rolling stones, bombs, burning oceans, and translucent flesh are all ingredients in Alice\xe2\x80\x99s narrative slurry. Near Biblical images of torture come before concerns about whether or not to check your texts first thing in the morning. There\xe2\x80\x99s likely some allegory in there, but in the chaos, it\xe2\x80\x99s difficult\xc2\xa0to parse what exactly they\xe2\x80\x99re going for.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s fine, though, since the lyrical fire and brimstone is\xc2\xa0a natural fit for Meatbodies\xe2\x80\x99 well-honed thrash. That said, the band behind Alice is a different beast than the one on\xc2\xa0Meatbodies. The debut album\xe2\x80\x99s massive sound fell largely on the shoulders of Ubovich, who played\xc2\xa0most of the instruments himself (with an assist from Segall). Alice is a proper full-band effort. While Ubovich still plays multiple instruments, and his guitar solos take a good share of the spotlight (especially the monster that opens \xe2\x80\x9cDisciples\xe2\x80\x9d), drummer Erik Jimenez keeps things frantic. Bassist Kevin Boog is responsible for the band\xe2\x80\x99s monolithic low end this time. The biggest wrinkle in the band\xe2\x80\x99s makeup comes with the addition of Patrick Nolan (of\xc2\xa0Walter), who trades lead vocal duties with Ubovich throughout.\xc2\xa0More\xc2\xa0voices means more\xc2\xa0variety, and the full band pack even more\xc2\xa0psychedelic textural experimentation than before.' b'While there are a few livewire moments that recall Meatbodies\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0most exciting work\xe2\x80\x94the triumphant riff from \xe2\x80\x9cTouchless,\xe2\x80\x9d for example\xe2\x80\x94*Alice *doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exactly come out swinging. It\xe2\x80\x99s a more sedate record; mellow grooves and acoustic strumming make up its core infrastructure. On \xe2\x80\x9cKings,\xe2\x80\x9d big, fuzzy guitar solos are largely just\xc2\xa0dressing\xe2\x80\x94they sit alongside the synths, adding atmosphere instead of maintaining focus. \xe2\x80\x9cGyre\xe2\x80\x9d is caked in fuzz and leads with a high drama guitar solo, but the song\xe2\x80\x99s seven-minute runtime drags as the melody and instruments thin out. Several songs go on for\xc2\xa0a little too long, and the added guitar fireworks\xc2\xa0rarely overcome the repetitive, less interesting melodies. There\xe2\x80\x99s not a standout hook that\xe2\x80\x99s as\xc2\xa0immediate or exciting as 2014 tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cHim,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cMountain,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cDisorder.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0That\xe2\x80\x99s ultimately the trouble with Meatbodies\xe2\x80\x99 concept record ambitions. A muddled narrative isn\xe2\x80\x99t a big deal, but with\xc2\xa0Alice, Meatbodies have snuffed out a little too much of their old fire.'

column7: b'Following their collaboration on\xc2\xa0last year\xe2\x80\x99s Atrocity Exhibition, the Accelerator 12\xe2\x80\x9d finds Danny Brown and producer Paul White coloring even more brazenly outside of hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s lines.'
column8: b'Speaking to an audience in Glasgow during a Red Bull Music Academy lecture in 2015, Danny Brown attempted to describe Atrocity Exhibition, his then forthcoming album. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just trying to push myself as far and make rap as progressive as possible,\xe2\x80\x9d Brown explained. \xe2\x80\x9cSo maybe like, I\xe2\x80\x99m on some Trent Reznor shit with this one, you know what I\xe2\x80\x99m saying?\xe2\x80\x9d Atrocity Exhibition\xc2\xa0made good on this, employing lumbering post-punk rhythms, industrial textures, and obscure musique concr\xc3\xa8te samples in service of Brown\xe2\x80\x99s dystopic vision. Of course, Brown didn\xe2\x80\x99t work alone; the English beatmaker Paul White produced the bulk of the album. The pair\xc2\xa0have a long history of pushing boundaries together. White has contributed to every Brown album since 2011\xe2\x80\x99s XXX**, and with Atrocity Exhibition, it felt like they had finally managed to tear down whatever barriers remained between hip-hop and their wide-ranging influences.' b'A victory lap of sorts, the\xc2\xa0Accelerator\xc2\xa012\xe2\x80\x9d feels even more uncompromising. Take the title track, wherein White pummels the listener with disorderly polyrhythms and driving intensity. Included here in the barrage of sounds are a tangle of bongos that clop like hooves at a horse track; a buzzing, prog-rock guitar run; a rolling, rubberband bassline; and a psychedelic, reverb-soaked guitar solo. If that sounds like an emcee\xe2\x80\x99s worst nightmare, you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t know it from Brown\xe2\x80\x99s nimble rapping. He manages to effortlessly surf the track\xe2\x80\x99s competing drum lines. \xe2\x80\x9cRappers rap about it/But never really live it/I never glorify it/I tell it how it is,\xe2\x80\x9d he yelps in his signature squeaky register, neatly summing up his documentarian appeal. Of course, Brown\xc2\xa0can\xe2\x80\x99t help but see the sonic chaos around him as a metaphor for a mind\xc2\xa0on drugs, half-singing, \xe2\x80\x9cWalking light\xc2\xa0the ground is so shaky/Losing sight, \xe2\x80\x99cause things is so hazy.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The song\xe2\x80\x99s video features a man chasing his escaped, anthropomorphic brain through the streets of London, which feels about right.' b'The B-side, \xe2\x80\x9cLion\xe2\x80\x99s Den,\xe2\x80\x9d takes a slightly different tack\xe2\x80\x94while it\xe2\x80\x99s plenty unorthodox, it slows things down to an even keel. The song is built around a loop of a y\xc3\xa9-y\xc3\xa9 singer set atop a plaintive pan flute melody; instead of a hi-hat, the steady boom-bap beat lands on a tambourine hit. Brown knows a thing or two about juxtaposition and here he delivers on the promise he makes in \xe2\x80\x9cAccelerator,\xe2\x80\x9d weaving a tale of street life and addiction that\xe2\x80\x99s anything but glamorous. Brown details days spent hustling \xe2\x80\x9cjust to get up out the gutter,\xe2\x80\x9d admits to \xe2\x80\x9cserving out our momma\xe2\x80\x99s house\xe2\x80\x9d and finally concedes, \xe2\x80\x9cthe pain never ends.\xe2\x80\x9d Still, the song\xe2\x80\x99s ultimate message is one of defiance in the face of hopelessness: \xe2\x80\x9cWe gotta break the cycle, a future for our kids/You see it half empty, I\xc2\xa0see it half full.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'White\xe2\x80\x99s audaciousness\xc2\xa0on Accelerator is commendable, though the single suffers a bit for its maximalism. As bold as Atrocity Exhibition was, it also felt refined, with\xc2\xa0the record\xe2\x80\x99s sharpest edges counterbalanced by moments of restraint. Accelerator throws that moderation out the window, resulting in two songs that feel unnecessarily cluttered; in particular, the vocal loop that runs throughout \xe2\x80\x9cLion\xe2\x80\x99s Den\xe2\x80\x9d distracts from Brown\xe2\x80\x99s rapping, holding back what\xe2\x80\x99s very nearly a great song. That said, both of these tracks do seem to be abrasive by design\xe2\x80\x94like White is intentionally pitching curveballs at Brown, just to see if he can hit them. To that end,\xc2\xa0Accelerator\xc2\xa0also feels like a dare to any other emcees\xc2\xa0who think they could\xc2\xa0tackle these beats. It seems unlikely that very many will try.'

column3: b'Now That the Light Is Fading'
column7: b'Following the viral success of her Pharrell-approved hit \xe2\x80\x9cAlaska,\xe2\x80\x9d this young singer-songwriter searches for an original sound on her major label debut EP.'
column8: b'Maggie Rogers\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cAlaska\xe2\x80\x9d was born with the kind of serendipitous discovery story entire TV series are commissioned to replicate. She was one of many students\xc2\xa0at New York University\xe2\x80\x99s Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, a school with enough largesse to commission Pharrell Williams for a masterclass. That half-hour listening session made it to YouTube in its entirety, but the highlight was obvious. Eighteen minutes in, when Rogers played an early demo of her song \xe2\x80\x9cAlaska,\xe2\x80\x9d a star was born: Rogers, in a casual sweater and jeans, eyes averted, wincing in that way one does when hearing their own voice; Pharrell, moved to tears, invoking Stevie Wonder and the Wu-Tang Clan in his praise. The video went viral on the musical enclaves of Reddit, always ready to laud anything that sounds acoustic or authentic, and thus followed everything virality brings: getting signed, a headlining North American tour, the interview circuit, and\xc2\xa0hundreds of thousands of fans from the get go.' b'Like most famous discovery stories, though, this one doesn\xe2\x80\x99t quite start at the beginning. Though she\xe2\x80\x99s since been f\xc3\xaated around as an entirely new voice, Rogers has four releases on Bandcamp dating back to 2012. Recorded in high school, they show great promise in a specific genre: banjo- and ukelele-driven folk indebted to Joni Mitchell and Patti Smith. There are hints at Rogers\xe2\x80\x99 current\xc2\xa0expanded direction on these early tracks, in the cirrus flicks of synths on \xe2\x80\x9cDrift\xe2\x80\x9d off 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Blood Ballet, the cello-enhanced \xe2\x80\x9cSatellite,\xe2\x80\x9d or the entirety of The Response, a remix album of 2012\xe2\x80\x99s The Echo*\xc2\xa0*that proves Rogers\xe2\x80\x99 music is amenable, at least in theory, to dance. But for the most part the Bandcamp material provides\xc2\xa0thoughtful examples of a genre that\xe2\x80\x99s simultaneously thriving and, unless your surname is Mumford, deeply, deeply unmarketable.' b'Rogers credits her new, synthier direction on \xe2\x80\x9cAlaska\xe2\x80\x9d and subsequent five-song EP Now That the Light Is Fading to a year of clubbing in Europe, but an equally apt explanation may involve facts of the marketplace. Pharrell said \xe2\x80\x9cAlaska\xe2\x80\x9d was like nothing he\xe2\x80\x99d ever heard, but in 2017 it fits right in: a gently lilting beat that vaguely evokes tropicalia (or, for that matter, the Neptunes in their prime) along with a falsetto pre-chorus that vaguely evokes R&B. The result isn\xe2\x80\x99t far off from Broods, or early Ellie Goulding, or, to go back to the last time folktronica blew everyone\xe2\x80\x99s minds, early Beth Orton. Follow-up single \xe2\x80\x9cDog Years,\xe2\x80\x9d dotted with pan flutes, comes across as the exact midpoint of Peter Gabriel, Lorde, and \xe2\x80\x9cBleeding Love,\xe2\x80\x9d and while no one\xe2\x80\x99s done that particular intersection lately, the industry\xe2\x80\x99s certainly revived everything in the vicinity.' b'Perhaps this is why *Now That the Light Is Fading *feels transitional, as if Rogers is unsure how far from trad-folk she wants to stray. On one end of the spectrum is \xe2\x80\x9cColor Song,\xe2\x80\x9d which consists of bird chirps, Rogers\xe2\x80\x99 multitracked choral vocals, and not much else. The track\xe2\x80\x99s melody drifts up and down the scale like an old hymn or trad-Americana cut\xc2\xa0as the lyric lingers on certain evocative details (when she sings the word \xe2\x80\x9ccreeping,\xe2\x80\x9d her vocals are tracked a split second off one another, letting the consonants crackle in the air), and nothing anywhere suggests Pharrell\xe2\x80\x99s involvement, spiritual or otherwise. \xe2\x80\x9cOn +\xc2\xa0Off\xe2\x80\x9d floats Rogers\xe2\x80\x99 voice above a choppy, Flume-like backing track and insistent piano loop, and \xe2\x80\x9cBetter\xe2\x80\x9d lets her sink amid a drone; both directions are promising, but in separate ways that don\xe2\x80\x99t quite cohere. Rogers is a promising songwriter when unattended\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAlaska\xe2\x80\x9d in particular is full of understated heartbreak, sort of like a PG take on Tori Amos\xe2\x80\x94but the poppier tracks here often dissolve into soft-rock nothingness.' b'A lot of this might resolve itself in time. Rogers is still very young at 22, after all, and she takes several game attempts at subtlety throughout the EP\xe2\x80\x94the pan flute, the guitar line rippling through \xe2\x80\x9cOn + Off\xe2\x80\x9d like wind chimes, the featherlight harmonies. She has a platform. She\xe2\x80\x99s got ideas. But like all discovery stories, the real reward lies in what comes next.'

column7: b'Jazz piano shredder Craig Taborn is a compositional force on his new quartet album. From the LP\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0grand design to its smallest quirks, Taborn and his bandmates\xc2\xa0make the music\xc2\xa0gently rage.'
column8: b'If invitations to jam can give any hint of a musician\xe2\x80\x99s reputation, then Craig Taborn has to be one of the most admired jazz pianists in the world. He\xe2\x80\x99s released a handful of\xc2\xa0albums under his own name, beginning with a hard-to-find 1994 debut on the DIW label. But Taborn has been featured in a sideman role on a stunning array of sessions. Of late, he has delivered vigorous free-improv work alongside Art Ensemble of Chicago co-founder Roscoe Mitchell. And he has also played some of John Zorn\xe2\x80\x99s most lyrical pieces in a trio that included the fiercely swinging bassist Christian McBride.' b'Central to Taborn\xe2\x80\x99s wide appeal is the way he can thread \xe2\x80\x9cfree jazz\xe2\x80\x9d style playing inside more conventional structures. A knowledge of funk and electronic music informs his ability to create catchy, short vamps, in the midst of otherwise frenetic solos. In his original compositions, Taborn\xe2\x80\x99s playing has an exquisite rightness\xe2\x80\x94even during the most out-there passages. If he starts playing motifs in different meters, in each hand, it\xe2\x80\x99s not because he\xe2\x80\x99s in a particular hurry to show off his chops. When a rush of tricky rhythm hits, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that the tune has been building toward that density. The fact that Taborn can shift into this experimental high gear so casually helps keep his music feeling poised and approachable.' b'Since signing to ECM earlier this decade, Taborn\xe2\x80\x99s output as a leader has ticked up in pace a bit. A 2011 solo piano album, both impressionistic and intense in character, served as his label debut. A trio record of subtle heat followed in 2013. The peaks of bash that Taborn produces elsewhere were mostly absent on those outings. (It\xe2\x80\x99s not a complete surprise, given ECM\xe2\x80\x99s focus on serene aesthetics.) The trend continues on Taborn\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0new quartet album, Daylight Ghosts, but on this occasion, he\xc2\xa0sets a quixotic challenge for himself. The pianist and his bandmates find ways to make the music sound raging despite the moderate dynamic levels.' b'Opening track \xe2\x80\x9cThe Shining One\xe2\x80\x9d creates drama through jagged switches. To start, drummer Dave King\xe2\x80\x94most famous for his work in the Bad Plus\xe2\x80\x94teases listeners with a brief solo groove. Then he\xe2\x80\x99s gone, leaving Taborn and tenor saxophonist Chris Speed to voice the piece\xe2\x80\x99s winding, long-lined theme together. When the rhythm section comes back in, the beat is free. Taborn dives with precision over the keyboard during his solo, while Speed rephrases portions of the main hook, rooting the performance.' b'The contrasts here\xe2\x80\x94between fixed and free rhythms, between melody and cacophony\xe2\x80\x94are wild. Still, the group\xe2\x80\x99s collective touch remains gentle, sublime. As they eventually converge on a beat that recalls King\xe2\x80\x99s opening, there\xe2\x80\x99s a sense that the music is fulfilling an inevitable destiny. This all happens in three and a half minutes: an economy of duration that is rare in exploratory modern jazz.' b'Nothing else on Daylight Ghosts repeats this pattern, though several other tracks manage to be equally surprising. On \xe2\x80\x9cAncient,\xe2\x80\x9d an introductory solo from bassist Chris Lightcap has a solemn spirituality. The rest of the ensemble enters gingerly\xe2\x80\x94yet by the end of the tune, they\xe2\x80\x99re all engaged in an ecstatic group dance. The title track\xe2\x80\x99s initial chorus and solos sound bummed out beyond belief; soon, the cloistered vibe gives way to a minimalist theme that suggests rising spirits. \xe2\x80\x9cAbandoned Reminder\xe2\x80\x9d is driven by noir sonics\xc2\xa0before a Taborn riff puts the tempo into urgent overdrive. On \xe2\x80\x9cThe Great Silence,\xe2\x80\x9d Speed switches to clarinet\xe2\x80\x94and\xc2\xa0Taborn\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0arrangement responds to the reed player\xe2\x80\x99s lustrous tone with an electronic percussion part.' b'In between those unpredictable statements, Taborn provides a few palette-cleansers that are more direct. \xe2\x80\x9cJamaican Farewell,\xe2\x80\x9d his cover of a Roscoe Mitchell ballad, is handled gorgeously, as the bandleader oversees a slight electronic sheen. And \xe2\x80\x9cNew Glory\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t shroud its intentions at all. It\xe2\x80\x99s simply an uptempo shot of Taborn\xe2\x80\x99s gift for joyous, funk-inspired riffing\xe2\x80\x94as well as a look at his ability to ornament a catchy melody for as long as he wants.' b'The final cut, \xe2\x80\x9cPhantom Ratio,\xe2\x80\x9d is a fitting capstone for an album with this much range. The lengthy track features droning tones that would fit in well in a concert of contemporary-classical chamber music, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also driven by an electronic keyboard loop. This is the\xc2\xa0sort of fractured, almost-danceable motif that Taborn has occasionally toyed with since his influential 2004 fusion album Junk Magic. Here, the stylistic distance from vintage IDM trends is greater. A brief electronic percussion pulse rounds out the performance\xe2\x80\x94and the album\xe2\x80\x94much as a brief hit of King\xe2\x80\x99s acoustic drumming started things off. From its grand design down to its smallest quirks, Daylight Ghosts shows that Taborn is much more than an elite jazz piano shredder. He\xe2\x80\x99s a compositional force, as well.'

column7: b'On their full-length\xc2\xa0debut, the Danish dream pop group\xc2\xa0take a quantum leap forward, with a richer and more eclectic sound.'
column8: b'When Lowly first appeared with a string of singles in 2014, the Danish five-piece\xe2\x80\x99s proficiency with atmospheres was clear. Those singles, along with an EP the following year, showcased the band\xe2\x80\x99s affinity for soaking its songs in heavy reverb. Naturally, Lowly\xe2\x80\x99s music hearkened back to previous generations of dream pop, shoegaze, and even the Beach Boys recording vocals in a swimming pool. But atmosphere alone isn\xe2\x80\x99t much more effective than aiming a video camera at a hunk of dry ice, and Lowly\xe2\x80\x94like countless bands who aim for a similar feel\xe2\x80\x94appeared to approach music from the outside in, as if tones and pedals could substitute for drama.' b'On Heba, Lowly\xe2\x80\x99s debut LP, the band takes a quantum leap forward. Opener\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cStill Life\xe2\x80\x9d taps into universal feelings of sadness and isolation with such power it would be unbearable if the music supporting it weren\xe2\x80\x99t so beautiful. \xe2\x80\x9cStill Life\xe2\x80\x9d captures that moment when one becomes aware that a relationship is doomed.\xc2\xa0Guitarist/vocalist Nanna Schannong and sampler/vocalist Soffie Viemose sing together, as\xc2\xa0keyboardist Kasper Staub\xe2\x80\x99s synths sweep across the music like gusts of remorse.\xc2\xa0Viemose and Schannong convey a sense of repetition over multiple lifetimes when they sing, \xe2\x80\x9cThe memories distort before I can tell/For centuries they\xe2\x80\x99ve been fading/Over and over again.\xe2\x80\x9d Meanwhile, drummer Steffen Lundtoft\xe2\x80\x94who manages to play with both a jazz player\xe2\x80\x99s taste for active patterns and a pop musician\xe2\x80\x99s instinct for economy\xe2\x80\x94drags the beat back to a crawl, as if to frame the glacial pace\xc2\xa0of the lyrics.' b'Lowly\xe2\x80\x99s previous work hovered in a state of somber, slightly edgy, but otherwise unremarkable introspection. The music on Heba is exponentially more rich. And unlike, say, Mazzy Star, Lowly don\xe2\x80\x99t\xc2\xa0dwell in the languid cadence of the first song. \xe2\x80\x9cDeer Eyes\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0might have qualified as techno if Lundtoft hadn\xe2\x80\x99t, in a sense,\xc2\xa0reverse-engineered an electronic beat for his live kit. Even if they had opted for a programmed\xc2\xa0beat, the song\xe2\x80\x99s tempo layering and synths, along with bassist Thomas Lund\xe2\x80\x99s Moog work, make it all difficult to classify.' b'At times, \xe2\x80\x9cDeer Eyes\xe2\x80\x9d recalls Radiohead\xe2\x80\x99s Kid A-era forays into a form of music that is neither organic nor synthetic, but some combination thereof. At one point, the music clears away as Staub plays a synth line that evokes a warped, somewhat cartoonish string section;\xc2\xa0Staub drops the line in just once, a deft move that gives the song a fleeting touch of vintage records where pop chanteuses are backed by an orchestra.' b'The band varies its approach on pretty much every song after that. When Schannong sings lead on the funkier \xe2\x80\x9cLook at the Sun,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0her\xc2\xa0cutting voice injects a dose of Morcheeba-esque electro-R&B into the mix. And even though most of the lyrics only vaguely illustrate their subject matter, they shift in texture enough to magnify the stylistic changes from song to song. Named after a friend of the band who emigrated to Denmark from Syria, Heba doesn\xe2\x80\x99t explicitly reference the real-life Heba\xe2\x80\x99s experience. Without that\xc2\xa0context, you\xe2\x80\x99d be hard-pressed to spot a\xc2\xa0correlation, although\xc2\xa0several of the songs could be interpreted to fit a refugee or immigrant\xe2\x80\x99s perspective. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you ever felt so lonely/That you could map it on your body?\xe2\x80\x9d Viemose sings. The answer for all of us is \xe2\x80\x9cof course.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet Lowly have found a way to ask the question so that it sounds fresh every time, much like this album as a whole.'

column7: b"Ryan Adams\xe2\x80\x99 new album is being positioned as one of his classic breakup records. In terms of its sound, at least, it's a winner."
column8: b'Ryan Adams\xc2\xa0gravely misread the pop culture climate of 2015 and his\xc2\xa0fan letter\xc2\xa0to\xc2\xa0Taylor Swift\xc2\xa0was incinerated on arrival by the hot takes. But at least\xc2\xa01989\xc2\xa0was a reminder of a time when he was generating reactions that ran deeper than a respect for craft. For most of the past decade, Adams has made albums of almost oppressive competence: whether the songs from\xc2\xa0Ashes & Fire and\xc2\xa0Ryan Adams took five minutes or five years of soul-searching to create, they all come out sounding equally effortless. Purely in terms of its content, Adams\xe2\x80\x99 new album,\xc2\xa0Prisoner, is more of the same, and how that sits will depend on whether you\xe2\x80\x99ve heard the singles or read the press clippings. It\xe2\x80\x99s another down-the-middle, crowd-pleasing Ryan Adams record\xc2\xa0at a time when that crowd was expecting him to bring the heat.' b'Still, as latter-day Ryan Adams albums go, there\xe2\x80\x99s more buzz than usual around\xc2\xa0Prisoner, and rightfully so. The neural blasts of guitar misfiring all over \xe2\x80\x9cDo You Still Love Me?\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDoomsday\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s pink-mist shimmer outline a convergence point where the heartland comfort food of\xc2\xa0Ryan Adams, the puckish punk whims of\xc2\xa01984, and the arena-rock aspirations of\xc2\xa01989\xc2\xa0meet. Purely as sound,\xc2\xa0Prisoner\xc2\xa0unquestionably succeeds; though Reagan-era AOR is basically a primary color of modern pop at this point, Adams\xe2\x80\x99 vocals and lyrical tics are so well established that any genre bends to his will.\xc2\xa0If the title track and \xe2\x80\x9cAnything I Say to You Now\xe2\x80\x9d aren\xe2\x80\x99t career highlights, they\xe2\x80\x99re at least ambitions fully realized\xe2\x80\x94quintessential 2010s Ryan Adams, conveying a mis-remembered \xe2\x80\x9980s where\xc2\xa0Tunnel of Love\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0The Queen Is Dead\xc2\xa0are close neighbors on record shelves and equally revered documents of idealized longing.' b'Previews of\xc2\xa0Prisoner\xc2\xa0have not been shy about stating the obvious:\xc2\xa0this is Adams\xe2\x80\x99 first album since separating from actress Mandy Moore, which he described as a\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9chumiliating and just a fucking horrible\xc2\xa0thing to go through.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The context of the breakup is so central to how the album is being heard, news of the event might as well be slapped on a sticker on the cover. But though it lacks the intoxicating, top-of-the-world cockiness that powered\xc2\xa0Gold\xc2\xa0through its street-walkin\xe2\x80\x99 low points,\xc2\xa0Prisoner\xc2\xa0is Adams\xe2\x80\x99 most complete work since then\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s not stuck in a single mode. The Deadheaded \xe2\x80\x9cTo Be Without You\xe2\x80\x9d rambles on like\xc2\xa0Cold Roses, so that the line \xe2\x80\x9cnothing really matters anymore\xe2\x80\x9d registers like a cashed-bowl shrug, while, the chipper strum of \xe2\x80\x9cHaunted House\xe2\x80\x9d shows the dark side of the record\xe2\x80\x99s offhandedness, coming very close to Hootie\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cOnly Wanna Be With You.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Adams is the first to joke about his stock phrases, and his self-awareness renders his most objectively miserable work tolerable\xe2\x80\x94any mention of \xe2\x80\x9crain\xe2\x80\x9d or "trains" in one of his songs, for example, has a meta quality, his version of a DJ tag. But hearing \xe2\x80\x9cThorn in my side/Pain I can\xe2\x80\x99t hide,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my soul is/Black as coal,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cFeel like I\xe2\x80\x99m headed for a breakdown/Feel like I\xe2\x80\x99m racing and I can\xe2\x80\x99t come down\xe2\x80\x9d tossed around carelessly within the same song is enough to question where Adams\xe2\x80\x99 appreciation of soft-rock\xc2\xa0schlock ends and appropriation begins.\xc2\xa0Prisoner\xc2\xa0is filled with lyrics like these, lines\xc2\xa0that feel like placeholders for universal truths or even personalized expressions of pain that rarely emerge. While it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to evaluate the album\xe2\x80\x99s sincerity, inspiration is a more tangible quality, and Adams comes off like an A student uncharacteristically frozen by an essay prompt, filling the margins with the hopes that his reputation can get him out of this jam, this one time.' b"A generous reading of\xc2\xa0Prisoner\xc2\xa0can play it off as a commentary on the futility of \xe2\x80\x9cbreakup albums\xe2\x80\x9d at a certain point in your life\xe2\x80\x94that the hurt can feel as debilitating and devastating as it did in similar situations years ago, but the need to dramatize it just isn\xe2\x80\x99t there\xc2\xa0anymore. In fact, as tell-alls have become the norm for public breakups between artists in recent years\xe2\x80\x94ranging from\xc2\xa0Dirty Projectors\xc2\xa0to\xc2\xa0Dirty Sprite 2, from\xc2\xa0Tourist in This Town to,\xc2\xa0ahem, Taylor Swift\xe2\x80\x94it can be a relief to hear something that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like an invasion of privacy for the party not present. But the emotional equanimity of Prisoner always feels unintentional, or worse, a byproduct of his unerring craft. While\xc2\xa0Prisoner clearly aspires to join\xc2\xa0Love Is Hell or\xc2\xa029\xc2\xa0or\xc2\xa0Heartbreaker as another platonic ideal for a \xe2\x80\x9csad Ryan Adams album,\xe2\x80\x9d it can't help but be \xe2\x80\x9canother Ryan Adams album.\xe2\x80\x9d"

column7: b'The debut album by Hand Habits\xe2\x80\x94aka Albany D.I.Y. stalwart Meg Duffy\xe2\x80\x94is a joyous, open-ended study in vulnerability.'
column8: b'Hand Habits\xe2\x80\x99 debut LP, *Wildly Idle (Humble Before the Void), *evokes a striking image, that of submitting oneself to an expansive unknown with arms outstretched. It\xe2\x80\x99s a feeling Meg Duffy, the singer-songwriter behind this project, knows well; the upstate New York native once packed up everything and moved to Los Angeles to become the guitarist for Kevin Morby. Before that, she\xe2\x80\x99d experimented as Hand Habits around the Albany D.I.Y. scene and, in 2014, released Small Shifts, a 10-inch split with Avi Buffalo\xe2\x80\x99s Sheridan Riley.' b'It is with an earthly reverence that Duffy attends to her music. When Duffy plays with Morby, she\xe2\x80\x99s a calm and grounded presence, shredding with natural ease, often with eyes closed. Here, her meditations are never rushed and the record rumbles along patiently. Duffy recorded Wildly Idle herself between the Catskills and Los Angeles with assistance from Riley, Quilt\xe2\x80\x99s Keven Lareau, and M. Geddes Gengras. Rather than feeling pigeonholed by the sonic stereotypes of either locale (woodsy vs. hi-fi), *Wildly Idle *sounds birthed from exploration and experimentation.' b'Like her main influences, Grouper and Phil Elverum, Duffy understands that songs are \xe2\x80\x9cevolving, living things,\xe2\x80\x9d as the latter musician once said. One gets the sense that Duffy\xe2\x80\x99s songs are so thoroughly composed that they could fly off on their own. \xe2\x80\x9cActress\xe2\x80\x9d is overflowing with minutiae like the shaking of maracas, gentle guitars, and a moment when all these fizz into dissolution. \xe2\x80\x9cNow isn\xe2\x80\x99t it just like me?/I\xe2\x80\x99m cracking up out of the blue,\xe2\x80\x9d she asks after this break, with a hint of levity. Indeed, on *Wildly Idle, *Duffy displays a joy in opening herself up. Part of submission is admitting one\xe2\x80\x99s own vulnerability and reliance on the intangible, which Duffy does many times here. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want no one else/It\xe2\x80\x99s better to believe in something/Bigger than ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings on opener \xe2\x80\x9cFlower Glass.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Three poems (\xe2\x80\x9cscenes,\xe2\x80\x9d per Duffy), are scattered throughout the record and are read by their authors: Kayla Ephros, Catherine Pond, and Lucy Blagg. Beneath their distorted voices, Duffy warps her instruments into haunting, ethereal atmospheres. Each poem purposefully addresses one of the motifs Duffy confronts on Wildly Idle: \xe2\x80\x9cGreater LA\xe2\x80\x9d probes the metropolis\xe2\x80\x99 inherent despair, \xe2\x80\x9cCowboy\xe2\x80\x9d subverts gender roles, and \xe2\x80\x9cTime Hole\xe2\x80\x9d questions the rapid pace of contemporary life. Like Jenny Hval\xe2\x80\x99s collaborations with writer Annie Bielski, these additions work to minimize the distinction between poetry and song.' b'Listening to *Wildly Idle (Humble Before the Void) *reminds me of a line from Eve Babitz\xe2\x80\x99s collection Slow Days, Fast Company: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been in love with people and ideas in several cities and learned that the lovers I\xe2\x80\x99ve loved and the ideas I\xe2\x80\x99ve embraced depended on where I was, how cold it was, and what I had to do to be able to stand it.\xe2\x80\x9d Duffy sings of romances come and gone without ever sounding jaded or spiteful; future love promises a mystery, a sensuality that\xe2\x80\x99s open like the road. \xe2\x80\x9cI just wanna be a bad boy/Baby in your arms tonight,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmurs at one point, with an Elvis-like softness. There\xe2\x80\x99s a hope here that the unknown contains more positivities than anxieties. The final words on the album are \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m gonna grow,\xe2\x80\x9d and there\xe2\x80\x99s every reason to believe it\xe2\x80\x99s a promise Duffy will keep.'

column3: b'Being You Is Great, I Wish I Could Be You More Often'
column7: b'Prolific Detroit rapper-producer Quelle Chris offers up his most compelling bout of\xc2\xa0existential voyaging to date, ultimately catching more than just his own reflection in the mirror.'
column8: b"Catharsis has been such an effective coping mechanism lately that it can be easy to forget what you really need sometimes is a strong sense of meditative focus. Before you can ramp yourself up enough to go out there and Get Shit Done, you need to believe that you're the kind of person who actually can and that it matters if you do in the first place. If you cultivate your chill well enough, you'll be able to bust through barriers and push off antagonists with a sly deadpan and your energy still preserved." b"That's been the recent vibe given off by prolific Detroit MC/producer Quelle Chris, a low-key incisive weed-and-brew wiseass whose halting flow deliberates like the underground's rejoinder to mumble rap. Innocent Country, from 2015, was the album that hinted at deeper existential crises beneath the veneer of comedic bravado, a curious interrogation of his surroundings on both a personal and a wide-picture scale. Last year's Lullabies for the Broken Brain\xc2\xa0highlighted that same sense of walls-closing-in restlessness with a string of bass-rich but sandpapery instrumentals that communicated an insomniac anxiety through kick drums. Being You Is Great, I Wish I Could Be You More Often is the logical progression from both: a bout of existential voyaging that can't help but catch more than just Quelle's own reflection in the mirror." b"Single \xe2\x80\x9cBuddies\xe2\x80\x9d is probably the pull-quote track of the album, an ego trip statement delivered with a calmly bemused, beatifically sincere voice: \xe2\x80\x9cI fuck with myself/I fucks with myself/Might bring myself some flowers/I'm in love with myself.\xe2\x80\x9d After that hook winds up resurfacing as a reprise once most of the record's portrait has been assembled, it's a bit easier to recognize as the problem he hints at: what is there, really, to love about himself, and does he even fuck with anyone else he knows? So he questions his own intelligence along with everyone else's (\xe2\x80\x9cDumb for Brains\xe2\x80\x9d), bites \xe2\x80\x9cthe bullet, the case, and the trigger\xe2\x80\x9d en route to finding some measure of perseverance (\xe2\x80\x9cPopeye\xe2\x80\x9d), takes on a crew's worth of voices as he both champions and shoots down a rap-game-focused end run around a dead-end living (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Dreamer in the Den of Wolves\xe2\x80\x9d), and generally tries to reconcile the bad stuff with the side of himself that\xe2\x80\x99s worthy of celebrating." b"Quelle's heaviness isn't a burden, though. His flow is immersed in a conversational ease, somewhere between classic Madlib and a Hannibal Buress routine, his inflections coming across like emotive gestures\xe2\x80\x94shrugged shoulders, rolled eyes, rubbed temples. He's expressive enough to excuse lines flatter or cornier than the ones he actually brings, but mostly his cadence adds resonance to simple sentiments. When he admits, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, I like to drink/Yes, I like to smoke/Yes it's an escape/I don't like to cope\xe2\x80\x9d over a pitched-up quasi-Quasimoto overdub on \xe2\x80\x9cLearn to Love Hate,\xe2\x80\x9d or takes a breather to rattle off a distilled barrage of pure-lyricist punchline shit-talk on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Prestige,\xe2\x80\x9d Chris adapts to those shifts in tone and intensity with an almost disorienting ease." b"He\xe2\x80\x99s got some strong hands on deck for guest spots, too. There are characteristically quotable verses by Roc Marciano, Elzhi, Homeboy Sandman, Jean Grae, and other frequent cohorts, as well as beats by producers ranging from MNDSGN (woozily harmony-driven on \xe2\x80\x9cPopeye\xe2\x80\x9d) to Alchemist (looping psych-folk wails on \xe2\x80\x9cPendulum Swing\xe2\x80\x9d) to Chris Keys (ruminative on three wildly different cuts). But for all the friends around him, Quelle\xe2\x80\x99s personality\xe2\x80\x94fractured as it is\xe2\x80\x94manifests clearly through his own particular quirks. Whether it's a self-produced beat that kicks up dust particles (like the snare-melting trudge of \xe2\x80\x9cFascinating Grass\xe2\x80\x9d) or his tendency to put on a voice that threatens to push you away before luring you back in, Quelle's whole approach is a self-examination that cuts both ways. Once you get that whole value-of-the-self situation figured out, Being You Is Great, I Wish I Could Be You More Often bumps enough to pace a purposeful movement out into the streets."

column7: b'A solo artist gathers some pals for a trippy trip through the droney side of the avant-garde. Good for island meditations and pretending to be weightless.'
column8: b'A project begun on an island in Washington State, Mind Over Mirrors springs from the imagination of Jaime Fennelly, who now resides in Chicago. Across five limited edition releases, Fennelly has performed alone. And while Undying Color, his sixth album (and first for Paradise of Bachelors) also began as a solo excursion (this time with Fennelly decamping to southwestern Wisconsin), he then went back into the studio with a full-fledged ensemble, including members from Eleventh Dream Day, Califone, Circuit des Yeux and Jon Mueller of Death Blues, to add more color to his drones and drifts.' b'But while Mind Over Mirrors now sounds like a live group, their influences don\xe2\x80\x99t reference bands per se as much as they do iconoclastic American composers of the 20th century. Mirrors\xe2\x80\x99 bio references G.I. Gurdjieff\xe2\x80\x99s esoteric harmonium music, but almost every piece on Undying Color hearkens back to the likes of Terry Riley, Harry Partch, Laurie Spiegel and Henry Flynt, to name a few. And at the center of it all remains Fennelly\xe2\x80\x99s hard-pumping harmonium. His drone hovers over opener \xe2\x80\x9cRestore & Slip,\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s most energetic number. It then swiftly scales up thanks to a tumbling drum kit beat and some furious fiddling that evokes the sawing fury of Henry Flynt and his penchant for hillbilly minimalism. Together it all builds to an ecstatic and buzzing peak that the album is hard-pressed to replicate for the remainder of the album.' b'While Fennelly\xe2\x80\x99s Indian pedal harmonium has always been the centerpiece of Mind Over Mirrors, with Undying Color he adds in an Oberheim synth and shows a wider range and malleability. On \xe2\x80\x9cGray Clearer,\xe2\x80\x9d he has a tone that wheezes and expands like Pauline Oliveros\xe2\x80\x99s bandoneon against a shuffling, shamanic thump. For \xe2\x80\x9cSplintering,\xe2\x80\x9d Fennelly mimics the antigravity properties of Laurie Spiegel\xe2\x80\x99s analog components, floating free alongside rubbed singing bowls and a wordless vocal from Eleventh Dream Day and Freakwater member Janet Beveridge Bean. His harmonium swirls and slowly accrues a thick shoegaze fuzz on the flickering \xe2\x80\x9c600 Miles Around.\xe2\x80\x9d And on \xe2\x80\x9cGlossolaliac,\xe2\x80\x9d Fennelly\xe2\x80\x99s keys churn and cycle like one of Terry Riley\xe2\x80\x99s vintage all-night flights, soon synching with violin and Haley Fohr\xe2\x80\x99s voice. It\xe2\x80\x99s the clear album highlight, a cosmic trip that condenses such expansive minimalist explorations into a delectably concise three-minute length.' b'Inversely, where the album stumbles is on the lengthy 12-minute song, \xe2\x80\x9cGravity Wake.\xe2\x80\x9d The Oberheim yawns and crests, a steady snare pattern giving the piece its processional rhythm. Bean and Fohr\xe2\x80\x99s voices entwine in murmurs about space and Einstein\xe2\x80\x99s theory of general relativity, Fohr\xe2\x80\x99s more dramatic voice giving gravitas to the command: \xe2\x80\x9cBe the gravity wake.\xe2\x80\x9d Tasteful and restrained as Fennelly\xe2\x80\x99s playing is, here it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have quite enough energy or movement to sustain such a runtime. That said, the expanded palette and membership bodes well for future explorations.'

column7: b'By embracing the detuned bass and dope boy cool of state-of-the-art trap, Lupe Fiasco delivers his most subversive album\xc2\xa0yet.'
column8: b'Lupe Fiasco\xe2\x80\x99s new album introduces itself with a shocking display of force: \xe2\x80\x9cDopamine Lit (Intro)\xe2\x80\x9d is two minutes and 49 seconds of foghorn bass, fiery bars, and a half-joking, half-drunken chorus that includes a Billboard flip-off, a Lord of the Rings reference, and some self-consciously nonsensical trap grunts, for good measure. The song especially feels like a pleasant surprise attack when held against the eternally put-upon rapper\xe2\x80\x99s consistently inconsistent delivery over the last few years. DROGAS Light may not surpass his auspicious debut, 2006\xe2\x80\x99s Food & Liquor, but it is easily the least scattered\xc2\xa0statement he\xe2\x80\x99s made in about a decade.' b'Not coincidentally, it is also the first album he is releasing independently after concluding his long and unhappy relationship with Atlantic Records. So rather than turning in a collection of songs that are easily sorted into column A (safer, radio-playable, label-approved) and column B (self-indulgent and somewhat superior), Lupe goes hard at a coherent sound on every single track, most pointedly on the album\xe2\x80\x99s stellar first half. But coherence is not the only or most important difference here. There\xe2\x80\x99s also an unexpected sonic strategy that finds Lupe unleashing a relentless assault of huge 808s, bomb-tick snares, and constantly chopped\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99popping vocal samples; he\xe2\x80\x99s simultaneously trying on sounds of the moment while retaining his contrarian viewpoint on modern trap trends.' b'Unchained from major-label groupthink, Lupe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t go completely left with a set of stiflingly dense art-raps. Instead, many of these tracks seem purpose-built\xc2\xa0to compete with Rae Sremmurd and Migos for sheer bumpability, while lyrically running laps around them. The trap-heavy production is a major asset; 808s and psychedelic ambience provide Lupe with a vehicle for his worldview, which is critical of the genre\xe2\x80\x99s gangster tropes. \xe2\x80\x9cYou seen the movie/They killed the n***ga/Why you still wanna be like Scarface?\xe2\x80\x9d he raps on \xe2\x80\x9cNGL.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'This novel collision of style and substance is a welcome switch in approach for the rapper. Lupe never quite felt comfortable in the boom-bap lineage of backpacker rap that some fans and critics have wanted him to stick to ever since\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cKick Push\xe2\x80\x9d cast him as an unlikely torchbearer of the Native Tongues ethos back in 2006. He soon found his own mold\xe2\x80\x94a mix of West Coast and Midwest gangsta rap influences with an emo/goth-pop aesthetic that never quite worked for anybody except diehard fans. Unfortunately, a few DROGAS cuts, like \xe2\x80\x9cMade in the USA\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cPick Up the Phone,\xe2\x80\x9d still fall into that underwhelming category. The filter house outing \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Not Design\xe2\x80\x9d and dance-rocky \xe2\x80\x9cWild Child\xe2\x80\x9d also feel like throwbacks to the days of base-covering radio singles\xe2\x80\x94concessions to a label boss he\xe2\x80\x99s already fired.' b'DROGAS\xe2\x80\x99 bold new sound, however, demands to be measured, less against Lupe\xe2\x80\x99s own catalog than the current field of sources\xc2\xa0he\xe2\x80\x99s drawing from and bouncing off of. The best songs on the album feel kindred in spirit to some of Kanye\xe2\x80\x99s The Life of Pablo\xc2\xa0but are nowhere near as original, transgressive, or transportive. Run the Jewels have combined 808s with subversive strains of anger and paranoia to stronger effect, not to mention Kendrick. And even compared with artists like 2 Chainz and Migos, Lupe\xe2\x80\x99s bars lack a certain snap. That\xe2\x80\x99s because he is only here to flirt and subvert\xe2\x80\x94he is not really in the moment, not really about that life. Plays on drug slang provide this album with much of its\xc2\xa0imagery\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTranquillo,\xe2\x80\x9d in particular, serves as sort of a key to the record\xe2\x80\x99s central conceit\xe2\x80\x94but overall the listener gets the sense that is Lupe still too self-conscious to\xc2\xa0truly loosen up, get lifted,\xc2\xa0and achieve the altered state that is so key to Future\xe2\x80\x99s screwed soul or Kanye\xe2\x80\x99s gospel-inflected high.' b'Ultimately, DROGAS Light reaffirms, rather than fundamentally alters, Lupe\xe2\x80\x99s place in the rap pantheon. He\xe2\x80\x99s always been too lyrical and heady to count out as an innovator in the game, even if his moves sometimes make you want to do just that. But here, with a newfound urgency to his sound, he proves once again that he is still the brainy smurf of rap.'

column3: b'Studio One Rocksteady 2: The Soul of Young Jamaica'
column7: b'Drawn from the deep catalog\xc2\xa0of Jamaica\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0legendary Studio One,\xc2\xa0every song on this new compilation is a bonafide classic, underscoring the connection between spacious rocksteady music and U.S. soul.'
column8: b'Rounding out the sound of Jamaica\xe2\x80\x94alongside mento, ska, reggae, dancehall, and dub\xe2\x80\x94rocksteady is one of the many\xc2\xa0genres born on the island. Providing the link between the swift bounce of ska and the slower throb of reggae, the reduced speed of rocksteady music means there is more space between the beats for organ flourishes, horn solos, smooth singing, and experimentation. On the\xc2\xa0new Studio One Rockstead**y\xc2\xa0compilation, every song is a bonafide classic, drawing from\xc2\xa0the deep late-\xe2\x80\x9960s/early-\xe2\x80\x9970s catalog of Kingston producer Clement \xe2\x80\x9cSir Coxsone\xe2\x80\x9d Dodd\xe2\x80\x99s legendary Studio One during the height of his powers.' b'In the context of street-dance, when huge stacks of speakers emit a range of rocksteady tunes, there\xe2\x80\x99s usually an accompanying U.S. soul selection. The two styles work well together, and Studio One Rocksteady 2 shows just how, underlining the influence of soul music on the mid-1960s Jamaican genre.\xc2\xa0As historian Steve Barrow writes in the liner notes, \xe2\x80\x9cmany of the tracks on this set could easily be considered as yet another regional style of American soul music.\xe2\x80\x9d Case in point: the mournful horn solo in Delroy Wilson\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cRiding for a Fall,\xe2\x80\x9d a cover of song\xc2\xa0from the Atlanta vocal group the Tams, which matches the original\xe2\x80\x99s message of relationship disappointment and pushes the melancholy even more.' b'Many of the singers and instrumentalists on\xc2\xa0Rocksteady 2 can also claim the pedigree of the equally legendary Alpha Boys\xe2\x80\x99 School: Vin Gordon on trombone during \xe2\x80\x9cChange Your Style,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0for example, and Karl \xe2\x80\x9cCannonball\xe2\x80\x9d Bryan fronting\xc2\xa0Cannon & the Soul Vendors on \xe2\x80\x9cBad Treatment.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The collection provides early evidence of John Holt\xe2\x80\x99s talents, from his \xe2\x80\x9cStrange Things\xe2\x80\x9d performance, to his vocal duties as the Paragons, to exhorting a lover over hooliganism on \xe2\x80\x9cChange Your Style.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Rocksteady 2\xc2\xa0also demonstrates\xc2\xa0the enduring popularity Jamaican sounds: Alton Ellis\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Still in Love With You\xe2\x80\x9d remains a dancehall classic\xc2\xa0thanks to Sean Paul and Sasha\xe2\x80\x99s early-\xe2\x80\x9900s cover. It\xe2\x80\x99s well known that\xc2\xa0Studio One instrumental rhythms (referred to as \xe2\x80\x9criddims\xe2\x80\x9d) have been used over and over again, and many originated\xc2\xa0as rocksteady standards.' b'Rocksteady is a perfect music for swaying and slow dancing; it\xe2\x80\x99s no wonder that folks will still couple up for tunes like Hortense and Alton Ellis\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cBreaking Up Is Hard to Do,\xe2\x80\x9d another gem here. It\xe2\x80\x99s also Hortense\xe2\x80\x99s pure tone that makes\xc2\xa0the collection\xe2\x80\x99s opening\xc2\xa0track\xe2\x80\x94a version of Chicago soul singer Billy Stewart\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSitting in the Park\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94as pleasant an experience to listen to as, well, sitting in the park on a warm day. (Just don\xe2\x80\x99t concentrate too hard\xc2\xa0on the lyrics, which describe what it\xe2\x80\x99s like to be left waiting.)' b'Breathing a different type of life into American soul, rocksteady also opened the door to the reggae of the \xe2\x80\x9970s: the bouncy lyrics and keys of \xe2\x80\x9cRub Up Push Up\xe2\x80\x9d point directly towards later reggae.\xc2\xa0Every February,\xc2\xa0it\xe2\x80\x99s officially Reggae Month in Jamaica, with a jam-packed schedule of events emphasizing\xc2\xa0the country\xe2\x80\x99s striking cultural richness. A\xc2\xa0focus on reggae requires shedding some light on rocksteady, and\xc2\xa0Studio One Rocksteady 2\xc2\xa0is a vivid celebration.'

column7: b'The Orwells\xc2\xa0recognize the need for a space where the ground rules of Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Garage\xe2\x80\x9d still have merit, where knucklehead behavior is allowed and encouraged, so long as no one gets hurt.'
column8: b'The Orwells\xc2\xa0are five dudes from the suburbs of Chicago playing a codified style of garage rock, like so many suburban dudes before them. But despite what you may have read about the impending obsolescence of groups exactly like this one,\xc2\xa0the Orwells signed to a major label before they turned 21 and were quickly thrust towards enviable font size on festival lineups\xc2\xa0and a career-making\xc2\xa0performance on \xe2\x80\x9cLate Show With David Letterman.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s clearly an under-served audience for a band like the Orwells, and\xc2\xa0Terrible Human Beings caters to their needs and lets everyone else know they can fuck right off.\xc2\xa0These guys wisely recognize the need for a space where the ground rules of\xc2\xa0Weezer\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Garage\xe2\x80\x9d still have merit, where knucklehead behavior is allowed and encouraged, so long as no one gets hurt.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cTold me \xe2\x80\x98Act your age\xe2\x80\x99/That\xe2\x80\x99s why she\xe2\x80\x99s underage,\xe2\x80\x9d Mario Cuomo shouts on \xe2\x80\x9cThey Put a Body in the Bayou,\xe2\x80\x9d which will only raise an eyebrow if you\xe2\x80\x99ve never read a single thing about the Orwells up to this point. The two things most people know about the Orwells is that they are young and they like to\xc2\xa0start shit, twin concerns summed up nicely on the chorus: \xe2\x80\x9cGood boys come in last/Bad girl by my side/Poppin\xe2\x80\x99 pills on the fly/Cold grave when I die.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Considering their sound, their look, their name,\xc2\xa0the zippy hooks and laddish malfeasance\xe2\x80\x94and not even counting the BBC and NME namedrops on \xe2\x80\x9cRing Pop\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the Orwells probably would\xe2\x80\x99ve been called rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll\xe2\x80\x99s new saviors at least twice over by this point if they were British.' b'They might as well be, with Jim Abbiss behind the boards here. He was one of the\xc2\xa0three heavyweights responsible for producing their 2014 album\xc2\xa0Disgraceland**, along with\xc2\xa0TV on the Radio\xe2\x80\x99s Dave Sitek and Chris Coady (Beach House,\xc2\xa0Future Islands).\xc2\xa0Abbiss, meanwhile is best known for helming the\xc2\xa0Arctic Monkeys\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0canonical debut, as well as\xc2\xa0Kasabian\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0Editors\xc2\xa0albums you probably haven\xe2\x80\x99t heard if you\xe2\x80\x99re American. He knows how to get a song to sound like it belongs on satellite radio, but this just leaves\xc2\xa0Terrible Human Beings in a netherworld between the\xc2\xa0Black Lips\xc2\xa0pisstakes of their earliest work and\xc2\xa0the Black Keys\xc2\xa0commercial ambitions of their present.' b'Terrible Human Beings can still be cherry-picked for catchy singles bound for algorithmic playlists, but\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to overlook how much of the Orwells\xe2\x80\x99 appeal is bundled into their persona as\xc2\xa0enfants terribles.\xc2\xa0And\xc2\xa0since there\xe2\x80\x99s absolutely no way for them to generate the violent potential of their live shows here, Cuomo has to bring it second-hand: \xe2\x80\x9cHeavy Head\xe2\x80\x9d is a weirdly sanitized hostage narrative, and the song called \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Francis\xe2\x80\x9d includes a\xc2\xa0nod to California street gangs\xc2\xa0plucked directly from\xc2\xa0Pixies\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cNo. 13 Baby.\xe2\x80\x9d The borrowed menace is awkward on many levels, but it mostly underlines how\xc2\xa0wholesome\xc2\xa0these guys feel in 2017.\xc2\xa0This\xc2\xa0is\xc2\xa0an album called\xc2\xa0Terrible Human Beings with a naked woman on the cover, but like so much of what lies herein, they suggest malevolence without much to show for it.' b"Rock music doesn't have to be \xe2\x80\x9cdangerous\xe2\x80\x9d to be thrilling, of course. Rock music\xc2\xa0is still relevant, in large part because it can do other things besides conveying suburban angst\xe2\x80\x94it can comfort, confound, speak for marginalized voices or give people the energy to get the fuck out of bed. But the Orwells aren\xe2\x80\x99t here for any of that.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s going to bring rock back,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0guitarist Matt O\xe2\x80\x99Keefe said about the record. \xe2\x80\x9cI just think it\xe2\x80\x99s a rock record that maybe some people will enjoy.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s best to take O\xe2\x80\x99Keefe at his word\xe2\x80\x94if you don\xe2\x80\x99t expect too much from them, you might not be let down."

column7: b'As Fire-Toolz, the Chicago experimentalist Angel Marcloid\xc2\xa0creates an abrasive\xc2\xa0sonic world: Mundane internet ephemera swirls around in a boiling industrial centrifuge, powered by her\xc2\xa0fearsome growl.'
column8: b'Shortly before the turn of the century, the Chicago-based experimentalist Angel Marcloid began self-releasing electronic noise music under nearly two dozen names: WEBSITE \xe3\x83\x84, Path to Lobster Believers, and DJ Eyebrow Ring are but a few of the guises. Her\xc2\xa0first album as\xc2\xa0Fire-Toolz, Further Down the Files,\xc2\xa0arrived in 2015, followed by Even the Files Won\xe2\x80\x99t Tough You. The Fire-Toolz project is akin to\xc2\xa0a postmodern bildungsroman, transcending aesthetics, scenes, and genders.\xc2\xa0Marcloid came out as transgender during the gestation of the latter release, thereby assuming a new pedestal. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was like the trans-community handed me a mic and they all were standing there, staring at me blankly, waiting for me to say some angry shit,\xe2\x80\x9d she told Life Is Noise last summer: \xe2\x80\x9cIt did provide a new perspective... But I also felt like I had nothing to say, even though I was (and am) a girl.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Certainly, Marcloid doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say much on Fire-Toolz\xe2\x80\x99s third album and Hausu Mountain debut, Drip Mental. Instead, she screams\xe2\x80\x94unleashing yell after sandpapery, cord-shredding yell, reducing words to rubble and pushing the listener\xe2\x80\x99s focus outwards into the surrounding digital din. Call it vaporwave hell: an intimidating world where mundane internet ephemera (AIM message sounds, cat purrs, library music samples) swirls around in a boiling industrial centrifuge. Marcloid\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0soundscapes are\xc2\xa0powered by IBM drum machines, cyberpunk synths, and the odd, brittle hip-hop beat. Throughout, her\xc2\xa0fearsome growl sounds straight from the throat of a black-metal banshee, alternated every so often with a disorienting, pitch-shifted rasp.' b'On \xe2\x80\x9cThe Graying of the Crocs,\xe2\x80\x9d euro-dance synths and leaden drum machines stab with reckless abandon, rendered all the more dizzying by Marcloid\xe2\x80\x99s mechanized warbling. This Auto-Tuned nightmare doubles as a facsimile for the record\xe2\x80\x99s nostalgic mission writ large: aural salves repurposed as toxins. Intermittently, the artist blesses us with an opportunity to nod our heads (\xe2\x80\x9cLibra Virgo Cusp Shit,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAt the Pig Well\xe2\x80\x9d), but for every direct connection Marcloid forges with her audience, there is plenty of ugliness and abrasion.\xc2\xa0In terms of spectacular self-sabotage, it\xe2\x80\x99s on a level with\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0MTV reality starlet Farrah Abraham\xe2\x80\x99s 2012 album My Teenage Dream Ended, a similarly frankensteined pop record; the only difference is that Marcloid\xe2\x80\x99s self-immolation is intentional, and far more engrossing.' b'No matter how massive her sound, Marcloid is ultimately a deconstructionist\xe2\x80\x94if not musically, than philosophically. As with the discographies of Oneohtrix Point Never, James Ferraro, Vektroid, and other \xe2\x80\x9cpost-internet\xe2\x80\x9d luminaries, Fire-Toolz poses a timely, bleak query: How can we humans possibly hope to accomplish our starry-eyed goals of taming the machines, of finding nostalgic refuge in a void so glutted with information? *Drip Mental *serves as a scathing, passionate reminder that we can\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x94but we may as well try, or at the very least, wreak as much havoc as possible. Musical formalism, Western pop psychology, the gender binary: Marcloid\xe2\x80\x99s already laid waste to plenty of long-standing systems so far, and it\xe2\x80\x99s hard not to cheer her on from the sidelines as\xc2\xa0she marches down the warpath.'

column7: b'This new archival set documents\xc2\xa0an all-star tribute to Ornette Coleman held\xc2\xa0in 2014\xe2\x80\x94at which the saxophonist gave his last public performance\xe2\x80\x94as well as recordings\xc2\xa0from his\xc2\xa02015 funeral.'
column8: b'Ornette Coleman was not scheduled to perform at the all-star concert held in his honor, back in the summer of 2014. That celebration, at Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s Prospect Park, was chiefly organized as a way for fans and associates to pay tribute to the saxophonist\xe2\x80\x99s legacy as an American composer and innovator. The lineup\xe2\x80\x94including talents like Henry Threadgill and Ravi Coltrane\xe2\x80\x94suggested Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s towering influence over multiple generations of jazz players. And the bill also promised elite musicians from other stylistic zones, such as Laurie Anderson and Patti Smith.' b'There aren\xe2\x80\x99t too many artists capable of drawing Flea and Branford Marsalis into the same orbit. Though it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to understand how Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s boisterous catalog does this. Once you strip away all the baggage associated with \xe2\x80\x9cfree jazz\xe2\x80\x9d (never Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s preferred term), you\xe2\x80\x99re left with the joyful idiosyncrasy of that sound. Many of his melodies and solos channel traditional song styles, while his arrangements and harmonies are frequently unexpected\xe2\x80\x94and inspired. Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s interest in collaboration, whether with Jerry Garcia or the Master Musicians of Jajouka, also sets a high standard for risk-taking that can appeal to artistic seekers working in any genre.' b'On the night of the 2014 Prospect Park gig, Coleman took his final risk on a public stage. He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t performed for a crowd in several years; his last official recording was 2006\xe2\x80\x99s Pulitzer prize-winning Sound Grammar. In the interim, journalists and fans passed on rumors regarding the genius\xe2\x80\x99 failing health. So when the 84-year-old Coleman emerged from the wings of the Prospect Park bandshell, mid-concert, with his white alto saxophone in hand, it was a modest surprise even to his son and longtime drummer, Denardo.' b'After walking out carefully and taking a seat near the other saxophonists, Ornette simply listened for a bit. Soon after, he delivered 20\xc2\xa0minutes of playing: a stretch that drew on two of his early compositions (\xe2\x80\x9cRamblin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cTurnaround\xe2\x80\x9d). Within a year, he would be dead.' b'Heard now, on an archival release from Denardo Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s new Song X imprint, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s technique in 2014 was more fragile than at any other point in his immortal career. His phrases flow more slowly. Sometimes Coleman reaches for a note with audible difficulty. While his reduced physical capabilities are obvious, the spiritual intensity communicated by his playing is equally apparent\xe2\x80\x94and all the more remarkable for the context. Every elderly body confronts decline. But some veteran spirits can discover new strategies for persisting, recognizable to the last.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s a frailty in Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s tone, early on, during \xe2\x80\x9cRamblin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d Despite the occasional tremor of timbre, there\xe2\x80\x99s no desire to hide from his limitations. And Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s way of following up a long-held, bluesy tone with a sprightly flourish of notes remains forceful, unmistakable. When Denardo\xe2\x80\x99s funk-influenced backing group comes in, a saxophone section also joins. (Their ranks include Threadgill and David Murray.) The extra players help thicken out the sound and lift Ornette up\xe2\x80\x94with the icon eventually contributing some ecstatic, piercing notes that cut through the group texture. After finishing up with his playing for the night, the saxophonist hung around on stage for a portion of the rest of the gig. What he took in was a jammy, consistently potent tribute to his catalog, and his spirit of creativity.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s thrilling to hear Threadgill\xe2\x80\x99s alto sound\xe2\x80\x94one conscious of Ornette\xe2\x80\x99s style, but not overly indebted to it\xe2\x80\x94during a performance of \xe2\x80\x9cBlues Connotation.\xe2\x80\x9d (And Flea holds his own, on bass!) A powerhouse ensemble that includes Branford Marsalis, the Master Musicians of Jajouka, and Bruce Hornsby gathers for a fiery take of \xe2\x80\x9cSong X.\xe2\x80\x9d On\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cPeace,\xe2\x80\x9d Ravi Coltrane\xe2\x80\x99s soprano sax leaps create an excitable feel alongside the spiky blues playing of guitarist James Blood Ulmer. And Geri Allen, the pianist with perhaps the best track record of collaborating with Coleman and his mysterious \xe2\x80\x9charmolodic\xe2\x80\x9d theory, turns in imaginative supporting lines throughout a performance of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sphinx.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The less-canonical tributes also work. Guitarist Nels Cline handles the melody of \xe2\x80\x9cSadness\xe2\x80\x9d while Thurston Moore lays down a din of expressionistic noise in the background. Laurie Anderson\xe2\x80\x99s group\xe2\x80\x94which includes avant-saxophonist John Zorn\xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0bassist Bill Laswell\xe2\x80\x94creates a lyrical squall that feels fully appropriate (in part, because it often references Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s famous composition \xe2\x80\x9cLonely Woman\xe2\x80\x9d).
