Patti Smith plays a pair of tunes from her then-recent album Banga; the way she switches between vocals and stray blasts of clarinet comes across as a tribute to Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s own multi-instrumental practice.' b'By the time the concert closes\xe2\x80\x94with a cathartic, all-hands-on-deck rendition of \xe2\x80\x9cLonely Woman\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94it seems as though few aspects of the artist\xe2\x80\x99s vast playbook have been ignored. What\xe2\x80\x99s particularly touching is the knowledge that everyone thought to pull this gig together in time for Ornette to experience their love for his work.' b'Performances from Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s public funeral are also included in this new archival set. The mood of that 2015 concert is necessarily more somber than that of the the Prospect Park show, but the results are similarly intriguing, and no less star-studded. Pharoah Sanders\xe2\x80\x99 brief tenor sax solo carries an affecting tenderness. The last living member of free jazz\xe2\x80\x99s inaugural class drops by to pay his respects, as well: Cecil Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s eight-minute tribute encompasses poetry (to the confusion of some in the audience), stark-but-stately piano motifs, and one swirl of atonal density at its midpoint. It\xe2\x80\x99s a stunner.' b'As a multimedia package, Celebrate Ornette provides fans a wide range of perspectives on both shows. Its three CDs give a complete account of the Prospect Park blowout and the performances from the Riverside Church funeral. The Prospect Park discs stray from a chronological presentation, in order to create a more ideal flow for home listening. (And yes, Ornette\xe2\x80\x99s own appearances are queued up first.) A pair of DVDs also gives you visual representation of each event\xe2\x80\x94though some performances from Prospect Park are omitted, in favor of some backstage commentary from key participants. The DVD of the Riverside service also includes all eulogies and remembrances, which the audio disc breezes past. This lavish, pricey artifact isn\xe2\x80\x99t an ideal first port of entry to Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s art. But the way the set explores the cumulative impact of his work makes it a deeply rewarding experience for devoted admirers.'

column7: b'The only record by Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s James Stinson as the Other People Place is prescient in imagining our current connected-yet-disconnected state.'
column8: b'Last year, Ian Fenton (the man behind the Frozen Reeds label responsible for reissuing Julius Eastman\xe2\x80\x99s Femenine) pointed out a parallel between the artwork that adorned Detroit electronic duo Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s albums and the illustrations made by Emory Douglas, artist and Minister of Culture for the Black Panther Party. It came as a history rediscovered, re-connecting the black roots of techno back to its heritage of protest. Listen closer to the frenzied tracks that James Stinson and Gerald Donald crafted over their ten years as Drexciya and the anger is audible. For all of their electro and techno roots, Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s live wire tracks (some clocking in at two minutes) always felt closer to the furious outbursts of punk. Which made sense, as the group\xe2\x80\x99s origin story was a brutal one: Drexciya was the duo\xe2\x80\x99s name for an underwater country colonized by the unborn children of pregnant African women thrown off of slave ships during the Middle Passage. It read less like science-fiction/fantasy and more about the modern horror and cornerstone of our American reality.' b'But by the time James Stinson released what would be his lone solo album as The Other People Place, that anger had been somewhat tempered. By turns luminous and melancholic, low-key and sensuous, wry and soulful, Lifestyles of the Laptop Caf\xc3\xa9 hinted at new vistas for Stinson. He had talked about touring, a rarity for the reclusive duo. But Lifestyles couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have had a more star-crossed release, coming out on September 3, 2001 and vanishing soon after. Less than a year later, Stinson would be dead due to heart complications, *Lifestyles *the last record to be released during his lifetime.' b'For the duration of Drexciya, neither member revealed their names, so attempting to draw a biographical connection is haphazard at best. That said, there\xe2\x80\x99s a gentleness and humanity to Stinson\xe2\x80\x99s programming and production as The Other People Place that makes it sound like a reconciliation of fate, a looking back at the world around him not in anger but instead with a twinge of heartache and a smile. That sensibility seeps through Stinson\xe2\x80\x99s machines and makes it stand apart in Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s catalog. As such, it\xe2\x80\x99s the perfect gateway for those standing at the banks of their oceanic body of work looking for a way into its depths.' b'Stinson conveys rich sentiment with the slightest of gestures. With a few hums, the tap of a ride cymbal, and rippling pads, \xe2\x80\x9cEye Contact\xe2\x80\x9d casts a spell, both seductive and a little silly. \xe2\x80\x9cSomething\xe2\x80\x99s happening to my transmitters/Starting to overload/Sitting here in this caf\xc3\xa9/Drinking my latte,\xe2\x80\x9d he purrs two minutes in\xe2\x80\x94adding some Chicago acid vocals (think Adonis\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cNo Way Back\xe2\x80\x9d) reconfigured for the Starbucks set.' b'By 2001, the \xe2\x80\x9cSecond Wave of Coffee\xe2\x80\x9d was upon us and Starbucks seemed to be on every street corner, one of the few places to enabled users to have high-speed internet access. Stinson looks out onto a world increasingly disassociated, communicating by computers instead of voices. Rather than replicate caf\xc3\xa9 society and its public conversations, said caf\xc3\xa9s now feel eerily sterile and near silent, patron faces lit by the glow of phones and laptops. It makes for a sad state\xe2\x80\x94or as the last single from The Other People Place put it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSorrow & A Cup Of Joe.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Beneath the skittering 808s, unsettled chords and fidgety songs, a sense of melancholy and resignation flow. The twinkling keys Stinson sets atop \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Your Love\xe2\x80\x9d set off his digitally treated voice, so that he sounds like a heartbroken alien, wistfully sighing: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s your love that\xe2\x80\x99s keeping me so lost.\xe2\x80\x9d A female vocalist whispers across the snares and swelling synths of \xe2\x80\x9cYou Said You Want Me,\xe2\x80\x9d but as the track flickers its seductiveness gets balanced by sadness and failure to connect, that \xe2\x80\x9cwant\xe2\x80\x9d turning into the past tense. Even the anthemic electro of \xe2\x80\x9cLet Me Be Me\xe2\x80\x9d has a bittersweet tinge, its chords opening little wormholes of doubt.' b'The title itself cheekily suggests a room full of people, mute and withdrawn into themselves and their devices, so that even a song like \xe2\x80\x9cEye Contact\xe2\x80\x9d reads not as eyes interlocking on the dancefloor but rather two people who can only connect via their laptops. It\xe2\x80\x99s prescient in imagining our current connected-yet-disconnected state, our daily lives increasingly valuing FaceTime over face time, and the album itself anticipates a shift in how people even interact with electronic music, geared more towards home listening than the club. The album ends on a hopeful note though. \xe2\x80\x9cSunrays\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94with its bubbling melody, placid ticks and a female voice whispering \xe2\x80\x9crelax your mind/slowly unwind\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94sounds like Roy Ayers\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody Loves the Sunshine\xe2\x80\x9d for the new century. It\xe2\x80\x99s a warm sunbeam that can best be felt away from a laptop screen.'

column7: b'Jesca Hoop\xe2\x80\x99s fourth album Memories Are Now sounds like her most complete and refined statement yet, a boisterously declarative album that\xe2\x80\x99s urgent and at times seditious.'
column8: b'\xe2\x80\x9cAnimal Kingdom Chaotic,\xe2\x80\x9d the centerpiece of Jesca Hoop\xe2\x80\x99s fourth album, opens with a sound that may take a moment or two to identify. That clacking rhythm certainly sounds like an old-school typewriter rather than a computer keyboard, which may be her slyest joke in a song about life lived online. \xe2\x80\x9cI say it is possible,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, then answers herself: \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6but your computer says no!\xe2\x80\x9d That phrase becomes a testy mantra, its cadence growing trickier with each repetition. As Hoop\xe2\x80\x99s guitar provides a nimble, eye-rolling commentary, sounding more and more like an African mbira, the song resembles a folkie take on Laurie Anderson\xe2\x80\x99s giddily eccentric art-pop arrangements. Computer screens, the implication goes, have turned us into a population of proxies who simulate doing things more than we actually do things.' b'Hoop can\xe2\x80\x99t be accused of not doing things. In the last ten years, she has released four official studio albums, plus a handful of acoustic compilations, although readers may know her from Love Letter for Fire, her duets record with Sam Beam. But Memories Are Now sounds like her most complete and refined statement yet, a boisterously declarative album that\xe2\x80\x99s urgent and at times seditious. As such, it can be unruly and unfocused, full of ideas half- and wholly formed, the occasional jarring transition, and a few interminable passages (\xe2\x80\x9cSimon Says\xe2\x80\x9d is just over three minutes, but sounds like it will never end.)' b'However, from such disorder springs an animating sense of outrage: a readiness to take on the world from every angle of attack. That comes through most boldly on the title track, which opens with a slowly revving guitar and moves at an imperturbable crawl, subdued yet taut and disciplined. Hoop\xe2\x80\x99s vocals are much wilder: \xe2\x80\x9cMemories are now!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaims, defiantly. She might be arguing about the temporal displacement of online\xc2\xa0life (the internet\xc2\xa0is a recurring character in these songs), where the past and the present fuse together and the future never quite arrives. Or she\xe2\x80\x99s trying to get at something a bit more banal: Every moment is precious and has the potential to become a memory.' b'Hoop is making memories, whether you like it or not: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got work to be doing,\xe2\x80\x9d she declares. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you\xe2\x80\x99re not here to help, go find some other life to ruin.\xe2\x80\x9d If the melody weren\xe2\x80\x99t so intricately snaky, if the hook didn\xe2\x80\x99t depend on her odd phrasing, that chorus might be the kind of thing you\xe2\x80\x99d chant while marching on the White House\xe2\x80\x94especially when she gets to the line, \xe2\x80\x9cLet me show you the door.\xe2\x80\x9d Memories Are Now, perhaps more than anything she has done in the past, is closely engaged with the present moment, yet so lyrically and musically idiosyncratic that it never sounds overtly political. The best moments possess a sense of intrigue, a subterranean conspiracy, as though she\xe2\x80\x99s imparting dangerous knowledge to you.' b'Hoop\xe2\x80\x99s most visceral assault is \xe2\x80\x9cThe Coming,\xe2\x80\x9d which opens with a few measures of ambient guitar noodling, as though she\xe2\x80\x99s gathering her thoughts or summoning her courage. As the song sprawls and contorts, Jesus resigns as Messiah and laments a tenure defined by double standards and misunderstood instructions. If there was nothing but this performance review, the song would be merely clever, but it takes on tremendous gravity the more personal Hoop gets: \xe2\x80\x9cI refuse to think that my best friend\xe2\x80\x99s going to hell anymore and condescend to offer her a key to salvation like it\xe2\x80\x99s something that I have and can afford,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, but she\xe2\x80\x99s past singing by this point. Instead, she\xe2\x80\x99s testifying about a \xe2\x80\x9cspirit-rattling scare\xe2\x80\x9d: the realization that the moral code that has defined America for so long has curdled into something grotesque and virulent. Hoop has the temerity to fight against it, and if you\xe2\x80\x99re not here to help...well, you know.'

column3: b'Africa Airways Three: The Afro-Psych Excursion 1972-1984'
column7: b'After two volumes of heavy, straight-up motherland funk, DJ/label curator John Bryan culled Africa Airways 3 from only the sleekest and fastest-burning cuts from mid-\xe2\x80\x9970s West Africa.'
column8: b'After two volumes of heavy, straight-up motherland funk, DJ/label curator John Bryan culled Africa Airways 3 from thousands of warehouse records from West Africa, paring down to only the sleekest and fast-burning cuts. Coming from a time when West Africa was full of military rulers and one-party states fueled by oil money, the compilation provides sneaky testimony that the region flourished culturally all the same. Some collectors might grumble that there\xe2\x80\x99s a few overlaps with Stone Throw\xe2\x80\x99s excellent 2005 comp World Psychedelic Classics 3. AA3 has no big names except for Manu Dibango (\xe2\x80\x9cSoul Makossa\xe2\x80\x9d), with a number of groups only existing for a few singles or an album. The tunes are mostly instrumentals, sprinkled with occasional vocals (many times in English) scattered in the lo-fi mixes, leaning more towards guitar freak-outs and tropicalia itself. And even though many of AA3 songs are complex, multi-part journeys, most of them still confine themselves to the classic under-five-minutes single format.' b'What\xe2\x80\x99s extraordinary about these otherwise forgotten, barely existent singles isn\xe2\x80\x99t just their dynamic, insistent groove but also how each piece giddily slices across traditions and styles as much as it honors them. Since the lilting poly-rhythms of Nigerian juju were also coming up in the early \xe2\x80\x9970s, it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise to hear them in cuts like Afro National\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPush Am Forward\xe2\x80\x9d and Bunzu Soundz\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cZinabu.\xe2\x80\x9d You can hear Santana-like modal guitar flights in the Bunzu as well as in Ofo & the Black Company\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAllah Wakbarr,\xe2\x80\x9d which also adds chants and thunderous percussion over flailing guitar stabs. Just as with other classic dance records, we get boogie instructional guides here too, including Afro National\xe2\x80\x99s directive to \xe2\x80\x9cpush am forward, to the left, to the right\xe2\x80\x9d and theatrical Indonesian outliers Aka\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cShake \xe2\x80\x9d which offers up James Brown tributes surf music drum rolls, and a shout-out to Mickey Mouse over a halting groove.' b'Cultural clashes abound too, with Sory Bamba\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cKanaga 78\xe2\x80\x9d pitting Chic-like guitar riffing over an insistent art-rock synth, followed by African Black\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cNzango\xe2\x80\x9d with guitars/keys fighting for lead, resolved by ambient atmospherics. Even for psych music, there\xe2\x80\x99s some real oddities here\xe2\x80\x94 try Dibango\xe2\x80\x99s soundtrack-culled \xe2\x80\x9cCeddo\xe2\x80\x9d (from a flick ironically about corrupting foreign influences) with xylophone/synth interplay that could be a Frank Zappa piece or Damas Swing Orchestra\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cOdylife,\xe2\x80\x9d with solitary piano and taped crowd noises that sound like they crept out of an early Pere Ubu session.' b'With all these little-heard wonders creeping out of Bryan and friends\xe2\x80\x99 warehouse, we can only wonder what other hidden treasures are buried there, waiting to come out and illuminate us about other barely known slices of \xe2\x80\x9970s/\xe2\x80\x9980s African musical history.'

column7: b'Jim O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s 1997 album Bad Timing\xc2\xa0turns his obsessions with Americana into a\xc2\xa0tangle of deep reverence and exuberant skepticism.'
column8: b'In the early 1990s, years before he joined Sonic Youth or partnered with Wilco or tried his hand at singing, Jim O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke was a kind of prodigy in the experimental music underground. He recorded albums in his early twenties for labels like Sound of Pig, Amsterdam\xe2\x80\x99s Staalplaat, and John Zorn\xe2\x80\x99s Tzadik. He made music with whatever was at hand and was proficient on many instruments, and he often performed in the context of free improvisation. But O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s first instrument was guitar, and one of his deepest musical loves was the art of arrangement\xe2\x80\x94the precise placement of this note in this pocket of space, the choice of this instrument for that note. The two obsessions met in glorious fashion on his 1997 album Bad Timing.' b'In the 21st century, we take music built around steel-string guitar for granted. New practitioners have emerged (William Tyler, James Blackshaw, Ben Chasny), a latter-day legend has come and gone (Jack Rose, R.I.P.), and an endless series of reissues of albums by major figures stream by (hello, Bert Jansch). But 20 years ago, the notion of solo acoustic guitar as a medium for expression of album-length ideas was only just emerging from hibernation. Some of its resurgence during that period could be traced to the work of critic Byron Coley, who had written an article in SPIN in 1994, in which he\xe2\x80\x99d tracked down the then-obscure John Fahey in Oregon. Fahey had barely recorded in the few years\xc2\xa0previous, and was living off the grid and on the edge of poverty, occasionally sleeping in homeless shelters. That SPIN piece, along with the Rhino compilation Return of the Repressed, which put his out-of-print music back in stores, cemented the guitarist\xe2\x80\x99s status as an icon of American music. Neither he, nor his instrument, have left the conversation since.' b'In North America, the acoustic guitar is often associated\xc2\xa0with \xe2\x80\x9cfolk\xe2\x80\x9d music of a certain mood; from 1970s singer-songwriters to the \xe2\x80\x9980s emergence of new age and then onto the rise of \xe2\x80\x9cunplugged\xe2\x80\x9d music in the \xe2\x80\x9990s, the acoustic became associated with relaxation, intimacy, quiet contemplation\xe2\x80\x94a sound ostensibly more closely connected to the natural world than its electric counterpart. But Fahey\xe2\x80\x99s vision for acoustic guitar was something else entirely. He was among the first to fully grasp that the instrument had uniquely expressive qualities, that its possibilities as a device for melody, harmony, and rhythm were untapped, and alternate tunings gave it further flexibility other instruments couldn\xe2\x80\x99t match. In Fahey\xe2\x80\x99s hands, the guitar became an orchestra in miniature, and long, multi-part pieces with the thunderous sweep of a symphony could sit alongside rustic evocations of the past. Fahey\xe2\x80\x99s guitar became a tool for collapsing time and space, able to incorporate the grand sweep of music history in a flurry of strummed chords, fingerpicked melodies, and raga-like repeating rhythms.' b'Fahey\xe2\x80\x99s mid-\xe2\x80\x9990s resurgence served as a backdrop for Bad Timing, and the connection colored how it was received at the time. The Fahey connect was further underscored by O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s earlier work in Gastr del Sol, his post-rock duo with David Grubbs (they covered Fahey on their 1996 album Upgrade & Afterlife.) But while *Bad Timing *has deep spiritual connections to Fahey\xe2\x80\x99s work, the actual music comes from a very different place. You could almost think of Bad Timing as as a record that\xe2\x80\x99s *trying *to be a Fahey album but keeps getting derailed and ends up going somewhere even more interesting. It was originally written to be a solo guitar record, and O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke has performed versions of the pieces in that setting, but as he worked on the music, he decided he wanted to take it into another direction, one that would incorporate his obsession with carefully arranged sound.' b"Expanding *Bad Timing *allowed O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke to paint on a much larger canvas. \xe2\x80\x9cFor me both Happy Days and Bad Timing were about my myths,\xe2\x80\x9d O'Rourke explained to writer Mike McGonigal in a 1997 interview in the zine Music. \xe2\x80\x9cA big part of my head is Americana. But the Americana I know comes from listening to Van Dyke Parks, John Fahey, and Charles Ives. That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exist, and I have to face the fact that it doesn't exist. I have to address that it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing but a construct.\xe2\x80\x9d O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke has always wrestled with the \xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d part of record-making. He\xe2\x80\x99s an avid and thoughtful listener and has absorbed a mountain of music, so with each project, he considers exactly why he should be adding to the pile. Bad Timing may be\xc2\xa0an homage to some of his heroes, but he takes their collective influence and bends it into a peculiar shape, a tangle of deep reverence and exuberant skepticism. It\xe2\x80\x99s a fantasy that is aware of itself as fantasy, a self-conscious evocation of an individual artist\xe2\x80\x99s obsessions that also functions as a neat historical snapshot." b'Parks\xe2\x80\x99 lush arrangements and his gentle irony; Fahey\xe2\x80\x99s vast scope; Ives\xe2\x80\x99 clash of folk simplicity and avant-garde dissonance\xe2\x80\x94these elements\xc2\xa0are all over Bad Timing, and minimalism is the final piece of the puzzle. Though it draws heavily from the music of other cultures, particularly India, minimalism as a compositional technique is closely identified with American icons, in particular the work of Philip Glass, Steve Reich, Terry Riley, and LaMonte Young. Glass, Reich, and Riley are best known for repetition\xe2\x80\x94they build meaning through gradually shifting clusters of sound. Young\xe2\x80\x99s music has alternated between repetition and carefully tuned and deeply physical drone. Two other composers, Phill Niblock and Tony Conrad, both of whom O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke work with, further extended Young\xe2\x80\x99s drone conceptions. For this group, held tones become a form of change; from moment to moment in a drone piece, you expect shifts and development to happen, and when they don\xe2\x80\x99t, you\xe2\x80\x99re constantly re-discovering where you are in the now.' b'*Bad Timing *has this mercurial quality. It flows beautifully and is easy for a newcomer to enjoy, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also a series of head-fakes, regular juxtapositions that jar the music off course as it moves from one mode to the next. The opening \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s Hell in Hello But More in Goodbye\xe2\x80\x9d starts off almost as a carbon-copy of Fahey in his most whimsical mode, with a sunny finger-picked melody that one could imagine a turn-of-the-century farmer whistling as he strolled across a field. But after a few bars, it drops into a single repeating pattern played on just a small handful of notes, like a needle slipping into a skipping groove, and it stays there, as a lone chord is examined, poked at, and wrung dry. Other subtle instruments fold in\xe2\x80\x94organ, piano\xe2\x80\x94and as \xe2\x80\x9cHello\xe2\x80\x9d unfurls it becomes a pure drone piece, quieter and prettier but not so far from the Niblock-inspired hurdy-gurdy blast that defined O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s previous album, Happy Days. What started as \xe2\x80\x9cfolk\xe2\x80\x9d ends as a kind of raga meditation.' b'This kind of shell game happens throughout Bad Timing, as the individual pieces convince you they\xe2\x80\x99re one thing while they\xe2\x80\x99re in the process of becoming something else. \xe2\x80\x9c94 the Long Way\xe2\x80\x9d opens with a tentative, lurching fingerpicked section, hinting at possible songs behind it, but not quite committing, until finally a pattern emerges that mixes a lurching bass-string loop, repetition in the middle register, and a simple descending three-note melody that becomes the center around which the rest of the track orbits. It at first sounds too simple, like it\xe2\x80\x99s barely even a melody, but O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke adds cheery keyboards, gorgeous pedal steel guitar, and trombone, and it starts to feel like a John Philip Sousa march\xe2\x80\x94you think of fireworks and parades and kazoos and guys in funny hats and rolling expanses of land stretching to the horizon.' b'The construction of the piece is impressive as new instruments are added every few bars and they all lock into place. But there\xe2\x80\x99s also something joyously silly about it all, a cartoon of civic engagement. The bumptious cheeriness evokes children performing an exaggerated \xe2\x80\x9cwhistle while you work\xe2\x80\x9d march, pounding forward in service of some high-minded collective ideal. The hint of camp extends further. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always taken the \xe2\x80\x9c94\xe2\x80\x9d in the title to be a reference to I-94, the interstate highway that runs through Chicago. If you\xe2\x80\x99re in the Midwest and you want to take a road trip, you\xe2\x80\x99re almost certainly going to find yourself in I-94 at some point. O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s song can be heard as an ode\xc2\xa0to the freeway, his acoustic Americana version of Kraftwerk\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAutobahn\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94indeed, the structure of the two songs is similar, and the snaking pedal steel is evocative of the gliding guitar in the Kraftwerk tune. It\xe2\x80\x99s a soundtrack for looking out the window as you roll through the farmland of Wisconsin and Minnesota.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cAmericana\xe2\x80\x9d is an inexhaustible descriptor entirely dependent on perspective. American music, after all, is by its nature fractured, a bottomless\xc2\xa0well of influences that zig-zag around the country and then around the world. Hyper-local folk forms are \xe2\x80\x9cdiscovered\xe2\x80\x9d and stolen from and then sold back in a gnarled form by professionals from far away. Aaron Copland, composer of \xe2\x80\x9cFanfare for the Common Man,\xe2\x80\x9d was a gay, cosmopolitan Jew with communist sympathies, and he created work steeped in American myths, dreaming up places where he might not be entirely comfortable (or welcome) if he were to actually visit them. O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s musical fantasy is steeped in the past but also feels ripe with the possibility of the present moment; it\xe2\x80\x99s *of *history but it sits outside of it.' b'The second side of *Bad Timing *is essentially a single 20-minute piece split into two sections that grows steadily stranger while playing with ideas of nostalgia and memory. O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke presents ancient notions of \xe2\x80\x9cAmerican music\xe2\x80\x9d and then toys with them. The title track opens with another playful folk guitar figure before losing itself in haze of keyboard melody. For minutes on end, the song seesaws between two slowly plucked chords as hints of accordion nudge the tune along. You keep listening for changes, and you think you *might *hear something shifting, but you\xe2\x80\x99re also happy to get lost in the repetition, the simple twinkling beauty and building tension of the arrangement.' b'And then it explodes: a huge distorted power chord launches us into \xe2\x80\x9cHappy Trails,\xe2\x80\x9d the final piece. Suddenly we\xe2\x80\x99re in the middle of a psychedelic rock record, and it\xe2\x80\x99s like a light switch thrown on, or explosive laughter that sucks the discomfort out of a room. After the lengthy fallout from that blast, there\xe2\x80\x99s another extended fingerpicked acoustic passage, and then the song is overwhelmed with a crashing marching band fanfare (a possible nod to Charles Ives\xe2\x80\x99 Symphony No. 4, where a brooding string passage is interrupted by blasts of horns that sound borrowed from another piece). Adding further contrast, pedal steel guitarist Ken Champion, whose impossibly beautiful swells of sound add so much poignancy to \xe2\x80\x9c94 the Long Way,\xe2\x80\x9d returns with a downright loopy solo fit for the Country Bear Jamboree. Then the song sunsets in a golden-purple haze of muted horns, returning to uncanny beauty one final time.' b'This seesaw between mischievous subversion and slack-jawed beauty is the key to O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s best music. His sense of humor is both generous and slightly dark; there\xe2\x80\x99s irony in his touch, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not a negating one. It\xe2\x80\x99s more about being open to hearing every possibility in a given piece of music. In a\xc2\xa02001 interview O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke was asked if *Bad Timing *had an element of parody. \xe2\x80\x9cNot a parody at all, or infatuation, it\xe2\x80\x99s more like trying to reconcile what is imagined, learned, real, and imaginary.\xe2\x80\x9d And then he added, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it really that impossible to believe that something can be funny and sincere at the same time?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Bad Timing, and O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke\xe2\x80\x99s solo career that followed, is a convincing argument for creation in the face of self-consciousness. The \xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d of music-making is under-explored. Does your individual record need to exist? For O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke, and especially for his solo albums on Drag City, he justifies their release by lavishing care on every detail, and embracing the music of the past in all its complexity. O\xe2\x80\x99Rourke has always been very careful about how his music is packaged and presented. He only allowed it to be released digitally in the last couple of years, and the downloads on Drag City\xe2\x80\x99s newly created Bandcamp pages urge the listener to \xe2\x80\x9cplease download the best possible quality.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s fighting against his music being reduced, whether that means shrinking the artwork, compressing the digital files, or removing individual tracks from the context of the whole. He\xe2\x80\x99s asking for a lot from the listener, but\xc2\xa0giving even more in return. *Bad Timing *was where so many of these ideas came together for the first time, a glorious imaginary world that becomes real every time it plays.'

column7: b'In the late \xe2\x80\x9990s, two\xc2\xa0art students in Detroit formed the heavily Kraftwerk-inspired electro/techno group Le Car. This new compilation from Clone Records surveys their curio of a catalog.'
column8: b'Adam Lee Miller and Ian Clarke met as art students in Detroit in the late 1990s, and from \xe2\x80\x9996 to \xe2\x80\x9998, they released four projects as the electro/techno group Le Car. The titles of those\xc2\xa0releases betrayed their vehicular interest: Auto-Fuel,\xc2\xa0Auto-Graph,\xc2\xa0Automatic, and\xc2\xa0Auto-Motif. Le Car\xe2\x80\x99s entrance into the city\xe2\x80\x99s nightlife came a full decade after the Belleville Three (Juan Atkins, Kevin Saunderson, Derrick May) invented Detroit techno, which May once colorfully described as\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9clike George Clinton and Kraftwerk caught in an elevator with only a sequencer to keep them company.\xe2\x80\x9d In that sense, Clarke and Miller (later of the electronic duo ADULT.) draw influence from this local\xc2\xa0lineage.\xc2\xa0Le Car, if it is not obvious in their choice of names, are heavily inspired by the sleek, robot automation and cybernetic tendencies of Kraftwerk.' b'In practice, Le Car\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0work demonstrates an almost endearingly uncool attempt to reinterpret \xe2\x80\x9cThe Robots,\xe2\x80\x9d if they were reborn in the bodies of Detroit area art students. And if that either sounds bad or good to you, both the worst and best outcomes are available in Clone Records\xe2\x80\x99 new compilation and survey of their discography, Auto-Reverse.' b'The opening track, \xe2\x80\x9cCar Scene One,\xe2\x80\x9d begins with a question. A helium-inflected voice pulls up to a stranger and asks if they\xe2\x80\x99d like a ride. The stranger, with a deeper, metallic, but equally inhuman baritone, cheerfully agrees. Then they turn on the radio, and a brief gurgle of electric noise plays. It\xe2\x80\x99s percussive, vaguely groovy, but rigid: the kind of music the robot overlords in *The Matrix might play at parties. The car stalls, the radio stops\xe2\x80\x94barely a minute and half in, *it is immediately clear things are not what they seem to be. This gesture of artistic malfunction makes their connection to Kraftwerk even more apparent. It recalls the German group\xe2\x80\x99s own 1970s electronic epiphany: During one show,\xc2\xa0Ralf H\xc3\xbctter put so much weight down on his keyboard that the wild crowd just kept on dancing \xe2\x80\x9cto the machine.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The compilers of this\xc2\xa0collection cleverly recognize that so much of Le Car\xe2\x80\x99s music feels like the\xc2\xa0afterglow of such a moment.\xc2\xa0The cheeky loops of\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cAluminum Rectangles\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cWarm Humans\xe2\x80\x9d conjure up seconds of late-night sound\xc2\xa0that unintentionally hang in the air,\xc2\xa0playing out when\xc2\xa0no one is behind the board. That\xe2\x80\x99s not to say that Le Car\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0songs are shapeless, but they are in so many ways formulaic.\xc2\xa0There is something about the music of Le Car that is distinctly campy, simple, and repetitive in the way arcade games are.\xc2\xa0Even though their synthesizer loops sometimes lose steam, and some of the tracks feel more like fragmentary studies than club-oriented experiences, their music represents an earnest attempt to make real life feel virtual. But as the endless march of technology can attest, their experiments feel hilariously anachronistic in the light of the present day.' b'While there are a number of standouts in the 20 tracks\xe2\x80\x94including the triumphant early chiptune of \xe2\x80\x9cMalice,\xe2\x80\x9d and the acidic beat of \xe2\x80\x9cAudiofile 10\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the compilation presents Le Car in an incidentally\xc2\xa0satirical light, like a caricature of techno.\xc2\xa0But the exuberance of Miller and Clarke is undeniable. There is a relentlessly cheery aspect to their music that makes it hard to hate. Even if *Auto-Reverse *might just be a curio, it documents a brief pocket of time that feels feels quaint, fun, and fresh today, like that pair JNCO jeans hidden deep in your closet.'

column7: b"Detroit indie rocker Stef Chura's lowlit, burnished debut Messes showcases her way with setting a twilit mood and her magnetic, mutable voice."
column8: b'Detroit indie rocker Stef Chura has the kind of magnetic voice that music writers fall into ditches attempting to describe. Froggy, trembling, and full of unexpected catches, it sits in the forefront of her debut album Messes, and she often uses her finger-picked guitars behind it to trace and echo her vocal melody, framing for maximum scrutiny. She seems confident with her instrument\xc2\xa0and to grasp how it works, the same way a good character actor knows how to use their pointy chin, their waggling nose, or their thick eyebrows. Breath to breath, note to note, she\xc2\xa0 evokes different singers: On \xe2\x80\x9cFaded Heart\xe2\x80\x9d she sounds like Stevie Nicks impersonating Dan Bejar. On \xe2\x80\x9cSlow Motion,\xe2\x80\x9d she recalls Television\xe2\x80\x99s Tom Verlaine, while on \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x9d she channels the velvety longeurs of\xc2\xa0Chrissie Hynde.' b'Nevertheless, she retains complete control of this unruly, coltish instrument, even as it tramples over small stuff like enunciation and diction. On paper, her lyrics are poetic and sharply rendered (\xe2\x80\x9cThin like the skin on a lottery ticket\xe2\x80\x9d) but the journey from the page through her larynx is a rough one, and a line as simple as \xe2\x80\x9cYou can do that\xe2\x80\x9d (the hollered chorus from \xe2\x80\x9cSpotted Gold\xe2\x80\x9d) can turn into an eleven-syllable phonetic rollercoaster with no discernible entry or exit point. The lyrics suggest the\xc2\xa0album\xe2\x80\x99s title\xc2\xa0refers to the sorts of messes we make of each other (\xe2\x80\x9cPutting in overtime/To get my revenge on you/I can see in your eyes/There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing left to lose\xe2\x80\x9d) while her voice itself shows what can happen when a perfectly clear-seeming thought gets garbled by its expression. It\xe2\x80\x99s a metaphor for the gulf separating what we mean to say and what others hear, maybe.' b'Or maybe just an odd voice. In any case, Messes is alluring largely\xc2\xa0because of it, and the band surrounding her reinforces that allure. They play a simple style\xe2\x80\x94roughshod, lowlit indie rock, with guitars and voice all flickering around the same burnished midrange\xe2\x80\x94with quiet style and intuitive command. The music mostly stays at a mid-tempo simmer, only boiling over for a few moments of yelped catharsis, the guitars squealing as if kicked. The drumming has just the right hairs\xe2\x80\x99-breadth hesitation holding back the downbeat, keeping the music loose and full of air. The album falls just right, like a stretched-out sweater with holes in the collar.' b"Messes, true to its title, feels inchoate,\xc2\xa0a few sloppy first strokes down on a big white page that catches the eye. It would be nice if she wrote some sharper songs; while her delicate and echoey fingerpicking tangles sound nice, she maybe gets a little too lost in them. A couple drowsier songs stretch out so languorously they start to lose shape\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHuman Being,\xe2\x80\x9d a pleasant tangle of fingerpicking and Chura\xe2\x80\x99s moan, is more mood than song. But it's a rich mood, sumptuous enough that the blurry contours don't matter much. It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to indulge a reverie when it\xe2\x80\x99s a vivid one, and Messes\xc2\xa0invites you to lose track of time for awhile with it."

column7: b'The Danish rock band Communions offer a familiar sound\xe2\x80\x94vaguely Strokes-y, \xe2\x80\x9980s-inspired pop rock\xe2\x80\x94but they do it well.'
column8: b"There\xe2\x80\x99s something to be said for familiarity. Sometimes you just want a burger to taste exactly like the one you had last time, and\xc2\xa0Blue, the full-length debut by the Danish quartet Communions, announces its ingredients right away with opener \xe2\x80\x9cCome On, I\xe2\x80\x99m Waiting.\xe2\x80\x9d Had the band added a signature Greg Hawkes-style keyboard line, it would have been even easier to imagine \xe2\x80\x9cCome On, I\xe2\x80\x99m Waiting\xe2\x80\x9d as being by the Cars. Within a few measures, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that Communions aren\xe2\x80\x99t trying to hide the well of styles they're drawing from." b"If you\xe2\x80\x99re already familiar with the band's previous EPs, you know that Communions alternate between shoegaze and the meat-and-potatoes pop-rock that the Strokes sold to the world as punk/post-punk revivalism. On Blue, the smokestack plumes of guitar have mostly been cleared away in favor of a stripped-down production style that cuts closer to the bone. Second track \xe2\x80\x9cToday,\xe2\x80\x9d in fact, starts with a serrated, airtight guitar riff reminiscent of the Strokes\xe2\x80\x99 2001 debut Is This It. The similarity is so apparent that Communions may as well have tattooed the album cover onto their foreheads." b'By this point, one has to wonder if there\xe2\x80\x99s anything left to say, musically speaking, when bands choose to go down this well-traveled road. And when you consider that acts like the Strokes and Interpol lifted so blatantly from Television in the first place, Communions risk the quality erosion that you get when you make a copy of a copy. Nevertheless, *Blue\xe2\x80\x99*s skill rescues it. After the Strokes-style riff introduces \xe2\x80\x9cToday,\xe2\x80\x9d the song switches to a looser \xe2\x80\x9980s-pop atmosphere\xc2\xa0reminiscent of the Smiths\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cAsk.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'That looseness is crucial; even the album\xe2\x80\x99s basic production retains an openness that\xe2\x80\x99s inviting rather than confining.\xc2\xa0Other bands who mold themselves after these styles typically do so with a fervor that can be stifling, but\xc2\xa0Blue\xc2\xa0conveys the sense that the band simply enjoys this music.\xc2\xa0At times, Communions sound inspired, like they pushed themselves to write songs that at least show some character. At other times, the band can sound somewhat lazy, as if it didn\xe2\x80\x99t push quite hard enough. Which side of that line the songs on this album fall depends on where you draw the line yourself. Either way, the music on Blue is always lovingly crafted, and the album\xe2\x80\x99s lack of musical pretense makes for an enjoyable, if predictable listen. If Blue were a restaurant, it would be the kind of place you go to for consistency and tasteful decor when you\xe2\x80\x99re not in the mood for something fancier or more adventurous.'

column7: b"On It\xe2\x80\x99s Good To Be Differ-Ent, Detroit's Differ-Ent (aka DJ Bone) doubles down on his hometown\xe2\x80\x99s techno legacy,\xc2\xa0delivering a triple LP that acts as a sort of manifesto."
column8: b'Eric Dulan, aka DJ Bone aka Differ-Ent, has spent the past two decades as a loyal soldier in the trenches of Detroit techno. Though often overlooked (his bio defensively asserts \xe2\x80\x9cThink of Detroit Techno and DJ Bone might not be high on your list of luminaries because he is 100% independent and does things on his terms and on his terms only\xe2\x80\x9d), he has developed a small-but-rabid following for his flashy, technical and decidedly old-school approach to DJing. His productions\xe2\x80\x94often self-released on his Subject Detroit label\xe2\x80\x94adhere faithfully to the fundamental principles set forth by Underground Resistance and Jeff Mills, with tough, driving drum programming laying a solid foundation for either wide-eyed celestial synth work or teeth-gritting severity, designed to drive dancers into a frenzy. If this suggests a kind of bunker mentality, it\xe2\x80\x99s not without good reason: For many, Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s original strain of techno remains the most potent, with transatlantic exports rarely making good on the Motor City\xe2\x80\x99s exhilarating mix of meditative depth and rushing energy.' b'On It\xe2\x80\x99s Good To Be Differ-Ent, his debut album as Differ-Ent, Dulan doubles down on his hometown\xe2\x80\x99s legacy, delivering a triple LP that acts as a sort of manifesto, career encapsulation and litmus test for fans. As with many dance music albums, the format itself runs counter to the nature of the music. Simply put, listening to a long stretch of DJ tools can be a tiring affair, with extended intros and outros begging to be blended with something else. It\xe2\x80\x99s an issue that every producer who ventures outside the comfort zone of 12\xe2\x80\x9d EPs has to contend with, and Dulan does so in his signature style, by putting his head down and powering through.' b'The slightly-overwhelming eighty minutes of It\xe2\x80\x99s Good\xe2\x80\xa6 are meant strictly for DJs and heads, with plenty of bangers and little else. To be fair, this record was likely never meant to be listened to front-to-back. Each side has two songs on it, allowing you to digest each of the three 12\xe2\x80\x9ds as a standalone EP. Approached this way, the album clicks, with each third offering a slightly different side of the producer\xe2\x80\x99s work.' b'Opener \xe2\x80\x9cInhabit Tense\xe2\x80\x9d dives right in with some thick pads and pummeling, machine funk toms. This first run of songs blasts out of the gate, with Dulan\xe2\x80\x99s extrovert side in full effect. Exciting as it is, he can lapse into a predictable deference to his elders, particularly Mike Banks. The fidgety lead and blasting strings on \xe2\x80\x9cMarvel Less\xe2\x80\x9d scratch the Detroit itch well enough, but by same token feel a bit rote. No doubt in the right hands they will come alive on a dance floor, but elsewhere on the album Dulan delivers the goods with more personal aplomb.' b'The middle of the album offers some of the strangest and strongest work attributed to the Differ-Ent alias so far. \xe2\x80\x9cWe Have U Surrounded\xe2\x80\x9d pares back the sound palette, using a single liquid note and tight percussion to cast a graceful spell. \xe2\x80\x9cMotive Hate Shun\xe2\x80\x9d chokes out all the air in the room with miasmic subbass and menacing flanger\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s one of the album\xe2\x80\x99s highlights. Perhaps meant as a counterpoint, \xe2\x80\x9cFasten 8 Shun\xe2\x80\x9d returns to Dulan\xe2\x80\x99s beloved string sounds, but here his melodies ambitiously reach beyond the clouds rather than cruise coldly into the abyss. Finally, E-side opener shows \xe2\x80\x9cGem In Eyes\xe2\x80\x9d shows Dulan\xe2\x80\x99s emotional side, reminiscent of Hieroglyphic Being\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSo Much Noise 2 Be Heard\xe2\x80\x9d if it was recorded in a real studio.' b'The album\xe2\x80\x99s closing stretch feels a little throwaway, with the obligatory chill-out of \xe2\x80\x9cA Calm Bliss.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s cool enough, but once it\xe2\x80\x99s over it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t particularly resonate, and \xe2\x80\x9cLazer Eyes\xe2\x80\x9d swerves right back to the dense paranoia rather than maintain the mood. \xe2\x80\x9cI M Different\xe2\x80\x9d closes the album in a more electro style. He may not actually be that different from his Detroit forebears, but It\xe2\x80\x99s Good To Be Differ-Ernt does stand apart from much modern techno. Orthodox but accomplished, it\xe2\x80\x99s an album that exists outside time, sidestepping fashionable tropes staying true to it\xe2\x80\x99s roots. However, it may be more rewarding for the casual fan to catch Bone in one of his virtuosic DJ sets than here.'

column7: b'After the death of guitarist Thomas Fekete last year, Surfer Blood return with an album shadowed\xc2\xa0by grief. Paradoxically, it\xe2\x80\x99s their sunniest and loosest record in years.'
column8: b'Surfer Blood\xe2\x80\x99s fourth album Snowdonia arrives with something the band hasn\xe2\x80\x99t experienced in a long time: good will. After frontman John Paul Pitts\xe2\x80\x99 2012 arrest for domestic battery instantly transformed the band from potential indie-rock mainstays into permanently damaged goods, he at times seemed to carry on the group out of sheer spite. Their 2013 album Pythons opened with him eating literal sour grapes and only got nastier from there; listeners understandably steered clear of it. Even the fans who jumped off the band\xe2\x80\x99s surf board long ago, however, had to feel for the group last year when they lost guitarist Thomas Fekete to stomach cancer. He was only 27 years old. \xc2\xa0Snowdonia may be the closest Surfer Blood gets to a second chance, and it poses a test for Pitts: Can he really be the kind of frontman that listeners empathize with, and maybe even care for, again?' b'He certainly puts his best face forward. There\xe2\x80\x99s no trace of opportunism on Snowdonia\xe2\x80\x94no bitterness, no self-pity, no overstatement of grief. Instead, Pitts uses the terrible circumstances as a chance for reinvention. With a shuffled lineup that includes new guitarist Michael McCleary and bassist Lindsey Mills, whose harmony vocals lend welcome warmth to the record, he recasts Surfer Blood as the kinder, gentler guitar-pop band they might have been better off trying to be a couple album cycles ago. It\xe2\x80\x99s their calmest record, a relaxed, sunny outing pitched at the same volume as The Feelies\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0casual late \xe2\x80\x9980s LPs.' b'This is not the same Pitts who blasted through walls, sledgehammers swinging, on \xe2\x80\x9cSwim,\xe2\x80\x9d nor is he the same bitter soul who played the victim so passive-aggressively on Pythons. He sounds about 90 anger management sessions removed from that guy, and the lyrics are peppered with promises that he\xe2\x80\x99s a changed man. \xe2\x80\x9cThought I had a corroded heart/Oxidizing, torn apart/Now you\xe2\x80\x99re starting it up yet again,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings, brimming with hope on the Inverted World-esque \xe2\x80\x9cDino Jay.\xe2\x80\x9d And rather than reaching for that bowl of sour grapes again, \xe2\x80\x9cMatter of Time\xe2\x80\x9d opens the album with an assurance that Pitts\xe2\x80\x99 aim is true this time: \xe2\x80\x9cIn a world so full of murky intentions, we\xe2\x80\x99ll make ourselves a home.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s really trying to make the best of things, he insists.' b'Given the circumstances, Snowdonia is a surprisingly light album. With its paisley guitars and Sunday drive tempos, many listeners would be hard pressed to even locate the grief on first listen. It\xe2\x80\x99s a nifty trick that the song that most directly touches on Fekete\xe2\x80\x99s death is also the album\xe2\x80\x99s most mirthful: \xe2\x80\x9cSix Flags in F or G\xe2\x80\x9d builds from a \xe2\x80\x9cRock Lobster\xe2\x80\x9d tempo to a confetti\xc2\xa0burst of Mamas and the Papas-style sunshine pop before signing off with some Wowee Zowee guitar scribbles. Instead of making a big display of their bereavement, they pay tribute to their friend with some sounds he always enjoyed. A similarly sweet pragmatism carries through closer \xe2\x80\x9cCarrier Pigeon,\xe2\x80\x9d a heartbreaker he wrote after his mother\xe2\x80\x99s breast cancer diagnosis. He responds not by cursing the cruel hand, but constructively, with an appreciation for the woman who always looked out for him and his sister: \xe2\x80\x9cI know you swam upstream for most of your life, dodging the grizzlies.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s never sounded closer to the songwriter we were promised on Astro Coast.' b"So does Snowdonia mark a redemption for a once toxic band? As with all issues surrounding the art/artist divide, it\xe2\x80\x99s not so clear cut. One tactful album can\xe2\x80\x99t buy a musician forgiveness any more than it can erase the pain of losing a loved one. And in truth, Snowdonia probably isn't a flashy enough album to re-spark significant interest in the band anyway. At their early peak, this group had a serious wow factor; now they're mostly setting out for modest pleasures. For the first time in five years, though, this band has a reason to exist, and possibly even a path forward. It\xe2\x80\x99s Surfer Blood\xe2\x80\x99s first album since their debut that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t invite you to think about what could have been. It simply makes the most of what is."

column7: b'The sound of trio Palberta evokes the\xc2\xa0post-punk era\xe2\x80\x99s great experimentalists, with\xc2\xa0overloaded glee and\xc2\xa0delirious energy. The 20-song\xc2\xa0*Bye Bye Berta *is their first attempt at doing so longform.'
column8: b'Palberta take joy in confusion. Formed in New York\xe2\x80\x99s Hudson Valley at Bard College, the trio of Lily Konigsberg, Anina Ivry-Block, and Nina Ryser has spent the last few years baffling audiences in the Northeast DIY scene with brief blasts of broken rounds, abstract nursery rhymes, and\xc2\xa0jittery haphazard rhythms that speed to cartoonish extremes or slow down to a crawl seemingly on a whim. Despite the anti-hero virtuosity that they each demonstrate on guitar, bass, and drums, Ivry-Block has said in interviews that she\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cnever really learned how to play songs on the guitar or really any of the instruments.\xe2\x80\x9d Consequently, their sound is largely in line with the post-punk era\xe2\x80\x99s great experimentalists\xe2\x80\x94This Heat\xe2\x80\x99s rattlesnake coils of toxic rhythmic interplay, Sun City Girls\xe2\x80\x99 prankish melodies\xe2\x80\x94but they approach these sounds with a sort of overloaded glee, crashing and careening through styles and sounds for little more than a couple minutes at a time. Then, they\xe2\x80\x99ll awkwardly trade instruments before barreling through another sub-two-minute track.' b'They\xe2\x80\x99ve released a couple of tapes and splits\xe2\x80\x94most notably 2013\xe2\x80\x99s *My Pal Berta *and 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Shitheads in the Ditch\xe2\x80\x94that attempted to bottle their delirious energy, but at 20-songs long, *Bye Bye Berta *is their first real attempt at doing so longform. The effect, even through just the first couple of bite-sized pieces, is jarring and deliberately so. Within five minutes, Konigsberg, Ivry-Block, and Ryser tunnel through dazed chorales (\xe2\x80\x9cWhy Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d), discordant speed blues (\xe2\x80\x9cAcoustic Rollup\xe2\x80\x9d), bracing\xc2\xa0noise rock (\xe2\x80\x9cJaws\xe2\x80\x9d), and narcotized concr\xc3\xa9te (\xe2\x80\x9cBells Pt. B\xe2\x80\x9d). The stylistic hopscotch is unsettling, but playful, something like attempting to hop onto a speeding carousel. Even as you start to feel sickly, you can\xe2\x80\x99t help but hang on tight.' b'Compared to some of the more outr\xc3\xa9 experiments they\xe2\x80\x99ve slipped onto singles and splits since Shitheads, the sounds that make up *Bye Bye Berta *feel especially well-considered. It\xe2\x80\x99s a strange thing to say about a record that has an intentionally misremembered\xe2\x80\x94and largely off-key\xe2\x80\x94rendition of the Bee Gees\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cStayin Alive,\xe2\x80\x9d but it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that Palberta are\xc2\xa0giving real thought to the diverse textures they can wring out of their instruments. \xe2\x80\x9cShe Feels That Way,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, is presented first as a sparse, unplugged ballad. It\xe2\x80\x99s then\xc2\xa0followed by\xc2\xa0a noisy, rumbling version of the same track\xe2\x80\x94the original\xe2\x80\x99s toy piano plinks are scoured by the brillo-tough, barely-in-tune guitar lines. These two versions of the same loose, spectral melody show it plainly,\xc2\xa0but\xc2\xa0Palberta never really repeat a specific sound between songs, even with their limited instrumental palette. It only adds to the euphoric disjunct of the record as a whole.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s happened elsewhere in Palberta\xe2\x80\x99s catalog, but on Bye Bye Berta\xe2\x80\x99s eighth track, \xe2\x80\x9cTrick Ya,\xe2\x80\x9d they finally break. As their atonal skronk and single line of lyrics\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t trick me! I\xe2\x80\x99m gonna trick ya\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94accelerates toward a brick wall, the trio can\xe2\x80\x99t keep up with the pace and then they one by one break down in laughter. The track descends into unplugged slow bass plucks, the wreckage of an effort toward ambitious playing. Amid all the intentionally awkward and off-putting melodies squeaked and squeezed from guitar, bass, and drums, that moment is the first outward indication that this isn\xe2\x80\x99t a stone-faced attempt at some lofty goal, like pushing the boundaries of guitar music or something. Instead, they pause and laugh, letting listeners who aren\xe2\x80\x99t already familiar with their occasionally goofy live shows know that their compositional efforts are as much a form of amusement for themselves as they are anything else. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard not to chuckle along with them.'

column7: b'Trevor de Brauw is the guitarist for the stalwart instrumental rock band Pelican. His solo debut collects six open-ended, marvelously textured guitar instrumentals written during the last decade.'
column8: b'For almost 20 years, the guitarist Trevor de Brauw has anchored the stalwart instrumental rock band Pelican. His chiseled riffs, stretching skyward from a crust of doom metal toward the wide skies of post-rock, have long been its real hook. As prolific as that band has been, de Brauw has kept busy with a litany of side-projects, too, from his new trio RLYR to the slow-motion creep of the drone collective Chord. Still, as late as last summer, de Brauw confessed to a lack of confidence in his guitar prowess, doubtful even of his ability to reproduce songs onstage. Making music, he said, was an emotional and mental necessity, not some chance to flex his technical abilities.' b'That compulsive approach is critical to Uptown, de Brauw\xe2\x80\x99s solo debut. Instead of serving as a\xc2\xa0showcase,\xc2\xa0Uptown instead collects six open-ended, marvelously textured guitar instrumentals written during the last decade. Sure, there is a certain level of wizardry here, especially with guitar loops that wrap into Moebius strips of sound or the army of ways de Brauw warps the signals from his six strings. During the record\xe2\x80\x99s tremendous finale, the twelve-minute beauty \xe2\x80\x9cFrom the Black Soil Poetry and Song Sprang,\xe2\x80\x9d de Brauw manages to conjure and control a symphony of guitars by himself. The piece\xc2\xa0suggests the choir-like calm of Rhys Chatham\xe2\x80\x99s A Crimson Grail or Growing in its prime a decade ago.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s sophistication, too, in the ways that de Brauw patiently peels layers apart or puts them together. \xe2\x80\x9cDistinct Frequency\xe2\x80\x9d is little more than three minutes of a powerful drone and a broadcast of what might be the evening news, pitted against one another. But de Brauw pulls them apart so slowly that the music is dramatic and demanding, as if always on the verge of some major revelation. But Uptown is a subtle record, and both signals just fade into silence.' b'Indeed, the complexity and real delight of Uptown stem more from its commingled, nuanced emotions than its instrumental execution. These six songs are, alternately, messy webs of anxiety and comfort, frustration and hopefulness, fatigue and energy, together always pushing past simple binaries of happy or sad, light or dark. The deliberate chords of \xe2\x80\x9cThey Keep Bowing,\xe2\x80\x9d for instance, seem at first caustic. But as they decay, they blossom into something beautiful, with individual notes suddenly circling above like halos.' b'Likewise, \xe2\x80\x9cTurn Up for What\xe2\x80\x9d (who said solo guitar records couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have a sense of humor?) transitions from chimes and bells into a loud electric groan into, finally, a riff that aims for liftoff. The boundary between each phase is fuzzy, implying that each state is linked to the others. Like the intertwined loops and nested layers, there are no discrete or easy feelings to Uptown. It is, de Brauw says without a word, complicated.' b'The world of solo guitar records isn\xe2\x80\x99t really the domain of urgent, timely statements. They are, more often, practiced steps on a continuum, sometimes speaking only to like-minded practitioners and listeners. Despite its long gestation, though, Uptown feels surprisingly necessary and somehow reassuring. There\xe2\x80\x99s confusion and clarity within these songs, an understanding that these ideas and emotions only make sense in the presence of each other. During Uptown, the darkest parts sometimes allow for flickers of light, though other times the darkness swallows the light whole. It is an apt soundtrack for the start of 2017, then, when signs of pending apocalypse and revolution seem to bleed into one.'

column7: b'With his new band Pillorian, former Agalloch vocalist/guitarist John Haughm dives more heavily\xc2\xa0into his former group\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0black and dark metal roots. Their furious first album is\xc2\xa0slightly underwhelming.'
column8: b'Agalloch\xe2\x80\x99s dissolution last year was a huge loss to bear, and only half of that has to do with how beloved the groundbreaking black metal group were. Vocalist/guitarist John Haughm was at the root of the breakup, something he\xe2\x80\x99ll own up to: he wanted to tour more than the rest of the band, especially guitarist Don Anderson, who chose to focus on his academic career. Haughm irked fans by referring to himself as a \xe2\x80\x9cvisionary,\xe2\x80\x9d not only committing the sin of Having an Ego (see: any time Kanye West makes headlines), but also marginalizing the contributions of his bandmates. Anderson was a key songwriter and brought much of the folk element to Agalloch. And Aesop Dekker, a powerhouse drummer who also plays key roles in VH\xc3\x96L and Worm Ouroboros, crucially filled out their live sound.' b'To his credit, Haughm realized he had to break away from the Agalloch name and start anew. His latest group, Pillorian, strips away some of Agalloch\xe2\x80\x99s neofolk influence and dives heavier into their black and dark metal roots. That he\xe2\x80\x99s rebuilding is obvious throughout their debut Obsidian Arc. For a less experienced band, the album would be a promising starting point. For someone of Haughm\xe2\x80\x99s caliber, it\xe2\x80\x99s slightly underwhelming.' b'Pillorian\xe2\x80\x99s strengths come from Agalloch\xe2\x80\x99s familiar comforts\xe2\x80\x94layered, sonorous riffs and tonal shifts as smooth as the guitars are heavy\xe2\x80\x94delivered with more immediacy. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the Light of a Black Sun\xe2\x80\x9d opens with the contrast of bright acoustic guitar and rolling metal waves that was a staple of 1999\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Pale Folklore\xc2\xa0and 2002\xe2\x80\x99sThe Mantle. The allure reigns brief, before succumbing to Haughm\xe2\x80\x99s torrents of fury, assisted by drummer Trevor Matthews and guitarist Stephen Parker. While there is another acoustic break towards the end of \xe2\x80\x9cSun,\xe2\x80\x9d the song sets the tone for the rest of the album, specifically its reliance on more metallic drivers and moods. Like Agalloch, Pillorian still finds a balance between soft and loud closer to their more progressive rock influences\xe2\x80\x94King Crimson and Genesis\xe2\x80\x99 artier takes and Rush\xe2\x80\x99s more hard-rock based brand\xe2\x80\x94than post-rock. It\xe2\x80\x99s a little more evident here, since Arc is Haughm\xe2\x80\x99s most \xe2\x80\x9cmetal\xe2\x80\x9d record thus far. Arc is far from breezy\xe2\x80\x94no interludes, no folky passages\xe2\x80\x94which clashes with Haughm\xe2\x80\x99s evident urgency to get it out there. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Sentient Arcanum\xe2\x80\x9d is the exception, drawing up on Haughm\xe2\x80\x99s solo guitar ambient works, more Fennesz than Fleurety.' b'The rest of Arc is more furious, but no less majestic. \xe2\x80\x9cA Stygian Pyre\xe2\x80\x9d feels angrier than anything he\xe2\x80\x99s ever done, an example of spark and quickness working in his favor. Haughm has a knack for elevating black metal\xe2\x80\x99s fast-picked tremolos, revealing their symphonic potential. They are the fuel for Arc\xe2\x80\x99s momentum, especially in \xe2\x80\x9cSun\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cPyre.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cArchanian Divinity\xe2\x80\x9d shows an affinity for Swedish black metal\xe2\x80\x94especially Watain\xe2\x80\x99s slower breaks and Dissection\xe2\x80\x99s frosty, florlorn atmosphere and blackening of classic metal melodies. Haughm is a living Jon N\xc3\xb6dtveidt without an accessory to murder charge, one who saw towering might in pushing the melodic pillars of Priest and Maiden to new heights.' b'While Agalloch existed in black metal\xe2\x80\x99s progressive wing, they were still a metal band, and thus understood the magic of a rapturous solo. Those moments are rare in Arc, which is its main problem. Haughm knows how to give his songs heft, but he\xe2\x80\x99s missing that lighter fluidity that complimented Agalloch\xe2\x80\x99s nature themes. One exception is \xe2\x80\x9cDark is the River of Man,\xe2\x80\x9d the closer, where those leads cut through the brooding atmosphere. It resembles Katatonia if they\xe2\x80\x99d honed in on their death/doom sound, instead of turning into goth AOR. \xe2\x80\x9cForged Iron Crucible\xe2\x80\x9d also features choral vocals that gleam at what made Agalloch great. Some more bursts of beauty like that would help.' b'Arc showcases Haughm\xe2\x80\x99s singular metal voice and commanding presence, but it also reveals what a group effort Agalloch was. Haughm is floundering without the right partners; it proves why his \xe2\x80\x9cvisionary\xe2\x80\x9d claim felt dubious. For any creative endeavor, a little self-assurance is necessary for survival. But no matter your skill, with a band, you can\xe2\x80\x99t go it alone.'

column7: b'I Decided. attempts to bury Big Sean\xe2\x80\x99s wide\xc2\xa0mean streak and present the 28-year-old in a mature light.'
column8: b'2015\xe2\x80\x99s Dark Sky Paradise was a massive and hard-earned leap forward for Big Sean. When pressed, he\xe2\x80\x99s a very good rapper, and the right selection of beats framed\xc2\xa0his words with a sense of new importance. The album was also unapologetically mean. Of course, its breakout hit was \xe2\x80\x9cI Don\xe2\x80\x99t Fuck With You,\xe2\x80\x9d but the same bitterness was applied across the LP to foes and exes alike. Perhaps no rapper is as obsessed with his own dick as Big Sean, and given the opportunity to brag and scorn, he found a comfort zone. I Decided. attempts to bury that mean streak, and present the 28-year-old in a mature light. In short: It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t work.' b'On I Decided., Sean continues to recount his come-up\xe2\x80\x94a banal narrative for a platinum-selling artist who\xe2\x80\x99s cracked the Top 5 with each album. The record\xe2\x80\x99s new twist is that Sean is quickly growing weary of fame and being in the public view. Bemoaning success is certainly a quick ticket\xc2\xa0to earn more success (see: Graham, Aubrey; West, Kanye), but Sean conveys no details or feelings to make his struggle compelling. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t want [paper] if it can\xe2\x80\x99t change shit drastically, dramatically,\xe2\x80\x9d he claims on \xe2\x80\x9cHalfway Off the Balcony,\xe2\x80\x9d but there\xe2\x80\x99s no sense of\xc2\xa0what change he wants, and therefore nothing to connect to. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t help that he still leans on forehead-slap lines like,\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cEverything gold like I just practiced alchemy,\xe2\x80\x9d from the same song.' b'Sean also badly wants to show us that he is an album artist, not a singles rapper. \xe2\x80\x9cVoices in My Head / Stick to the Plan,\xe2\x80\x9d is a two-part would-be epic in which nothing of consequence happens. Over a spare, diffuse beat, he hears voices telling he \xe2\x80\x9ccould do better.\xe2\x80\x9d Then the always-powerful\xc2\xa0Metro Boomin tag appears, as does a captivating beat, and Sean runs down the various distractions in his life\xe2\x80\x94women, money, fame, \xe2\x80\x9cnegative energy,\xe2\x80\x9d etc.\xe2\x80\x94 but the undertone is that \xe2\x80\x9cthe plan\xe2\x80\x9d is making hits. In attempting to demonstrate how layered and complicated he is, Sean reaffirms what we already knew about him\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s better when rapping well-delivered nonsense over heavy beats.' b'And so the best moments remain the pop songs. \xe2\x80\x9cBounce Back\xe2\x80\x9d has already gone gold, and it sticks to the Dark Sky Paradise script as much as anything else on the new record. Sean does an honest-to-God Cartman impression\xc2\xa0on the song,\xc2\xa0suggesting that he\xe2\x80\x99s at his best when he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t take himself too seriously. The other single, \xe2\x80\x9cMoves,\xe2\x80\x9d is equally effective\xe2\x80\x94Sean\xe2\x80\x99s agile flow is his best weapon to distract you from his litany of clunkers, jokes about Jason Statham and Mini-Me and Channing Tatum all blurring together into a rubbery and enjoyable bounce.' b'On the album\xe2\x80\x99s best song, \xe2\x80\x9cSacrifices,\xe2\x80\x9d Sean raps, \xe2\x80\x9cI came a long way from that \xe2\x80\x98Marvin & Chardonnay.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Quite literally, it is a true statement: The Finally Famous single came out over five years ago, and like the rest of the world, Sean has had thousands of days to deal with life\xe2\x80\x99s quotidian pressures. But while he has\xc2\xa0become incrementally more skilled over the years, not much else has changed. Throughout I Decided., Sean conflates the passing of time with growth and progress. Nothing on I Decided., however, suggests that he has gained perspective worth sharing or to which he should devote a whole album. He continues to be a talented pop act attempting to be something he is not.'

column7: b"Elbow's latest deepens their formula\xe2\x80\x94rich, sweeping rock songs about melancholy\xc2\xa0and love\xe2\x80\x94with a dreamy sense of loss and time passing."
column8: b'Ever since 2008\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Mercury Prize-winning The Seldom Seen Kid, Elbow have offered\xc2\xa0slight tweaks on a\xc2\xa0reliable formula:\xc2\xa0meditative, dramatic rock songs, studded with sweeping\xc2\xa0orchestration and boasting subtly idiosyncratic songwriting. At this point, they may not win many more new fans stateside (or elsewhere), but as they age, they are settling into this groove, one that deepens slowly with more years passed and miles traveled.' b'Their last album, 2014\xe2\x80\x99s* The Take Off and Landing of Everything*, catalogued the mixture of life changes that come with adulthood, but was specifically shaped by the end of frontman Guy Garvey\xe2\x80\x99s long-term relationship with the writer Emma Jane Unsworth. An album blurred between places and times, it found Garvey writing from a place of increasingly crowded memory. Their new album\xc2\xa0*Little Fictions\xc2\xa0*picks up those threads, with a few more years behind them as touring musicians. Living that way has a certain effect: other people\xe2\x80\x99s live drift out of yours and seem to settle into place, while yours keeps rushing forward but also remains static in its own way, with you simply replacing old characters with new ones. Much of the album outlines love lost, love percolating, love maturing. And, as always, Garvey is a skilled chronicler of human interaction, offering a manifesto for the album in its penultimate title track: \xe2\x80\x9cWe protect our little fictions/Like it\xe2\x80\x99s all we are.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Unlike its predecessor\xe2\x80\x94where the weight of the past sometimes bogged down the tempos, too\xe2\x80\x94*Little Fictions\xc2\xa0*moves. Lead single and opening track \xe2\x80\x9cMagnificent (She Says)\xe2\x80\x9d rides on a nimble guitar figure and string arrangement. The drum pattern in \xe2\x80\x9cGentle Storm\xe2\x80\x9d wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t feel out of place in a club, were it not for the beautifully ruminative song that surrounds it. Though at their most insistent Elbow still mostly operate at \xe2\x80\x9cpurposeful stride,\xe2\x80\x9d a song like \xe2\x80\x9cFirebrand & Angel\xe2\x80\x9d combines off-kilter elements to achieve a forward-momentum lurch.' b'Even at their most emotionally bombastic\xe2\x80\x94in huge orchestral sweeps like \xe2\x80\x9cOne Day Like This\xe2\x80\x9d or the slow-intensifying koan of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Take Off and Landing of Everything\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Elbow write songs with a careful architecture. And now, perhaps more so than ever, the affecting moments of their new material are rooted in very precise decisions, like the interplay of piano and percussion in \xe2\x80\x9cGentle Storm.\xe2\x80\x9d One of the most striking examples here is the vocal layering in \xe2\x80\x9cAll Disco\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cK2.\xe2\x80\x9d Abstracted, ghostly background vocals bubble in the background throughout \xe2\x80\x9cAll Disco\xe2\x80\x9d until they finally boil over and mingle with Garvey\xe2\x80\x99s, a manifestation of memory overtaking and reshaping your perception of the present. \xe2\x80\x9cK2,\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s highlight, pulls a similar trick. One long unhurried tumble (its verses and chorus elide together), it finds Garvey in a reverie, eager to unspool but doing so in many directions at once; the moments and places listed are far-flung. Throughout, his vocals echo themselves in the distance, slightly out-of-step with the main vocal performance. It\xe2\x80\x99s a watercolor representation of life passing and the experiences you collect, making the clarity of repeated lines like \xe2\x80\x9cOpens the fist just enough for a hand/To slip into the hand\xe2\x80\x9d hit harder.' b"*Little Fictions\xc2\xa0*is full of moments like this, where discrete flourishes yield quietly resounding payoffs. Sometimes it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to wish\xc2\xa0Elbow would let a different kind of intensity in\xe2\x80\x94that the storm wasn\xe2\x80\x99t always so gentle. But that's not really what Elbow do, and this many albums in, they know what they do well. They still excel in melancholic music about loss and love. But \xc2\xa0these days, wide-eyed wonder is always around the corner. \xe2\x80\x9cThen my telephone shakes into life I see your name,\xe2\x80\x9d Garvey sings towards the end of closer \xe2\x80\x9cKindling\xe2\x80\x9d (a song that plays like U2 in their lowest-key), before the repetition of \xe2\x80\x9cThen the wheat fields explode into gold either side of the train,\xe2\x80\x9d as the final lines of the album. In a different group\xe2\x80\x99s hands, it\xe2\x80\x99d all be too mawkish. But as Elbow settle into middle age, the additional wrinkles and whiskey stains only deepen the gravity of their stories."

column7: b'Matt Martians is the founding member and a driving force behind the band the Internet. His new solo record is full of slack, indolent funk.'
column8: b'As a founding member and driving force behind the band the Internet, Matt Martians got better the old-fashioned way: album by album, the group tinkered and tightened and scraped away dust, gradually revealing their identity as an adept lite-funk outfit. Their third full-length, 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Ego Death, twinkled softly, but with enough clarity to earn a Grammy nomination and radio play. After all that hard work, Martians unwinds on his new solo record, The Drum Chord Theory, slackening the traditionally taut lines of funk and rap to make a droopy, indolent\xc2\xa0album.' b'This is music judiciously leached of urgency. Martians keeps verses short or excises them completely, so there isn\xe2\x80\x99t much of an opportunity to upshift into refrains, which mostly come in the form of repetitive chants or near-whispers. Sometimes the drums and bass are overlaid at odd angles, hinting at a \xe2\x80\x9990s hip-hop groove but splaying sideways rather than cohering into something clipped and commanding. After a few minutes of a vamp\xe2\x80\x94keys and rhythm section, maybe hand percussion and a stray guitar line\xe2\x80\x94the band tires and moves on to a new one, frequently within the same song.' b'The recumbent funk comes paired mostly with stories of romantic woe; a central riff may change, but the male-female disconnect remains paramount. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t read minds,\xe2\x80\x9d Martians laments, addressing any potential future partners who might be listening on \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Love Is.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWe just want to know what the fuck you want\xe2\x80\x94is that hard?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cEvery time I think I found the one, something always goes wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings a couple tracks later. But he continues his search, assuring a woman on the album\xe2\x80\x99s final bonus cut, \xe2\x80\x9cElevators,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthat girl from the dream was you.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"These feelings don't bloom into anguish; The Drum Chord Theory is dillydallying on lazy Sunday, with stormy Monday kept at safe remove. Martians lightens the mood by flying into a synthetic, \xe2\x80\x9cAlvin and the Chipmunks\xe2\x80\x9d register to undercut a possible commitment\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif you were my girlfriend, I'd make you feel good\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and peppers songs with asides like the enthusiastic Internet endorsement that closes \xe2\x80\x9cWhere Are Yo Friends?\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cSyd, Chris, Steve, Pat, Jameel, I love y\xe2\x80\x99all niggas man,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, name checking bandmates. Then he adds happily, \xe2\x80\x9cBut everyone else man, if we ain\xe2\x80\x99t cool, then I\xe2\x80\x99m sorry.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s meta-commentary, too: after a couple tunes reorganize around a different vamp at the halfway point, on \xe2\x80\x9cBabyGirl,\xe2\x80\x9d Martians quips \xe2\x80\x9cAin\xe2\x80\x99t no hidden track back here\xe2\x80\x94next song.\xe2\x80\x9d Cue a track change." b'If you won\xe2\x80\x99t come to The Drum Chord Theory for a bracing shot of adrenaline, supine doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean unenjoyable. The more Martians sinks into his funk hammock, the better. On \xe2\x80\x9cSouthern Isolation,\xe2\x80\x9d the bass squirms up and down the scale, evoking Caetano Veloso\xe2\x80\x99s great \xe2\x80\x9cOlha O Menino,\xe2\x80\x9d while the singing washes back and forth, unhurried and opulent, like a sloop bobbing on the tide.\xc2\xa0Elsewhere, the band keeps sketching outlines and leaving them behind, dangling one riff, teasing it a bit, discarding it. Martians doesn\xe2\x80\x99t return to the rapturous, near nod-off state of \xe2\x80\x9cSouthern Isolation.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0The Drum Chord Theory is never unpleasant, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also never very distinct.'

column7: b'The Bristol-based electronic duo Emptyset are in a class by themselves when it comes to excavating brutality out of silence.'
column8: b"By its own description, the Bristol-based electronic duo Emptyset makes music as a meta-study of the relationship between sound, surface, space, gear, and process. Given how freely Emptyset\xe2\x80\x99s Paul Purgas and James Ginzburg expound on those relationships in academic terms, you might expect the pair's work to drip with intellectualism. Between them, Purgas and Ginzburg actually do have academic backgrounds\xe2\x80\x94in art, design, and music. So it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that they\xe2\x80\x99ve turned to spaces such as London\xe2\x80\x99s Ambika P3 testing bunker for commissioned installation projects, and that such spaces have served as one of Emptyset\xe2\x80\x99s primary habitats over the project\xe2\x80\x99s 12-year history." b'Taken on its own, however, Emptyset\xe2\x80\x99s music can be surprisingly single-minded. Borders, the band\xe2\x80\x99s fifth\xc2\xa0studio full-length (its first for Thrill Jockey following a string of releases for electronic labels like Subtext and Raster-Noton) can be boiled-down to three words: throbbing, bassy, sinister. More aggressive and pulse-driven than Emptyset\xe2\x80\x99s last studio album, 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Recur, Borders hits your senses with a brute force that belies Ginzburg and Purgas\xe2\x80\x99 conceptual approach to making sounds. The album opens with a flickering, short-lived wash of static that gets swallowed by a low-end thrum, a sound that pretty much persists from that point onwards until the final track concludes.' b'These repetitive bursts of bass-frequency shrapnel go through significant changes\xe2\x80\x94the timbre, layering, tempos, and intervals all morph\xc2\xa0from track to track\xe2\x80\x94but the central pattern and rhythmic attack remain constant as the pulses come one after another after another. And once the pattern shifts from album opener \xe2\x80\x9cBody\xe2\x80\x9d to a similar pattern on \xe2\x80\x9cBorder,\xe2\x80\x9d Purgas and Ginzburg establish relentless repetition as one of the album\xe2\x80\x99s primary features. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t take long before Borders induces a meditative effect not unlike when you stare at ocean waves for long periods.' b'Likewise, the music on Borders suggests a comparable sense of catching finite slivers within a greater pool of endlessness.
