With a bandname derived from the mathematical term for \xe2\x80\x9ca set of elements containing nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that Emptyset aim to bring a sense of physicality to empty space\xe2\x80\x94or, as Ginzburg once put it, to identify the \xe2\x80\x9cthingness\xe2\x80\x9d at the heart of an empty void. When it comes excavating brutality out of silence, Emptyset sit in a class by themselves.' b"The album even comes close to tunefulness on \xe2\x80\x9cDissolve,\xe2\x80\x9d where an unidentifiable sound source takes on the character of delicate guitar strumming. \xc2\xa0And though you'd never mistake Emptyset for dance music, theirs is still body music, in a way. One can only imagine that listening to Borders with a heavy-duty subwoofer would be a punishing affair. Similarly, even without one iota of percussion\xe2\x80\x94Borders contains nothing by way of a traditional \xe2\x80\x9cbeat\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the groove is undeniable. And the new material, perhaps more than ever, harbors ample evidence for why Emptyset continue to identify as a techno act, albeit one whose style hews much closer to Berlin than Detroit. Given their Bristol background, it makes sense that Purgas and Ginzburg see their work as an extension of sound system/DJ culture." b'In truth, Emptyset haven\xe2\x80\x99t evolved all that much since they began working in the full-length format in 2009. A microcosm of their overall progression, Borders essentially hovers in one mood, requires effort to recognize its contours, and ends on an anti-climactic note as the music simply ceases, without any sense of completion or finality. And whether it loses or gains flavor over multiple listens depends on the listener\xe2\x80\x99s patience threshold for repetition. But by turning up the volume and menace this time, Emptyset manage to put new spins on dubstep and industrial\xe2\x80\x94genres they don\xe2\x80\x99t explicitly reference\xe2\x80\x94as well. As such, Borders functions as a gateway between traditionalist dance forms and the artier end of the electronic-production universe. It also offers new ways of understanding both by reflecting each against the other.'

column7: b'Syd, the charismatic songwriter and performer at the center of R&B group the Internet, sounds more\xc2\xa0comfortable and focused than ever on her slinky, confident solo debut.'
column8: b'For being such a breezy new voice, Syd\xe2\x80\x94the charismatic songwriter and performer at the center of R&B group the Internet\xe2\x80\x94is unleashing her debut solo album with a curiously resolute title: Fin. The artist, born Sydney Bennett in Los Angeles, is just\xc2\xa024, part of a loose kinship of musicians, like Frank Ocean and her brother Taco, who rode into public consciousness with Odd Future and Tyler, the Creator (much of Odd Future\xe2\x80\x99s early work was produced in Syd\xe2\x80\x99s home studio, at her parent\xe2\x80\x99s house). Though she and the Internet have released three albums together, it was the 2015 Ego Death\xc2\xa0that provided a breakthrough, gaining them a Grammy nomination and a certified smash in the Kaytranada-produced single \xe2\x80\x9cGirl.\xe2\x80\x9d Now she\xe2\x80\x99s trying it out on her own, with an album of twelve slick hits that are the best proof yet of what she is capable of as an artist. Aren\xe2\x80\x99t things just beginning?' b'Fin is, indeed, a fresh start. Stepping away momentarily from the Internet\xc2\xa0finds her as comfortable and focused as she\xe2\x80\x99s ever sounded. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is my descent into the depth I want the band to get to,\xe2\x80\x9d she told the FADER last year. \xe2\x80\x9cFor me, this is like an in-between thing\xe2\x80\x94maybe get a song on the radio, maybe make some money, have some new shit to perform.\xe2\x80\x9d Working with a variety of superstar producers, like MeLo-X and Hit-Boy, she leans on her different influences\xe2\x80\x94boastful hip-hop, hippie neo-soul, sensual R&B\xe2\x80\x94without ever losing the thread that ties them together: her inventive songwriting and magnetic personality, which leaps from the speakers every time she opens her mouth. Syd has perfected a pose, a slouching shrug and studied distance that makes her appealing, if a little remote. On Fin, it\xe2\x80\x99s better defined than it ever has been.' b'She uses this bemused vantage point to\xc2\xa0reinvigorate\xc2\xa0some R&B archetypes, inhabiting them and winking slightly at the same time. The opening number, \xe2\x80\x9cShake Em Off,\xe2\x80\x9d is all dirt-off-your-shoulders bravado: \xe2\x80\x9cYoung star in the making/Swear they sleeping on me\xe2\x80\x9d she sings casually. Track two is called \xe2\x80\x9cKnow,\xe2\x80\x9d and it is an Aaliyah bop, with Syd singing\xe2\x80\x94in the airiest part of her vocal register and over a sputtering beat\xe2\x80\x94about keeping a hook-up hidden away from the public. \xe2\x80\x9cGot Her Own\xe2\x80\x9d is a playful gay flip on the theme of loving a girl for her independence and ambition. On a quick sensual interlude called \xe2\x80\x9cDrown in It,\xe2\x80\x9d Syd sounds as proudly nasty as Ty Dolla $ign when she promises to \xe2\x80\x9cSwim in it/Dive in it/Drown in it/Hide in it, babe.\xe2\x80\x9d And there is \xe2\x80\x9cBody,\xe2\x80\x9d a minimalist moment that\xe2\x80\x99s sole aim seems to be uncomplicated sensuality; as she told Zane Lowe in a recent interview, she just wanted it to be the \xe2\x80\x9cbaby-making anthem of 2017.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0This is a demonstrably cool album, but it\xe2\x80\x99s hot when it needs to be, and gay listeners (like myself) will be psyched to have songs that are romantic and sexy but do not belabor the fact that they are sung from one woman to another, manifested by an artist who sounds entirely comfortable with her persona and talent.' b'On the final track, the revealingly titled \xe2\x80\x9cInsecurities,\xe2\x80\x9d she shows that there is, in fact, another side to her beneath the relaxed exterior: a woman who may sound self-assured, but who gets stuck in the same toxic bullshit that so many of us do, in this case a girl she loves with all her heart who can\xe2\x80\x99t return the favor. Here, she sounds a little beleaguered and hesitant, singing, at first, about packed suitcases but an inability to leave. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can thank my insecurities,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0she sings. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re the reason I was down so long.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a welcome omen that there\xe2\x80\x99s deeper psychological anxieties for her to explore on the next album, and I\xe2\x80\x99d love to hear more about that more vulnerable Syd. But by the end of the track, we\xe2\x80\x99re back to where we started, and the song ends with a stiff upper lip and a casual middle finger, melting into a pool of psychedelia.\xc2\xa0On Fin, what Syd seems to want to portray most of all is an admirable, inspirational confidence, a young woman singing and rapping while totally at ease with the beats that please her most.'

column7: b'The Menzingers join the \xe2\x80\x9cpost-30 punk\xe2\x80\x9d club, alongside Beach Slang and Japandroids. The first chorus asks\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cWhere we gonna go now that our 20s are over?\xe2\x80\x9d and the LP\xc2\xa0proceeds from there.'
column8: b'The Menzingers are classic rock\xc2\xa0bards\xc2\xa0with expired\xc2\xa0Warped Tour laminates,\xc2\xa0as rooted in Social Distortion and ska as they are Springsteen and Kerouac. This is\xc2\xa0their thing, and five albums in, they have it so down that it threatens to leave nothing to the imagination. Their fiercely beloved and unabashedly nostalgic dirtbag opus *On the Impossible Past challenged Celebration Rock\xc2\xa0*for 2012\xe2\x80\x99s most accurately titled album. Its follow-up led off with \xe2\x80\x9cI Don\xe2\x80\x99t Wanna Be an Asshole Anymore,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0which emphatically slam-dunked its premise and left the rest of the dispirited\xc2\xa0*Rented World *to pick up the shattered backboard. And if there\xe2\x80\x99s any doubt about what *After the Party *is getting at, the very first chorus rants \xe2\x80\x9cWhere we gonna go now that our 20s are over?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'\xe2\x80\x9cPost-30 punk\xe2\x80\x9d feels like a subgenre of a subgenre at this point: age isn\xe2\x80\x99t a number for Beach Slang, it\xe2\x80\x99s a nullity, whereas Japandroids\xc2\xa0embraced maturity with the same legendary fire as their younger selves. *After the Party *works with more typical talking points: the buzz is shorter and the hangovers are longer. Can I hide these tattoos at my day job? Is playing Minor Threat on laptop speakers keeping it real or just lame? Am I too old to be sleeping on floors? Am I too old to be too broke to afford a hotel?' b'On first glance, single \xe2\x80\x9cLookers\xe2\x80\x9d plays too much to stereotype, name-dropping Dean and Sal, \xe2\x80\x9cJulie from the Wonder Bar\xe2\x80\x9d and a hook of \xe2\x80\x9cJersey girls are always total heartbreakers!\xe2\x80\x9d (also, lookers). Maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s the \xe2\x80\x9csha la la la!\xe2\x80\x9d in the chorus, but \xe2\x80\x9cLookers\xe2\x80\x9d has a self-aware, sarcastic edge, an added pain of looking back on a seemingly rebellious youth and seeing just another kind of conformity. The Menzingers earn the benefit of the doubt when \xe2\x80\x9cThick as Thieves\xe2\x80\x9d opens with a sly skewering of the songwriting process (\xe2\x80\x9cI held up a liquor store/ Demanding topshelf metaphors\xe2\x80\x9d) and \xe2\x80\x9cTellin\xe2\x80\x99 Lies\xe2\x80\x9d hits on a point where the difference between 29 and 31 really does feel like an entire decade: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen buying marijuana makes you feel like a criminal / When your new friends take a joke too literal.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"But this is a Menzingers album, so the laughs are momentary and ultimately futile deflections of fear. The narrators in these songs are people racing through their 20s who\xc2\xa0find themselves trapped in tour vans\xc2\xa0or, most of the time, relationships they can't convince themselves they deserve. \xe2\x80\x9cMidwestern States\xe2\x80\x9d provides a gutting account of a codependent and deeply-in-love couple couch-surfing across the country, unsure of when things will ever be different as\xc2\xa0their options and prospects dwindle with each passing year." b'The Menzingers\xe2\x80\x99 way with an anthem never fails them, even when the tough talkin\xe2\x80\x99 boyfriends on \xe2\x80\x9cCharlie\xe2\x80\x99s Army\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBad Catholics\xe2\x80\x9d lack definition beyond their bluster (\xe2\x80\x9cTo everyone you\xe2\x80\x99re such a sweet church girl/but I know your secret\xe2\x80\x9d), or the record\xe2\x80\x99s best melody searches for the rest of a proper song (\xe2\x80\x9cHouse on Fire\xe2\x80\x9d). *After the Party *might actually be *too *well-designed for jukeboxes, as the relentless, face-to-the-glass production results in the sad cowpoke shuffle of \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Mass\xe2\x80\x9d and the Meatloaf-inspired \xe2\x80\x9cThe Bars\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0clocking in at about the same volume as everything else, denying a dynamic range that\xe2\x80\x99s needed on a record that lives up to its title by sticking around one or two songs longer than it probably should.' b'At least it seems that way until \xe2\x80\x9cLivin\xe2\x80\x99 Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Easy.\xe2\x80\x9d The preceding title track could\xe2\x80\x99ve easily been an exit ramp for Menzingers, a wizened, hard-earned moment of contentment where a couple looks back on their drunken nights and wake-n-bakes to a new morning, confiding, \xe2\x80\x9cafter the party, it\xe2\x80\x99s me and you.\xe2\x80\x9d But on the very next song, singer Greg Barnett remembers the foreclosure sign in the yard and the empty bank account, and hits I-80 to another show that will surely be the start of someone else\xe2\x80\x99s debauchery. *After the Party,\xc2\xa0*though? It\xe2\x80\x99s the hotel lobby and, \xe2\x80\x9cthey\xe2\x80\x99re always out of coffee.\xe2\x80\x9d'

column7: b'Responding to harsh realities,\xc2\xa0Jamison Isaak uses softsynths, guitar amps, and his\xc2\xa0sensitive way with melody to craft\xc2\xa0an idyllic space.'
column8: b'Stardew Valley is a fictitious rural region in a 2016 video game of the same name. Described as an \xe2\x80\x9copen-ended\xc2\xa0country-life RPG,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0it\xc2\xa0is essentially a game about unplugging from the modern world and embracing the beauty of simple living. You, the customized character, quit your soul-sucking office job, move to\xc2\xa0an\xc2\xa0inherited farm, live off the land, and become a part of the small community in Pelican Town. You can get married and start a family, or just live alone with your farm animals. You can go on adventures. It\xe2\x80\x99s a story about escapism in a medium rooted in escapism, at a time when most everyone could use an escape once in awhile.' b'Among Stardew Valley\xe2\x80\x99s many fans is Jamison Isaak. The Canadian artist recently tweeted that playing the game has helped take his mind off the woes of the world, a small but important act of self-care. And it\xe2\x80\x99s not unlike the creation of his newest\xc2\xa0album as Teen Daze. When Isaak moved from the city of Abbotsford, British Columbia, to a more secluded part of the Fraser Valley, he began work on Themes for Dying Earth as a way of processing recent bouts of anxiety. The\xc2\xa0warm lullaby \xe2\x80\x9cFirst Rain\xe2\x80\x9d and its calming lilt operate like the soft-beating heart around which the record was built. In that way, Themes deals with harsh realities\xe2\x80\x94personal, environmental, social\xe2\x80\x94by seeking solace in nature. \xe2\x80\x9cDeep inside the woods is where I go to understand,\xe2\x80\x9d Nadia Hulett sings on the downcast \xe2\x80\x9cLost,\xe2\x80\x9d as if inviting us to follow.' b"The appeal is irresistible, and once wrapped up in Themes, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine leaving its embrace. Isaak\xe2\x80\x99s music has come a long way from his earliest material, the pop-friendly electronic stuff known as chillwave, but these songs also take a step back from the live band setup explored on 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Morning World. Like any well-adjusted adult, Isaak has found a happy compromise here, creating a lush paradise with guitar amps and softsynths alike. It\xe2\x80\x99s not that he hasn't used his pop sensibilities and sensitive way with melody to conjure the idyllic before\xe2\x80\x94Themes is just a more fully formed, comprehensive utopia. From \xe2\x80\x9cCycle\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s gentle glide to the weightless \xe2\x80\x9cBreath,\xe2\x80\x9d an unbroken feeling of tenderness flows gracefully." b'Such continuity comes down to the album\xe2\x80\x99s careful pacing, as winsome singalongs give way to fluttering ambience or uplifting instrumentals. Despite such a consistent, good-natured tone, Themes never grows stale or turns saccharine. A song like \xe2\x80\x9cWater in Heaven\xe2\x80\x9d has the solemn majesty of a hymn, while \xe2\x80\x9cCherry Blossoms\xe2\x80\x9d evokes the miniature splendor of M83\xe2\x80\x99s Dead Cities, Red Seas & Lost Ghosts. Isaak treats these lofty moments with the same care and attention as the more subdued ones, allowing the meditative \xe2\x80\x9cDream City\xe2\x80\x9d nearly five minutes to flutter and loop like a kite in the wind. When a pedal steel guitar shows up in \xe2\x80\x9cAnew,\xe2\x80\x9d its presence is strange, but it reveals an artist looking to color even the album\xe2\x80\x99s smallest corners.' b'Themes was recorded entirely within the Fraser Valley region. It was released on his own label, and each physical copy comes with a unique photo shot by the artist, which are said to showcase the local landscapes that inspired the music. It all makes for an exceptionally personal album from someone known for his intimate songwriting. And yet Themes\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0subtle power is rooted in the dichotomy of someone running far from the madding crowd, only to open themselves to the world\xe2\x80\x99s problems and offer the comfort of a brief reprieve. For every smack in the face, Themes pauses, grins, and returns a kiss on the cheek.'

column7: b'The work of London-born, Sudanese artist\xc2\xa0Ahmed Gallab, aka Sinkane, blends styles including sub-Saharan pop, shoegaze, and afro-rock. More than ever, his new album has\xc2\xa0the feel of a democratic band.'
column8: b'If any artist deserves to swerve\xc2\xa0around a borderless Earth with a real World Passport, it\xe2\x80\x99s the London-born, Sudanese artist\xc2\xa0Ahmed Gallab. Listen to his catalog under the Sinkane moniker and you\xe2\x80\x99ll hear\xc2\xa0fragments of sub-Saharan pop, shoegaze, afro-rock, electronica, krautrock, and everything in between\xe2\x80\x94all melded into his\xc2\xa0own funky blend. Jumping into Sinkane\xe2\x80\x99s discography\xc2\xa0is like a weekend immersed in your local record store\xe2\x80\x99s world music rack.' b'On Life & Livin\xe2\x80\x99 It, Sinkane\xe2\x80\x99s sound is, more than ever, that of a democratic band. Supporting\xc2\xa0its predecessor, Mean Love, Gallab and his musicians toured 166 shows in 20 countries, and this new album retains the immediacy of a live set.\xc2\xa0The highlife bluster and catchy hooks of Life & Livin\xe2\x80\x99 It\xc2\xa0are sweet as taffy, like a bright sunburst of positivity that could melt ice.' b'With production spotless from front-to-back, no instrument trips another\xe2\x80\x99s heels. The orchestration remains refreshingly breezy, from the simple-but-infectious keyboard riffs of \xe2\x80\x9cFavorite Song,\xe2\x80\x9d to the gentle sax lines on \xe2\x80\x9cU\xe2\x80\x99Huh,\xe2\x80\x9d to the afrobeat bluster of members of Brooklyn band Antibalas\xe2\x80\x99 rich horn sections on \xe2\x80\x9cTelephone.\xe2\x80\x9d (If anything, the mix could be a little *too *clean.) Gallab\xe2\x80\x94eternally infused with the spirits of his Sudanese pop forefathers\xe2\x80\x94shines on top of the rhythms with zero struggles.\xc2\xa0A bit of an outlier, opener \xe2\x80\x9cDeadweight\xe2\x80\x9d features the kind of digital blips that have underpinned some of Gallab\xe2\x80\x99s previous work: The chipped guitar chords, twinkling keys, and rapped bongos rev up slowly, culminating with wailing guitars.' b'The singer\xe2\x80\x99s gentle vocal tones perfectly suit the lyrics, which are sunny, upbeat, and sometimes a little goofy. There\xe2\x80\x99s an endearing simplicity to \xe2\x80\x9cFavorite Song,\xe2\x80\x9d inspired by Gallab\xe2\x80\x99s one-time side job as a DJ: \xe2\x80\x9cWon\xe2\x80\x99t you play my favorite song?\xe2\x80\x9d he repeats over and over. Elsewhere, \xe2\x80\x9cU\xe2\x80\x99Huh\xe2\x80\x9d sees Gallab asserting, \xe2\x80\x9cEverything is fine/We\xe2\x80\x99re all gonna be alright\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cKulu shi tamaam,\xe2\x80\x9d an Arabic phrase meaning \xe2\x80\x9ceverything is great.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s either an admirable shot of optimism or skittish fingers-crossing given these times we find ourselves in.' b'On closer \xe2\x80\x9cThe Way,\xe2\x80\x9d the guitars get nasty. The horns come down hard, and chants of \xe2\x80\x9cI know, I know, I know\xe2\x80\x9d summon the spirit of Bill Withers. It\xe2\x80\x99s psychedelic-era Temptations cut with Blaxploitation grooves. *Life & Livin\xe2\x80\x99 It\xc2\xa0*signs off with a stiff jab to the nose, hinting at what could be if Sinkane\xe2\x80\x99s next journey takes them deeper into the mud.'

column7: b"Carsten Jost, co-founder of Hamburg's Dial Records, returns with his first proper LP in over\xc2\xa0a decade. The result is hypnotic, torn between cool remove and encroaching dread."
column8: b'Carsten Jost is a co-founder of Hamburg\xe2\x80\x99s Dial Records, a label responsible for minimalist classics from Lawrence, Efdemin, and Pantha du Prince, among others. Jost (aka David Lieske) released his debut album, You Don\xe2\x80\x99t Need a Weatherman to Know Which Way the Wind Blows, way back in 2001, when Dial\xe2\x80\x99s favored strain of moody, minimalist house was still relatively novel; the deep house revival wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t happen for another decade. Since then, he\xe2\x80\x99s put out very little else, even as the style he helped establish has become ubiquitous in underground dance music, from the Smallville label\xe2\x80\x99s twinkly-eyed tone poems to the muted chords and buffed textures of the so-called \xe2\x80\x9clo-fi house\xe2\x80\x9d phenomenon.' b'Since 2007\xe2\x80\x94with three new Carsten Jost tracks that year, it was an uncharacteristically prolific period\xe2\x80\x94his output has slowed to a trickle: one song on Dial\xe2\x80\x99s *2010 *compilation; a split single with Lawrence in 2011; another compilation cut in 2015. Lieske put out a full-length with his duo Misanthrope CA last year, but that album\xe2\x80\x99s dissonant, doom-laden ambient is a long way from his ruminative and rhythmic sweet spot. Finally, however, the wind seems to have blown him back into the studio. The resulting album goes to the heart of the Dial aesthetic: wistful, hypnotic, and torn between ecstatic abandon, cool remove, and encroaching dread.' b'The bookending \xe2\x80\x9cIntro\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cOutro\xe2\x80\x9d are stylistic outliers. Closer in spirit to Misanthrope CA, they combine ethereal orchestral samples with drifting synthesizers and distant scrapes and drones, suggesting Wolfgang Voigt\xe2\x80\x99s GAS project if Voigt had been brought up on a steady diet of Ligeti and doom metal. The album\xe2\x80\x99s nine remaining tracks proceed almost like a set of variations upon a theme. His grooves invariably emphasize the thud and hiss of classic Roland machines, and his crisp claps and flashing hi-hats cut through the swirling murk like searchlights. He likes his chords plaintive and his reverb trails long.' b'A few cuts are more melodic; the bittersweet \xe2\x80\x9cAtlantis II\xe2\x80\x9d features a bassline vaguely reminiscent of Ricardo Villalobos\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cDexter,\xe2\x80\x9d and its layered string pads are unabashedly sentimental. \xe2\x80\x9cLove,\xe2\x80\x9d originally released on a split 12\xe2\x80\x9d in 2007, carves out a clean-lined counterpoint between Rhodes keys and a rich, tonal conga pattern. Mostly, though, he applies his layers of synthesizers like watercolors, and the blurred edges of his melodies seep outward like the outline of a stain.' b'Like much dance music, Perishable Tactics\xc2\xa0seldom gestures beyond its immediate environs; it\xe2\x80\x99s a music of immersion, of immediacy, and also of deep isolation. Whereas most dance music is social, Lieske spins his fibers into a soft, hermetic cocoon. But the occasional crack in the fa\xc3\xa7ade affords a glimpse of ideas not often found in conjunction with house music, beginning with the militaristic theme that runs through titles such as \xe2\x80\x9cArmy Green\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDawn Patrol,\xe2\x80\x9d as well as the ominous cover photo of a shirtless figure crouching beneath a Mylar space blanket, clutching some kind of heavy weaponry. The theme becomes explicit on \xe2\x80\x9cPlatoon RLX,\xe2\x80\x9d in which a brief snippet of dialogue echoes in an incessant loop over mournful strings and a restless drum groove. \xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99d you get the nickname?\xe2\x80\x9d asks a voice; \xe2\x80\x9cThe killer?\xe2\x80\x9d whispers another in reply.' b'The clip comes from The World of Charlie Company, a 1970 documentary that the CBS News reporter John Laurence made while embedded with an American rifle company in Vietnam. It\xe2\x80\x99s worth bearing in mind that the Bob Dylan lyric that\xe2\x80\x99s quoted in the title of his debut album has a deeper historical significance: That line, from \xe2\x80\x9cSubterranean Homesick Blues,\xe2\x80\x9d inspired the name of the Weather Underground, colloquially known as the Weathermen, the \xe2\x80\x9960s radicals who took up arms against the U.S. government. With these echoes of the civil unrest and military disasters of last century, Lieske adds even more sinister\xc2\xa0overtones to his already unsettling atmospheres. As it happens, the Weathermen have recently been back in the news: Steve Bannon, Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s shadowy right-hand man, cryptically shouted out the leftist revolutionaries in a 2010 speech. If Carsten Jost is a kind of dance-music Cassandra, complicating club music with some serious end-of-the-world vibes, Lieske couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have picked a more appropriate time to bring him back.'

column3: b'T2 Trainspotting: The Original Motion Picture Soundtrack'
column7: b'CHOOSE LIFE. (Again.)'
column8: b'\xe2\x80\x9cNostalgia: that\xe2\x80\x99s why you\xe2\x80\x99re here. You\xe2\x80\x99re a tourist in your own youth.\xe2\x80\x9d When Sick Boy (Jonny Lee Miller) sneers this midway through T2 Trainspotting\xe2\x80\x94his bleached-blond tufts thinner since we last saw him, his pretty brooding more intractably carved at the temples\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s lashing out at his estranged mate Renton (Ewan McGregor) and the two grim decades that have passed since they parted. He\xe2\x80\x99s gazing ruefully across the same desolate, outer-Edinburgh moors that mirrored their youths in the original Trainspotting, where they bemoaned their lots as needle-pocked nihilists, subpar grifters, and residents of Scotland (not necessarily in that order). But really, he\xe2\x80\x99s breaking the fourth wall, all but short of winking into the camera and waggling a cigar, Groucho Marx-style\xe2\x80\x94because T2 knows exactly why its audience has returned, and what we want from it.' b'Happily, the film delivers: T2 rings true to the spirit of the original\xe2\x80\x94the grubby lad humor, the graphic wastrel extracurriculars, the creeping desperation of consciously inert lives\xe2\x80\x94with an unhurried fondness that still raises stakes for its heroes. (It\xe2\x80\x99s also not shy about embracing Trainspotting\xe2\x80\x99s most zeitgeist moments, slotting in copious footage from the original.) T2 is a best-case scenario for nostalgia, bowing to the diehards while squaring up to present\xe2\x80\x94and its soundtrack fares similarly, offering a loose-limbed mash of callback remixes and fervent young upstarts that echoes the glee of the original without laboring to eclipse it.' b'The 1996 Trainspotting soundtrack has been rightly celebrated for merging the Britpop bests of the era (Pulp, Elastica, Blur) with big-beat rave (Leftfield, Underworld). Championing dance music, especially in the power-ballad techno of Underworld\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBorn Slippy,\xe2\x80\x9d introduced it to new audiences while it was edging up from the underground stateside. Proto-punk was the other bloodline, Iggy Pop\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLust for Life\xe2\x80\x9d the de facto theme, all joyous and seductive id; the wistful, near-sarcastic flow of Lou Reed\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cPerfect Day,\xe2\x80\x9d under Renton\xe2\x80\x99s overdose scene, leant pathos.' b'T2\xe2\x80\x99s mix stokes these moments as merrily as Renton, Sick Boy, and Spud (poor, hapless Spud) slide back into degeneracy. Underworld debuts \xe2\x80\x9cSlow Slippy,\xe2\x80\x9d a canter update to \xe2\x80\x9cBorn Slippy\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s sprint; splintered mutters replace the prior\xe2\x80\x99s yelps for \xe2\x80\x9clager lager lager lager,\xe2\x80\x9d but when those same gentle, sunrise synths nudge to the fore, they are a pensive homecoming. \xe2\x80\x9cLust for Life\xe2\x80\x9d gets a gnarled remix from the Prodigy, slicing a peppy group yelp between Pop\xe2\x80\x99s brays, though the scuzzy synth thrum tapers off into a curious shrug of a conclusion. Underworld\xe2\x80\x99s Rick Smith, T2\xe2\x80\x99s composer and soundtrack curator, also offers \xe2\x80\x9cEventually But (Spud\xe2\x80\x99s Letter to Gail),\xe2\x80\x9d a lovely, glacial runoff of an ambient ballad that folds in somber film dialogue; Blondie gets a return of sorts in \xe2\x80\x9cDreaming,\xe2\x80\x9d after their \xe2\x80\x9cAtomic\xe2\x80\x9d was covered by Sleeper in the original. (\xe2\x80\x9cPerfect Day\xe2\x80\x9d earns a piano reprise in the film that\xe2\x80\x99s not included here.)' b'T2\xe2\x80\x99s soundtrack doesn\xe2\x80\x99t just smack of the past, though; it gets a timely revamp alongside that seminal \xe2\x80\x9cchoose life\xe2\x80\x9d speech. Edinburgh\xe2\x80\x99s Young Fathers appear three times, magnetic in their scrappy ardor; despite winning the 2014 Mercury Prize for their debut, Dead, the Scottish-Liberian-Nigerian trio remain undersung for their high-velocity, socially astute experimental hip-hop. Director Danny Boyle has called their new track here, \xe2\x80\x9cOnly God Knows,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9cBorn Slippy\xe2\x80\x9d-style \xe2\x80\x9cheartbeat\xe2\x80\x9d of T2; it shares that adrenaline, their own rough-and-tumble abandon (\xe2\x80\x9cOnly God knows that the people are cheating/Only God knows you don\xe2\x80\x99t need him\xe2\x80\x9d) merging smoothly with a gospel choir.' b'In fact, hip-hop\xe2\x80\x94absent from Trainspotting\xe2\x80\x94scores the best scene in T2. As Renton accidentally reunites with the homicidal Begbie in a club bathroom (one of T2\xe2\x80\x99s many winking callbacks to toilets), Jason Nevins\xe2\x80\x99 rattling remix of Run-D.M.C.\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s Like That\xe2\x80\x9d thumps with palpable humidity, unyielding in four-to-the-floor rigor. (The 1997 track, a UK hit at the time, feels singularly like a return to roots for Boyle; his last film soundtracks have been tempered affairs, anchored by Bob Dylan and the Maccabees, Moby and Unkle, and Bill Withers and A.R. Rahman.) Elsewhere, the Welsh drum\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99bass DJ High Contrast whips up a fatalistic film opener in \xe2\x80\x9cShotgun Mouthwash;\xe2\x80\x9d the acidic staccato mimics the drums of \xe2\x80\x9cLust for Life\xe2\x80\x9d and abets a series of fitting poor-bastard asides. (The bleakest: \xe2\x80\x9cLast night I dreamt I went to Woodstock but I only saw Sha-Na-Na.\xe2\x80\x9d) The dusky London shoegazers Wolf Alice, the British surf-rockers Fat White Family, and the bawdy Irish comedy duo the Rubberbandits round out the new class ably.' b'The success of T2\xe2\x80\x99s soundtrack, and the film itself, lies in its sense of contentment; it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t lobby to be seminal again. It\xe2\x80\x99s as exuberant as its predecessor, with some honest grit flaking against the more mannered sentimentality; it keeps a popular hearth warm and has a kicking, striving spine. To paraphrase an old friend: T2\xe2\x80\x99s still got a great fucking personality.'

column7: b"On his third full-length as Porcelain Raft, Mauro Remiddi continues to put out sumptuous dreampop that's easy to mistake as style over substance."
column8: b'Since he first started putting out solo singles as Porcelain Raft in 2010, former Sunny Day Sets Fire frontman Mauro Remiddi has built a career on an indie/electro/dreampop blend so smooth it often obscures his songwriting gifts. With Microclimate, his third Porcelain Raft full-length, Remiddi grows as a songwriter/arranger while refining the subtlety of his approach. Of course, the problem with subtlety is that it\xe2\x80\x99s not particularly noticeable when you get better at it. So when you compare Microclimate to 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Half Awake EP, 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Permanent Signal, and his 2012 full-length debut Strange Weekend, Remiddi doesn\xe2\x80\x99t appear to be offering much of anything new.' b'Like those previous releases, the sense of space on Microclimate is so vast and full that it\xe2\x80\x99s as if Remiddi and\xc2\xa0mixing engineer Chris Coady meant for the music to be projected across a fluffy cloudscape that stretches for miles. The wide-angle scope of the music can sometimes engulf its central figure, especially as he\xc2\xa0relies more heavily on soft electronic beats and plush reverbs. On skittering numbers like \xe2\x80\x9cDistant Shore\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cKookaburra,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, Remiddi recaptures the vibe of \xe2\x80\x9cWest End Girls\xe2\x80\x9d-era Pet Shop Boys\xe2\x80\x94but it takes multiple listens to notice that he\xe2\x80\x99s managed to do so in his own image.' b'If, say, Remiddi dressed these tunes in stripped-down arrangements centered around piano or acoustic guitar (as he does at the beginning of \xe2\x80\x9cKookaburra\xe2\x80\x9d), the somewhat oddly-shaped relationship between his chord progressions and melodies would occupy center stage. Instead, you get songs like \xe2\x80\x9cRising,\xe2\x80\x9d where the quietly moving parts nearly\xc2\xa0drown in a kind of auditory soup.' b"On the other hand, wading through all the heavy layers of atmosphere to discern the song at the core of each track is one of Microclimate's rewards. Like the last two albums, Microclimate was heavily inspired by locale\xe2\x80\x94this time, the California desert. Remiddi has expressed both a romantic fascination for place and a sense of rootlessness in the past. Lyrically, the new material covers very little new ground with its airbrushed images of distant shores, breezes, trees. For a person who has worked as a circus musician and shaken hands with Kim Jong-un, Remiddi\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics don't disclose much. On \xe2\x80\x9cBig Sur,\xe2\x80\x9d he implores an unspecified person to come \xe2\x80\x9cto another world\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ccome on come on come on this way.\xe2\x80\x9d At the end of the song, he reassures us that \xe2\x80\x9cbefore you know it/all the answers are on the way.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"If the song asked more questions, perhaps the mystery of those answers would be more enticing. And when the album closes with the line \xe2\x80\x9cWe are falling... falling into the sun\xe2\x80\x9d on \xe2\x80\x9cZero Frames Per Second,\xe2\x80\x9d it would be nice to get a better sense for the kind of all-encompassing dissolution Remiddi wants to evoke. Nevertheless, as a pedal steel glimmers like setting sunlight reflecting over ocean waves on \xe2\x80\x9cBig Sur,\xe2\x80\x9d it's virtually impossible not to get nostalgic\xe2\x80\x94even if you've never been to Big Sur. The music on Microclimate can be so potently affecting that the lack of lyrical precision ceases to matter." b'\xe2\x80\x9cMicroclimate\xe2\x80\x9d is the formal term for a set of climatic conditions that apply to a small ecosystem within a larger one. Remiddi chose the title as a way of signaling that he wanted each song to stand apart from the rest. Sure enough, each song pulls you into its own standalone \xe2\x80\x9cworld,\xe2\x80\x9d so to speak. But because Remiddi also sustains an ear-pleasing flow between those songs, it may take a few listens to recognize and appreciate what an artistic success Microclimate actually is.'

column7: b"Black Joe Lewis trawls the familiar intersection of blues, soul, funk, and garage rock, but he's got a few enlivening strategies to make the old formula feel fresh."
column8: b'Black Joe Lewis trawls the intersection of blues, soul, funk, and garage rock\xe2\x80\x94a well-traveled juncture. But he has a few strategies to make this timeworn mixture more tangy on his new album, Backlash. The first is vocal: Lewis can unleash\xc2\xa0a stirring scream, a cauterizing billow of noise that\xe2\x80\x99s sure to flutter your nervous system. The second is compositional: he likes shifting dynamics so that a slack song suddenly stiffens and lashes out, like a horse kicking an inconsiderate handler.' b'That scream, coupled with his heavy reliance on guitars, has earned Lewis comparisons to blues institutions (Muddy Waters), soul shouters (Wilson Pickett), and funk innovators (James Brown). But he prefers a different descriptor. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all about putting on a good show and getting everyone having a good time,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0he said in 2013. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no category for that other than rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99 roll, as far as I know.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Lewis has shed collaborators and labels since releasing his full length debut, Tell \xe2\x80\x99Em What Your Name Is!, in 2009. After a pair of albums produced by Spoon\xe2\x80\x99s Jim Eno on Lost High Way records, he jumped to Vagrant and worked with an almost entirely different band for 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Electric Slave, while Stuart Sikes and John Congleton split duty behinds the boards. He\xe2\x80\x99s back with a similar crew this time\xe2\x80\x94Sikes produced the whole thing\xe2\x80\x94on InGrooves. It\xe2\x80\x99s been nearly three and a half years since the last record: his longest break as a recording artist, and maybe a sign that records don\xe2\x80\x99t matter much if your stage show is an effective good-times machine.' b'In truth, the changes between the second and third album didn\xe2\x80\x99t much alter the music coming out of your speakers, and the same rules apply to Backlash, where the foundation is still a selection of forms at most two degrees removed from the blues. When Lewis adds cement to the beat and irrigates his guitar with fuzz, there\xe2\x80\x99s an outline of the Sonics, or maybe the Black Keys. Snappy rhythms and bright, highly enunciated guitar leads put Lewis in the neighborhood of the New York soul revival labels Daptone and Truth & Soul. There\xe2\x80\x99s an \xe2\x80\x9cuh-ah\xe2\x80\x9d chant that might trace back to Sam Cooke\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cChain Gang\xe2\x80\x9d and female backing vocals that hint at the Sweet Inspirations.' b'You know this material well, and that\xe2\x80\x99s where Lewis\xe2\x80\x99 stand-at-attention strategies come in. He tends to ratchet up the energy just as his songs are ending, like a driver who speeds up to red lights. On \xe2\x80\x9cGlobal,\xe2\x80\x9d he hits you with the first howl just to straighten your spine in the song\xe2\x80\x99s final minute, then wallops you with three of these in a row and adds another one low and far back in the mix for good measure. A comparable moment occurs during the bridge of \xe2\x80\x9cFreakin\xe2\x80\x99 Out,\xe2\x80\x9d where the guitar quivers with enough agitation to merit a song of its own.' b'On \xe2\x80\x9cPrison,\xe2\x80\x9d Lewis generously gives you a 40-second lump of the really rowdy stuff. After a solo, he realigns with his band, and together they clobber their way out of the song with scabrous, cutthroat riffs and a dollop of defiance from Lewis: \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t mind being locked up!\xe2\x80\x9d But seconds later, the track comes to a close. It\xe2\x80\x99s thrilling and enervating at the same time\xe2\x80\x94Lewis gives the briefest glimpse of a supremely raucous affair, then shunts you out of a side door, all dressed up with nowhere to go.'

column7: b'With\xc2\xa0at least 50 albums over three decades, the jazz pianist Matthew Shipp has honed an inherently diverse and exploratory style. He says\xc2\xa0Piano Song will be his final recording.'
column8: b'After making at least 50 albums over the past three decades, pianist Matthew Shipp has decided that *Piano Song *is (probably) his final recording. So it\xe2\x80\x99s tempting to hear it as a definitive statement, perhaps even a career summation. But really, every one of his records could be called definitive. His playing style is so inherently diverse and exploratory that he\xe2\x80\x99s almost incapable of making narrow-sounding music. Even when he sticks to a specific theme or format, his full array of stylistic weapons eventually gets deployed.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s no explicit theme behind *Piano Song. *It\xe2\x80\x99s simply strong, well-considered jazz, with Shipp\xe2\x80\x99s piano leading a thorough dialogue with bassist Michael Bisio and drummer Newman Taylor Baker. In fact, the trio is so comfortably conversational it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to miss how much territory they cover, especially in the beginning. Opening with a slow, somber solo piece, Shipp guides his partners through subtle, subdued tracks that earn names like \xe2\x80\x9cBlue Desert\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSilence Of.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But once the trio launches into \xe2\x80\x9cFlying Carpet,\xe2\x80\x9d with Shipp slamming out portentous chords and Baker pounding snare-bombs in response, Piano Song\xe2\x80\x99s relentless variety becomes crystal clear. The contrast between those heavy sounds and the tune\xe2\x80\x99s calmer passages is thrilling, and it\xe2\x80\x99s one the band revisits in numerous variations throughout the album. On \xe2\x80\x9cMind Space,\xe2\x80\x9d short stretches of quiet energy burst into raucous crescendos, while during \xe2\x80\x9cGravity Point\xe2\x80\x9d furious action cleverly cascades into reflective pauses. The trio can run\xc2\xa0full-throttle for entire tracks, too: In \xe2\x80\x9cMicrowave,\xe2\x80\x9d Shipp\xe2\x80\x99s note clusters twist around Bisio\xe2\x80\x99s stair-stepping bass without few\xc2\xa0gasps of\xc2\xa0breath.' b'The conversations in *Piano Song *feel ongoing, as if we\xe2\x80\x99re merely getting glimpses of a longer, potentially-endless\xc2\xa0back and forth. All three players have an abundance of things to say, and though there\xe2\x80\x99s sufficient space for each, no single recording could really encompass it all. That\xe2\x80\x99s true of most of Shipp\xe2\x80\x99s work, which makes\xc2\xa0his decision to leave the realm of recording disappointing but\xc2\xa0not entirely disheartening. He surely will keep conversing with his piano\xe2\x80\x94he has no plans to stop playing or performing\xe2\x80\x94and if the best venues for that might be something other than albums, he\xe2\x80\x99s earned the right to make that call. Just absorbing\xc2\xa0his discography could take lifetimes as it is, and *Piano Song *is another entry that will reward listening for a long time.'

column7: b'On the new\xc2\xa0EP from Canadian producer Phoeb\xc3\xa9 Guillemot, she\xc2\xa0presents tracks as travelogues and postcards from strange realms, suggestive of old\xc2\xa0Ethnic Folkways Library records.'
column8: b'For the past five years, Canada\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Phoeb\xc3\xa9 Guillemot has been unobtrusively building up a peculiar little soundworld as RAMZi, mostly on small batch cassettes (now available on her Bandcamp page). But over\xc2\xa0the past few years, Guillemot\xe2\x80\x99s profile ticked upwards, with a release on the 1080p label, an eye-melting video, an art collaboration for RVNG Intl., and a full-length on Total Stasis (the label also responsible for Elysia Crampton\xe2\x80\x99s The Light That You Gave Me to See You). She quickly follows all that up with a tantalizing EP for the buzzing Mood Hut imprint. And the more of her music we become privy to, the weirder, wormier, and more immersive that little world becomes.' b'Guillemot\xe2\x80\x99s sound echoes trumpeter/composer Jon Hassell\xe2\x80\x94who, on a\xc2\xa01980 collaborative album with Brian Eno, called Fourth World, Vol. 1: Possible Musics, presented his notion of a \xe2\x80\x9cfourth world\xe2\x80\x9d to listeners. A mix of Western electronics and indigenous sounds, it\xc2\xa0drifted between minimalism, jazz, world music, and ambient, preferring the ether above them all. But Hassell\xe2\x80\x99s sound was exotic in much the same way as the painter Henri Rousseau\xe2\x80\x99s jungle canvases were; they came not from globetrotting, but from introspective imaginings of other cultures. Guillemot is not alone in her ethnographic electronics, as a new generation of producers like Don\xe2\x80\x99t DJ and Andrew Pekler (as well as Oneohtrix Point Never) concoct pretend world rhythms and then twist them into curious new shapes.' b'RAMZi presents her tracks as travelogues and postcards from strange realms; the sleeve designs for last year\xe2\x80\x99s Phobiza Dia: Vol.1 and \xe2\x80\x9cNoite\xe2\x80\x9d Vol. 2 resembled old field recordings. Inside, Guillemot takes on aspects of Ethnic Folkways Library records\xe2\x80\x94foreign voices, animals sounding in the landscape, tribal drumming patterns\xe2\x80\x94and spins them through her circuitry.' b'As the album title playfully alludes, opener \xe2\x80\x9cFor Vanda\xe2\x80\x9d might be the sound of Ibiza right after sunset. Cricket sounds mingle\xc2\xa0with spring gurgles. A synth patch mimicking a bamboo flute echoes a kilometer away and a voice (maybe Guillemot\xe2\x80\x99s own) gets pitched down until it rumbles like a tribal elder. A hand drum enters, as resonant as a heavy stone splashed into a pond. As it all comes together and grows denser, it approximates the environmental moments of the Orb\xe2\x80\x99s Orbus Terrarum.' b'RAMZi\xe2\x80\x99s sounds are tangible and tactile, yet each piece feels slippery as river rocks. Guillemot\xe2\x80\x99s voice slides across \xe2\x80\x9cFuma\xe2\x80\x9d like a little cloud, and soon other altered voices arise and mix with it. With a grounding tabla pattern, \xe2\x80\x9cMessiah\xe2\x80\x9d is\xc2\xa0the most DJ-friendly track on the EP, but RAMZi still makes it feel like it\xe2\x80\x99s floating four inches off the ground. Her whispered exhalations get pitched up until it wavers like a broken spider web. Equally playful is when she slows down her vocals of \xe2\x80\x9cMale heya\xe2\x80\x9d until they resemble a wobbly AutoTuned hook. She then sets it against another gently dubbed out ecosystem, suggesting what Future backpacking through Hassell\xe2\x80\x99s Fourth World might sound like.'

column7: b'Singer-songwriter Julie Byrne\xe2\x80\x99s*\xc2\xa0*new album\xc2\xa0has the lucidity and tactility of a healing crystal. Not unlike Phil Elverum, she\xc2\xa0paints sublime, awestruck moments when simple things become overwhelming.'
column8: b'There are two things you can\xe2\x80\x99t escape: the sky and yourself. It serves us, then, to understand both. Not Even Happiness, the pristine new album from singer-songwriter Julie Byrne, probes cosmic notions such as these with wonder and aplomb. Wanderer, dreamer, naturist, loner, romantic\xe2\x80\x94with her bold fingerpicking and deep voice, Byrne makes these well-worn identities feel newly alive. Not Even Happiness has all the lucidity and tactility of a healing crystal\xe2\x80\x94or more to the point, a rose quartz, the one that might help you to love.' b'Blending folk, new age, and silence, Not Even Happiness is a balm. In both sound and sensibility, it strives for clarity, that ultimate marker of enlightenment. Orchestral arrangements sit subtly in the mix; an occasional flute slides in, or a sample of crashing waves. Byrne solemnly charts the places she\xe2\x80\x99s seen\xe2\x80\x94Kansas, Arkansas, Montana, Wyoming\xe2\x80\x94and fills her lyrics with elemental things. She lies in a \xe2\x80\x9cverdant field,\xe2\x80\x9d catches \xe2\x80\x9cstars from a back porch,\xe2\x80\x9d watches a \xe2\x80\x9cdove over the prairie.\xe2\x80\x9d Her language is diffuse, braiding together themes of autonomy, desire, and struggle, but despite the heft\xc2\xa0of her poetry, the music exudes disarming ease. It feels much shorter than its 33 minutes. Not Even Happiness imagines a cross-section of Leonard Cohen\xe2\x80\x99s mysticism and\xc2\xa0Judee Sill\xe2\x80\x99s vulnerability\xe2\x80\x94like the latter artist, Byrne\xe2\x80\x99s keen pop sense and stacked harmonies play out like wind carrying her along. \xe2\x80\x9cBecause they take themselves lightly, angels can fly,\xe2\x80\x9d the philosopher Alan Watts notes in his book Become What You Are, and Byrne seems to mind this idea sonically.' b'Byrne named her album* Not Even Happiness* because happiness, perhaps, is not always the point. There are virtues beyond happiness\xe2\x80\x94strength, wisdom, integrity, self-possession\xe2\x80\x94and Byrne honors these. Though she is a nomad, she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t romanticize the position; her rootlessness sounds more like a calling, one that chose her, with sacrifices and doubts. \xe2\x80\x9cI have dragged my lives across the country/And wondered if travel led me anywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d Byrne sings on \xe2\x80\x9cI Live Now As a Singer,\xe2\x80\x9d conjuring the sweep of This Mortal Coil\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSong to the Siren.\xe2\x80\x9d She sounds devoted to an inner compass only. On opener \xe2\x80\x9cFollow My Voice,\xe2\x80\x9d Byrne sings, \xe2\x80\x9cI was made for the green, made to be alone,\xe2\x80\x9d and she prioritizes her solitude with a sly turn: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been called heartbreaker/For doing justice to my own.\xe2\x80\x9d Not unlike Phil Elverum, Byrne paints sublime, awestruck moments when simple things become overwhelming. \xe2\x80\x9cWill I know a truer time/Than when I stood alone in the snow,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the moon was in the sky and shone.\xe2\x80\x9d Nearly a capella, she intones, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been seeking God within.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Despite this self-reliance, these are patently love songs, processing the unravelling of a heart sewn shut. The human heart is never easy in a Byrne song, though, by nature of its connection to an active human mind. Byrne knows the difference between solitude and loneliness, and she bears the lessons of the former while endeavoring the enormous task of navigating the latter with dignity. On \xe2\x80\x9cMorning Dove,\xe2\x80\x9d her tone evokes Gillian Welch, as she vividly paints her surroundings\xe2\x80\x94the woods, the endless river\xe2\x80\x94but sweetly admits to trailing off: \xe2\x80\x9cI thought of you so presently,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings. \xe2\x80\x9cI could not wait to tell you the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Gleaming and steadied and wide, \xe2\x80\x9cSleepwalker\xe2\x80\x9d is Not Even Happiness\xe2\x80\x99 most gripping moment. It captures both the infatuated feeling of nascent love and how a dream of life can tempt you to lose control of your own. \xe2\x80\x9cI traveled only in service of my dreams,\xe2\x80\x9d Byrne sings, \xe2\x80\x9cI stood before them all/I was a sleepwalker.\xe2\x80\x9d Few contemporary songwriters earn a comparison to Angel Olsen, but in its acuity and grace\xe2\x80\x94what Leonard Cohen called \xe2\x80\x9cthat kind of balance with which you ride the chaos that you find around you\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Not Even Happiness makes a case for Byrne as one of them.' b'Throughout Not Even Happiness, Byrne sounds like a person who might worship the sky, but the majestic \xe2\x80\x9cNatural Blue\xe2\x80\x9d is a proper ode. There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing particularly unusual about her tale of driving through familiar southwestern towns on tour, but her images evoke the life-affirming feeling of catching the exquisite light just so through a moving car window, while meditating on the changing scenery as it flickers by. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I first saw you/That feeling, it came over me, too/Natural blue,\xe2\x80\x9d Byrne sings. Were \xe2\x80\x9cNatural Blue\xe2\x80\x9d released a decade ago, perhaps the poet Maggie Nelson would have found something in it to include in her 2009 prose-poem Bluets, a radiant reflection on the color. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I was alive, I aimed to be a student not of longing but of light\xe2\x80\x9d goes Bluets\xe2\x80\x99 final sentence, and a similar logic guides Not Even Happiness, in which the most worthy wandering happens on roads within.'

column7: b'Mega Bog is the malleable rock band masterminded by multi-instrumentalist Erin\xc2\xa0Birgy.\xc2\xa0Happy Together flits through a sound that is familiar and far-out, transforming the mundane into jazzy wonderlands.'
column8: b'Mega Bog is the Seattle- and Brooklyn-based band of\xc2\xa0Erin Birgy and her merry crew of players. Together, they have the power to transform the mundane into jazzy wonderlands. The group\xe2\x80\x99s second album, Happy Together, bubbles and abstractly teems without ever feeling excessive. Birgy flits through a sound that is both familiar and far-out. Mega Bog often summon the spirit of David Bowie with enigmatic lyrics and twinges of glam concretely based in guitar music. It\xe2\x80\x99s freaky in the best way.' b'Happy Together begins with a dizzying sensation comparable to tumbling down a rabbit hole. The uneasy spirals\xc2\xa0of\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cBlack Rose\xe2\x80\x9d evoke a soupy free fall into a new reality; the lyrics are equally spooky.\xc2\xa0The supernatural\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cBlackout\xe2\x80\x9d is paradoxically sunny\xe2\x80\x94still a tough nut to crack, but it\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0considerably more inviting. \xe2\x80\x9cMy heads in a bed of improbable palm trees on an ugly, cold Chicago night,\xe2\x80\x9d Birgy\xc2\xa0murmurs, the words dripping\xc2\xa0like\xc2\xa0honey.' b'Above all, Mega Bog\xe2\x80\x99s sound is malleable. Birgy\xe2\x80\x99s vocal character fluctuates from an operatic soprano to a wispy\xc2\xa0sage to a windswept\xc2\xa0Gold Dust Woman.\xc2\xa0The band itself is flexible, with members fading in and out while also working on their own projects. Performers on *Happy Together *include\xc2\xa0the multi-instrumentalists Zach Burba and Will Murdoch of iji (which Birgy has played\xc2\xa0in), Hand Habits guitar virtuoso Meg Duffy (seen recently on tour with Kevin Morby\xe2\x80\x99s band), and Big Thief\xe2\x80\x99s James Krivchenia (who also mixed and mastered the record), among others. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s hyper-sexual, Aquarian music,\xe2\x80\x9d Birgy once said, but rather than collapsing into some sort of Hair style free-love fest, Mega Bog\xe2\x80\x99s shape-shifting is carefully constructed.' b'Take \xe2\x80\x9cDiznee,\xe2\x80\x9d a swirling saxophone showcase that bobs along madly while spouting tongue-teasing lyrics like \xe2\x80\x9cSoda fountain on the fritz/In the ritzy/Underground Billy Goat bar.\xe2\x80\x9d The track is an absolute circus, always\xc2\xa0threatening to spin off its axis, if such a center even exists. The zippy\xc2\xa0dream that concludes \xe2\x80\x9cDiznee\xe2\x80\x9d flings Happy Together into a surrealism that is both sinister (\xe2\x80\x9cLondon\xe2\x80\x9d) and mystical (\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s History\xe2\x80\x9d), but like a disco ball, it always encourages dancing through the darkness.' b'This feels particularly pertinent on the haunted, interstellar \xe2\x80\x9c192014.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cSo when it\xe2\x80\x99s your turn to start working towards the light/And how do you plan on giving me back any of my precious time?,\xe2\x80\x9d Birgy asks\xc2\xa0over spasming saxophones. Speaking of horns, \xe2\x80\x9cDiznee,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9c192014,\xe2\x80\x9d and the sprawling \xe2\x80\x9cWorst Way\xe2\x80\x9d all celebrate the honking saxophone. Whether yelping, screeching, or beeping in joy, Mega Bog\xe2\x80\x99s use of the sax adds a wonderfully freewheeling detail to an already complex mosaic.' b'Then there\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cFwee,\xe2\x80\x9d a Happy Together standout that meditates on inner peace following\xc2\xa0a period of trauma. \xe2\x80\x9cHow could I have known,\xe2\x80\x9d Birgy asks carefully, each word melting like a pad of butter, \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a person out there who means me no harm.\xe2\x80\x9d As Birgy walks through her own realizations, \xe2\x80\x9cFwee\xe2\x80\x9d twists and turns alongside her, weaving spindly guitar through husky \xe2\x80\x9970s harmonies, before finally dissolving into psychedelic chaos at the climax of its lyrical consciousness. \xe2\x80\x9cFwee\xe2\x80\x9d is an outlier on Happy Together, in that it is the most temporal. Its concerns are bodily\xc2\xa0as much as they are mental. Whether\xc2\xa0Happy Together is\xc2\xa0boogieing through a lively cacophony or laying low, Mega Bog never lose sight of the end goal: exploring purity and joy that take a variety of forms but never evaporate.'

column7: b'Former GBV partner and Robert Pollard creative foil Tobin Sprout offers his reliable blend of lo-fi. At his best, he still proves that simplicity doesn\xe2\x80\x99t equate to half-assery.'
column8: b'When you hit play on The Universe and Me, \xe2\x80\x9cFuture Boy Today/Man of Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x9d begins as if the \xe2\x80\x9crecord\xe2\x80\x9d button had been pressed just a hair too late. This creates the sensation that the listener is stumbling in on the music and reinforces the idea that it\xc2\xa0exists\xc2\xa0in a kind of perpetual flow independent of its recorded form. Of course, anyone who is already familiar with Tobin Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s m.o. won\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised. For decades now, Sprout and his longtime on/off collaborator, Guided By Voices leader Robert Pollard, have generated massive piles of songs that they\xe2\x80\x99ve presented as works in progress, parlaying shoeboxes of rough homemade cassette demos into remarkably durable careers.' b"Most known for his work as Guided By Voices\xe2\x80\x99 guitarist for two crucial runs during that band\xe2\x80\x99s long and storied history, Sprout has pretty much been the only additional songwriter GBV has ever had, and the closest to a Lennon-McCartney style foil for Pollard. The duo\xe2\x80\x99s shared sense that production values basically don't matter positions Sprout as one of the key pioneers of the early-\xe2\x80\x9990s lo-fi aesthetic alongside Sebadoh\xe2\x80\x99s Lou Barlow and Pavement founders Stephen Malkmus and Scott \xe2\x80\x9cSpiral Stairs\xe2\x80\x9d Kannberg." b"Almost 30 years later, though, Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s dogged insistence on sticking to his original strategy casts him as the AC/DC of lo-fi rock. If you\xe2\x80\x99re still attached to the scratchiest Guided By Voices efforts that most bear Sprout's creative stamp\xe2\x80\x941993\xe2\x80\x99s Vampire on Titus, \xe2\x80\x9994\xe2\x80\x99s Bee Thousand, and \xe2\x80\x9995\xe2\x80\x99s *Alien Lanes\xe2\x80\x94*then The Universe and Me will likely hit you as both a bold reassertion by an artist saying \xe2\x80\x9cthis is who I am\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0and a sly step towards progress. If not, it will probably sound like more of the same." b'Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s crude recording of piano, for example, drapes a cozy familiarity over the title track. The song\xe2\x80\x99s warm, pleasant ambience also prevents lines like \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take along my wings/So all my dreams can fly\xe2\x80\x9d from tipping over into maudlin confessional. On \xe2\x80\x9cA Walk Across the Human Bridge,\xe2\x80\x9d Sprout wears Bowie\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSuffragette City\xe2\x80\x9d on his sleeve as he offers a way for humankind to avert a future that\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ccarnaged all to waste.\xe2\x80\x9d The ever-economical Sprout devotes but two lines to the verse before introducing the main hook that repeats over and over. You can\xe2\x80\x99t listen without hearing Bowie\xe2\x80\x99s iconic line \xe2\x80\x9cwham-bam, thank you ma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x9d in your head, but you also can\xe2\x80\x99t help but notice that Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s head is in a totally different\xe2\x80\x94and strikingly current\xe2\x80\x94place.' b"At his best, he still proves that simplicity doesn\xe2\x80\x99t equate to half-assery. Still, despite his voluminous output, Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s solo work doesn\xe2\x80\x99t always distinguish his style from Pollard\xe2\x80\x99s. If you\xe2\x80\x99re partial to Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s second tour of duty in GBV\xe2\x80\x94six relatively more developed albums spanning from 2010 to \xe2\x80\x9914\xe2\x80\x94it might be hard to shake the feeling of been-there-done-that as The Universe and Me unfolds in typically haphazard fashion.\xc2\xa0Some of Sprout's choices just come off as downright careless. \xe2\x80\x9cHonor Guard,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, begins with absentminded strums that start out of alignment with the rest of the song, snap into place, and then fall out of sync again\xe2\x80\x94over a drumbeat that\xe2\x80\x99s so unsteady it could have been played by a toddler. Such moves blunt the impact of Sprout\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics, which pop with personality and wisdom." b'When an artist spends an entire career riding the line between resolve\xc2\xa0and stagnation, maybe it\xe2\x80\x99s unfair to take them to task on not changing their tune. By this point, Sprout has made it perfectly clear what he\xe2\x80\x99s going to give us each time. The thing is, The Universe and Me also gives us plenty of indication that Sprout is capable of more. Some minor touch-ups would have gone a long way. Had Sprout tightened a few loose screws here and there, it would have told us more about who he is now.'

column7: b'Jade Lilitri, frontman for Long Island pop/punk outfit Oso Oso, assembles an album-length tribute to \xe2\x80\x9800s indie rock and emo, one style and song at a time.'
column8: b"Jade Lilitri\xe2\x80\x99s latest project has \xe2\x80\x9cmixtape\xe2\x80\x9d in the title, but it is pretty much the opposite of super-mutant strains like\xc2\xa0Coloring Book*\xc2\xa0*or *If You\xe2\x80\x99re Reading This It's Too Late\xe2\x80\x94*expensive-sounding,\xc2\xa0heavily publicized\xc2\xa0albums that have as much in common with an audiobook or an app as they do a mixtape. Oso Oso\xe2\x80\x99s second LP is\xc2\xa0advertised as an album *about *a mixtape, in the old rewind-and-record, Maxell-cassette sense. More accurately, it\xe2\x80\x99s a tribute to the emotional state of mixtape-making: being dumbstruck in love, or simply being dumbstruck by the concept of love, daydreaming the lifespan of an entire relationship and actualizing it within a span of 40 minutes." b'For \xe2\x80\x9900s indie rock fans,* Yunahon Mixtape *can be heard as a seamless Since I Left You-style collage borne from college radio crate digging between 2001-2004.\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s a veritable Easter egg hunt for brisk, Barsuk-era Death Cab for Cutie melodies, and the appropriately titled and panoramic \xe2\x80\x9cGreat Big Beaches\xe2\x80\x9d stages\xc2\xa0a misty-eyed, full-hearted reshoot of \xe2\x80\x9cCath\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d Elsewhere, Lilitri steps outside of classic emo to practice the fastidious, ship-in-a-bottle complexity of the Shins (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Secret Spot\xe2\x80\x9d), Built to Spill\xe2\x80\x99s anxious prog-pop (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Bearer of the Truths\xe2\x80\x9d) and the walking-wounded blues\xc2\xa0of Spoon (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Slope\xe2\x80\x9d).' b'But prior to starting Oso Oso, Lilitri played as State Lines, a\xc2\xa0Long Island emo outfit\xc2\xa0that demonstrated an endearingly fervent\xc2\xa0dedication to bringing a certain kind of late-90s New York back in the 2010s. Oso Oso\xe2\x80\x99s 2015 debut\xc2\xa0sounded like someone trying to deconstruct pop-punk,*\xc2\xa0*but it appears in its purest form on *The Yunahon Mixtape, *as a secret weapon: when things threaten to get too fastidious on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Walk,\xe2\x80\x9d the second half breaks into a mad dash, while \xe2\x80\x9cShoes (The Sneaker Song)\xe2\x80\x9d follows \xe2\x80\x9cGreat Big Beaches\xe2\x80\x9d with a four-minute mile.' b'Lilitri is as much of a student of his influences as he is a fan, understanding the exact methods that make the sound of this music hit a certain way at a certain age and linger in the years to come. This is music that reflects a mood more often than it sets one, and the coherence of Oso Oso\xe2\x80\x99s influences allows the emotional tenor to shift wildly without upsetting the flow, from drumming up the confidence to act on a crush, putting feelings\xc2\xa0out in the open, and the subsequent vertigo of awaiting reciprocation.\xc2\xa0Lilitri played everything but drums here, and the stacked harmonies and call-and-response actually enhance its insularity in a meaningful way: most mixtapes are conceptualized long before they hit the reels.' b'Whereas State Lines or even the first Oso Oso album had the pinched sound of teen melodrama, *The Yunahon Mixtape *is pure romantic comedy: meet-cutes, playful misunderstandings, inside jokes and the acoustic midpoint where three minutes apart feels like an eternity. And like most entries in this realm,\xc2\xa0Yunahon allows itself clich\xc3\xa9 as an indulgence; the very first line plays on \xe2\x80\x9cfalling in love\xe2\x80\x9d as a physical pratfall and \xe2\x80\x9cShoes (The Sneaker Song)\xe2\x80\x9d proudly wields its uber-emo sentiments.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s enough acidity to keep it from getting too cloying, enough specifics to keep it grounded, enough humor to make everyone feel like co-conspirators playing hooky from realistic interactions. All of this makes *The Yunahon Mixtape *a realization of its ambitions and completely out of step on numerous fronts. It\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0understandable if the current state of affairs has completely sapped your ambition to have your head in the clouds, but damn if *The Yunahon Mixtape *doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make a good argument for getting on Lilitri\xe2\x80\x99s level.'

column7: b'In this gripping song cycle, the vocalist-pianist M. Lamar pairs\xc2\xa0with Liturgy\xe2\x80\x99s Hunter Hunt-Hendrix to explore the tradition of African-American spirituals, mixing\xc2\xa0ideas from folk, opera, and metal.'
column8: b'In the landmark 1963 book Blues People, a critic and poet then going by the name LeRoi Jones quoted some scholarly writing that placed the \xe2\x80\x9cblack Christian spiritual\xe2\x80\x9d in a tradition of African melody. He also described how songs created by American slaves were \xe2\x80\x9csuperficially modeled\xe2\x80\x9d on white hymns. Despite the mutual influences, Jones argued that \xe2\x80\x9cthe Negro\xe2\x80\x99s religious music was his original creation, and the spirituals themselves were probably the first completely native American music the slaves made.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Drawing a line toward 20th century popular music, Jones wrote that the blues \xe2\x80\x9cissued directly from the shout, and, of course, the spiritual.\xe2\x80\x9d But his more original claim concerned the way each new form reshaped the American mainstream, in turn. According to Jones, this phenomenon demanded of black artists a consistent reinvention of performance styles, in order to avoid the marketplace \xe2\x80\x9coverexposure\xe2\x80\x9d of past innovations.' b'With Funeral Doom Spiritual, the male soprano M. Lamar has pulled off another one of these stylistic escapes from all the previous, expected forms. And he has done so in a way that Jones might well have appreciated: by grabbing and juxtaposing vocal-production ideas from folk lamentation, European opera, and contemporary metal. This odd mix isn\xe2\x80\x99t the product of an ironic mindset. Lamar is clearly aware, and respectful, of more typical approaches to the African-American religious songbook\xe2\x80\x94including those by operatic sopranos. Though he also knows that exploration is part of the spiritual tradition, too.' b'Alongside electronic textures composed by Liturgy frontman Hunter Hunt-Hendrix, Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s vocals and pianism reframe the lyrics to some well-known numbers (such as \xe2\x80\x9cLay This Body Down\xe2\x80\x9d). And he ventures some new spirituals, as well. The hour-long song cycle is conceptually coherent and dramatically gripping\xe2\x80\x94especially when Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s singing moves between stark exhalations of doom and soprano lines that are full of vibrato.' b'The power of this shocking transition is communicated during the album\xe2\x80\x99s overture, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Demon Rising.\xe2\x80\x9d Early on in the track, Hunt-Hendrix\xe2\x80\x99s electronic part supplies steady percussive explosions that amount to a slow beat. Lamar pounds on the low end of a Bosendorfer piano, and sing-sighs in tones of gravelly menace. Then, as Lamar moves up the keyboard, his vocals swoop up in pitch, to the top of his range.' b'At this point, the singer-pianist still hasn\xe2\x80\x99t uttered a word. Though the work\xe2\x80\x99s emotional progression has been previewed: after starting from a vantage of bleakest desolation, a more beautiful resilience comes into view. But forgetfulness is not part of the journey. Even as it anticipates some form of rebirth, Funeral Doom Spiritual holds fast to an awareness of racial injustice and physical violence.' b'The lyrics\xe2\x80\x99 potency comes from their broad applicability, across American history. On early listens, I often wondered whether a refrain like \xe2\x80\x9cI carry your coffin on my back\xe2\x80\x9d was plucked from a vintage spiritual, or from a first-person lament related to a contemporary tragedy. The fact that the question can be asked justifies the pallor that hangs over the album, as well as the more abrasive textures in its electronic arrangement.' b'While the tempos and harmonies remain fairly static, the arrangements contain subtle shifts that make outsized impacts. On \xe2\x80\x9cThey Took You From Me,\xe2\x80\x9d as Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s voice rises to a peak of indignation (on the word \xe2\x80\x9cguilty\xe2\x80\x9d), the texture of Hunt-Hendrix\xe2\x80\x99s electronics undergoes a change. What was once a drone now becomes bell-like and sparkling\xe2\x80\x94akin to what might result if Oneohtrix Point Never were to interpret the music of Arvo P\xc3\xa4rt. The sense of release, here, works as an ideal sonic accompaniment for the catharsis embedded in Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s judgment, and his casting of a demon\xe2\x80\x99s curse.' b'Funeral Doom Spiritual also exists as a work for the stage. That ritualized production recently appeared at New York\xe2\x80\x99s Prototype festival, which focuses on new operas (both traditional and experimental in nature). When performed there, the piece featured a string section arranged by Hunt-Hendrix, in addition to Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s singer-pianist role. I thought it was a captivating show\xe2\x80\x94particularly given Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s post-apocalyptic, diva costuming. Still, some of the transitions between songs were ragged. On the album, a few of Hunt-Hendrix\xe2\x80\x99s string harmony ideas have been preserved, most noticeably on the electronic portion of the track \xe2\x80\x9cCarrying.\xe2\x80\x9d Overall, the studio recording\xe2\x80\x99s more consistent precision makes this version of Spiritual an ideal way to encounter Lamar\xe2\x80\x99s radical innovations.'

column7: b'Homogenic embraced all of Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s most provocative contradictions. The main theme is the wish to rush headlong into a life lived to the fullest\xe2\x80\x94an unbridled yearning for the sublime.'
column8: b'Robed in silver satin, luminous against iridescent grey, Bj\xc3\xb6rk stares out as us from the cover of Homogenic. Filigreed flowers crawl across the background like frost crystals, mimicking the embroidery on her gown. The Alexander McQueen-designed garment looks vaguely Japanese, with a kimono-like sash; her elongated neck is wrapped in rings reminiscent of those worn by tribes in Burma and South Africa, while her pursed, painted lips smack of Pierrot. Behind narrowed lids, her eyes glaze like camera lenses. The longer you stare into those enormous black pupils, the more adrift you begin to feel. Beneath two tombstone-shaped slabs of hair, she appraises us coldly, her expression unreadable. She might as well be made of wax\xe2\x80\x94or marble.' b'After the dewy naturalism of Debut\xe2\x80\x99s sepia-toned portrait and the bullet-train rush of Post\xe2\x80\x99s blurry postcard from the edge, McQueen and Nick Knight\xe2\x80\x99s *Homogenic *cover showed Bj\xc3\xb6rk in a way viewers had never seen her before: at once ancient and futuristic, elegant and severe, part warrior queen and part cyborg\xe2\x80\x94a picture of near-perfect symmetry rendered in colors of ice and obsidian and blood. The album followed suit. Trading the playful eclecticism of *Debut *and *Post *for distorted, hardscrabble electronic drums and warm, melancholy strings, it showcased a newly focused side of the musician while embracing all of her most provocative contradictions.' b"By 1997, when she released Homogenic, Bj\xc3\xb6rk had been a familiar face to pop fans for a decade. The Icelandic singer and composer had first appeared on many listeners\xe2\x80\x99 radars in 1987, when the Sugarcubes\xe2\x80\x99 surprise hit \xe2\x80\x9cBirthday\xe2\x80\x9d made actual stars out of a quintet whose entire raison d'\xc3\xaatre had been to lampoon pop. (Her countrymen, meanwhile, had been listening to her since 1977, when she recorded her debut album\xe2\x80\x94a collection of covers translated into Icelandic along with a few original songs, including an instrumental written by Bj\xc3\xb6rk herself\xe2\x80\x94 at the tender age of 11.)" b'After a few whirlwind years with the band, she struck\xc2\xa0out on her own with 1993\xe2\x80\x99s Debut, enlisting Nellee Hooper of Soul II Soul and Massive Attack to co-produce the album. It was a clean break, trading the Sugarcubes\xe2\x80\x99 jangly alt-rock for the electronic sounds then coming out of the UK: house beats and basslines, trip-hop atmospheres, and the rippling textures of experimental techno, which she fleshed out with orchestral strings, big-band jazz, and a smattering of world music. Surprising even her record label, which scrambled to manufacture enough records to keep up with demand, it went all the way to No. 3 on the UK albums chart. On this side of the pond, some listeners were less thrilled with her new, electronic direction: Rolling Stone carped that Hooper had \xe2\x80\x9csabotaged a\nferociously iconoclastic talent with a phalanx of cheap electronic gimmickry,\xe2\x80\x9d adding, \xe2\x80\x9cBj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s singular skills cry out for genuine band chemistry, and instead she gets Hooper\xe2\x80\x99s Euro art-school schlock.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"Bj\xc3\xb6rk paid no heed to critics (including fellow Sugarcube \xc3\x9e\xc3\xb3r Eldon, now also her ex-husband) who were dismissive of her burgeoning interest in electronic music. Moving from Iceland to London, she threw herself into UK dance music, soaking up its club culture and collaborating with 808 State\xe2\x80\x99s Graham Massey, Tricky, Howie B, and Talvin Singh, among others. She may have come to electronic music as an outsider, but she had good instincts: For remixes, she avoided the usual suspects in favor of some of the most adventurous artists on the scene: the Black Dog, Andrew Weatherall\xe2\x80\x99s Sabres of Paradise, the junglist Dillinja, even Mika Vainio, aka \xc3\x98, of Finland\xe2\x80\x99s scorched-earth analog noiseniks Pan Sonic. Today, the material gathered on her early remix collections\xe2\x80\x941996\xe2\x80\x99s *Telegram *and also the lesser-known, cleverly (if not at all succinctly) titled The Best Mixes From the Album Debut for All the People Who Don't Buy White-Labels\xe2\x80\x94holds up far better than the vast majority of remixes from that era, keenly balancing the songs\xe2\x80\x99 essences with a restless experimental spirit." b'Part of that is because Bj\xc3\xb6rk never saw remixes as a simple marketing gimmick: Her youthful study of classical music had taught her to think of remixes as a contemporary iteration of the longstanding concept of theme-and-variations. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I think of that word remix, it\xe2\x80\x99s recycled, like trash,\xe2\x80\x9d she told Rolling Stone. \xe2\x80\x9cBut for me, the word remix means \xe2\x80\x98alternative version.\xe2\x80\x99 It is just another word\xe2\x80\xa6 for a variation. It\xe2\x80\x99s like Bach\xe2\x80\x94his symphonies were not completely written out so every time he played them, they would be different.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s unconventional instincts and her keen understanding of the hidden links between classical and experimental electronic music\xe2\x80\x94she had interviewed Stockhausen the year before, in fact\xe2\x80\x94guided her on Homogenic, as strange and uncompromising an album as pop music has produced. From the album\xe2\x80\x99s opening bars, it\xe2\x80\x99s clear that she\xe2\x80\x99s on to something new. Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s approach to electronic music had never been conventional, but it had generally been tuneful, and her beats tended to keep one foot tapping in time to house music\xe2\x80\x99s reassuring thump. Not so \xe2\x80\x9cHunter,\xe2\x80\x9d which bobs atop fluttering, fibrillating kicks and snares, its reversed accordion glistening like an oil slick. Aphex Twin had toured as Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s opener after Post, and you can hear his rhythmic influence across the album: in the filtered breakbeats of \xe2\x80\x9cJ\xc3\xb3ga,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBachelorette,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c5 Years\xe2\x80\x9d; the resonant zaps of \xe2\x80\x9cAll Neon Like\xe2\x80\x9d; and the buzzing, headlong stomp of \xe2\x80\x9cPluto.\xe2\x80\x9d (The engineer Markus Dravs assisted in the beat-making, as did LFO\xe2\x80\x99s Mark Bell, who co-produced much of the album.) Throughout, drums crunch and sizzle, throwing up little clouds of dust with every impact. And with the exception of the relatively frictionless skip of \xe2\x80\x9cAlarm Call,\xe2\x80\x9d her beats are far more kinetic than most programmed rhythms, twitching and flexing like fistfuls of cellophane curling open.' b'After the stylistic zigzags of her first two albums, Bj\xc3\xb6rk was determined to create something more focused.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThis is more like one flavor,\xe2\x80\x9d she told SPIN of the album. \xe2\x80\x9cMe in one state of mind. One period of obsessions. That\xe2\x80\x99s why I called it Homogenic.\xe2\x80\x9d The working title, in fact, was Homogenous. The Icelandic String Octet, performing Eumir Deodato\xe2\x80\x99s arrangements along with string parts she had written herself, was the glue that held it all together. The result is a strange, captivating mix of impulses, with seesawing drones exploding into lush, neo-classical passages. You can hear the influence of the Estonian minimalist Arvo P\xc3\xa4rt, whom Bj\xc3\xb6rk had interviewed for the BBC the year before, on the slow, elegiac string harmonies of \xe2\x80\x9cUnravel\xe2\x80\x9d; conversely, the cut-up harp and strings of \xe2\x80\x9cAll Is Full of Love\xe2\x80\x9d faintly mimic the burbling pulses of Steve Reich\xe2\x80\x99s Music for 18 Musicians. \xe2\x80\x9cEven though my arrangements are quite experimental, I\xe2\x80\x99m very conservative when it comes to song structure,\xe2\x80\x9d she told SPIN. \xe2\x80\x9cSo it\xe2\x80\x99s this beautiful relationship between complete discipline and complete freedom."' b'Many artists have attempted to fuse dance music\xe2\x80\x99s rhythms with classical instrumentation; recently, between events like Ha\xc3\xa7ienda Classical (a pops take on the hallowed Manchester dance-music institution) and Pete Tong and the Heritage Orchestra\xe2\x80\x99s Ibiza Classics, the concept seems resurgent. But endeavors like those, and even Jeff Mills\xe2\x80\x99 more highbrow attempts at orchestral techno, nearly always fail; it turns out that DIY electronic dance music and classical orchestras, a format that has barely evolved in over 100 years, are largely incompatible. Bj\xc3\xb6rk succeeded where so many others have failed by weaving the two inextricably together into an undulating fabric as flexible and as durable as Kevlar, processing the strings until it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to tell where the silicon ends and the catgut begins.
