You can hear the influence she exerted upon a young Alejandro Ghersi, aka Arca, who would go on to collaborate with her on 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Vulnicura; his own music\xe2\x80\x99s viscous textures and mutating forms would be unthinkable without the example set by Homogenic.' b'Blanketing the album\xe2\x80\x99s electronic elements like a heavy layer of snow, Homogenic\xe2\x80\x99s strings give the album a somewhat monochrome palette; it\xe2\x80\x99s a dense listen, and in songs like \xe2\x80\x9cJ\xc3\xb3ga\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBachelorette\xe2\x80\x9d there\xe2\x80\x99s not a lot of breathing room. But those rolling, subtly shaded contours periodically give way to jagged crags and extreme contrasts. This was not accidental: The album was meant as a kind of sound-portrait of her native Iceland. Bj\xc3\xb6rk envisioned beats \xe2\x80\x9clike rough volcanoes with soft moss growing all over it,\xe2\x80\x9d recalls Markus Dravs, whose percussive sketches formed the rhythmic foundation for her songwriting. \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted *Homogenic *to reflect where I\xe2\x80\x99m from, what I\xe2\x80\x99m about,\xe2\x80\x9d Bj\xc3\xb6rk told MTV. \xe2\x80\x9cImagine if there was Icelandic techno! Iceland is one of the youngest countries geographically\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s still in the making, so the sounds would be still in the making.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Many of Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s collaborators over the years have discussed her tendency to describe music in unusually synaesthetic terms: Despite her intensive formal schooling in music\xe2\x80\x94she began studying music at five, and was introduced to the work of modernist composers like Messiaen and Cage while still very young\xe2\x80\x94her studio vocabulary, when she\xe2\x80\x99s trying to get a point across, leans toward terms like \xe2\x80\x9cmore angular\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cpink and fluffy.\xe2\x80\x9d So it\xe2\x80\x99s hardly surprising that she would take formal inspiration from Iceland\xe2\x80\x99s steaming geysers, igneous formations, and other geological features that lend themselves especially well to the visceral textures and rhythms of late-\xe2\x80\x9990s electronica.' b'But there were also more personal reasons for her shift of focus.\xc2\xa0After years in London, she had become homesick for the land of her birth. She had traded a country with a population of fewer than 265,000 people for a city of some six million; not only that, she had been through hell and back in the years leading up to the album\xe2\x80\x99s creation. A string of relationships with high-profile artists\xe2\x80\x94the photographer Stephane Sednaoui, Tricky, jungle producer Goldie\xe2\x80\x94had all fizzled. A physical altercation with a journalist outside Bangkok\xe2\x80\x99s international airport had landed her in tabloids all around the world. And in September, 1996, a 21-year-old Miami pest control worker named Ricardo Lopez, furious about her relationship with Goldie\xe2\x80\x94unbeknownst to him, they had actually broken up just days before\xe2\x80\x94assembled a sulfuric acid bomb in a hollowed-out book and mailed it to Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s management before locking himself in his apartment, putting a loaded revolver in his mouth, and pulling the trigger, all in front of a video camera while Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI Remember You\xe2\x80\x9d played in the background. Police managed to intercept the device with no further casualties, but Bj\xc3\xb6rk was left shaken\xe2\x80\x94concerned for her ability to protect those closest to her, including her son, and conflicted about her own openness with her fans. Returning to Iceland for the Christmas holidays, as she did every year, she fell under the island\xe2\x80\x99s sway. Inspired by the country\xe2\x80\x99s landscape, she became determined to make music that expressed a geological essence that was as raw as her own nerves.' b'You don\xe2\x80\x99t need to know any of these details to connect with Homogenic, however; its emotional impact far transcends the biographical footnotes of its making. Lyrically, the record picks up themes she had already explored on her previous two albums\xe2\x80\x94loneliness; sexual desire; desperate, even defiant love; the feeling of being a fish out of water\xe2\x80\x94but her writing is more vivid than ever before. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a fountain of blood/In the shape of a girl,\xe2\x80\x9d she bellows in \xe2\x80\x9cBachelorette,\xe2\x80\x9d and later, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a path of cinders/Burning under your feet.\xe2\x80\x9d The song is a kind of epic saga, and Bj\xc3\xb6rk has explained that it forms the third part of a loose trilogy with \xe2\x80\x9cHuman Behaviour\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cIsobel\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a sort of Bildungsroman about Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s own adventures in the wider world.' b'Many lyrics take place as internal monologues grappling with her own contradictions. \xe2\x80\x9cHow Scandinavian of me!\xe2\x80\x9d she yelps on \xe2\x80\x9cHunter,\xe2\x80\x9d a desperate ode to self-empowerment, chiding herself for having believed she could \xe2\x80\x9corganize freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d (To Icelandic people, she later explained, Swedes and Danes are hopelessly regimented.) The distorted, minor-key \xe2\x80\x9c5 Years\xe2\x80\x9d is lovelorn and angry\xe2\x80\x94for anyone who has ever been stuck in a dysfunctional relationship, is there a more relatable lyric than \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t handle love\xe2\x80\x9d?\xe2\x80\x94while \xe2\x80\x9cImmature\xe2\x80\x9d channels broken-heartedness into a kind of empowering self-reprimand (\xe2\x80\x9cHow could I be so immature/To think he could replace/The missing elements in me?/How extremely lazy of me!\xe2\x80\x9d). Despite the self-flagellation, it\xe2\x80\x99s a quiet, tender song, with a beat carved out of a sigh; its twinkling arpeggios sound like a dry run for Vespertine.' b'When love turns up on this album, it is almost always something that is over or absent\xe2\x80\x94a missed signal, a sailed ship. But she makes real poetry out of these small, bitter tragedies, and she occasionally even finds hope in them. In the soft, delicate \xe2\x80\x9cUnravel,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings of her heart unraveling like a ball of yarn while her lover is away. The Devil promptly steals it: \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99ll never return it/So when you come back/We\xe2\x80\x99ll have to make new love,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, in a strangely affecting conceit about the fickleness and resilience of love.' b'But the main theme running through the album is the wish to rush headlong into a life lived to the fullest\xe2\x80\x94an unbridled yearning for the sublime. \xe2\x80\x9cState of emergency/Is where I want to be\xe2\x80\x9d she sings on \xe2\x80\x9cJ\xc3\xb3ga,\xe2\x80\x9d a song dedicated to her close friend and tour masseuse, in which churning breakbeats and slowly bowed strings mediate between lava flows and Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s own musculature\xe2\x80\x94a kind of Rosetta Stone linking geology and the heart. \xe2\x80\x9cAlarm Call,\xe2\x80\x9d the closest thing on the album to a club hit (the Alan Braxe and Ben Diamond remix, in fact, is a storming breakbeat house anthem) shouts down doubt with the indomitable line, \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t say no to hope/Can\xe2\x80\x99t say no to happiness,\xe2\x80\x9d as Bj\xc3\xb6rk professes her desire to climb a mountain \xe2\x80\x9cwith a radio and good batteries\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cFree the human race/ From suffering.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'If you\xe2\x80\x99re looking for catharsis, you won\xe2\x80\x99t find better than the album\xe2\x80\x99s final, three-song stretch: Following \xe2\x80\x9cAlarm Call\xe2\x80\x9d comes the incensed \xe2\x80\x9cPluto\xe2\x80\x9d:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me/But I just have to/Explode/Explode this body off me,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, launching into an ascending procession of wordless howls as buzzing synthesizers flash like emergency beacons. Finally, the quiet after the storm: The soft, beatless \xe2\x80\x9cAll Is Full of Love,\xe2\x80\x9d a downy bed of harp and processed strings. The title is self-explanatory, the lyrics wide-eyed, nearly liturgical. It is a song about ecstasy, about oneness, about infinite possibility\xe2\x80\x94and about letting go.' b'Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s voice is, without question, the life force of this music. You can hear her finding a new confidence on \xe2\x80\x9cUnravel\xe2\x80\x9d: The edge of her voice is as jagged as the lid of a tin can, her held tones as slick as black ice. A diligent student could try to transcribe her vocals the way jazz obsessives used to notate Charlie Parker\xe2\x80\x99s solos, and you\xe2\x80\x99d still come up short; the physical heft and malleability of her voice outstrips language.' b'Videos had long been an important part of Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s work, but they became especially crucial in building out the world of Homogenic. Compared to the sprawling list of collaborators on her first two records, she had pared down to a skeleton crew for this album; working with an array of different directors, though, allowed her to amplify her creative vision.' b'Chris Cunningham used \xe2\x80\x9cAll Is Full of Love\xe2\x80\x9d as the springboard for a tender, and erotic, look at robot love. Michel Gondry turned \xe2\x80\x9cBachelorette\xe2\x80\x9d into a meta-narrative about Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s own conflicted relationship with fame\xe2\x80\x94an epic saga turned into a set of Russian nesting dolls. Another Gondry video, for \xe2\x80\x9cJ\xc3\xb3ga,\xe2\x80\x9d used CGI\xc2\xa0to force apart tectonic plates and reveal the earth\xe2\x80\x99s glowing mantle below. At the end of the video, Bj\xc3\xb6rk stands on a rock promontory, prying open a hole in her chest\xe2\x80\x94a pre-echo of the vulvic opening she will wear on the cover of Vulnicura\xe2\x80\x94to reveal the Icelandic landscape dwelling inside her. In Paul White\xe2\x80\x99s video for \xe2\x80\x9cHunter,\xe2\x80\x9d a shaven-headed Bj\xc3\xb6rk sprouts strange, digital appendages, eventually turning into an armored polar bear, as she flutters her lids and wildly contorts her expression\xe2\x80\x94a vision of human emotion as liquid mercury.\xc2\xa0Her use of different versions of her songs for several of these videos also contributed to the idea that the work was larger than any one recording\xe2\x80\x94that these songs were boundless.' b'Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s initial idea for Homogenic was to be an unusual experiment in stereo panning. She imagined using just strings and beats and voice\xe2\x80\x94strings in the left channel, beats in the right channel, and the voice in the middle.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s kind of a genius idea: an interactive, self-remixable album, a sort of one-disc Zaireeka, that goes to the heart of the dichotomies that have always made Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x94theorist and dreamer, daughter of a hippie activist and a union electrician\xe2\x80\x94such a dynamic character. And while it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see why the concept never came to fruition\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s no way such a gimmick could have yielded an album as richly layered as Homogenic turned out to be\xe2\x80\x94it turns out to have been a prescient idea: the direct antecedent to Vulnicura Strings, which excised the drums and electronic elements of *Vulnicura *and focused on voice and strings alone.' b'In retrospect, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see the way that Homogenic paves the way for later career triumphs like Vespertine and Vulnicura: In its formal audacity and sustained emotional intensity, it represents a phase shift from *Debut *and Post, fine though they were. Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s personality has seen her seesaw between extremes throughout her catalog, and after the shadowy intensity of Homogenic, Vespertine would end up a softer, gentler record. (Bj\xc3\xb6rk has said that she envisions \xe2\x80\x9cAll Is Full of Love\xe2\x80\x9d as \xe2\x80\x9cthe first song on Vespertine.\xe2\x80\x9d) Created in the glow of her nascent relationship with Matthew Barney, it is the domestic album, the comfort album, the beach-house-weekend album. But *Homogenic *is the one that complicated the picture of Bj\xc3\xb6rk, that threw aside big-time sensuality in favor of more volatile forces, revealed a glimpse of her deepest self for the first time.'

column7: b'This 17-track compilation on XL Recordings offers\xc2\xa0a snapshot of the new generation of London\xe2\x80\x99s rappers, singers, and dancehall kings.'
column8: b'You can find the beating heart of the U.K. rap underground online, somewhere among the thousands of kids desperately spitting bars on YouTube in hopes of getting noticed. On channels like SBTV, Link Up TV, and GRM Daily, no-name rappers spit (mostly written) rhymes for \xe2\x80\x9cfreestyle\xe2\x80\x9d competitions, battling for relevance in a digital Hunger Games for the chance to be anointed as the next Stormzy or Skepta.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s from this pool of hopefuls\xc2\xa0that New Gen was born; at first, as a showcase for promising talent stymied by London police\xe2\x80\x99s aggressive targeting of rap shows, and later as an Sunday afternoon radio show on Radar Radio. The latest incarnation is a compilation of original songs on XL Recordings, a 17-track album meant to be a snapshot of the new generation of London\xe2\x80\x99s rappers, singers, and dancehall kings. Grime is still the city\xe2\x80\x99s most famous urban musical export, but the youngest members of the U.K. scene seem less concerned with subgenre\xe2\x80\x94on New Gen, you\xe2\x80\x99ll hear garage, dancehall, reggae, and R&B singers alongside the grime and hip-hop MCs, the lines bleeding between each without regard for the old guard\xe2\x80\x99s gatekeeping.' b"New Gen is the brainchild of Caroline SM, a GRM Daily editor that had found success breaking rappers on the site\xe2\x80\x99s YouTube channel. Barely in her 20s, she's worn many hats: editor (GRM Daily), host (NewGenRadio), A&R (XL Recordings), executive producer (the New Gen LP), and artist manager (Bonkaz and J Hus, who each signed to Sony in 2015 and 2016, respectively). As much as any of the New Gen rappers, she\xe2\x80\x99s carving her own role in the industry, with each gig feeding exposure and opportunity to the other, vertically integrating A&R, production, management and publicity under one brand. Though her sole appearance on the comp is to intro Kojey Radical\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cFuck Your Feelings,\xe2\x80\x9d in effect, New Gen is her debut album." b'But it\xe2\x80\x99s the producers that keep New Gen from simply being a collection of hard YouTube bars. Seeking to mimic the creative energy of production camps like Rick Rubin\xe2\x80\x99s Malibu retreat or Kanye\xe2\x80\x99s Hawaii sessions for My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, Caroline SM and her fellow executive producer, the MC Renz, recruited Jevon, Nyge, and Soul\xc2\xa0to handle all the production duties, with artists popping in and out of different rooms at Red Bull\xe2\x80\x99s studios in London. The three manage to weave a handful of styles from hungry artists with varying dialects into a cohesive statement, from the sinister synths on the opening track (Avelino & Bonkaz\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWelcome to the New Gen\xe2\x80\x9d) to bouncy R&B (Ray BLK\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBusy\xe2\x80\x9d), to a tasteful sample of Nina Simone\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSinnerman\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cMan of the Hour\xe2\x80\x9d), somber King Krule-ish guitar tones (\xe2\x80\x9cLife Support\xe2\x80\x9d), or a dancehall spin on the Atlanta strip club sound (\xe2\x80\x9cMoney Haffi Mek\xe2\x80\x9d). It\xe2\x80\x99s no small feat.' b'Like a lot of U.K. hip-hop, New Gen may require a bit of lyrical decoding for an American audience; even if you\xe2\x80\x99re familiar with the various Caribbean patois and know that \xe2\x80\x9cMoney Haffi Mek\xe2\x80\x9d means \xe2\x80\x9cmoney to be made,\xe2\x80\x9d there\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of British slang that requires translation. Despite this, you might be able to deduce what AJ Tracey means when brags that he\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cstill got these yatties up in my gaf,\xe2\x80\x9d or the \xe2\x80\x9cskengs in the rides\xe2\x80\x9d on 67\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cJackets\xe2\x80\x9d are weapons meant for nefarious purposes. The dialect may be different, but the tried-and-true topics of sex, haters, and violence are apparently universal.' b"Among all the artists featured on the compilation, Avelino & Bonkaz stand out as the most polished talents. Avelino, a 23-year-old from Tottenham, has three\xc2\xa0mixtapes and the EP F.Y.O. under his belt, while Bonkaz, the latest MC out of the South London town of Croydon (Krept and Konan, Stormzy, A2, Section Boys), is in the second year of a deal with Sony Music. Their tag-team on the LP\xe2\x80\x99s first track is an opening salvo, a two-minute barrage of lyrical punches that never quite gets topped: \xe2\x80\x9cA: Welcome to the New Gen/B: Funny how sometimes the new friends can be the real friends/A: You should mind your business, I know dragons in a few dens/B: It's like a whole family camping, them niggas too tense.\xe2\x80\x9d" b'New Gen feels like a proof of concept\xe2\x80\x94that given the means and opportunity, these YouTube warriors can create work worthy of coming back to. For curious Americans who\xe2\x80\x99ve only just heard of Skepta and Stormzy, it\xe2\x80\x99s a preview of the artists in the London underground most likely to break through, cheesing at future MOBO Awards, taking down trophies (New Gen artists WSTRN & Abra Cadabra were already honored at the 2016 edition in November). And while a cynic might see New Gen as merely a reflection of Caroline SM and Renz\xe2\x80\x99s taste and grassroots network; an optimist might say it\xe2\x80\x99s an underground scene collectivizing for its mutual benefit. Nevertheless, it\xe2\x80\x99s one of the more impressive collections of underground talent of late.'

column7: b'The hard-bitten and prolific Sacramento rapper Mozzy shifts slightly to accessibility on his first album of 2017. YG, Jadakiss,and G-Eazy are featured.'
column8: b'The title of Mozzy\xe2\x80\x99s latest album, Fake Famous, is ambiguous. The Sacramento rapper\xe2\x80\x99s star has certainly risen. He followed his prolific 2015 with an even more active 2016. YouTube hits for his\xc2\xa0music videos traffic in the millions. He\xe2\x80\x99s recently appeared on releases from E-40 and Rihanna favorite Boogie. And his first album of 2017, Fake Famous, features YG, Jadakiss, and actual pop star G-Eazy. So is Mozzy fake famous or just famous? Better yet, does he want to be? The album\xe2\x80\x99s compactness and consistency speak to Mozzy\xe2\x80\x99s pop sensibilities, but its heavy tones and themes suggest that he has more on his mind than stardom; maybe he just hopes to earn greater renown on his own terms.' b'Mozzy\xe2\x80\x99s greatest attribute is on full display throughout the record: He has one of the richest, most unique and elaborate vocabularies in all of hip-hop. His phrasing focuses\xc2\xa0details and brings out the poignancy in his words. A line like \xe2\x80\x9cI could get your flowers watered for a bronze Rollie\xe2\x80\x9d brilliantly emphasizes\xc2\xa0the outcomes of killing for gain, not the act. Later, on \xe2\x80\x9cGet Em,\xe2\x80\x9d Mozzy straightforwardly states that he could easily commit murder\xe2\x80\x94no help needed. His attitude in both cases is the same, but it shows the measured perspective of someone who has weighed the serious consequences of a brutal situation.' b'Gang activity and violence are consistent throughout Mozzy\xe2\x80\x99s work. Fake Famous is no exception, yet it still feels vital, which speaks to his ability as a storyteller and lyricist. Instead of providing an account with a beginning, middle, and end (\xc3\xa0 la \xe2\x80\x9cMeet the Flockers\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cThe Art of Peer Pressure\xe2\x80\x9d), Mozzy tends to create micro-narratives within each song. He sometimes veers into generalities, but for the most part, he plucks out the right specifics to immerse the listener in any given moment. \xe2\x80\x9cBorrowed Time,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, stitches together admissions of a drug-addicted family with tales of driving away from cops. On \xe2\x80\x9cThe People Plan,\xe2\x80\x9d he ranges from the perils of the courtroom to the church days of his youth and back to the destructive system that breeds inequality.' b'Mozzy\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics are brought to life by his exceptional delivery and flow. His lines don\xe2\x80\x99t layer double entendres like\xc2\xa0Pusha T\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0or explode with vivid\xc2\xa0similes like\xc2\xa0Danny Brown\xe2\x80\x99s. They\xe2\x80\x99re remarkably colorful and elastic, though, full of sharp phrasing: \xe2\x80\x9cThrowing handles when I steer/Couple piglets in the rear/Watch the diamonds do they Dougie/I had to adjust the mirror.\xe2\x80\x9d He has a dexterity that works greatly to his benefit, but also his detriment: When nearly every line is high quality, and they connect seamlessly, few pop out.' b'Fake Famous does not aim to have a breakout single, but it is a relative shift toward accessibility for Mozzy. Ironically, the G-Eazy and YG-featuring \xe2\x80\x9cHold on Me\xe2\x80\x9d is lackluster compared to more effortless pop swings like \xe2\x80\x9cScorin.\xe2\x80\x9d Still, G-Eazy\xe2\x80\x99s slower, easier-to-follow verse highlights what Mozzy is unwilling (or unable) to do to cater to more casual fans: Let his foot off the gas. Of course, Mozzy is not trying to land on a song with Britney Spears. But particularly when he hands off hook duties (to Iamsu!, Lex Aura, and Bobby Luv), crossover potential is evident.\xc2\xa0F**ake Famous\xc2\xa0is the best he\xe2\x80\x99s done in translating his talents to a more conventional format. But Mozzy\xe2\x80\x99s mindset remains the same as ever: He\xe2\x80\x99s mired in a troubled past and present that define him. He may never be a superstar, but he is very close to what others could consider real fame. It seems to be his choice not to reach that so-called pinnacle.'

column7: b'The third full-length\xc2\xa0from Richmond thrash metal crew Iron Reagan\xe2\x80\x94featuring members of Municipal Waste, Darkest Hour, and Cannabis Corpse\xe2\x80\x94is a compact vehicle for nihilistic escapism.'
column8: b'Iron Reagan aren\xe2\x80\x99t your typical political provocateurs. Forget fighting the two-party system: The Richmond crew, whose lineup comprises members from latter-day crossover thrash groups such as Municipal Waste, Darkest Hour, and Cannabis Corpse, would rather throw a party\xc2\xa0of their own, shotgunning beers and riffs while Main Street burns. Iron Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s name may nod to punk\xe2\x80\x99s longstanding war with conservatism, but their music hardly resembles a call to legislative action. It\xe2\x80\x99s more of a drunken primal scream, the kind that issued forth from the throats of millions on Election Night as the Chyrons announced Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s stunning victory. (Not that the band were rooting for his opponent: a simple glance at their merch offerings reveals a disdain for authority on both sides of the aisle, Clinton included.) Activism can wait; for now, it\xe2\x80\x99s time to rage.' b'And that Iron Reagan do, on their new album Crossover Ministry. Like their first two records (2013\xe2\x80\x99s Worse Than Dead and the following year\xe2\x80\x99s The Tyranny Of Will), the band\xe2\x80\x99s latest effort doubles as a vehicle for violent, nihilistic escapism. And it\xe2\x80\x99s a compact one at that, clocking in at 18 tracks in 30 minutes. Songs like \xe2\x80\x9cA Dying World,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBlatant Violence,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBleed the Fifth\xe2\x80\x9d retain the same shoot-from-the-hip paradigms that fans have come to expect. Frontman Tony Foresta shouts himself hoarse over chugging chords and snare-heavy backbeats before yielding to his Municipal Waste comrade Phillip \xe2\x80\x9cLand Phil\xe2\x80\x9d Hall for a free-wheeling solo.' b'The single\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDead With My Friends\xe2\x80\x9d is an exception, then\xe2\x80\x94an Anthrax-laced paean to whiling away humanity\xe2\x80\x99s final moments with good friends and cheap beer. And a few friends take turns at the mic as well. Screaming Females\xe2\x80\x99 Marissa Paternoster does some yelping on \xe2\x80\x9cEat Or Be Eaten,\xe2\x80\x9d and David Wood of straight edge hardcore greats Down to Nothing presides over the bludgeoning, 14-second \xe2\x80\x9cNo Sell.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Is this approach formulaic? Certainly. Does Crossover Ministry challenge the mores of its genre? Absolutely not. Of course, such is the DNA of thrash metal itself, not only as a descendant of hardcore punk\xe2\x80\x94a style similarly rooted in rudimentary parts\xe2\x80\x94but as the booze-soaked musical equivalent of the reptile brain, which could give two shits about intricacy or subtext. The id manifests most thrillingly (and hilariously) on \xe2\x80\x9cFuck the Neighbors,\xe2\x80\x9d which opens with the ring of a doorbell, followed by the entreatments of a dorky neighbor \xc3\xa0 la Ned Flanders, who asks the band to tone down the racket.\xc2\xa0Needless to say, Iron Reagan veto that request, eventually erupting in the song\xe2\x80\x99s sophomoric titular chant. It\xe2\x80\x99s the ideal anthem for left-wingers marooned in the Bible Belt, not to mention an apt sketch of our divided, pissed-off republic in the year 2016. But Iron Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0revolution runs on ribaldry.'

column1: b'Neill Von Tally'b'The Last Artful, Dodgr'
column7: b'On this collaborative album with producer Neill Von Tally, Portland via Los Angeles rapper/singer The Last Artful, Dodgr displays her gifts for melody and realism.'
column8: b"In a genre as rooted in storytelling as hip-hop, nothing\xe2\x80\x94not a way with words, or an ear for hooks\xe2\x80\x94is as valuable as an interesting perspective. The Last Artful, Dodgr certainly stands out in that regard: she\xe2\x80\x99s a queer black woman from Portland, Oregon\xe2\x80\x94not exactly a city known for its hip-hop scene. However, she also draws a great deal of inspiration from her hometown of Los Angeles, the nucleus of west coast rap. Growing up in the Midcity neighborhood, Dodgr had a front-row seat to the turmoil of the L.A. riots, a fact that she nods toward in her stage name: it\xe2\x80\x99s not just an L.A. Dodgers pun wrapped in a Dickens reference, it's also an allusion to dodging bullets." b"Knowing this connection, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard not to hear echoes of the L.A. rap landscape in Dodgr's music: Kendrick\xe2\x80\x99s melodic moments, Vince Staples\xe2\x80\x99 barbed delivery, the sing-songy cadence of Boogie. Still, Dodgr\xe2\x80\x99s voice is a distinctive instrument, a sharp, nasal sound that she bends into a variety of shapes. More so than with her peers, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to draw a line between her\xc2\xa0rapping and singing\xe2\x80\x94in her hands, everything feels guided by a strong sense of melody. For her second full-length, Bone Music, she\xe2\x80\x99s partnered with Neill Von Tally, a Portland producer whose au courant beats draw a great deal of inspiration from the atmospheric moodiness of Noah \xe2\x80\x9c40\xe2\x80\x9d Shebib and Clams Casino." b'Bone Music takes its name, at least in part, from the Soviet-era practice of bootlegging banned records using X-ray film. It\xe2\x80\x99s a timely reference to censorship, not to mention a fitting title for an album whose focus on the alienation of labor is near-Marxist. \xe2\x80\x9cAll you ought to do is work/Knee pad keep to the dirt/Mine all life long/Die young, then you die young,\xe2\x80\x9d Dodgr raps on \xe2\x80\x9cLLC" before instructing, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I die, play my beats.\xe2\x80\x9d Even when she\'s stunting, her boasts are undercut by the realities of working-class life. \xe2\x80\x9cI made 24 dollars on my night shift...And I\xe2\x80\x99ma spend it all/Spend it all on me,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings on the lurching \xe2\x80\x9cBleu Replica,\xe2\x80\x9d wherein she tries to distract herself from a cheating lover by spending what little she\xe2\x80\x99s made at the club.' b'In the world of Bone Music, sex and death are the only escapes available from the daily grind; accordingly, more than a few of these songs focus on the former. Take the lead single \xe2\x80\x9cOofda,\xe2\x80\x9d an escapist bedroom jam (\xe2\x80\x9cSpoil ya baby/Explore your cravings\xe2\x80\x9d) cloaked in a darkly shimmering beat. The two-part \xe2\x80\x9cGood/Gravy\xe2\x80\x9d mines similar territory, segueing from a double-time rapping workout set to gated house synths to a back-half that sounds like the sparks thrown off by some futuristic machine. There\xe2\x80\x99s romantic tension here too, most notably on the airy \xe2\x80\x9cForeclosed,\xe2\x80\x9d which finds guest vocalist Natasha Kmeto playing Dodgr\xe2\x80\x99s yearning foil (a different version of the song, sung by Dodgr, appeared as \xe2\x80\x9cForeclosure\xe2\x80\x9d on last year\xe2\x80\x99s Fractures EP).' b'With Bone Music, The Last Artful, Dodgr assuredly steps into a lane that\xe2\x80\x99s hers alone. And while her perspective certainly sets her apart, she\xe2\x80\x99s hardly leaning on her identity here. Rather, Bone Music finds Dodgr extending her viewpoint into an exercise in broader, more allegorical storytelling. In an era where most rappers appeal to their listeners\xe2\x80\x99 aspirations, Dodgr aims instead for reliability, zooming in on harsh realities rather than well-heeled fantasies. It\xe2\x80\x99s an unusually grounded mindset for a promising young rapper, one that will likely serve her well as her profile rises.'

column7: b'After singing with Solange, Drake, Kanye, and Frank, Sampha releases his debut LP. It\xe2\x80\x99s a remarkable, meditative work, as he processes grief and navigates self-discovery.'
column8: b'When Sampha Sisay was three years old, his father brought a piano into the family\xe2\x80\x99s Morden, England home. It wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a grand gesture\xe2\x80\x94just a way to get his sons away from the TV. Yet for Sampha, the youngest of five siblings, the instrument became a vessel for his personal growth. It helped enlighten the young boy, offering solace and purpose, commencing a spiritual journey that he\xe2\x80\x99s still navigating. In Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s world, the piano is one of the few things that\xe2\x80\x99s always been there. It\xe2\x80\x99s never gotten sick or faded away from disease. \xe2\x80\x9cYou would show me I had something some people call a soul,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings on \xe2\x80\x9c(No One Knows Me) Like the Piano,\xe2\x80\x9d a gorgeous ballad and one of many standouts from Process, Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable debut album.' b'The song\xe2\x80\x94much like the LP\xe2\x80\x94comes from a deeply meditative place, reflecting the innermost thoughts of a man still coping with heavy loss. His father, Joe, passed away from lung cancer in 1998. His mother, Binty Sisay, died of cancer in September 2015. Throughout the spare electro-soul of\xc2\xa0Process,\xc2\xa0you feel his mom\xe2\x80\x99s spirit in the stillness, pushing her son in his quest for understanding. Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s endured his own health struggles as well. He once discovered a lump in his throat while on tour; despite an endoscopy, doctors couldn\xe2\x80\x99t determine a cause.\xc2\xa0It\xc2\xa0became\xc2\xa0a catalyst for the singer to assess his own mortality here.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cSleeping with my worries,\xe2\x80\x9d goes the\xc2\xa0opener \xe2\x80\x9cPlastic 100\xc2\xbaC,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t really know what that lump was.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s career dates back to 2010 and the release of Sundanza, his first EP. In 2011, Sampha was featured heavily on producer SBTRKT\xe2\x80\x99s debut album;\xc2\xa0his second EP, Dual, followed in 2013. Sampha played the background from there, turning up on tracks with Drake (\xe2\x80\x9cToo Much,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe Motion\xe2\x80\x9d), Kanye West (\xe2\x80\x9cSaint Pablo\xe2\x80\x9d), Frank Ocean (\xe2\x80\x9cAlabama\xe2\x80\x9d), and Solange (\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Touch My Hair\xe2\x80\x9d). His\xc2\xa0presence was\xc2\xa0strong, even if his voice\xe2\x80\x94a gentle, shimmering falsetto\xe2\x80\x94added light touches to the scenery. Despite its delicate texture, Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s inflection hovers perfectly above the music, cracking at certain pitches to convey grief.' b'In a way, Process feels like a concept album on which Sampha rediscovers himself.\xc2\xa0The musician\xe2\x80\x99s mother was diagnosed with cancer the same year\xc2\xa0Sundaza\xc2\xa0came out, and as her primary caregiver, he naturally focused his attention on her well-being. Now, he\xe2\x80\x99s attempting to reconnect with his core while coping with despair.\xc2\xa0In the\xc2\xa0past, he\xe2\x80\x99d mix his voice to fit within the instrumental; on Process, he makes\xc2\xa0it the focal point. Co-produced with Rodaidh McDonald, *Process *brings to mind\xc2\xa0James Blake\xc2\xa0while nodding to mainstream hip-hop. On \xe2\x80\x9cUnder,\xe2\x80\x9d in particular, Sampha utilizes a sleek trap beat.' b'Even the album\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0most upbeat tracks are shaded with tension. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been with me since the cradle,\xe2\x80\x9d Sampha recalls on \xe2\x80\x9cKora Sings,\xe2\x80\x9d presumably referring to his mom. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve been with me, you\xe2\x80\x99re my angel, please don\xe2\x80\x99t you disappear.\xe2\x80\x9d With \xe2\x80\x9cBlood on Me,\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s second single, the vocalist sings through heavy breaths, seemingly haunted by his own insecurities. It addresses the fear of moving forward after personal trauma, and for a quiet soul like Sampha, it also speaks to the panic of navigating the world by himself. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m on this road now,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaims. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m so alone now/Swerving out of control now.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'On album closer \xe2\x80\x9cWhat Shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t I Be?,\xe2\x80\x9d you feel Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s air of prolonged detachment. It catches the singer at his most vulnerable, trying to remember the sketches of his childhood. Close your eyes, and you can almost see Sampha\xe2\x80\x99s family\xe2\x80\x94happy, affectionate, and together. \xe2\x80\x9cI should visit my brother,\xe2\x80\x9d he ponders, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I haven\xe2\x80\x99t been there in months.\xe2\x80\x9d His self-imposed isolation doesn\xe2\x80\x99t outweigh the song\xe2\x80\x99s overall premise: \xe2\x80\x9cYou can always come home.\xe2\x80\x9d'

column7: b'Allison Crutchfield\xe2\x80\x99s debut solo LP jettisons punky guitars for\xc2\xa0pirouetting synths, vast open spaces, and lyrics that explore haunted memories and still-fresh heartache.'
column8: b'In 2014, between projects, Allison Crutchfield released Lean in to It, a synth-led EP of private epiphanies on love and heartbreak. From an artist given to collaboration\xe2\x80\x94not least with her sister, Waxahatchee\xe2\x80\x99s Katie Crutchfield\xe2\x80\x94its starkness was intriguing. Allison and Katie\xe2\x80\x99s first major outfit was Birmingham, Alabama\xe2\x80\x99s P.S. Eliot, a raucous pop-punk band whose busy\xc2\xa0lyrics and zipwire melodies seemed, in brief moments, to make the planet spin twice as fast. In 2012, a year after they split, Allison moved from drums to the mic with Swearin\xe2\x80\x99, still reveling in the racket of ferocious guitars. She began work on Tourist in This Town after Swearin\xe2\x80\x99 played their last show, in 2015, due to her split with co-songwriter Kyle Gilbride. After years touring with her sister and boyfriend, the 28-year-old\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Lean in to It follow-up\xe2\x80\x94and debut solo LP*\xe2\x80\x94*might have occasioned a reckoning with independence and her unmapped\xc2\xa0future. Instead, she finds her compasses jammed by existential drift and haunting\xc2\xa0memories.' b'As on Lean in to It, which corralled tales of youth romance gone awry, Tourist in This Town is a breakup record whose ennui goes beyond romance. Couched in her stories are trials of self-acceptance, psychic grappling, physical\xc2\xa0dislocation. Cleanly produced by Philly synth-whisperer Jeff Zeigler, the LP channels the kind of late-80s synth pop that jettisoned style in favor of vastness and grace\xe2\x80\x94skyline synths pirouette, vocals implore, pensive guitars sporadically erupt. The effect is to coalesce\xc2\xa0Crutchfield\xe2\x80\x99s anecdotes and soliloquies into a blur of fury and melancholy.' b'Like her sister, Crutchfield has a knack for sardonic observations designed to bore through the bullshit of young adulthood (mostly emanating from other young adults). With less room\xc2\xa0for stormy punk guitars, Tourist proceeds with a new lightness of touch. Instead of steel-plating her tongue, the music consoles and reveres the heart-on-sleeve lyrics. On \xe2\x80\x9cSightseeing,\xe2\x80\x9d as piano chords sprout\xc2\xa0reverb, Crutchfield recounts an awkward face-to-face encounter (\xe2\x80\x9cYou say nothing/You just come sit next to me\xe2\x80\x9d) in an anguished tone that suggests a divine experience. It\xe2\x80\x99s oddly dramatic, and a little jarring, but the lyrics\xe2\x80\x99 psychological layers\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBaby, you are not as sad as you want me to think\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94somehow bring you to her level.' b'Rather than submit to the inevitability of breakups, Crutchfield obsessively autopsies what went wrong: she purports to be \xe2\x80\x9cselfish\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cshallow,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cunstable\xe2\x80\x9d on \xe2\x80\x9cBroad Daylight\xe2\x80\x9d; on \xe2\x80\x9cMile Away,\xe2\x80\x9d she seethes to her partner, \xe2\x80\x9cYou assume you understand because your voice is the loudest.\xe2\x80\x9d These scenes often occur in public\xe2\x80\x94waiters refill glasses, onlookers mock her tears. More than heated blow-outs, they sound like scrappy internal monologues, filling silences made unbearable\xc2\xa0by the weight and breadth of what\xe2\x80\x99s unsaid. On \xe2\x80\x9cCharlie,\xe2\x80\x9d Crutchfield and her partner inhabit a domestic space flooded with conflicting memories\xe2\x80\x94their touching pillow-talk, his yelling in her face. When she concludes, \xe2\x80\x9cYou bite me on my neck like I was something you could eat/You bite me \xe2\x80\x99cos you like the way I feel in your teeth,\xe2\x80\x9d her tone taints the cuteness with a dash of something sinister.' b'If there\xe2\x80\x99s a drawback to this psychic dredging, it\xe2\x80\x99s a slightly limited emotional range. Crutchfield frames scenes vividly, yet we rarely feel the weight of the mutual devastation, the perverse thrill of love discarded. When her post-romantic tumult subsides, on \xe2\x80\x9cExpatriate,\xe2\x80\x9d a moment of introspective honesty is warranted\xe2\x80\x94one that might carry more weight had the\xc2\xa0tone ventured further afield elsewhere. \xe2\x80\x9cThe things you used to hate about me are all heightened now,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings, with a measure of contentment. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I love myself, or I\xe2\x80\x99m figuring out how.\xe2\x80\x9d The line still resonates, but it\xe2\x80\x99s more satisfying, in this case, to see her meticulous, anxiety-parsing work\xc2\xa0as its own redemption\xe2\x80\x94entombing the past in a reliquary of sad matters settled.'

column7: b'Peter Sagar is a former\xc2\xa0guitarist for Mac DeMarco, and his charms are not dissimilar from DeMarco\xe2\x80\x99s own. Here, he\xc2\xa0incorporates yacht rock and R&B tropes for a\xc2\xa0thrift store synth-pop sound.'
column8: b'Since leaving Mac DeMarco\xe2\x80\x99s touring band in 2013, Peter Sagar has been releasing music as Homeshake. His first two albums albums,\xc2\xa0In the Shower and Midnight Snack,\xc2\xa0were\xc2\xa0not terribly far\xc2\xa0from DeMarco\xe2\x80\x99s own charm. They were endearing and melancholic,\xc2\xa0but also introspective and kind of gross. His sound was pleasantly ramshackle, born from groovy guitars, echo, and a lilting, almost bored singing voice.\xc2\xa0Sagar\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0music oozed a languorous, supine, stoned feeling, and he played the guitar as if\xc2\xa0it were a balloon animal: his riffs were\xc2\xa0elastic, contorted, and silly.' b'Overall, on those two records,\xc2\xa0Sagar\xe2\x80\x99s spin on slacker rock was easy listening, malleable and affecting in the way DeMarco\xe2\x80\x99s rock was anthemic. Both Sagar and DeMarco\xc2\xa0sell\xc2\xa0versions of the world that you want to inhabit: devil may care, but anxiously millennial. And of all the musicians spawned from DeMarco\xe2\x80\x99s smokey den (Alex Calder and Walter TV among them), Sagar always seemed poised to be the one to breakout.' b'On his third album, Fresh Air, Sagar incorporates new tropes, including AM-radio yacht rock and quiet storm R&B, into his practice. He\xe2\x80\x99s incorporated the off-kilter guitar playing of\xc2\xa0his earlier work into his new sound, cleaved from cheap synthesizers and drum machines, and the result could be described as thrift store synthpop, or as it might have been called eight years ago: chillwave. Generally, this vibe suits Sagar. The architecture of his sound has always held\xc2\xa0some of the funniest parts of the \xe2\x80\x9980s at its core. And here, the pure sleaziness he is able to extract from his instruments can be gloriously campy, or unexpectedly elegant and morose. But he\xe2\x80\x99s also capable of laying down the cheese too thick.' b'In the album\xe2\x80\x99s title track, he pairs together white noise and funky guitars into an inexplicable but personable ballad of\xc2\xa0loneliness and stress. In the background, a faltering metronome chimes in, giving the song an even more broken down feel. On \xe2\x80\x9cCall Me Up\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cEvery Single Thing,\xe2\x80\x9d Sagar adds\xc2\xa0unforgettably sugary synth riffs that are equally danceable and mopey. Yet, he also has a tendency to stretch his voice way past his range, sometimes with effects, or through plodding vocal gymnastics. If anything, his voice might be a big reason some of this music falls flat. On \xe2\x80\x9cTiming,\xe2\x80\x9d his voice is far too brittle to carry the mercurial beat.' b'But his aesthetic, for better or worse, has not veered too far from his earliest efforts. On early cassettes, and previous albums, the low-quality trappings of his recordings were\xc2\xa0appealing. Three albums in, it seems like Sagar still has some learning to do. All over Fresh Air\xc2\xa0lay old tropes: bursts of static, helium-inflected voices, scratchy sound, guitar noodling. The album also lacks cohesive pacing; its level of energy is low enough that it easily becomes background listening. While there isn\xe2\x80\x99t quite anyone who possesses Sagar\xe2\x80\x99s style in the wide world of indie rock, he\xe2\x80\x99ll have to add a few more tricks, lest he fall into rote routine.'

column7: b'In the \xe2\x80\x9980s underground, the Pacific Northwest artist\xc2\xa0Kerry Leimer never fit into any one category or scene. His soundtrack for the\xc2\xa01982 documentary Land of Look Behind could be called ambient reggae.'
column8: b'Three years ago, RVNG Intl.\xe2\x80\x99s loving survey of Pacific Northwest musician Kerry Leimer revealed a contemplative player in the American late 70s/early 1980s underground who didn\xe2\x80\x99t quite slot into any one category or scene. He wasn\xe2\x80\x99t really a punk, though he took a decidedly unlearned approach to music-making. And despite delving into synthesizers and ambient soundscapes, Leimer didn\xe2\x80\x99t really turn himself into a new age cottage industry. He even made twitchy, drum-heavy tracks as Savant, but he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t quite be considered a dance music producer either. In retrospect, Leimer seemed\xc2\xa0mostly like a one-man iteration of American kosmische music.' b'A sense of\xc2\xa0detachment from genres and scenes comes up again on this reissue of Leimer\xe2\x80\x99s long out-of-print soundtrack for Alan Greenberg\xe2\x80\x99s 1982 documentary, Land of Look Behind. Not readily available on streaming sites, the film is\xc2\xa0one to track down. It remains one of the most fascinating looks at the Rastafarian culture that begat Jamaican music, its eye trained on both the dense, tangled \xe2\x80\x9cbad land\xe2\x80\x9d of Cockpit Country as well as Kingston in the wake of Bob Marley\xe2\x80\x99s funeral. And while plenty of Jamaican music fills the film, Leimer\xe2\x80\x99s contribution to the score expertly hovers between the island\xe2\x80\x99s ritualistic nyabinghi drumming and futuristic analog synthesizers. It\xe2\x80\x99s a soundtrack for a film that at times seems\xc2\xa0like a vague remembrance of a film itself, disassociating certain elements from the celluloid and imagining them in strange new ways.' b'Call it ambient reggae\xe2\x80\x94even if it\xe2\x80\x99s too fidgety to fully settle into either\xc2\xa0of those sounds. When the nyabinghi drums crop up, they\xe2\x80\x99re\xc2\xa0often background sounds rather than immediate thunder, adding\xc2\xa0just a subtle pulse to\xc2\xa0the sublime shimmer of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Outpost.\xe2\x80\x9d And when the drum circles move to the fore\xe2\x80\x94as on centerpiece \xe2\x80\x9cThe Cockpit\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Leimer makes the ambient washes more ethereal, recalling\xc2\xa0some of Steve Roach\xe2\x80\x99s work with percussionists from the \xe2\x80\x9980s. On \xe2\x80\x9cConfusion in Belief,\xe2\x80\x9d sunburst synths entwine with tribal drums from the film, mixing with Leimer\xe2\x80\x99s keys and a battery of percussionists: Steve Fisk, Kevin Hodges, David and James Keller. At times, the sound anticipates Boards of Canada, with chunky drums, drifting chords, and\xc2\xa0voices swirling about, just at the verge intelligibility.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s rare to have vocals emerge in Leimer\xe2\x80\x99s work, so his way with looping, tweaking, and layering voices from the film into rhythmic counterpoint fascinates. Chant, casual chatter, an overheard conversation\xe2\x80\x94they all get minced into sound. A location recording of a crowd clamors in the distance on the post-punk landscape of \xe2\x80\x9cGun Court.\xe2\x80\x9d Leimer then samples\xc2\xa0a Jamaican voice discussing the bush and contorts it into all sorts of patterns on \xe2\x80\x9cTestimony and Honor.\xe2\x80\x9d He chops up that distinct patois and adds\xc2\xa0an array of handclaps, bird sounds, tapped hi-hats, and rewound tape atop it.' b'Three bonus tracks are tacked onto this reissue, though Leimer didn\xe2\x80\x99t finish them until many years later. Outside of an extended version of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Cockpit,\xe2\x80\x9d they don\xe2\x80\x99t grapple with the coarse elements of Jamaica; Leimer instead emphasizes\xc2\xa0the piano and other acoustic sounds in his studio. In a decade that would see numerous artists engage in ethnic music and modern composition, from the likes of Jon Hassell to the Made to Measure series, the eight tracks of the original soundtrack remain unmatched in the decade. By turns raw and elegant, rhythmic and unearthly, Leimer\xe2\x80\x99s music evokes and retains the\xc2\xa0mystery of Jamaica itself.'

column7: b'This live album, consisting mostly of late-career highlights, emphasizes what Sleater-Kinney does best: playing not just with urgent feeling, but in service of immense meaning.'
column8: b'In the recently released video for \xe2\x80\x9cSurface Envy,\xe2\x80\x9d there\xe2\x80\x99s a \xe2\x80\x9cstop Bush\xe2\x80\x9d sign in the background of one of the many live performances that comprise the clip. Written about their reunion after about eight years apart, \xe2\x80\x9cSurface Envy\xe2\x80\x9d is the story of Sleater-Kinney in that it is the story of bands\xe2\x80\x94groups of people, really\xe2\x80\x94that attempt to go against the grain: \xe2\x80\x9cWe win, we lose, only together do we break the rules,\xe2\x80\x9d goes the chorus. So while \xc2\xa0the No Cities to Love\xc2\xa0standout is not about \xe2\x80\x9cthe system\xe2\x80\x9d per se, it is one of the best fight songs they\xe2\x80\x99ve ever written\xe2\x80\x94a fact underscored by the pummeling version that appears on their new live album.' b'If there is one unifying thread among many of the songs that make the cut on Live in Paris, it\xe2\x80\x99s not just that they\xe2\x80\x99re late-era Sleater-Kinney highlights (five of the 13 songs come from No Cities to Love, four from 2005\xe2\x80\x99s The Woods). From the post-recession terror of opening track \xe2\x80\x9cPrice Tag\xe2\x80\x9d to the sly sendup of capitalist femininity on closing song \xe2\x80\x9cModern Girl,\xe2\x80\x9d the tracklist emphasizes what Sleater-Kinney does best: playing not just with urgent feeling, but in service of immense meaning. Corin Tucker, Carrie Brownstein, and Janet Weiss came back swinging in 2015 as strongly as they ever had\xe2\x80\x94a gift considering how rarely it happens in rock. *Live in Paris *is the victory lap leaving us wanting more.' b'The setlists for S-K\xe2\x80\x99s comeback tour throughout 2015 were maximized to show the band\xe2\x80\x99s power after the better part of a decade away, and Live in Paris\xe2\x80\x94recorded at the historic venue La Cigale about a month into the trek\xe2\x80\x94has enough of it to make anthems out of lesser S-K songs. Girl-gang harmonies originally made One Beat\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d sound delightfully bratty, but Tucker\xe2\x80\x99s exaggerated vocals on the chorus resemble a demented Mickey Mouse; it\xe2\x80\x99ll stick with you like a childhood trip to Orlando. Old live footage suggests she hasn\xe2\x80\x99t always sang it so idiosyncratically, which can be said of numerous vocal takes here from both Tucker and Brownstein. \xc2\xa0The latter\xe2\x80\x99s blood-curdling bird squawks on \xe2\x80\x9cI Wanna Be Your Joey Ramone\xe2\x80\x9d will make you A.) wonder why Carrie Brownstein hasn\xe2\x80\x99t formed some avant-garde metal band for the sole purpose of squawk-singing (could also work as a \xe2\x80\x9cPortlandia\xe2\x80\x9d sketch); B.) love it even more.' b"Listening to Brownstein and Tucker sing together now, 20+ years after Sleater-Kinney\xe2\x80\x99s founding, you can hear how their voices have changed. On early Sleater-Kinney records, their vocals often recklessly (and joyfully) clashed, like a pit of dance-punks tossing their bodies at one another. These days, it's more common that their voices fall into worn, soulful grooves when they harmonize, like in the chorus of No Cities\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cA New Wave\xe2\x80\x9d; Tucker hoists her voice up above Brownstein\xe2\x80\x99s like she\xe2\x80\x99s casually hopping out of a pool." b"The obvious downside of being a band with serious history is that fans who prefer the old stuff are probably always going to be a given. Sleater-Kinney toured around the January 2015 release of eighth LP No Cities to Love, so clearly those songs were prized. It was an excellent album, but S-K also played older fan favorites like \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re No Rock n\xe2\x80\x99 Roll Fun,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWords and Guitar,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLittle Babies\xe2\x80\x9d throughout the tour and they don\xe2\x80\x99t end up here. That\xe2\x80\x99s the only real downside to what is surprisingly the first live album from a touring rock band that remains one of America's best." b"Sleater-Kinney\xe2\x80\x99s existence as, in their own mocking words, \xe2\x80\x9cthe girl band\xe2\x80\x9d may seem less revolutionary now than it did on the other side of their hiatus, but it\xe2\x80\x99s partially because S-K helped pave a way for the women who now lead indie rock. In this sense, their presence is inherently political, even when they\xe2\x80\x99re playing a characteristically Corin love song like \xe2\x80\x9cTurn It On.\xe2\x80\x9d With that and with our current world in mind, *Live in Paris *makes an inspiring mixtape for the various battles at hand. Like Tucker belts on \xe2\x80\x9cSurface Envy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cWe've got so much to do, let me make that clear.\xe2\x80\x9d"

column7: b'In the early 1980s, the Glasgow pop duo Strawberry Switchblade were a band with many possible futures. This raw three-song demo catches a glimpse of the group they could have become.'
column8: b'The story of Strawberry Switchblade is a reminder of just how small the alternative music scene was in the early 1980s, and how deeply its subcultures intertwined. Formed in 1980 in Glasgow by Jill Bryson and Rose McDowall, the pair\xe2\x80\x99s eye-catching look\xe2\x80\x94gothic Geisha in polka dot dresses and black lace gloves\xe2\x80\x94set them apart from their immediate peers, the buttoned-up young men of the Postcard Records scene. Their early live performances caught the attention of John Peel, for whom they recorded a BBC session. But with renegade A&R man Bill Drummond\xe2\x80\x94later to form pop terrorists the KLF\xe2\x80\x94installed as the group\xe2\x80\x99s manager, Strawberry Switchblade turned to face the mainstream.' b'Their 1984 single \xe2\x80\x9cSince Yesterday\xe2\x80\x9d was a breezily nostalgic electronic pop song that McDowall later claimed was about nuclear war. It broached the UK Top 10, propelled the duo onto the cover of Smash Hits, and made them officially big in Japan\xe2\x80\x94screaming fans, limousines, the works. Strawberry Switchblade split acrimoniously two years later. By now, though, McDowall was a face on the post-industrial scene, singing with Psychic TV, Coil, and the neofolk groups Current 93 and Death in June. She was also hanging out with a young Bj\xc3\xb6rk, then part of Icelandic anarcho-punk band\xc2\xa0Kukl.' b'For a group that lasted just one album, this is a long and tangled history, and one that Glasgow label Night School have made it their task to unknot. In 2015, Night School released McDowall\xe2\x80\x99s lost post-Switchblade LP Cut With the Cake Knife**, and they\xc2\xa0follow now with this\xe2\x80\x94a seven-inch of previously unreleased music from Switchblade\xe2\x80\x99s earliest days.\xc2\xa04-Piece Demo lines up three songs in 10 minutes, and it passes quick. Captured while the group was briefly a quartet, completed by bassist Janice Goodlett and drummer Carole McGowan, this recording captures a Strawberry Switchblade only hinted at by their existing recordings: a cutie garage group hiding something desperate and nihilistic beneath their gently shambolic exterior.' b'The sweet-savage juxtaposition of Strawberry Switchblade\xe2\x80\x99s name found echo in their music. Bryson and McDowall wrote songs that sounded winsome and naive, but spoke of an emotional desolation that was anything but contrived. In interviews, McDowall has spoken of her hard-knock upbringing in a Glasgow sink estate, where violence was rife and she watched her six-year-old brother die following a beating. Bryson, meanwhile, suffered from extreme agoraphobia, writing about her condition on Strawberry Switchblade\xe2\x80\x99s debut single \xe2\x80\x9cTrees and Flowers.\xe2\x80\x9d The version here, pared down to droning guitar and clumpy drums, is some of the sweetest fear and loathing that you ever heard. \xe2\x80\x9cI hate the trees/And I hate the flowers/And I hate the buildings/And the way they tower over me,\xe2\x80\x9d sings McDowall. The song closes with a lament: \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t you see/I get so frightened/No one else seems frightened/Only me, only me\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d' b'One song here is wholly new. With its hopscotch rhythms, keening harmonies, and squirming bass, \xe2\x80\x9cSpanish Song (Don\xe2\x80\x99t Go)\xe2\x80\x9d would sound like textbook C86 were it not for the mariachi guitar outro that starts out halting and ends close to joyous. Meanwhile, \xe2\x80\x9cGo Away\xe2\x80\x9d offers another glimpse of how Strawberry Switchblade\xe2\x80\x99s debut album might have sounded. The version that appeared two years later is a high-gloss thing, all breathy synths and pseudo-oriental melodies\xe2\x80\x94but this take, with its wispy Velvets jangle and gently deflating chorus, arguably captures the song\xe2\x80\x99s lyric of sorrowful abandonment all the more keenly.' b'Completing the package is liner notes written by Stephen Pastel, a friend of Strawberry Switchblade who, around the time these songs were recorded, was busy prepping the debut single by his own young group, the Pastels. Their music was, like that found on 4-Piece Demo, a little primitive and rough around the edges, but full of creativity and life. The Pastels would kickstart a whole new indie-pop fanzine culture, though, and prove extraordinarily resilient, remaining an ongoing concern today. Strawberry Switchblade were a band with many possible futures, and this demo offers just a fleeting glimpse of the group they could have become.'

column7: b'Since leaving the Pipettes,\xc2\xa0Rose Elinor Dougal has quietly released an impressive trove of lovelorn pop music. Stellular is wry, frosty and swooning by turns, romantic but hesitant.'
column8: b'The Pipettes as a group were never bound to last\xe2\x80\x94a decade on, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t sound so appealing to combine the girl-group fandom of indie rock with the schtick of Meghan Trainor and the singer-retention of the Sugababes. The Pipettes as a group of artists, though, have been remarkably prolific. Two years ago, Gwenno Saunders released the year\xe2\x80\x99s highest-concept album, the Welsh-language, sci-fi-enamored Y Dydd Olaf. Bandmate Rose Elinor Dougall, meanwhile has quietly released several albums and EPs\xe2\x80\x99 worth of lovelorn pop music. The comparison is inevitable\xe2\x80\x94both artists work in more or less the same vein of synthpop\xe2\x80\x94but where Gwenno prefers futurism, Dougall prefers romanticism. On tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cFallen Over\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cHanging Around,\xe2\x80\x9d she sheds the self-consciousness and polka-dotted prurience of her old group for a disarmingly earnest swoon.' b'Stellular, produced with Oli Bayston of Boxed In\xc2\xa0(who also sings on and co-wrote \xe2\x80\x9cDive\xe2\x80\x9d) is not a departure from her past solo work\xe2\x80\x94if you\xe2\x80\x99ve heard any of the EPs, you know what to expect, and even if you haven\xe2\x80\x99t, you can venture a guess. Dougall is a Pipettes alum; pastiche is expected. Specifically, most of Stellular wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t exist without the past several decades of post-punk (in particular, Blondie), and the rest of it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t exist without Trish Keenan and Sarah Cracknell. The lilting \xe2\x80\x9cTake Yourself With You\xe2\x80\x9d recalls \xe2\x80\x9970s folk, spacey Stereolab, and some of ABBA\xe2\x80\x99s pastoral, statelier tracks. As influences, they\xe2\x80\x99re ideal\xe2\x80\x94they don\xe2\x80\x99t lend themselves to kitsch so much as sturdy, comfortable arrangements that Dougall\xc2\xa0inhabits with love and familiarity.' b"Take the title track: it begins bramble-spiky, but Dougall makes it entrancing. She winds through verbosities like \xe2\x80\x9cHopes and despairs in parallel live wildly side by side\xe2\x80\x9d effortlessly, almost distracted. It\xe2\x80\x99s a love song, but a hesitant one, caught between prickly guitars and moony sentiments, warning itself off in the bridge: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re giving yourself away again.\xe2\x80\x9d The title, as precisely chosen as the rest, compares her would-be partner to a small star; full-on cosmic crushing is just not something the narrator allows herself. She does allow herself the more earthy kind on \xe2\x80\x9cCloser\xe2\x80\x9d: closing time in some arbitrary bar, gazing at\xc2\xa0someone who\xe2\x80\x99d rather blather on about something so much less important than moving their hand that last crucial centimeter. Dougall\xe2\x80\x99s a wry songwriter when she wants to be, and she delivers these details to match, but the way her coy chorus and frosty \xe2\x80\x9cI don't care about your band\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s 3:45 a.m.\xe2\x80\x9d melt within seconds reveals her hopes, and the speeding-heartbeat guitar lick, her blissful impatience. The other blatant new wave cut, \xe2\x80\x9cAll at Once,\xe2\x80\x9d pulls the same sleight-of-heart. There\xe2\x80\x99s as much \xe2\x80\x9cRapture\xe2\x80\x9d in it as actual rapture; the funk and whispers and \xe2\x80\x9ctonight\xe2\x80\x9ds affect cool and do it quite well, but the lyrics\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGive me apathy...sentence me to heaven\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94merely aspires toward it, from a longing place." b"Indeed, what elevates Stellular from just another decade\xe2\x80\x99s nostalgia exercise is that longing. \xe2\x80\x9cAnswer Me,\xe2\x80\x9d while the weakest track here\xe2\x80\x94Dougall\xe2\x80\x99s posh voice doesn't navigate soft-rock or R&B ballads well\xe2\x80\x94redeems itself in its final minute, a plush pile of backing vocals; \xe2\x80\x9cSpace to Be\xe2\x80\x9d is nothing but redemption. It\xe2\x80\x99s a sequel to \xe2\x80\x9cStellular\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the chorus melody is tucked into the synths\xe2\x80\x94set in the same city with the same loneliness, but none of the hesitation. The chorus might lend itself to a girl-group arrangement, and certainly the sentiment would: \xe2\x80\x9cI want a love to lift me up high, to wreak havoc on this heart of mine, tear me limb from limb until I find some kind of space to be.\xe2\x80\x9d But where the Pipettes would give it irony or sex somewhere, and just about every other girl-group revivalist would lean into the darkness and violence, Dougall leaves it at full-throated emotion."

column7: b'The six-piece BANANA features\xc2\xa0members of the Red Hot Chili Peppers\xc2\xa0and Warpaint, as well as\xc2\xa0the singer Cate Le Bon.\xc2\xa0LIVE is a playful, energetic session, influenced by Arthur Russell and Jon Hassell.'
column8: b'In March of last year, six musicians congregated in a house in Los Angeles, intent on making something original. Their band, BANANA, originally assembled as an opening act and backing group for the singer Cate Le Bon, included members of the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Warpaint as well as Le Bon herself, coming off of her excellent 2016 release Crab Day. The ensemble was helmed by Josiah Steinbrick, a producer and fixture of the L.A. music scene who\xe2\x80\x99s collaborated with Devendra Banhart, Charlotte Gainsbourg, and Tim Presley of White Fence.' b'The musicians had gotten familiar with each other while touring\xc2\xa0Crab Day, and it seems that they were in an even looser mood than usual when they came together to record what would become LIVE, a mix that uses original compositions by Steinbrick as a jumping-off point for the rest of the musicians to improvise over. Influenced by the recordings of the trumpeter and composer Jon Hassell and incorporating the work of Arthur Russell, the playful, energetic LIVE*\xc2\xa0*was originally recorded as a special for the online radio station Dublab. But it proved to have staying power, so Leaving Records has issued it as a standalone album this month.' b'*LIVE\xc2\xa0*is comprised of four tracks named for the first four letters of the alphabet, and runs 24 minutes its length. Its tracks are predicated not on guitar, piano or drums, but on loops of vibraphone and woodwind, with other instruments chiming in wildly, a rainforest cacophony layered over the slower, deeper patterns of a lush musical ecosystem. Tracks don\xe2\x80\x99t develop in a linear fashion but instead grow outward in strange, unexpected directions. On \xe2\x80\x9cA\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cB,\xe2\x80\x9d this growth is segmented, as a second loop tags in to replace the first at the midpoint of each song. \xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x9d are more coherent and as a result, more easily digestible.' b'Depending on the listener\xe2\x80\x99s mood, the record\xe2\x80\x99s early going can be frustratingly chipper. All those plinking mallets and that farting brass come to feel grating, a forced smile that stays on too long. But occasional moments of shade dull the insistent sunshine, providing some relief as you delve further into the record. Plaintive strings on the back side of \xe2\x80\x9cB\xe2\x80\x9d \xc2\xa0and the sudden jangle of piano two and half minutes through \xe2\x80\x9cC\xe2\x80\x9d cool things down, \xc2\xa0and \xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x9d by far the shortest track here, is decidedly the darkest, introducing a somber note that anchors an otherwise escapist record in the real world.' b'The compositions here forsake Western divisions of major and minor keys. This gives all the tracks a modal, somewhat hard-to-place flavor, particularly the baroque \xe2\x80\x9cB,\xe2\x80\x9d which makes use of ceremonial music from Southeast Asia and incorporates a minimalist piece from the Estonian composer Heino J\xc3\xbcrisalu, before morphing into a tribute to Arthur Russell\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9970s work that includes a yearning sample of electric piano from Russell himself.' b'Steinbrick has said that he wants the music to sound \xe2\x80\x9cexotic\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cpleasant,\xe2\x80\x9d both characteristics that LIVE\xc2\xa0nails easily. But after a half dozen listens, despite some of its more outr\xc3\xa9 qualities,\xc2\xa0LIVE\xc2\xa0starts to sound familiar, even tightly controlled. The members of BANANA\xc2\xa0know each other well, and on the record, they seem capable of anticipating their tourmates improvisational tendencies, like a conversation at the family dinner table where it\xe2\x80\x99s always obvious who\xe2\x80\x99s going to speak up next. That makes for a strikingly coherent improvised album. But it also dulls some of the surprises that LIVE*\xc2\xa0*might have otherwise offered, making something that was supposed to feel fresh and alive, seem occasionally, if not unhappily, predictable.'

column7: b'Priests\xe2\x80\x99 debut expands into a rich diorama of stinging guitar, funk, yearning indie pop, and jazz; there hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been a punk debut this certain and poised since Savages\xe2\x80\x99 Silence Yourself.'
column8: b'Fire-starting D.C. punks Priests started work on their transcendent debut several years before election day, so don\xe2\x80\x99t blame them if Nothing Feels Natural feels relevant in the extreme at this moment. Since debuting with Tape One five years ago, the four-piece have never stopped shredding through corrupt power hierarchies and attempting to disentangle personal freedom from consumer choice. Across two tapes, a single, and an EP, they\xe2\x80\x99ve used a deranged sort of surf rock to launch lucid, grimly funny expos\xc3\xa9s of the false binaries and systemic oppressions that built America. This, after all, is the band that screamed, \xe2\x80\x9cBarack Obama killed something in me and I\xe2\x80\x99m gonna get him for it.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'As we enter 2017, we\xe2\x80\x99re in danger of tying every faintly despairing new piece of culture to the ascent of America\xe2\x80\x99s Cheeto-in-Chief, as if January 20 flipped a switch that instantly soured all milk. But injustice wasn\xe2\x80\x99t born earlier this month; it just became apparent to many\xc2\xa0who never had much cause to worry about it before. And the lyrics to Nothing Feels Natural show the existential weight of having spent a lifetime fighting. Priests\xe2\x80\x99 debut has an entirely different energy from their previous releases, expanding into a rich diorama of stinging guitar, funk, yearning indie pop, and jazz. The leap in range and ambition from their 2015 EP Bodies and Control and Money and Power\xc2\xa0is huge: There hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been a punk debut this certain and poised since Savages\xe2\x80\x99 Silence Yourself.' b'The title works a few different ways. There\xe2\x80\x99s the obvious what the fuck sensation that accompanies your early morning Twitter scroll these days, and Priests have always done a mean line in sardonic disbelief. There\xe2\x80\x99s less of that on Nothing Feels Natural, though it\xe2\x80\x99s no less potent: \xe2\x80\x9cPink White House\xe2\x80\x9d is a hostile cheerleader chant about the illusion of choice, where the disorientation mounts alongside Taylor Mulitz\xe2\x80\x99s spiraling bass. On the boisterously funky \xe2\x80\x9cPuff,\xe2\x80\x9d Katie Alice Greer sneers at accelerationism\xe2\x80\x94the crackpot academic theory that society hitting rock bottom is good because it will surely engender radical change. And on \xe2\x80\x9cJJ,\xe2\x80\x9d she balks at how easily we let branding influence the way we construct identity. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought I was a cowboy because I smoked Reds,\xe2\x80\x9d Greer wails, as surf riffs and battered piano behind her evoke a debauched saloon caper.' b'Priests have always had a keen eye for fakery and bullshit, though on Nothing Feels Natural, they\xe2\x80\x99re confronting \xe2\x80\x98normalcy\xe2\x80\x99, a force far more insidious than artifice, because the partisan values informing it are invisible. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a long movie, a long movie/And you are not you, you are not you,\xe2\x80\x9d Greer exhorts on opener \xe2\x80\x9cAppropriate.\xe2\x80\x9d Adding saxophone, piano and hand percussion to their sound, they change direction from song to song much in the same way that the Clash did with Sandinista!, and commit to every hairpin turn. \xe2\x80\x9cAppropriate\xe2\x80\x9d hurtles from spiny sloganeering through nihilistic thrash to a condemned doom jazz wasteland, leaving the listener as alienated as Priests feel. The title track brings to mind rain-thrashed British indie pop, and on \xe2\x80\x9cSuck,\xe2\x80\x9d Priests try their hand at nimble ESG-indebted funk, though Greer\xe2\x80\x99s frustrated pleas expose the dark underbelly of the New Yorkers\xe2\x80\x99 effervescent cool. She had to stop screaming because it was killing her throat. The desperation in her singing voice might be more jarring than her howls.' b'Priests have always been thrillingly direct, but that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t stopped their words being twisted by publicists who want to profit from them (\xe2\x80\x9cYou hinge your success on that which you might bleed from me,\xe2\x80\x9d Greer sneers on \xe2\x80\x9cNicki\xe2\x80\x9d) and guilty parties who interpret their calls for respect as personal attacks (\xe2\x80\x9cPlease don\xe2\x80\x99t make me be someone with no sympathy,\xe2\x80\x9d she pleads on \xe2\x80\x9cSuck\xe2\x80\x9d). Here, they sound unusually worn down by commodification, a lack of good faith from those around them, and the difficulty of surviving as a punk band: the title Nothing Feels Natural could also signify that the abyss has started to feel like home. We\xe2\x80\x99re told that this is where punk thrives, at the bottom of the barrel\xe2\x80\x94accelerationism, again. Priests reject that idea in the most forceful terms. Led by drummer Daniele Daniele in a relentless, disbelieving sing-speak, the terrifying \xe2\x80\x9cNo Big Bang\xe2\x80\x9d peers into the void of shame and failure that accompanies creativity. On the title track, a depressed Greer satirizes the sacrifices she\xe2\x80\x99d make to feel balanced again. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I go without for days will I finally hallucinate a real thing?\xe2\x80\x9d she pleads. The self\xc2\xa0becomes a slippery concept: \xe2\x80\x9cPeople are born and dying inside of me all the time,\xe2\x80\x9d Greer sings on \xe2\x80\x9cLelia 20.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'When kakistocracy reigns and George Orwell\xe2\x80\x99s 1984 is a bestseller again, you might wonder if now\xe2\x80\x99s the best time for Priests to get introspective. But their insistence on wriggling free from definition and feeling the weight of darkness has roots in resistance. On \xe2\x80\x9cNicki,\xe2\x80\x9d which rings with cavernous dread, Greer intones, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t make friends easily or naturally,\xe2\x80\x9d sliding over the consonants like an eel escaping grasping hands. Priests\xe2\x80\x99 insistence on mutable identity, and their disinterest in pinning down a 10-point plan to vanquish fascism, let them slip free of those who seek to gentrify, identify, commodify.\xc2\xa0In a society where it\xe2\x80\x99s becoming increasingly apparent to everyone that your words can and will be used against you, Nothing Feels Natural is a valuable philosophy.'

column7: b'In an underground scene\xc2\xa0where guitar bands tend to be one trick ponies, pummeling punk duo Urochromes\xe2\x80\x99 unpredictability lends them\xc2\xa0a rare star quality.'
column8: b'Urochrome, singular, is the pigment that determines the color of urine. Urochromes, plural, are\xc2\xa0the pummeling duo from Western Massachusetts that\xc2\xa0released a handful of noisy hardcore platters over the past two years on underground punk labels. Frontman Jackie Jackieboy commands attention with his rabid, yammering screams. Dick Riddick is the shredder, responsible for solos and the band\xe2\x80\x99s massive, gnarly guitar tone. Their drummer is (literally) a machine. On their first release, 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Get in Line 4 Mental Decline, Jackie shout-sang about pissing in a bottle in his room, and then, pissing on his best friend. At a glance, that appears to be the ceiling for Urochromes\xe2\x80\x94fun, volatile, rapid-fire scatological\xc2\xa0punk. With their new EP Night Bully, the duo and their robot drummer seek paths beyond hardcore\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic limitations.' b"The title track begins with crackling guitars mingling with deep, burbling electronics. Jackie forgoes a\xc2\xa0scream, focusing all his intensity into an aggressive, rhythmic whisper. The title \xe2\x80\x9cNight Bully\xe2\x80\x9d suggests \xc2\xa0intimidation, and there is definitely a posturing pushiness to its narrative. \xe2\x80\x9cI am the new muscle/Everyone needs a secret hustle,\xe2\x80\x9d Jackie notes, menacingly, before prodding further: \xe2\x80\x9cYou should know that/You should *really *know that.\xe2\x80\x9d He repeatedly demands that you \xe2\x80\x9cbe the uromancer\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94someone who divines the future by reading urine bubbles. It\xe2\x80\x99s the only overt reference to piss, and it\xe2\x80\x99s puerile, yes, but it's also\xc2\xa0an incomprehensible, psychedelic call to action." b'\xe2\x80\x9cNight Bully\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s overall tone isn\xe2\x80\x99t unprecedented for Urochromes. The band had already been working with drum machines, and their obsession with industrial punk acts like Chrome came through loud and clear on their 2015 cover of \xe2\x80\x9cChromosome Damage.\xe2\x80\x9d Jackie\xe2\x80\x99s whispers take that aesthetic into new territory. The EP\xe2\x80\x99s closing track, however, comes out of left field. The Northampton, Massachusetts-based coldwave duo Boy Harsher deliver a remix of \xe2\x80\x9cNight Bully\xe2\x80\x9d that renders the source material unrecognizable. A smooth, beatific synthesizer melody floats over a pulsing drone as a somber Jae Matthews croons the same words Jackie had just been aggressively whispering. It\xe2\x80\x99s a wholly unexpected turn, but the synth pop jam shares Urochromes\xe2\x80\x99 sonic DNA. There are familiar stabs of darkness that come through\xe2\x80\x94demonic voices and the occasional squeal of guitar. It\xe2\x80\x99s a welcome note to end on.' b'The record\xe2\x80\x99s entire A-side, by contrast, shows Urochromes at the height of their hardcore powers. Riddick\xe2\x80\x99s hooks are polished on \xe2\x80\x9cConfront Ya,\xe2\x80\x9d and the drum machine ratchets up the\xc2\xa0urgency. Jackie ladles bile on his target\xe2\x80\x94someone who boasts\xc2\xa0about finding success while outlining their plans to climb the ladder. \xe2\x80\x9cYou want to crush me with your boot,\xe2\x80\x9d he observes before bellowing with disgust, \xe2\x80\x9cYou want to move to L.A.!\xe2\x80\x9d Jackie\xe2\x80\x99s frustration holds sway on \xe2\x80\x9cMy Disposition\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94his disposition, apparently, is that he always manages to blow a relationship before it even gets off the ground.\xc2\xa0That\xe2\x80\x99s the nature of Night Bully\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99re frustrated, and they\xe2\x80\x99re lashing out.' b'Urochromes\xe2\x80\x99 new one is about 11 minutes long (if you don\xe2\x80\x99t count the second Boy Harsher remix that\xe2\x80\x99s offered as a digital bonus), and within those time constraints, they build an emotionally complex and sonically elaborate world. This chaotic, always-fluctuating, heavy music undercuts self-consciousness, bitterness, anger, and an unsettling self-confidence. It\xe2\x80\x99s a record that\xc2\xa0easily lends itself to shoving or dancing (or, you know, both) before arriving at a\xc2\xa0shimmering, uncharacteristic come-down. Given how ambitious these 11 minutes are, it\xe2\x80\x99s impossible to predict where they go from here. In an underground scene\xc2\xa0where guitar bands tend be one trick ponies, Urochromes\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0unpredictability lends them\xc2\xa0a rare star quality.'

column7: b"On their fourth album proper, Cuddle Magic dive into the pop side of chamber pop with more fluency and confidence\xc2\xa0than they've ever shown in the past."
column8: b"Individual members of the chamber pop group Cuddle Magic have worked with the likes of Beyonc\xc3\xa9, Amanda Palmer, and Okkervil River.\xc2\xa0But for better or worse Cuddle Magic have never come across as pop-music natives. Their conservatory training always shows through in the combination of complex structures, bright harmonies, and snappy humor that has defined their sound.\xc2\xa0Ashes/Axis marks a major turning point. The proper follow-up to 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Info Nympho\xc2\xa0(following a 2014 full-length collaboration with toy pianist Phyllis Chen and pianist Ran Blake), Ashes/Axis captures Cuddle Magic diving into the \xe2\x80\x9cpop\xe2\x80\x9d side of \xe2\x80\x9cchamber pop\xe2\x80\x9d with more fluency and confidence\xc2\xa0than they\xe2\x80\x99ve ever shown in the past. Right off the bat, the smooth, spit-shined mix by Bryce Goggin (Pavement, Atony and the Johnsons) contrasts dramatically with the dusty immediacy of the band's previous records. From the\xc2\xa0fat, synthetic groove of leadoff track \xe2\x80\x9cSlow Rider\xe2\x80\x9d onward, they've traded the primarily acoustic instrumentation of past work for gurgling, bottom-heavy synths and electronic drumbeats." b"On Let It Be You, last year\xe2\x80\x99s collaboration between Cuddle Magic bandleader Benjamin Lazar Davis and Joan As Policewoman, Lazar Davis went for the commercial jugular with an audacious turn at arena-ready bubblegum R&B. In some ways, Ashes/Axis behaves as a companion piece to that album. Like Let It Be You, several of the songs have a basis in intertwined Ghanaian rhythmic patterns. And it\xe2\x80\x99s obvious that Let It Be You's bassy thump was still in Lazar Davis\xe2\x80\x99 ear when he sat with Goggin to run the original studio tracks for Ashes/Axis through post-production effects." b"But Lazar Davis\xe2\x80\x99 bandmates bring such strong presence to the table that they offset the exaggerated, sweaty-handkerchief affectations that nearly turned Let It Be You into a caricature. Though Lazar Davis remains the principal songwriter, Cuddle Magic\xe2\x80\x99s fellow multi-instrumentalists Christopher McDonald and Alec Spiegelman also contributed songs, as did guest co-writers like Bridget Kearney of Lake Street Dive and Lip Talk\xe2\x80\x99s Sarah K.
