Pedinotti. With all those hands on deck, it's no surprise that Ashes/Axis contains more layers, both musically and thematically. And Kristin Slipp\xe2\x80\x99s vocals, whether she sings lead or backup, serve as a kind of backbone that binds\xc2\xa0the album together." b'Where Joan Wasser opted to keep pace with Lazar Davis\xe2\x80\x99 playful melodramatics on Let It Be You, Slipp\xe2\x80\x99s more reserved style conveys an infinitely wider range of emotions. If you go back to the Info Nympho track \xe2\x80\x9cHoarders,\xe2\x80\x9d she invests the line \xe2\x80\x9cShit/that/fills/our/homes/is/too/hea-/-vy/to/move/and/so/we/leave/it\xe2\x80\x9d (a veiled reference to feeling trapped in a relationship) with a lingering resentment that belies the tune\xe2\x80\x99s quirkiness. On Ashes/Axis, Slipp approaches her vocal parts like an actress with a healthy aversion to overstatement. Once again, she laces the music with faint traces of woe, bringing a sense of everyday believability to the songs even when the lyrics aren\xe2\x80\x99t explicitly clear.' b'When Slipp harmonizes with McDonald on the line "give me the keys / to your condo" on the new tune "Getaway," her voice supplies an extra touch of mournfulness to an already melancholy mood. Easily the most haunting and atmosphere-heavy Cuddle Magic song to date, the song percolates with detail. Throughout the whole album, Lazar Davis and Goggin find creative ways to vary the balance between natural sounds and effects. On "Getaway," they filter a helium-pitched Slipp vocal (that\'s not actually pitched-up) to mimic violin strumming. And when they turn McDonald and Slipp\'s vocals into spectral blurs of reverb at the beginning and end of the tune, the music causes goosebumps, scaling breathtaking heights the band has never attempted before.' b'Strangely enough, Cuddle Magic\xe2\x80\x99s move to a chillier, more digitized palette actually adds dimension to the songs. By reaching outside their comfort zone, they bring the content of the songs to the foreground. Which is not to say the band has lost its organic flavor. On the contrary: at the end of the quasi-title track, \xe2\x80\x9cThe First Hippie on the Moon, Pt. I,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, the music unravels as all of the instruments simply collapse into chaos. At that moment, Cuddle Magic land surprisingly close to a rock band, closing its set out in a heap of smoldering noise. By that point, though, the band\xe2\x80\x99s transformation into a formidable pop act is already complete.'

column7: b'The Copenhagen duo Age Coin features two former members of the post-punk band Lower producing bleak industrial techno. Their second LP\xc2\xa0is inconsistent, but shows promise.'
column8: b'Though Age Coin produces industrial techno, the Copenhagen duo isn\xe2\x80\x99t quite of the club. Kristian Emdal and Simon Formann were both members of the now-defunct post-punk band Lower, and their proximity to punk and noise is tangible on\xc2\xa0Performance, their second full-length, which echoes the intense, bleak temperaments of the bands who have come to define that scene. While the release\xe2\x80\x99s best moments are intricate and beat-driven, its dominant mode seems located more in its interludes of thinly-built, staticky unease. Taken as a whole, these stops and starts can feel less intentionally unsteady and more flat-out inconsistent.' b'In terms of cultivating a mood,\xc2\xa0*Performance\xc2\xa0*starts on a high note. Opener \xe2\x80\x9cEsprit\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s rumbling bass crawls into focus, low-end slowly receding to highlight a single tinny beat. It\xe2\x80\x99s dread-inducing, but also engaging and concise. The lead single \xe2\x80\x9cRaptor,\xe2\x80\x9d far and away the release\xe2\x80\x99s standout track, follows in this vein: its staccato rhythm is tempered with broad, wavering strokes of melody, creating a rare sense of breathing room. It\xe2\x80\x99s reminiscent of textured, Modern Love-style ambient techno, like a softer-edged Demdike Stare.' b'Elsewhere, things turn more abstract, and more claustrophobic. \xe2\x80\x9cDamp\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99s horror-film textures ruminate for a few minutes before opening into cold, insistent percussion, never quite boiling over into true noise. \xe2\x80\x9cProtein\xe2\x80\x9d is similarly soaked in chilling atmospherics, structured around an anxious, fragmentary jungle beat. In a jarring change of pace, \xe2\x80\x9cDomestic I\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cDomestic II\xe2\x80\x9d dispense with beats altogether, instead overlaying a persistent buzz and clatter with mournful instrumentation: on \xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d a cello met with whining harmonies, and on \xe2\x80\x9cII,\xe2\x80\x9d a pretty, rickety piano solo.\xc2\xa0They\xe2\x80\x99re not unattractive compositions, but for the time they take up on this otherwise fairly brief release, these interludes don\xe2\x80\x99t feel particularly well-integrated or useful.' b'Moments of\xc2\xa0Performance\xc2\xa0offer\xc2\xa0welcome glimpses of something more complex than their once-stated mission to evoke\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cfeeling really low in a corner of the club.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cRaptor\xe2\x80\x9d gives a particularly danceable example of this forward movement, but more fearsome moments like closer \xe2\x80\x9cHeadron\xe2\x80\x9d are also promising. At their best, Age Coin synthesize the ambient and industrial mood-building of their past and concurrent projects with the physicality of techno, inducing anxiety through the occasional application of a frenetic texture. A more exciting approach might\xc2\xa0dispense with the instrumental experiments and embrace this path full-on.'

column7: b'The Atlanta trio Migos come back after a commercial and creative dry spell with a #1 single and a definitive work.'
column8: b'Okay, just for a second\xe2\x80\x94as a thought experiment\xe2\x80\x94let\xe2\x80\x99s treat Culture as the sophomore album from the Migos. In this reality, it marks a sharp improvement from the North Atlanta trio\xe2\x80\x99s debut, 2015\xe2\x80\x99s Yung Rich Nation, an album that showed a tremendous amount of technical dexterity, but stiffer writing and only half-formed pop instincts. The Migos are better now, we\xe2\x80\x99d say. They really grew.' b'In the real world, of course, Culture comes in a long, long line of hits, mixtapes, and one-offs. Since \xe2\x80\x9cVersace\xe2\x80\x9d and Y.R.N. (Young Rich Niggas) marked their breakthrough in 2013, they\xe2\x80\x99ve been one of the most influential acts in hip-hop, and frequently one of the best. Their most obvious mark on the culture has been the tight, triplet-laced flow they resurrected and perfected. They also brought the dab to the world at large, and injected a handful of slang terms into the syntaxes of aspiring rappers from coast to coast.' b'So Culture arrives in what feels like the second act of a long career, by rap standards. The Migos came out as young upstarts, suffered through a litany of legal hang-ups and incarcerations, had short creative dry spells where they sniped at the kids on the lawn stealing their styles, and eventually came back around. This time, they have a #1 hit in tow, and they want to stick at the top of the commercial pyramid.' b'The first voice you hear on Culture is DJ Khaled\xe2\x80\x99s, which couldn\xe2\x80\x99t be more misleading. This isn\xe2\x80\x99t a big-budget parade of set pieces and stunt casting; if anything, it\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable for how long stretches of it are sober, somber. Culture\xe2\x80\x99s midpoint is the phenomenal, Zaytoven-produced \xe2\x80\x9cBig on Big,\xe2\x80\x9d which is towering and defiant, and even flips their well-documented label troubles into a point of pride. That track is followed by two more (\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the Price,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBrown Paper Bag\xe2\x80\x9d) that stick to minor keys and contemplative piano. There are plenty of stray prescription pills and idle threats to go around, but they\xe2\x80\x99ve been reassembled to be eerier, more perilous. (Incidentally, this would have been a perfect place to insert \xe2\x80\x9cCocoon,\xe2\x80\x9d their staggering loosie from last year.)' b'Culture\xc2\xa0is front-loaded with singles, which\xe2\x80\x94perhaps counter-intuitively\xe2\x80\x94makes for a nice balance. Heard back-to-back-to-back, \xe2\x80\x9cT-Shirt,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cCall Casting,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cBad and Boujee\xe2\x80\x9d are not only packed with color and virtuosic rapping, but elucidate exactly what each of the three rappers bring to the table, how they complement one another. Hearing Quavo float is a joy, but it\xe2\x80\x99s even better when it\xe2\x80\x99s underscored by Takeoff\xe2\x80\x99s bass and Offset\xe2\x80\x99s serration. There are also fascinating reconciliations:\xc2\xa0The Cardo-produced,\xc2\xa02 Chainz-featuring \xe2\x80\x9cDeadz\xe2\x80\x9d seems to find a middle ground between the sparse Atlanta sounds and Chicago\xe2\x80\x99s maximalism that were warring around the time of\xc2\xa0Y.R.N.' b'Then there\xc2\xa0are truly strange moments. \xe2\x80\x9cAll Ass,\xe2\x80\x9d from the album\xe2\x80\x99s (uh) back end, sounds like Magic City mixed with industrial Berlin. \xe2\x80\x9cSlippery,\xe2\x80\x9d in an inspired move, turns a \xe2\x80\x9cskrrt skrrt\xe2\x80\x9d ad-lib into the song\xe2\x80\x99s melodic backbone. Even when Culture grasps for the radio dial, it skirts expectations.\xc2\xa0The arc here is not one of artists leaving their roots to chase pop\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s pop coming back around to accommodate them.' b'While the Migos are decidedly of Atlanta (coupled with some cadences from up in Tennessee), their records frequently remind you of rap\xe2\x80\x99s earlier years, when creative kids holed up in bedrooms and tried to impress or make each other laugh\xe2\x80\x94think The Migos Is Dead or Bizarre Ride II Nawfside. Culture might have national aspirations, but it\xe2\x80\x99s charged with the energy of history, of family. On \xe2\x80\x9cWhat the Price,\xe2\x80\x9d Takeoff raps about the teachers and preachers of his youth who presented an inaccessible, exclusionary path forward. When he shirks that (\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ma go find me a better route\xe2\x80\x9d), it\xe2\x80\x99s not flippant, it\xe2\x80\x99s resolute.' b'Later on the same song, Offset runs through a consumer fever dream, anchored by the line \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t plan on going out sad today.\xe2\x80\x9d In other contexts, that might be a curious aside, but over Ricky Racks, 808Godz and KeanuBeats\xe2\x80\x99 somber track, it sounds like the album\xe2\x80\x99s spiritual center. The Migos are (probably) not better than the Beatles,\xc2\xa0but their existence shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be reduced to memes that debate the issue. On Culture, their world is richly rendered, full of hopes and paranoia and unbridled joy. This gives the Migos the last laugh on those who thought they\xe2\x80\x99d never crack the retail album format, marked all the while by the knowledge they never needed one to succeed. It\xe2\x80\x99s a definitive work.'

column7: b'The godfather of grime\xe2\x80\x99s back-to-basics swan song isn\xe2\x80\x99t just a celebration of his 20 year career\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s a victory lap for grime at large.'
column8: b'To the casual listener, grime might seem like a once-dormant genre in the midst of a revival. But truth be told, the hybrid of hip-hop and UK garage never went anywhere\xe2\x80\x94the only thing that changed was the genre\xe2\x80\x99s visibility. Ever since grime\xe2\x80\x99s emergence on British pirate radio at the turn of the millennium, the UK mainstream (not to mention American listeners) has tended to pay attention to the genre only when it produces a charismatic star. Wiley knows this better than most. He was a chief architect of grime\xe2\x80\x99s early sound (his tracks were among the first\xc2\xa0to be labeled \xe2\x80\x9cgrime\xe2\x80\x9d), assembled the seminal Roll Deep crew, helped his prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9 Dizzee Rascal become grime\xe2\x80\x99s first breakout artist and later, pushed the genre even deeper into the mainstream with a string of successful club-pop singles. He\xe2\x80\x99s somehow managed to weather the interest of a fickle public for two full decades, though he has plenty of scars to show for it. In response to allegations of selling out, he\xe2\x80\x99s spent a good deal of his career apologizing for and actively disowning any attempts he\xe2\x80\x99s made to court a wider audience, though his frequent course-corrections have sometimes felt more like self-sabotage. He\xe2\x80\x99s a survivor, if not a particularly triumphant one.' b"Given this history, you\xe2\x80\x99d think Wiley would be frustrated to find that the latest wave of grime artists have arrived at\xc2\xa0success far more easily and on their own terms: for today\xe2\x80\x99s emcees, staying true to grime\xe2\x80\x99s sound and topping the charts are hardly mutually exclusive. Instead, Wiley seems reinvigorated by his peers' achievements, especially those\xc2\xa0of Skepta, the latest of his mentees to follow in Dizzee\xe2\x80\x99s footsteps, Mercury Prize and all. Supposedly his parting gift to the culture he helped birth, Godfather finds Wiley attempting to pull off the same trick that Skepta did with Konnichiwa: a lifer goes back to his roots and channels the energy of a hungry upstart. It\xe2\x80\x99s a tall order for a rapper pushing 40 but Godfather largely delivers, feeling at once like a return to form for Wiley and a celebration of grime\xe2\x80\x99s foundational sound." b"Part of the album\xe2\x80\x99s success stems from its single-minded focus. Unlike many of Wiley's albums,\xc2\xa0Godfather tends to cut to the chase, that being manic, double-time rapping over chirpy 140 bpm beats. Production has always been Wiley\xe2\x80\x99s primary strength but on Godfather, he mostly absolves himself of those duties, turning over the boards to young upstarts like Preditah and Swifta Beater, as well as seasoned vets like Rude Kid. Still, each of these collaborators works in service of the overarching mission: songs that update Wiley\xe2\x80\x99s blocky \xe2\x80\x9ceskibeat\xe2\x80\x9d sound using modern production techniques." b'Wiley has never been a great rapper per se, but on every song here he shows up with a surplus of energy, confidence and charisma. On the frantic \xe2\x80\x9cBait Face,\xe2\x80\x9d he goes bar-for-bar with his old crewmate Scratchy without breaking a sweat. He sounds right at home on the torch-passing posse cut \xe2\x80\x9cName Brand,\xe2\x80\x9d which brings together Roll Deep member J2K with Jme and Frisco from Boy Better Know. On tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cBirds N Bars\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t Go Wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xc2\xa0borrows Skepta\xe2\x80\x99s breathless flow but cuts it with a halting, staccato delivery. There are, of course, a few corny one-liners scattered throughout the record (\xe2\x80\x9cI stand out like one break light,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFresh out the oven like a Sunday roast,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re plain, I\xe2\x80\x99m the loaded nachos\xe2\x80\x9d) and even an entire song dedicated to his MacBook Pro (\xe2\x80\x9cLaptop\xe2\x80\x9d). However, at this point in Wiley\xe2\x80\x99s career, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard for this stuff to read as anything but endearingly goofy, more like dad jokes than genuine missteps.' b'Ultimately, Godfather is a thoroughly enjoyable record, one that manages to leverage grime\xe2\x80\x99s elemental sounds in a way that feels vital and forward-looking. Sure, its peaks might not be quite as high as those of Konnichiwa, the record that it\xe2\x80\x99s bound to be measured against (Skepta\xe2\x80\x99s mastery of the massive, shout-along hook continues to give him an edge). But for anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s ever rooted for Wiley, it\xe2\x80\x99s a deeply satisfying listen. After all, until recently, Wiley disowned not just the \xe2\x80\x9cgodfather of grime\xe2\x80\x9d nickname but the term \xe2\x80\x9cgrime\xe2\x80\x9d altogether. And here he is, unapologetically owning his influence, toasting to his peers\xe2\x80\x99 successes and claiming his rightful place as grime\xe2\x80\x99s elder statesman. Who knows if Godfather is actually Wiley\xe2\x80\x99s final solo album\xe2\x80\x94we\xe2\x80\x99ve certainly heard that one from him before. But if it is, he can step away knowing that his legacy has been secured.'

column7: b"In the wake of the tragic Ghost Ship fire,\xc2\xa0100% Silk has released Sensate Silk, a well-curated compilation that doubles as a rallying cry for dance music's underground."
column8: b"Britt and Amanda Brown never could have imagined that their record label would one day make national news, or that it would happen under the worst possible circumstances. Founded in 2011, 100% Silk began as a home for scrappy electronic artists from various musical backgrounds. Their predominant sound, a lo-fi approach that became known as \xe2\x80\x9coutsider house\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9chipster house,\xe2\x80\x9d was decidedly niche\xe2\x80\x94dance music by and for experimental, DIY music communities. But last year, on December 2, 100% Silk became widely mentioned outside of their usual circles. A fire broke out that Friday in an Oakland warehouse known as the Ghost Ship, where an event featuring some of the label's artists was underway, and it claimed 36 lives. Amanda wrote on Facebook the next day: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat happened in Oakland is an unbelievable tragedy, a nightmare scenario. Britt and I are beside ourselves, utterly devastated.\xe2\x80\x9d" b"The Ghost Ship fire was more than tragic national news; it sent a resounding shockwave through underground music communities around the world. As the names, photos, and stories of the deceased began to surface, a common response from musicians and fans was that it all \xe2\x80\x9chit so close to home.\xe2\x80\x9d Many saw themselves in the faces and lives of the lost; there were those who were meant to attend the party that night but didn't, those who would have been there if they'd been in town, and of course there were those who lost their dear friends and family. Among the numerous young, talented people killed in the fire were 100% Silk artists Johnny Igaz, aka Nackt, and Chelsea Faith Dolan, aka Cherushii. Nearly two months later, relief events continue providing a place to honor and mourn these vibrant lives that feel all too familiar." b"In his article about the Oakland DIY scene in the fire's aftermath, Sam Lefebvre underlined the necessity of places like the Ghost Ship with a quote invoking the words of MLK: \xe2\x80\x9cPeople need places to gather in Beloved Community.\xe2\x80\x9d More than just a concert or a dance party, the 100% Silk showcase was a gathering for locals and likeminded visitors, a space to explore and develop their culture. It was an event not unlike countless others that happen every night around the world, many of which have since come under scrutiny or been shut down by law enforcement. The Ghost Ship tragedy has brought about a renewed focus on safety in DIY venues, but it has also put them at greater risk. In the midst of this, 100% Silk has released Sensate Silk, a well-curated compilation that doubles as a rallying cry for dance music's underground." b'Sensate Silk was conceived as the label\xe2\x80\x99s 100th release well before December 2, but it has come to represent more than a milestone in their catalog. For some it\xe2\x80\x99s a memorial, featuring one of the last tracks written by Nackt, the patient, cheerful acid of \xe2\x80\x9cRising Tide.\xe2\x80\x9d Or it\xe2\x80\x99s an embodiment of intertwined global scenes, with beautiful deep house from Japanese artists Keita Sano and Inoue Shirabe alongside a bass-loaded banger by LA\xe2\x80\x99s Sage Caswell and meditative melodies from UK producer Helios Mode. The compilation is also an important show of perseverance from a label and community still reeling from disaster. In a Facebook post at the end of 2016, Britt Brown wrote, \xe2\x80\x9cThis has been a negative year for plenty of other reasons. But music brought us together. And music will keep us together.\xe2\x80\x9d The sentiment seems to pulse through every synth and drum machine on Sensate Silk.' b'From the soulful atmosphere this kind of house music exudes, Sensate Silk fosters a sense of healing as well. \xe2\x80\x9cRoses\xe2\x80\x9d is a groovy, intricate standout by Donny, an alias of Golden Donna, who survived the Ghost Ship fire. Its energy is split between contemplative chords, distant vocal abstractions, and a lively bounce, like a dancer whose memories follow them into the club. PARC\xe2\x80\x99s 11-minute \xe2\x80\x9cSilk Road\xe2\x80\x9d rises from burbling electronics into a cosmic dancefloor embrace, while the sax Cromie weaves through the plush \xe2\x80\x9cShe Knew\xe2\x80\x9d resonates with quiet heartache. These songs weren\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily written as balm for listeners, but their thoughtfulness and delicate natures will graciously soothe those who need it.' b"At the end of Sensate Silk is a song by unknown Berlin artist Westcoast Goddess. \xe2\x80\x9cUntitled Soul \xe2\x80\x9898\xe2\x80\x9d is the compilation's brightest highlight, and not just because it has an uncommon way with tension and euphoria. Its buoyant slow build sounds lovingly handmade, with hi-hats clattering slightly too loud and a central synth loop that shifts and swells like a DJ mixing on the fly. Seven bubbly minutes in, it culminates in a brilliant lead line that could coax hands into the air as soon as bring a tear to the eye. Closing a compilation that\xe2\x80\x99s heavy with meaning for many people, \xe2\x80\x9cUntitled Soul \xe2\x80\x9998\xe2\x80\x9d is a welcome burst of joy after months of grief. It\xe2\x80\x99s only fitting that those who are still here should remember those who are gone in celebration of the music they lived to support and create."

column7: b'This Mexico City-based experimental collective\xc2\xa0has been operating underground for over 20 years.\xc2\xa0Here,\xc2\xa0Feeding Tube Records reissues a vital compilation of their\xc2\xa0art-rock psychedelia.'
column8: b'With our crate-digger culture reaching peak levels, it\xe2\x80\x99s always surprising to find an artist that has been making music for over 20 years and\xc2\xa0hasn\xe2\x80\x99t already been anthologized. That\xe2\x80\x99s what makes the surprise arrival of Los Lichis, a collective of experimental musicians and visual artists from Mexico City that first started working together in 1996, such a vital shock to the system. Chances are the recent reissue by Massachusetts-based\xc2\xa0Feeding Tube Records of Dog, a comp culling from the group\xe2\x80\x99s self-released material, is the first time you\xe2\x80\x99re hearing of them.' b'The members of Los Lichis\xe2\x80\x94Jos\xc3\xa9 Luis Rojas, Gerardo Monsiv\xc3\xa1is, Manuel Mathar, and\xc2\xa0French sound artist Jean Baptiste Favory\xe2\x80\x94are entirely responsible for keeping below the cultural radar. Until recently, their music was only available for purchase in art galleries in Mexico. They have been slow to embrace digital distribution; their Bandcamp\xc2\xa0is just\xc2\xa0a couple months old. But from the sounds of this fantastic collection of dessicated art rock, cracked electronic experiments, and AM radio intrusions, their emergence from the shadows feels\xc2\xa0long overdue.' b'While the two-LP set isn\xe2\x80\x99t arranged chronologically, listening through reveals how these men evolved as musicians and improvisers. Their work from the late \xe2\x80\x9990s\xe2\x80\x94made before the arrival of Favory and his synthesizers\xe2\x80\x94is rough-hewn and exploratory, built from junky-sounding drum machine rhythms and warbling electronic melodies. It has the excitement of Morton Subotnick compositions. Other tracks from that era, like the loopy and drowsy \xe2\x80\x9cOpium Boogie\xe2\x80\x9d and Throbbing Gristle-esque \xe2\x80\x9cOsaka \xe2\x80\x9977,\xe2\x80\x9d are a little more direct but remain\xc2\xa0suffused with a healthy dose of tape hiss and a playful energy.' b'As a producer, Favory\xe2\x80\x99s input through the \xe2\x80\x9900s on\xc2\xa0helped bring Los Lichis even further into focus. Favory\xc2\xa0met Mathar and Monsiv\xc3\xa1is when the pair showed their art at Paris\xe2\x80\x99s International Contemporary Art Fair (FIAC) in 2000, and since then, he\xc2\xa0has been a satellite member of the group, visiting Mexico once a year for improv sessions and performances. His impact helped clean up their recordings considerably, and it\xc2\xa0also brought a welcome psych rock influence to the proceedings. \xe2\x80\x9cL\xe2\x80\x99Origine de la Guitare Fant\xc3\xb4me\xe2\x80\x9d slinks from its slow, glittery build into a nicely dawdling Dead-like jam punctuated by insistent keyboard bleats. \xe2\x80\x9cL\xe2\x80\x99In\xc3\xa9vitable Catastrophe,\xe2\x80\x9d meanwhile, has the overwhelming gush of a Loveless\xc2\xa0interlude.' b'What this collection is missing is the more overt political commentary that has been central to the visual work that Los Lichis has done on their own and as a collective. There are hints within certain song titles\xe2\x80\x94the early Sonic Youth sounding \xe2\x80\x9cKrondstat Variation\xe2\x80\x9d is an apparent reference to the site of a major uprising during the Russian Civil War, and an overmodulated blues jam from 2002 is given the name \xe2\x80\x9cEva und Adolf\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but otherwise, the music could have even more impact if married with some of the group\xe2\x80\x99s striking videos and paintings. Even without visual accompaniment, Los Lichis retain that naturalistic spark and simmering wildness that only the best improvised music can provide.'

column3: b'The World Is a Loud Place'
column7: b"On their third\xc2\xa0album, Brooklyn\xe2\x80\x99s Landlady perfect their quizzical prog-pop. The album is best when it's most vexing, while frontman Adam Schatz explores basic human sensation with a Cheshire Cat wit."
column8: b'Certain political travesties of the last few months have promoted a hands-over-ears response from even the most optimistic citizens, with logic drowned out by alternative\xc2\xa0facts and social media bloviations. Suddenly it feels much more difficult just to be in the world, which is the animating idea behind the third\xc2\xa0album by the Brooklyn collective Landlady. The World Is a Loud Place is one of those works of art that was made in one era but released in another, darker one. It\xe2\x80\x99s an album that perhaps wasn\xe2\x80\x99t intended to be political, but in 2017 it\xe2\x80\x99s inescapably politicized. Frontman and chief songwriter Adam Schatz isn\xe2\x80\x99t trying to topple regimes or even speak truth to errant power; rather, he\xe2\x80\x99s just trying to evoke the sensation of being in a human body at this point in time.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cFeel your heart beat once, there it goes again,\xe2\x80\x9d Schatz sings on \xe2\x80\x9cElectric Abdomen,\xe2\x80\x9d the album\xe2\x80\x99s opener, as though the continuity of consciousness was a surprise. The song itself spools out in zig zags, changing direction and tempo abruptly and without warning. From their previous record to this one, the band have mastered a kind of lenticular prog-pop, defined by busybody arrangements and winding structures that form a fitting musical approximation of that .gif album cover: always in motion, always jumping from one idea to the next. \xe2\x80\x9cRest in Place\xe2\x80\x9d snakes around into a big brass fanfare, although it fades out before you can discern the motive: Is it triumphant or cautionary? Do those horns constitute a happy ending or is the killer still alive, ready to pounce at us once more?' b'Schatz presides over these songs with a mischievous glint in his eye\xe2\x80\x94half wiseacre Virgil leading us through a new American hellscape, part grinning Cheshire Cat sitting in inscrutable judgment. His lyrics recall the fragmented domestic scenery of recent Wilco tunes: trapped in first person, always trying to make sense of another person. \xe2\x80\x9cTeach me how you\xe2\x80\x99re organized,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings on \xe2\x80\x9cCadaver,\xe2\x80\x9d and it sounds like the most existential pick-up line imaginable. \xe2\x80\x9cJust be happy with the guts that we\xe2\x80\x99ve got\xe2\x80\x9d is his warped version of a kitten-poster platitude. It\xe2\x80\x99s a harsh world, but certainly not unpleasant to visit, thanks to Schatz\xe2\x80\x99s gnomic\xc2\xa0charisma.' b'Has anyone ever enunciated the word \xe2\x80\x9cCalifornia\xe2\x80\x9d with as much loopy precision as he does on \xe2\x80\x9cDriving in California\xe2\x80\x9d? Schatz savors every consonant and vowel, then tosses the word out the car window with a distracted \xe2\x80\x9c-yeah.\xe2\x80\x9d The\xc2\xa0song is almost purposefully annoying, like a parody of tour songs or Golden State paeans: \xe2\x80\x9cDriving in Californ-yeah makes me forget everywhere that\xe2\x80\x99s not Californ-yeah.\xe2\x80\x9d Then Schatz moves eastward, first to Colorado and then to Niagara, picking up in cleverness along the way. It\xe2\x80\x99s the only track on The World Is a Loud Place where Schatz\xe2\x80\x99s lyrics are superficially sensical, where the lyrical conceit is too unwieldy for him and the agile band to handle.' b'The album is best when it\xe2\x80\x99s most vexing, when its puzzle-piece arrangements demand you put everything together. Part of the fun is following the circuitous routes these compositions take and hearing the oddball flourishes Landlady insert into the arrangements. Landlady craft a cacophony, but Schatz won\xe2\x80\x99t put his hands over his ears: There\xe2\x80\x99s some beauty in the noise that\xe2\x80\x99s worth going deaf to hear.'

column7: b'The new album from R&B singer Kehlani Parrish\xc2\xa0is refreshingly\xc2\xa0self-assured. She\xe2\x80\x99s got a lot to say on these songs, which are blunt, unflinching, and exuberant.'
column8: b'There are a couple of ways to tell the story of Kehlani Parrish\xe2\x80\x99s ascension from a gifted hopeful to a higher R&B court. One is a story of unhindered success: in her teens, Kehlani was the vocalist of a covers band that earned fourth place on \xe2\x80\x9cAmerica\xe2\x80\x99s Got Talent\xe2\x80\x9d and placed her on the radar of Nick Cannon and most major labels. Atlantic groomed her publicly and behind the scenes for cred and stardom, from 2014 mixtape *Cloud 19 *to 2015\xe2\x80\x99s album-called-mixtape You Should Be Here to heavy promotion at radio. By 2016, she\xe2\x80\x99d scored nods from both pop and pomp culture: a trendily morose cut on the soundtrack to\xe2\x80\x94brace yourself for the following phrase\xe2\x80\x94the Oscar-nominated *Suicide Squad *and a left-field Grammy nomination for a Best Urban Contemporary Album that is still a free set on SoundCloud.' b'The other story is one of overcoming the system. That \xe2\x80\x9cAmerica\xe2\x80\x99s Got Talent\xe2\x80\x9d stint only panned out after several difficult years\xe2\x80\x94contractual hell, homelessness, depression\xe2\x80\x94and what followed was\xc2\xa0hardly fairytale. It\xe2\x80\x99s pretty uncontroversial now to recognize turn-of-the-century R&B as overflowing with innovation and talent, but A&Rs remain\xc2\xa0terrible at knowing what to do with it. For every *The Writing\xe2\x80\x99s on the Wall or Aaliyah,\xc2\xa0*there are three slept-on debuts and overlooked follow-ups, and who knows how many shelved, stalled, and otherwise mismanaged counterparts. The 2010s revival is more ephemeral in its streaming numbers and blog buzz, but not much kinder to its potential stars. Despite two hits in \xe2\x80\x9c2 On\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAll Hands on Deck,\xe2\x80\x9d Tinashe\xe2\x80\x99s *Joyride *tour was cut short. Kelela and SZA are excellent yet still \xe2\x80\x9crising.\xe2\x80\x9d Jhen\xc3\xa9 Aiko is in a group with Big Sean. And Kehlani\xe2\x80\x99s output and talent has consistently exceeded what its promotion would imply. *You Should Be Here *was a big-leagues album promoted like a mixtape\xe2\x80\x94an increasingly common blurred \xe2\x80\x9cindie\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmainstream\xe2\x80\x9d marketing tack\xe2\x80\x94and judging by the album features (Zayn?) and tour spots (G-Eazy) she\xe2\x80\x99s done since, the industry seems to be pigeonholing her with performers who are hilariously out of her league.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s even more remarkable, then, that *SweetSexySavage *is so self-assured: the work of a distinctive artist owning\xc2\xa0a style that seemingly everyone is attempting. Kehlani doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even try to disinvite comparisons\xe2\x80\x94the album\xe2\x80\x99s title is a direct play\xc2\xa0on TLC\xe2\x80\x99s CrazySexyCool, and it\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0full of nods to the past, like the \xe2\x80\x9cTry Again\xe2\x80\x9d intro of \xe2\x80\x9cAdvice.\xe2\x80\x9d But unlike so much R&B, *SweetSexySavage *neither relies on nostalgia nor falls into the traps these throwback albums tend towards: treating R&B as a costume, the musical equivalent of a belly shirt, or recreating in hazy moods and amorphous vibes a genre better known for massive hooks.' b'The production helps. In addition to longtime producer Jahaan Sweet, *SweetSexySavage *brings in Pop & Oak\xe2\x80\x94among the more promising of pop-R&B production teams (Usher\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cGood Kisser\xe2\x80\x9d is a highlight)\xe2\x80\x94and it avoids many diluted\xc2\xa0Top 40 names. \xe2\x80\x9cEscape\xe2\x80\x9d is a sweet mid-tempo ballad that flirts and flutters around the edge of saying \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t make you love me,\xe2\x80\x9d but it\xe2\x80\x99s also kind of like a Jordin Sparks album cut. The soundtrack cut \xe2\x80\x9cGangsta\xe2\x80\x9d is a clever update of 2000s thug-love tracks, like \xe2\x80\x9cSoldier\xe2\x80\x9d or almost any Ja Rule duet, to the glum mien of movie and radio pop, but it\xe2\x80\x99s rightly relegated to the bonus tracks.' b'Good production is relatively easy to find, though; voices like Kehlani\xe2\x80\x99s are not. Her closest Y2K peer is probably Kandi Burruss: a consummate songwriter equally adept at hitmaking and candor. Kehlani is a talented vocalist, but on record she\xe2\x80\x99s conversational, with a lot\xc2\xa0to say. Much of SweetSexySavage is about reclamation: taking all the shit women receive from men, shrugging, and asking, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat about it?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf I gotta be a bitch, I\xe2\x80\x99mma be a bad one,\xe2\x80\x9d she taunts on \xe2\x80\x9cCRZY,\xe2\x80\x9d and the track isn\xe2\x80\x99t resigned but an anthem. \xe2\x80\x9cDistraction,\xe2\x80\x9d arranged like a one-woman girl group, walks the independent-woman walk by setting clear, disinterested boundaries for its come-on: \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t say I give my all... are you down to be a distraction?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNot Used to It\xe2\x80\x9d is unflinching in its fear of commitment. On \xe2\x80\x9cDo U Dirty,\xe2\x80\x9d Kehlani\xe2\x80\x99s a player and proud of it; the dreamy production makes lines like \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m cold and yet life is colder.../I could fuck you now and years later on you\xe2\x80\x99re going to be stuck just reminiscing\xe2\x80\x9d catch listeners off-guard. The bluntness is welcome\xc2\xa0in today\xe2\x80\x99s music world, full of men reveling in such scumbaggery and women exploring, in song after despairing song, codependence and the wounds it\xc2\xa0causes. Kehlani\xe2\x80\x99s adept at the latter as well; \xe2\x80\x9cEverything Is Yours\xe2\x80\x9d is a moody love song steeped in loathing. Kehlani sings \xe2\x80\x9cmy ring is yours, everything is yours,\xe2\x80\x9d and it\xe2\x80\x99s just as much a confession of love as of giving up.' b"But Kehlani can be more optimistic. She told Rolling Stone\xc2\xa0that, where\xc2\xa0Cloud 19 proved \xe2\x80\x9cI can sing!\xe2\x80\x9d and\xc2\xa0You Should Be Here showed \xe2\x80\x9cI can write!,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0her new album says, \xe2\x80\x9cI can chill! And have fun!\xe2\x80\x9d The single\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cUndercover,\xe2\x80\x9d for one, captures perfectly the delirious headspace of having the most disastrous and unlikely of your crushes reciprocated:\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThey don't wanna see it happen,\xe2\x80\x9d Kehlani sings, \xe2\x80\x9cBut we say fuck it.\xe2\x80\x9d Refreshingly,\xc2\xa0SweetSexySavage is at its best\xc2\xa0when it\xe2\x80\x99s most exuberant,\xc2\xa0giddy in the face of haters and common sense alike."

column3: b'Drawing the Target Around the Arrow'
column7: b'Caroline Polachek, of the recently disbanded synth-pop outfit Chairlift, offers eighteen sparse instrumental tracks, with reedy sine wave tones moving meditatively in negative space.'
column8: b'Caroline Polachek\xe2\x80\x94of the recently-disbanded synth-pop outfit Chairlift\xe2\x80\x94has characterized her forays into sine-wave synth composition as a recuperative process, \xe2\x80\x9can ear break from working on whatever I was working on.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0Drawing the Target Around the Arrow, released under her initials, CEP,*\xc2\xa0*collects eighteen of these sparse instrumental tracks, recorded between 2012 and 2016. Polachek\xe2\x80\x99s songwriting for Chairlift and solo projects like Ramona Lisa often skews dreamy and ornate, sometimes edging into cloying, but these compositions embrace a neutral, elemental sound.\xc2\xa0Drawing the Target\xc2\xa0is less a departure than a detour, but it\xe2\x80\x99s a lovely one all the same, offering a sort of instinctual minimalism without conceptual baggage.' b'Sine waves are sound in its most elemental (and, in a sense, least stylized) form; aesthetically,\xc2\xa0*Drawing the Target\xc2\xa0*is made of thin, its reedy tones bending into one another but rarely intersecting. Full of negative space, it\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of music that gets lost if it\xe2\x80\x99s competing with conversation, or street sounds, or the rush of a subway car. In this sense, these tracks are personal by design, cultivating something of a contemplative space. Some melodies on the album emerge more resolute than others\xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cSingalong\xe2\x80\x9d repeats, in vibraphone-like staccato, a sweet, optimistic phrase, and \xe2\x80\x9cSleeping Fish\xe2\x80\x9d sounds like it could be a sketch for a B-side from Huerco S.\xe2\x80\x99s recent album\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s just as likely to softly growl and hum. \xe2\x80\x9cBorg Pillow\xe2\x80\x9d is almost pure texture, quietly groaning in and out, and \xe2\x80\x9cPupil\xe2\x80\x9d sustains the same unchanging notes for its full five-and-a-half-minute duration.' b"The overall tone is generally unobtrusive, and the individual tracks often run together. To this effect, it almost seems odd that the songs have been given titles that conjure physical objects, nature, and human emotion: perhaps the most satisfying aspect of this release is its definitively non-linguistic form of expression.\xc2\xa0And yet, even if the sine wave is a distinctly unvarnished tool for music-making, Polachek\xe2\x80\x99s compositions are also stylish in their way. Minimalism is often embraced as a utilitarian salve to cultural overload\xe2\x80\x94in this case, applied as a practical break from pop music's loaded emotional structures. But the smart elegance that drives Drawing the Target, I imagine, will also map well onto the fleshier pop songs Polachek has to come."

column3: b'Three Worlds: Music From Woolf Works'
column7: b"Max Richter's score for the narrative dance piece Woolf Works shows how the minimalist composer has become obsessed with storytelling in the later years of his career."
column8: b'Two years ago, the choreographer Wayne McGregor premiered \xe2\x80\x9cWoolf Works,\xe2\x80\x9d a narrative dance piece based on three Virginia Woolf novels (Mrs. Dalloway, Orlando, and The Waves) at the Royal Opera House. He enlisted Max Richter to pen an original score for over\xc2\xa0two-hour, three-act affair. The production, by and large, was polarizing, eliciting high praise and violent rebuke.\xc2\xa0The New York Times singled out\xc2\xa0Richter\xe2\x80\x99s score, which \xe2\x80\x9cfrequently veer[ed] into cinematic manipulativeness.\xe2\x80\x9d It is hard not to read this an indictment of Richter, but in reality, it highlights how his score is able to stand apart from the piece it belongs to. Now available for the first time, a slightly truncated version of Richter\xe2\x80\x99s score proves something he has been talking about quite a bit in the later years of his career: that his work is unified by an obsession with storytelling.' b'The score opens up with \xe2\x80\x9cWord,\xe2\x80\x9d the first movement in the first act (inspired by Mrs. Dalloway). The piece is composed of a chorus of bells, gongs, and sampled human bustling\xc2\xa0(the bell of Parliament\xe2\x80\x99s Elizabeth Tower, traffic in Gordon Square). Seconds later, through the haze, the only known recording of Virginia Woolf\xe2\x80\x99s voice plays. She reads a portion of the essay part of a BBC broadcast called \xe2\x80\x9cWords Fail Me,\xe2\x80\x9d waxing poetic on the ghostly nature of the English language (\xe2\x80\x9cWords, English words, are full of echoes, of memories, of associations\xe2\x80\x9d) and the impossible negotiation between private meaning and public discourse in prose writing. It is a stunning way to open the score, and gives credence to Richter\xe2\x80\x99s invisible hand shaping the narrative of the dance.' b'After the introduction, the next three pieces cleave closer to convention. Apparently, much like Dalloway, the sounds are supposed to evoke the novel\xe2\x80\x99s revolutionary focus on the \xe2\x80\x9ctexture of the ordinary day,\xe2\x80\x9d and here, Richter takes that to mean something closer to rote string arrangements, where dips and dives are telegraphed like a routine ballroom dance. Some of it is quite beautiful, foregrounding his graceful piano playing. \xe2\x80\x9cWar Anthem,\xe2\x80\x9d in particular, is quite similar to some of his earlier work, like \xe2\x80\x9cOn the Nature of Daylight,\xe2\x80\x9d epic scale and all.' b"The more adventurous side of Richter is made more apparent in the dance\xe2\x80\x99s second act, based on Orlando, Woolf\xe2\x80\x99s most personal work. Inspired by the novel\xe2\x80\x99s transformational conceit, (it tells a fictional biography of a 16th-century male poet who turns into a woman, and lives till the present day) he turned to the \xe2\x80\x9cLa Folia,\xe2\x80\x9d a Portuguese folk dance so wild and noisy that it was associated with madness. Richter's singular ability to meld electronics into classical arrangements breathes life into this idea, and on pieces\xc2\xa0like the \xe2\x80\x9cThe Explorers\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cModular Astronomy,\xe2\x80\x9d he deploys electronics that are both silken and pointedly mechanical. He uses glitches, hiccups, and washes of noise to elevate pockets of lonely strings and keystrokes to heights of anachronistic beauty. Other works\xc2\xa0like \xe2\x80\x9cEntropy\xe2\x80\x9d recall the squeamish grace of Oneohtrix Point Never." b'The score concludes with the sounds of waves lapping in the middle of the ocean, and\xc2\xa0Gillian Anderson\xe2\x80\x99s voice floats into focus, giving dramatic reading of Woolf\xe2\x80\x99s suicide letter to her husband Leonard. After almost 40 minutes of instrumental music, the introduction of an august British voice is startling. For a second, it can feel too on-the-nose (of course the section about *The Waves has waves), and maybe even manipulative to use the letter to elicit an emotional response. But, as Anderson\xe2\x80\x99s voice dissolves into the oceanic strings, the next 21 minutes build to a plaintive, melancholy peak. Richter said that his 8-hour piece Sleep\xc2\xa0*was a much easier work than Woolf Works, and it shows; he was asked to make a musical world for three vastly different novels, united by an almost private language of symbols and themes. His goal with the score was to \xe2\x80\x9cevoke the experience of jumping between languages\xe2\x80\x9d in order to mimic what Woolf so often does in her writing. Like McGregor, he set an impossible bar, and even if he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t clear it, the fall leads to something arresting nonetheless.'

column7: b'On his latest as Egyptrixx, it sounds more than ever like the Toronto electronic musician is trying to burrow inside a migraine, stick contact mics to its contours, and figure out what makes it tick.'
column8: b'It must not be easy being one of David Psutka\xe2\x80\x99s reverb units. He pushes them hard, stretching their sustain settings to extreme lengths and running heavy material through them constantly: The clang of struck sheet metal, the crash of broken windows, the dissonant peal of heavy bells. His reverb is so glassy and expansive it feels like the main attraction, not the supplementary effect. Most musicians apply reverb the way a photographer might subtly retouch an image, using it to add a sense of depth to a given sound. But in Psutka\xe2\x80\x99s hands, it comes across more like one of Madame Tussaud\xe2\x80\x99s wax sculptures\xe2\x80\x94an eerie, distended facsimile immobilized under a spotlight, a frozen echo deep in the uncanny valley.' b'Where Psutka\xe2\x80\x99s first two records hewed to the jagged blueprint proposed by his Night Slugs peers, his recent work has been getting more and more abstract, downplaying club music\xe2\x80\x99s beats in favor of an all-encompassing throb. On his latest album as Egyptrixx, his main alias, it sounds more than ever like the Toronto electronic musician is trying to burrow inside a migraine, stick contact mics to its contours, and figure out just what makes it tick. It is a heaving mass of ringing copper and seasick frequencies. Not only is it free of anything you might classify as a melody; even its basslines are reduced to an ominous rumble, and its glancing riffs feel as accidental as wind chimes.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a long way away from the prickly, technoid pulse of tunes like \xe2\x80\x9cA/B Til Infinity\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0or \xe2\x80\x9cBible Eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d which variously explored John Carpenter synths and the loping beats of UK funky. But it makes for a logical next step from his last album as Egyptrixx, 2015\xe2\x80\x99s doomy Transfer of Energy (Feelings of Power), and it comes even closer in spirit to a record that he released last year under his Ceramic TL alias, Sign of the Cross Every Mile to the Border. That album, a mostly ambient exploration of held bell tones and granular delay, had the bitter reek of an electrical fire, and this record replicates those noxious atmospheres and reintroduces beats: thudding kick drums, zippering hi-hats, and the incessant din of battered metal. His scrap-heap percussion often has more in common with Einst\xc3\xbcrzende Neubauten than it does club music peers like Bok Bok or Jam City.' b'Despite the heaviness, the bell tones\xe2\x80\x99 broad, spectral sweep infuses the music with a rich, burnished glow, and the presence of vocoders and chiming FM synths only adds to the luminous air. The album opens with the sound of running water, and that sound recurs throughout the record, bubbling up like a hot spring and offering a soothing counterpoint to the omnipresent violence. The mood is jarring and gentle all at once, battering the listener with car-crash frequencies and then offering sweeter sounds as a kind of balm. It\xe2\x80\x99s a disorienting listen: His arrangements are as murky as a flooded catacombs, and the way that arpeggiated bell tones and other motifs recur in nearly identical forms across the album, it can be easy to feel marooned amidst its swirl, and the claustrophobic sameness of his sound design verges on the suffocating.' b'Presumably this is all part of the point. Taking inspiration from the ocean\xe2\x80\x99s burgeoning quantities of plastic flotsam and jetsam, Psutka describes the album\xe2\x80\x99s aesthetic as \xe2\x80\x9cpacific litter clank; chill torrents and artificial triumphalism.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s definitely nailed the vibe: The music drifts in a great, heaving mass, like the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, and it\xe2\x80\x99s beautiful and monstrous all at once. It really does sound like a ton of plastic shifting its weight around: Dumping a tub of my kid\xe2\x80\x99s Legos on the floor, I was immediately struck by the sonic similarity to Egyptrixx\xe2\x80\x99s palette. There\xe2\x80\x99s simply too much of it, though. What feels bracingly alien for the first five or six tracks turns into a hard slog by the tenth; it would have been far effective to shut things down after \xe2\x80\x9cPlastic Pebble [beat],\xe2\x80\x9d a climactic mixture of grime synths, trap hi-hats, and the dissonant clang of EVOL-era Sonic Youth. That was a problem on Psutka\xe2\x80\x99s last couple of albums, too; his concepts are stronger than his editing skills. Still, taken in moderate doses, it\xe2\x80\x99s a strangely moving portrait of ecological collapse translated into sound.'

column7: b'This twelve-track compilation celebrates the German label Tresor, a vital point in the Detroit-Berlin techno axis. Drexciya,\xc2\xa0Donato Dozzy, Jon Hassell, and others contribute.'
column8: b'When Dimitri Hegemann set up an art space in the vaults under the Wertheim department store in East Berlin in the spring of 1991, it seemed unlikely that it\xc2\xa0would last out the initial\xc2\xa0three-month lease. But the club Tresor became a vital point on the Detroit-Berlin axis in the early \xe2\x80\x9990s, its lease was extended, and the underground club became a conduit that brought the first practitioners of techno over to Europe, introducing the likes of Jeff Mills, Carl Craig, and more to the continent, which in turn helped it become a worldwide force. The club has always been a more vital catalyst than the label of the same name, established the same year. But its heaviest releases\xe2\x80\x94Robert Hood\xe2\x80\x99s Internal Empire, Surgeon\xe2\x80\x99s Basictonalvocabulary, Drexciya\xe2\x80\x99s Harnessed the Storm, X-102\xe2\x80\x99s Discovers The Rings Of Saturn, for starters\xe2\x80\x94have maintained its international status.' b'While perhaps no longer at the cutting edge, twenty-five years in Tresor continues to stay relevant, tapping newcomers like Objekt and providing a home for the likes of Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s Terrence Dixon. To help celebrate, the label presents Dreamy Harbor, a twelve-track assortment of older artists that helped establish the label, a few newcomers from the far corners of the globe, as well as a legendary composer not previously associated with the label. Veering from woozy ambience to clanging techno and back, it shows the label to be in a transitional space of sorts.' b'One of the first surprises is the opening track, Vainquer\xe2\x80\x99s now-legendary \xe2\x80\x9cSolanus (Extracted 2).\xe2\x80\x9d Originally a B-side on the Chain Reaction label, it\xe2\x80\x99s one of the defining beatless dubs to drift out in the mid-90s. It\xe2\x80\x99s a bit difficult to tell just how much has been tweaked on this version from\xc2\xa0the original. Those chords that mimic exhalations from the void; that sense of serenity cut with the prickly buzz of cicadas\xe2\x80\x94it remains intact here, save that its ethereal nod now lasts a precious three minutes longer.' b'It segues into a track from newcomer Shao, who released his first single on Tresor in 2015. Shao\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSensi (edit)\xe2\x80\x9d fidgets and slowly ratchets up a sense of dread on the track, but at times it feels like an echo of the old Tresor sound. Donato Dozzy, a longtime master of such chasm-like techno in Italy, also recalls that type of sound but with more nuanced results.\xc2\xa0Where the set fares best is in breaking from the merciless sound of techno and having its artists worm into the spaces between the\xc2\xa0beats. Recent signee Marcelus lets live, loose-metered drums skitter beneath the floorboards of the haunting \xe2\x80\x9cOdawah Jam.\xe2\x80\x9d Newcomer Claudia Anderson gives \xe2\x80\x9cPhase\xe2\x80\x9d a buoyant stutter step, and Terrence Dixon slips in some saxophone breaths and a beat that seems to just gathering loose marimba tone bars together like firewood.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s the shortest track on the comp, but the haunting voices that float across the spine-tingling keys of \xe2\x80\x9cDirection Asymmetry,\xe2\x80\x9d from Gerald Donald\xe2\x80\x99s post-Drexciya project, Daughter Produkt, might be the most affecting, sure to pique Drexicya fans wondering what\xe2\x80\x99s to come. Most curious is the inclusion of fourth-world composer (and Brian Eno compatriot) Jon Hassell to the mix. Recently, Hassell\xe2\x80\x99s groundbreaking work has been getting a long overdue reassessment, and more and more new artists are drawing on his reimagining (and inverting) of indigenous and ambient sounds for their own work. Hassell\xe2\x80\x99s piece is the odd one\xc2\xa0out here, but its flickering electronics and gorgeous piano and trumpet twinkle like lights on the far shore. Hopefully it hints at more work from Hassell to see light on the label in the near future. Dreamy Harbor might not be as handy or invigorating a comp as some of Tresor\xe2\x80\x99s mid-90s sets, but it\xe2\x80\x99s that rare release on the imprint that finds greater effect coming from the dreamier side of its telltale sound.'

column7: b'Like\xc2\xa0the Cure\xe2\x80\x99s *Disintegration or\xc2\xa0Depeche Mode\xe2\x80\x99s Violator,\xc2\xa0*the Pet Shop Boys\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0fourth album transitioned\xc2\xa0their creators into the \xe2\x80\x9990s by both refining and breaking from the past.'
column8:
b'Pet Shop Boys arrived in the second half of the \xe2\x80\x9980s to out-gay essentially everybody. Combining Oscar Wilde-ian wit, compositional and lyrical sophistication that harkened back to Cole Porter and No\xc3\xabl Coward, sartorial style that split the difference between uptown chic (singer Neil Tennant) and downtown rough trade (keyboardist Chris Lowe), and a command of \xe2\x80\x9980s club music that soon proved itself far more comprehensive than most of their contemporaries, this North England-raised/London-based synthpop duo aestheticized gay life long before Tennant came out in 1994. Every LGBT person knew exactly what the pair meant in the chorus of \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s A Sin,\xe2\x80\x9d arguably the angriest and certainly most overtly anti-Catholic chorus ever to top the UK pop chart and reach the U.S. Top 10:' b'\xe2\x80\x9cEverything I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever done
Everything I ever do
Every place I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever been
Everywhere I\xe2\x80\x99m going to
It\xe2\x80\x99s a sin\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But after becoming one of the most internationally prominent acts of the \xe2\x80\x9980s with hits like their UK/U.S. #1 \xe2\x80\x9cWest End Girls,\xe2\x80\x9d Tennant and Lowe entered the \xe2\x80\x9990s knowing their \xe2\x80\x9cimperial phase\xe2\x80\x9d of uninterrupted success was over: Setting \xe2\x80\x9cCh\xc3\xa9 Guevara and Debussy to a disco beat,\xe2\x80\x9d their quintessential manifesto \xe2\x80\x9cLeft to My Own Devices\xe2\x80\x9d stalled at #84 on Billboard\xe2\x80\x99s pop chart in late \xe2\x80\x9988; their \xe2\x80\x9989 collaboration with Liza Minnelli, Results, pretty much flopped in North America beyond gay dancefloors, and the \xe2\x80\x9990 comeback they helped helm for Dusty Springfield, Reputation, didn\xe2\x80\x99t even get a U.S. release\xe2\x80\x94despite all of them doing quite well in the UK.' b'Following these alternately sunny and frosty records, they released their decidedly autumnal fourth album Behaviour\xc2\xa0in the fall of 1990. Like the Cure\xe2\x80\x99s Disintegration, Depeche Mode\xe2\x80\x99s Violator, and George Michael\xe2\x80\x99s *Listen Without Prejudice, *it\xc2\xa0would transition their creators into the new decade by both refining and breaking from the past. The time was right, for the duo and indeed much of its following were now in mourning. Singer/lyricist Tennant\xe2\x80\x99s longtime best friend had recently died of AIDS. So had\xc2\xa0Robert Mapplethorpe, who shot some of their Please-period publicity photos, and Keith Haring, who similarly intersected fine art and the club scene. Reported U.S. AIDS cases were well over 100,000, with millions on the way globally, and despite the earliest AIDS drugs like AZT, which in those days often made people sicker, an HIV-positive test result was still pretty much a death sentence. Created in resistance to a mainstream that treated LGBTs as subhuman, the queer culture of defiance and liberation that shaped \xe2\x80\x9970s disco and much of \xe2\x80\x9980s pop\xe2\x80\x94particularly PSB\xe2\x80\x99s hybrid of both\xe2\x80\x94was literally dying.' b'Unfolding like an elegy for much of what had gone before, Behaviour shifted the Boys from sly commentators to reserved-but-pained participants, with its understated but devastating lead track, \xe2\x80\x9cBeing Boring.\xe2\x80\x9d The first verse presents the singer looking through keepsakes, as one does after losing a loved one. He finds a party invite paraphrasing\xc2\xa0Zelda Fitzgerald\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cEulogy on the Flapper,\xe2\x80\x9d specifically the line \xe2\x80\x9cShe refused to be bored chiefly because she wasn\xe2\x80\x99t boring.\xe2\x80\x9d Boredom was a prickly subject for the pair: Their early deadpan videos and TV appearances were routinely dismissed by clueless critics as generating it.' b'Set in the \xe2\x80\x9970s, the next verse depicts the singer leaving his hometown, a mandatory rite of LGBT passage. He softly declares, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d bolted through a closing door,\xe2\x80\x9d an image evoking both the end of his closeted adolescence and the beginning of fully realized adulthood. By the third verse, which is set in the \xe2\x80\x9990s, the singer is self-actualized, but reflective: \xe2\x80\x9cAll the people I was kissing/Some are here, and some are missing.\xe2\x80\x9d That simple rhyme still reduces gay men who lived through this era to tears, for AIDS had sorted our intimates into these two categories\xe2\x80\x94those who died young, and those who might soon follow suit, including ourselves. If you hadn\xe2\x80\x99t seen your gay neighbors and friends and former sexual partners around town, chances were they were dead, had gone home to die, or were nursing the dying just like you. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I thought in spite of dreams,\xe2\x80\x9d the survivor sings of his fallen pal, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d be sitting somewhere here with me.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Fashion photographer Bruce Weber shot the song\xe2\x80\x99s lush B&W video, which features models enacting a fantasy version of the parties Tennant attended in the \xe2\x80\x9970s. The tension between the freedom of Weber\xe2\x80\x99s imagery and the sadness of the third verse makes the eulogy even more devastating, but some fleeting nudity meant that MTV in America had an excuse not to show it. Still, \xe2\x80\x9cBeing Boring\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94ostensibly a dance track, but one featuring fluttering rhythms, a Larry Heard-style deep house bassline that appears only as the album version fades out, a subtle upward chorus modulation that adds sweetness to the sorrow, and a whirring plastic tube conjuring spectral cries\xe2\x80\x94eventually earned its rightful acclaim. A fan site solely devoted to it dwarfs the official web presence of many bands, and on its 20th anniversary, a Guardian critic proclaimed it the greatest single of all time. Even Axl Rose allegedly bemoaned its non-appearance during the duo\xe2\x80\x99s 1991 tour.' b'That tour, Performance, their first in North America, transformed the staginess of their videos into opulent theater just as Blonde Ambition did for Madonna the year before; in the Pets\xe2\x80\x99 case, it was so over-budget that the well-attended\xc2\xa0trek still lost half-a-million dollars. And just as the autobiographical Like a Prayer fed Blonde Ambition, the personal nature of Behaviour lent Performance pathos. The dirge that opened the show, \xe2\x80\x9cThis Must Be the Place I Waited Years to Leave,\xe2\x80\x9d affirmed that, like Madonna, Tennant suffered major Catholic damage. The tune is hummable, but the tone intersects opera and Joy Division as it evokes Catholic mass, freezing rain, and grey architecture. No wonder the Pets eschewed the church for wit and disco.' b'True to their queer sensibility, PSB are intrinsically contrary, even with themselves, and just as their previous release, 1988\xe2\x80\x99s Introspective, is all 12\xe2\x80\x9d-length dance numbers, Behaviour is mostly ballads. Even on overt club cuts, its lead single \xe2\x80\x9cSo Hard\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cThe End of the World,\xe2\x80\x9d the dance grooves that defined the duo are muted: No more big \xe2\x80\x9980s drums, no electro rumble or hi-NRG clatter, even if \xe2\x80\x9cSo Hard\xe2\x80\x9d ramps up the trademark orchestral blasts of their previous hits. Rather than the sample-heavy rave bleeps that ruled 1990 UK pop, the album favors analogue synths overseen by co-producer Harold Faltermeyer, the Munich synth whiz who\xe2\x80\x99d been Giorgio Moroder\xe2\x80\x99s key player and had scored with Beverly Hills Cop\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cAxel F.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"But though the instrumentation is mostly as synthetic as before, it\xe2\x80\x99s less pointedly so; the future was no longer as inviting as it had been in the duo\xe2\x80\x99s formative years, when they dreamt of man-machines and home computers. Embracing their humanism to mirror their messages, the pair often blur\xc2\xa0the boundaries between synthetic and natural sounds: Mirroring the instability of post-communist Russia, \xe2\x80\x9cMy October Symphony\xe2\x80\x9d fuses banging Italo-house piano, \xe2\x80\x9cFunky Drummer\xe2\x80\x9d syncopation, Marvin Gaye-esque yearning, and the classical strings of Balanescu Quartet, which all blend with the Prophets and Rolands and Marr\xe2\x80\x99s wah-wah guitar so seamlessly that the hybrid suggests Shostakovich going Blaxploitation. You certainly couldn't\xc2\xa0call it just \xe2\x80\x9csynthpop.\xe2\x80\x9d" b'In the booklet for the album\xe2\x80\x99s 2001 deluxe reissue, Tennant paints the unabashed love aria \xe2\x80\x9cTo Face the Truth\xe2\x80\x9d as the story of a man who cannot acknowledge his girlfriend\xe2\x80\x99s infidelities. But like so many PSB songs, it makes more sense in an LGBT context; that his lover is a bisexual who dodges their emotional bond. Having same-gender sex dictates that you\xe2\x80\x99re homosexual, but loving someone of your own gender makes you gay\xe2\x80\x94a step too far for some. \xe2\x80\x9cI wonder if you care and cannot bear the proof/It hurts too much to face the truth,\xe2\x80\x9d Tennant croons at the top of his tenor. Having just worked with Liza and Dusty, he\xe2\x80\x99d suddenly become a more expressive singer, one here as adept at conveying sincerity as he\xe2\x80\x99d always been at generating irony. The programmed rhythms hail from \xe2\x80\x9980s R&B, but his vocal is \xe2\x80\x9970s Bee Gees; had this been on the Saturday Night Fever soundtrack, we\xe2\x80\x99d all know it.' b'Lyrically the most old-school PSB-y song of the lot, \xe2\x80\x9cHow Can You Expect to Be Taken Seriously?\xe2\x80\x9d roasts sanctimonious rock stars who claim to hate fame\xe2\x80\x99s machinations but nevertheless align themselves with the trendiest causes. There\xe2\x80\x99d been plenty of those in the wake of Band Aid, Live Aid, Farm Aid, and \xe2\x80\x9cWe Are the World,\xe2\x80\x9d and they pretty much wiped out the more subversive and often queer \xe2\x80\x9cNew Pop\xe2\x80\x9d movement that spawned the Pets. The album version is set atypically to a New Jack Swing beat, the kind that gave even Boy George a US R&B radio hit with \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Take My Mind on a Trip\xe2\x80\x9d the year before, but the seldom heard single/video version remixed it into a more flattering Soul II Soul-style shuffle. Back home, its critique was bolstered by appearing on the flipside of their newly recorded medley of U2\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cWhere the Streets Have No Name\xe2\x80\x9d and the Four Seasons\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cI Can\xe2\x80\x99t Take My Eyes Off of You,\xe2\x80\x9d which echoed Boys Town Gang\xe2\x80\x99s shamelessly camp disco-ization of the latter. Bono, who spotted the satirical finger being pointed in his direction, quipped, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat have we done to deserve this?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'As straightforward as \xe2\x80\x9cSeriously\xe2\x80\x9d is skewed, album closer \xe2\x80\x9cJealousy\xe2\x80\x9d goes furthest in a quasi-symphonic direction. Played on keyboards but booming like a massive orchestra, it\xe2\x80\x99s fraught with romantic angst like their earliest work, yet it suits their new phase of unfettered emotionality. The scene-setting opening conjures the outsized ardor of 19th-century\xc2\xa0art song: \xe2\x80\x9cAt dead of night when strangers roam/The streets in search of anyone who\xe2\x80\x99ll take them home/I lie alone\xe2\x80\xa6\xe2\x80\x9d And the rest similarly picks up where Scott Walker\xe2\x80\x99s covers of Jacques Brel left off.' b'A crooner, not a belter, Tennant sets his vocal understatement against the over-the-top nature of his blinding passion for an unrequited love. This conflict mirrors the LGBT experience itself: You\xe2\x80\x99ve got all this desire that must\xc2\xa0somehow be contained to\xc2\xa0a small percentage of the population, lest you find yourself making a pass at someone who might not share your sexuality and who might respond with condemnation or even\xc2\xa0violence. So you keep your outer voice small and whispery like Tennant\xe2\x80\x99s, but that constant monitoring and muting only intensifies your inner life, and so you bear\xc2\xa0the burden of these feelings\xe2\x80\x94here represented by the grandness of the orchestration, the despair of the descending vocal melody, the processional horns that bear a stubbornly regal retreat. There\xe2\x80\x99s no apology implied\xe2\x80\x94quite the opposite.' b'Simpatico women understand this proud juxtaposition: Liza Minnelli considers Tennant and Lowe geniuses akin to Broadway maestro Stephen Sondheim or her dad. Pet Shop Boys critique masculinity the way classic rock bands exude it, but rather than the flamboyance that\xe2\x80\x99s intrinsic to the gay pop star from Little Richard onward, PSB offer the calm control of the outsider looking in, their noses pressed against the shop window.' b'Having experienced worldwide eminence exactly when their people fell into deeper crisis than ever, they rarely took the\xc2\xa0easy path, and on subsequent releases like Very\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cDreaming of the Queen,\xe2\x80\x9d they imagined a world in which there were no more lovers left alive. Fortunately, people kept dancing, and Pet Shop Boys still supply their nocturnal soundtrack. Last month, Billboard announced PSB as the all-time top male act on its dance club chart: With last year\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Pop Kids,\xe2\x80\x9d they landed their 40th hit on that list in 30 years, and 11th No. 1. That they did so with a song as wistful as those on Behaviour makes this achievement truly singular. Embracing disposable pop, they\xe2\x80\x99ve created lasting queer culture just as it was in danger of disappearing. They celebrate the melancholia of being gay.'

column7: b'The latest from\xc2\xa0Melodies International, the reissues label by Floating Points\xe2\x80\x99 Sam Shepherd, is the 1976 LP\xc2\xa0from Chicago soul-disco band\xc2\xa0Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s People\xe2\x80\x94featuring an audacious 20-minute title track.'
column8: b'When he\xe2\x80\x99s not touring as Floating Points, Sam Shepherd also DJs a funk and soul party, called You\xe2\x80\x99re a Melody. His selections skew\xc2\xa0ludicrously rare, and for most DJs, just flashing them before the trainspotters is enough. But Shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s love of the music led him to start up Melodies International, a reissues label run\xc2\xa0in tandem with DJ Love on the Run, Mafalda, and Javybz. They\xc2\xa0suss out, lovingly remaster, and (legitimately) reissue long-lost singles for a new generation of fans, from a $500 7\xe2\x80\x9d to the complete recorded works of the woefully obscure Detroit band Aged in Harmony, housed in a picture sleeve with an accompanying newsprint fanzine. This\xc2\xa0level of care and dedication towards the physical artifact is rare in an increasingly streaming-only world. And while such speculation over\xc2\xa0old records typically benefits only the seller, the profits from these reissues wind up going back to the original artist themselves.' b'For the third release on the imprint, Shepherd went beyond, reissuing the lone full-length from Chicago soul-disco group Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s People. Comprised of four brothers (Kevin, Maurice, Gerald, and Timothy Burton), their 1976 album Open Soul may not have sold many copies on the short-lived Stage Productions label, but since then it\xe2\x80\x99s become a true \xe2\x80\x9choly grail,\xe2\x80\x9d with copies in the last year changing hands for over $1,500. With the master tapes lost 20\xc2\xa0years ago, the label set about reissuing the LP\xc2\xa0sourced from multiple copies of the original album. Alas, the foxy cover of the original is now replaced with a drawing of the four brothers.' b'For those not taken with the rarefied stratosphere of private press funk and soul albums, the first half of\xc2\xa0Open Soul might leave you wondering what the fuss is all about. \xe2\x80\x9cLovers to Friends\xe2\x80\x9d is a slow-burner featuring the brothers\xe2\x80\x99 effortless harmonies, but there\xe2\x80\x99s not too much that would have made it stand\xc2\xa0out during that decade. \xe2\x80\x9cIt Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Fair\xe2\x80\x9d continues along at nearly the same tempo, with a bit more eerie analog synth and a saxophone line drifting across as the brothers coo \xe2\x80\x9cooooh, don\xe2\x80\x99t take your love away.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a soulful plea, but unless you\xe2\x80\x99ve worn out the Gamble & Huff discography, there\xe2\x80\x99s more immediately rewarding fare to be had there. More upbeat is \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s Get Down With the Beat,\xe2\x80\x9d which features the kind of proto-disco beat and cymbal work that Earl Young pioneered during those years. The fidgety instrumental \xe2\x80\x9cHurt Perversion\xe2\x80\x9d puts the keyboards front and center\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s contemporaneous of Bernie Worrell and his key work with Funkadelic, and\xc2\xa0not nearly as wigged out.' b'No matter how rare the album might be, no one is paying a month of New York City rent for the first five songs of Open Soul. And no one pleaded during a You\xe2\x80\x99re a Melody DJ set for this album to be made available again (based on the A-side). But flip it over and you\xe2\x80\x99re presented with the stunning 20-minute title track. Brother Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s spare organ work and Brother Gerald\xe2\x80\x99s guitar cast a spell, and for the first minute, you might think you\xe2\x80\x99re in for a beatless cosmic soul trip. Just as the two-minute mark approaches, though, that guitar tightens up, a conga drum flares to life, and \xe2\x80\x9cOpen Soul\xe2\x80\x9d bursts into full flame. \xe2\x80\x9cSoul.../Everybody\xe2\x80\x99s asking me what it is,\xe2\x80\x9d the brothers chant as the drums and hand percussion run at double time.' b'Like any good writer, in providing an answer, they show rather than tell. \xe2\x80\x9cOpen Soul\xe2\x80\x9d soon moves\xc2\xa0into a psychedelic break, with each successive electric guitar solo and sax squall nudging\xc2\xa0the temperature up a few more degrees. Seven minutes in, the brothers\xe2\x80\x99 harmonies return, and it seems that surely the song will begin to lose steam or focus. But the Burtons keep that momentum going (and going). And while the song never veers off the path of funk, in its tirelessness and doggedness it starts to mutate and resemble a motorik groove, seeming like it might forever run to the horizon.' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s examples of such audacity in African-American music of that time\xe2\x80\x94Funkadelic\xe2\x80\x99s double-digit explorations, the unreleased J.B.\xe2\x80\x99s album, and Norman Whitfield\xe2\x80\x99s ambitious productions for the Temptations immediately spring to mind\xe2\x80\x94but none are as determined and downright exhaustive as \xe2\x80\x9cOpen Soul.\xe2\x80\x9d By the time that final drum roll comes around some 17\xc2\xa0minutes in, it feels like a marathon runner collapsing at the end of a race and the song recedes back to its soul ambient opening. The song no doubt wore down even the most fervent of dancers during Shepherd\xe2\x80\x99s DJ sets. And thanks to his due diligence, now it can perform a similar feat in your living room.'

column7: b'On his latest, guitarist Delicate Steve seems interested in animating rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll\xe2\x80\x99s most outrageous qualities, using his studio savvy to make it do all the things it can\xe2\x80\x99t in real life.'
column8: b'Over the past six years, Steve Marion has become something you didn\xe2\x80\x99t know you even needed in this day and age: a guitar hero. And\xc2\xa0just as contemporary superhero franchise reboots tend to focus less on their protagonists\xe2\x80\x99 powers and more on their flaws, Marion\xc2\xa0wields his ample talent with the humility of a mortal. On the (mostly) instrumental albums he\xe2\x80\x99s released as Delicate Steve, Marion\xe2\x80\x99s guitar playing is always in the spotlight, but never hogging it\xe2\x80\x94rather, his luminous leads form the emotional undercurrent around which everything else flows. What makes Marion a guitar hero isn\xe2\x80\x99t his technical wizardry, but his music\xe2\x80\x99s mission to help you through dark times.' b'The home-brewed Afro-psych soundscapes of Marion\xe2\x80\x99s previous releases made him a natural collaborator with contemporaries mining similar terrain, like Yeasayer and\xc2\xa0Dirty Projectors. Last year, he received the ultimate endorsement when he was invited to play on the latest album from the patron saint of worldly pop experimentation, Paul Simon. Though he makes primarily instrumental music, Marion\xe2\x80\x99s never been shy about using his titles to telegraph\xc2\xa0his aesthetic, be it the Stevie salute of 2011\xe2\x80\x99s Wondervisions or the nod to Sly Stone\xe2\x80\x99s lo-fi funk masterwork There\xe2\x80\x99s a Riot Goin\xe2\x80\x99 On in \xe2\x80\x9cAfria Talks to You\xe2\x80\x9d (from 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Positive Force). The track list to his new album, This Is Steve, features no such obvious call-outs, but one song title suggests a doozy of a defining statement: \xe2\x80\x9cCartoon Rock.\xe2\x80\x9d This time out, Marion is less interested in rendering his inner visions than in animating rock \xe2\x80\x98n\xe2\x80\x99 roll\xe2\x80\x99s most outrageous qualities, using his studio savvy to make it do all the things it can\xe2\x80\x99t in real life.' b'This Is Steve may share its predecessors\xe2\x80\x99 hermetic, self-made M.O.\xc2\xa0(with Marion once again performing all the instruments himself), but it\xe2\x80\x99s the first Delicate Steve album that feels like it was designed to be performed in front of a crowd\xe2\x80\x94and an inebriated one at that. The pan-cultural influences and meditative quality that permeated his previous records have given way to more carefree kicks: southern-rock choogle, country-funk fusion, and new-wave spazziness. They\xe2\x80\x99re the sort of hazardous materials that, in less capable hands, could easily degenerate into schticky clich\xc3\xa9. But Marion handles them with the same craft and sensitivity he approached his previous, more contemplative records, translating the cheeky into the charming.' b'The aforementioned \xe2\x80\x9cCartoon Rock\xe2\x80\x9d is a case in point: what begins as an exercise in Eliminator-era ZZ Top robo-boogie eventually gives way to a joyous synth-pop coda that sounds like it\xe2\x80\x99s being performed through a CalecoVision. Likewise, on the opening \xe2\x80\x9cAnimals,\xe2\x80\x9d Marion revs up a greasy slide refrain in anticipation of an explosive rock-out eruption; instead, at the expected moment of detonation, it dissolves into a celestial disco daydream. In essence, the song plays out like an alternate-universe version of the 1979 Disco Demolition in Comiskey Park, where instead of blowing up Saturday Night Fever LPs, the raging long-haired ruffians storming the field suddenly break into the hustle.' b'Marion\xe2\x80\x99s previous records occasionally used vocals for textural effect, but here, he lets his guitar do all the singing. And in light of This Is Steve\xe2\x80\x99s more irreverent approach, those George Harrison-styled leads play an ever more crucial role. They invest otherwise frivolous tunes\xe2\x80\x94like the murky\xc2\xa0boombox reggae of \xe2\x80\x9cNightlife\xe2\x80\x9d and the fidgety, synth-buzzed \xe2\x80\x9cTogether\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94with unexpected pangs of poignancy, while on centerpiece track \xe2\x80\x9cHelp,\xe2\x80\x9d he fashions a \xe2\x80\x9cMy Sweet Lord\xe2\x80\x9d for atheists, its chirpy, cloud-parting guitar melody grounded by a gritty acoustic groove.' b'But Marion is also conscious of not overusing his string-bending skills for emotionally manipulative effect: one of the album\xe2\x80\x99s most moving moments comes during the nocturnal reverie \xe2\x80\x9cDriving,\xe2\x80\x9d where the chilly, piano-sculpted post-rock atmospherics give way to a flurry of sunrise-summoning acoustic oscillations. Though it clocks in at just 28 minutes, This Is Steve is generously overstuffed\xe2\x80\x94with gorgeous melodies, compositional quirks, sonic details, goofy ideas, and messy feelings. But if there\xe2\x80\x99s a message Marion is trying to convey through the album\xe2\x80\x99s jammed frequencies, it\xe2\x80\x99s that you\xe2\x80\x99re welcome to have a laugh\xc2\xa0while his guitar gently weeps.'

column3: b'p h a r a o h'
column7: b'California producer Jansport J makes instrumental hip-hop that summons J Dilla\xe2\x80\x99s Donuts without falling in its shadow.\xc2\xa0p h a r a o\xc2\xa0h\xc2\xa0is his eighth and best album.'
column8: b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think a lot of us heard Donuts\xc2\xa0and made it our Bible.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Talking about his excellent new album *p h a r a o\xc2\xa0h *in an interview with Bandcamp, the California producer Jansport J (aka Justin Williams) was blunt about the beat tape\xe2\x80\x99s most obvious influence. Since Dilla\xe2\x80\x99s Donuts came out, a little more than a decade ago, it has stood as both monolith and lodestar at the base camp of the beat scene. Few producers have been able to escape its shadow or avoid the microsample-strewn path it lays out. *P h a r a\xc2\xa0o h *does not seek to try.' b'But by ridding himself of the anxiety of influence, J has made the best of his eight records to date, and one of the more compelling offerings to emerge from the beat scene in recent years.
