He\xe2\x80\x99s absorbed and built on the lessons to be found on *Donuts *and in the work of instrumental hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s other leading lights. *P h a r a o\xc2\xa0h *was originally conceived in the midst of a New York snowstorm, and the record jumps off with eight tracks worth of diamantine blizzard beats, many of them punctuated by or predicated on the human voice. Chants, shouts, whoops and screeches fill the record to great effect creating an atmosphere of engaged protest. J explained in the same interview that the track \xe2\x80\x9cRIP Harambe\xe2\x80\x9d speaks to more to than just an assassinated zoo animal; its sharply edited music is immediately followed by a 911 dispatcher, issuing yet another report of a suspicious male. That ominous audio attends the beginning of a track called \xe2\x80\x9c12,\xe2\x80\x9d a title barely more subtle than the one N.W.A. kicked off some shit with almost thirty years ago. *P h a r a o h *is remarkably effective as an explicit political document; no lyrics necessary.' b'Williams opens up and shows his range in the records latter two thirds, starting around the tributes to classic New York rap on \xe2\x80\x9c45 Joint\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSet it Off.\xe2\x80\x9d Though Williams may mean it to signal otherwise\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s remarked several times that this is his New York record\xe2\x80\x94this section begins something of a national tour. While Williams continues to honor Gotham (check out the MC Lyte sampling on \xe2\x80\x9cBKNY\xe2\x80\x9d), he stretches beyond the city, from O.D.B.\xe2\x80\x99s shouts to Miami on \xe2\x80\x9cThe Dirt II\xe2\x80\x9d all the way to California on \xe2\x80\x9cLive From the Forum \xe2\x80\x9986\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCrenshaw\xe2\x80\x9d near the album\xe2\x80\x99s back half. In allowing his beats to criss-cross the country, choosing a diverse array of samples even as he cleaves to a classicist style, he retraces the original migration of hip-hop throughout the country.' b'*Donuts *was characterized by the Detroit producer\xe2\x80\x99s rare mastery of sampling, both as technical skill and artistic expression, speaking his deathbed fears and desires through prerecorded voices. J shows a similar facility here, but this is not some covers record. On songs like \xe2\x80\x9cCrush\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cCrenshaw,\xe2\x80\x9d he takes a page out of the pop-loving programming of his contemporary Knxledge, essentially cross-wiring Michael Jackson\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cRock With You\xe2\x80\x9d and Luther Vandross\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cBetter Love.\xe2\x80\x9d Williams also has a knack for isolating intriguing spoken samples: one of the best tracks here is \xe2\x80\x9cIwasFeelinShortee,\xe2\x80\x9d which hands the mic over to Mos Def\xe2\x80\x99s lovelorn monologue from \xe2\x80\x9cMs. Fat Booty.\xe2\x80\x9d And he favors a diversity of approaches, as happy using a hyper-recognizable Bob James drum sample as he is veering toward the obscure.' b'A record like *P h a r a o h *makes a compelling case for Jansport J to be considered for a short list of names associated with transcendent instrumental hip-hop, a pantheon that, along with Dilla, would include Madlib, Knxledge and Oddisee, as well as pioneers like DJ Shadow and Blockhead. Though *Donuts *and Madlib\xe2\x80\x99s *Beat Konducta *series continue to loom over the scene, making it difficult to expand the genre, these artists like have continued to add depth and breadth within the boundaries already set out. *P h a r a o h *hits upon a particularly deep wellspring, exploring it with curiosity and a coherent point of view that characterizes the instrumental hip hop\xe2\x80\x99s best work. Though it barely features Williams\xe2\x80\x99s own vocals, it speaks in a passionate, warm, consistently recognizable voice.'

column7: b'The young Icelandic post-punk band Fufanu traffic in icy disaffection and glacier-cool synths, but their latest album hints at hearts beating beneath the veneer.'
column8: b'Though Iceland has a fertile music scene, it has produced few international names. The ones that have emerged\xe2\x80\x94Bj\xc3\xb6rk, Sigur R\xc3\xb3s, and, uh, Of Monsters and Men\xe2\x80\x94tend to paint a picture \xc2\xa0to the outside world: A\xc2\xa0tiny nation filled with artsy, insular weirdos. Yet the scene there is bustling with all sorts of sounds: \xc2\xa0Black metal, punk rock, serrated electronic music, rap. And then there\xe2\x80\x99s the chilly post-punk offered by Fufanu, Iceland\xe2\x80\x99s most exciting young band.' b'Revolving around the core duo of Hrafnkell Fl\xc3\xb3ki Kaktus Einarsson and Gu\xc3\xb0laugur Halld\xc3\xb3r Einarsson (no relation; Icelandic names use patronymics), Fufanu has grown from an experimental techno duo (then known as Captain Fufanu, when Kaktus and Gulli were just teens) into purveyors of terse, claustrophobic post-punk, injected with bleary-eyed psychedelia and dystopian electronic textures. (Live, the band expands their sound into a raging, swaggering storm, though they\xe2\x80\x99ve opted to reign it in on record thus far.) There is also a surprising amount of Britpop lurking in their DNA. Kaktus worked on Damon Albarn\xe2\x80\x99s 2014 solo release Everyday Robots; Fufanu opened for the Britpop star later that year, and for Blur at Hyde Park in 2015. Though the band understandably chafes at the focus on their connection to Albarn, there\xe2\x80\x99s no denying how their echoes of late-\xe2\x80\x9990s Britpop enriches their music.' b'Sports is the group\xe2\x80\x99s sophomore LP, following quickly on the heels of their late 2015 debut\xc2\xa0Few More Days to Go.\xc2\xa0It flows more than its predecessor, and trades their debut\xe2\x80\x99s corroded guitar for glacier-cool synths and hissing electronic rhythms, both propulsive and meditative. Like many great post-punk groups before them, the band consistently sounds disaffected and removed. Lead single and standout \xe2\x80\x9cSports\xe2\x80\x9d is a terse\xc2\xa0drawl of seemingly disconnected thoughts, a masterclass in building\xc2\xa0tension. \xe2\x80\x9cBad Rockets\xe2\x80\x9d sounds like a Bond theme from an alternate timeline in which 007\xe2\x80\x99s become an ashen-faced junkie, featuring the haunting refrain \xe2\x80\x9cBad rockets hit\xe2\x80\x94rockets fly above my head.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'The title\xc2\xa0Few More Days to Go\xc2\xa0was a refrain the band members would deliver to loved ones asking when they\xe2\x80\x99d return home.\xc2\xa0Sports, though brooding at first glance, celebrates the little moments of homecoming, of reunion, of pleasant daily life. Kaktus, who lives with his girlfriend in Reykjavik, sings of young but stable love throughout. \xe2\x80\x9cGoing out, with my love/Jump around like a six year old\xe2\x80\x9d on \xe2\x80\x9cSports\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cJust hold me like I\xe2\x80\x99m your fool/We\xe2\x80\x99ll sleep on the back of the new moon\xe2\x80\x9d on \xe2\x80\x9cYour Fool\xe2\x80\x9d; \xe2\x80\x9cI said something about leaving soon/It\xe2\x80\x99s drumming in my heart/And asking for restart\xe2\x80\x9d in \xe2\x80\x9cRestart.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"\xe2\x80\x9cYour Fool\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRestart\xe2\x80\x9d form the record's conclusion, and they\xe2\x80\x99re unlike anything else the band has done, vulnerable and beautiful.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0The disassociation and disaffection of the rest of the album suddenly makes sense in the rearview, a buildup to moments of pure, aching romanticism. They transform a solid album into something of an emotional journey, and hint strongly that beneath their low-key snarling, Fufanu have grander things on their minds."

column7: b'On this brief EP, the duo of Ariel Pink and Weyes Blood\xe2\x80\x99s Natalie Mering collaborate on strange folk-synth hybrids, evoking\xc2\xa0the \xe2\x80\x9980s Paisley Underground and X.'
column8: b'Ariel Pink is a misogynist;\xc2\xa0he\xe2\x80\x99s not funny;\xc2\xa0he\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0the worst thing ever;\xc2\xa0Ariel stinks. Paint him as provocateur and raging narcissist, but as the past few years have proven, he\xe2\x80\x99s also a team player, down for\xc2\xa0boosting his friends and game for collaborations of all stripes. And so tapping him for the second installment of Mexican Summer\xe2\x80\x99s Myths series seems like a no-brainer, especially since he\xe2\x80\x99s worked\xc2\xa0with Weyes Blood\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Natalie Mering previously, her voice gracing \xe2\x80\x9cEarly Birds of Babylon\xe2\x80\x9d on his 2012 album Mature Themes.' b'With the breakout success of last year\xe2\x80\x99s Front Row Seat to Earth, Weyes Blood\xe2\x80\x99s profile ticked up considerably, and while four songs clocking in at 14\xc2\xa0minutes is slight by design, Ariel is wise to accentuate Mering\xe2\x80\x99s voice. Only on opener \xe2\x80\x9cTears on Fire\xe2\x80\x9d does Pink take the lead. It begins with guitar\xc2\xa0jangle and what is either a warbling synthesizer or else Mering doing her best Yma Sumac impersonation in the background. For the first 40 seconds, it\xe2\x80\x99s the gentlest I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever heard Ariel\xe2\x80\x94only for an operatic metal stomp, like a gate of hell, to rip open\xc2\xa0immediately after at the chorus. The song jags between pomposity and modesty, with Pink lurching between\xc2\xa0lines about \xe2\x80\x9croasting pigs on the pyre\xe2\x80\x9d and how \xe2\x80\x9cthe\xc2\xa0joke was from the heart.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Then Mering\xc2\xa0takes over on \xe2\x80\x9cDaddy, Please Give a Little Time to Me\xe2\x80\x9d against a queasy synth gurgle and a snare that cracks from a room over, all of it swaddled in a haze of reverb and echo. It\xe2\x80\x99s a peculiar song, as weirdly stilted and stylized as that of Pink, as Mering moves from a high quaver to delivering her lines like lost a Shangri-Las soliloquy.' b'In tandem, they do a hazy approximation of the early-\xe2\x80\x9980s L.A. Paisley Underground\xc2\xa0on \xe2\x80\x9cOn Another Day,\xe2\x80\x9d as if some demo from 1983 suddenly bobbed to the surface. It\xe2\x80\x99s a slow burn of a duet between the two, at times evoking X\xe2\x80\x99s John Doe and Exene Cervenka. Even though the end of the song\xc2\xa0reveals it\xe2\x80\x99s played live in front of a crowd, there remains\xc2\xa0that tactile sense of distance that Pink\xe2\x80\x99s sonics readily tap into, as if echoing not just from the past but from a parallel dimension.' b'But the clear standout of this brief collab is \xe2\x80\x9cMorning After.\xe2\x80\x9d Another strange folk-synth hybrid, Mering\xe2\x80\x99s voice sounds like Fairport Convention\xe2\x80\x99s Sandy Denny\xc2\xa0doodling around on a Moog; she stuns while barely climbing above a purr. \xe2\x80\x9cHere it comes/A cure for the night I\xe2\x80\x99ve been waiting/To let you inside,\xe2\x80\x9d Mering\xc2\xa0sings of a long-anticipated love. But as the sinewaves quiver in the background, the moonlight-tinted love song turns into a vampire tale: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen I saw you I knew I was cursed/I\xe2\x80\x99m the one who got bit first.\xe2\x80\x9d Short-lived as Myths may be, one hopes that Pink and Mering\xe2\x80\x94odd, kindred spirits\xe2\x80\x94have the chance\xc2\xa0to commune again.'

column7: b'Following 2016\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0breakout debut\xc2\xa0Cardinal, the New Jersey band Pinegrove have collected some of their best songs on a lovable new live album, with\xc2\xa0proceeds going to the Southern Poverty Law Center.'
column8: b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard not to root for Pinegrove. Even before they raised more than $21,000 for Planned Parenthood and released Elsewhere\xe2\x80\x94a lovable new live album whose proceeds are being donated to the Southern Poverty Law Center\xe2\x80\x94the band seemed to be propelled entirely by positivity and goodwill. For a certain kind of listener, Pinegrove\xe2\x80\x99s music will feel like a warm hug, cozy without being cloying, eliciting a rush of memories of drinking in furnished basements and driving aimlessly through quiet streets. Frontman Evan Stephens Hall\xe2\x80\x99s voice is a strained, twangy yowl that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have sounded out of place on \xe2\x80\x9990s alternative rock radio, and it\xe2\x80\x99s a perfect vessel for communicating his vulnerable thoughts. \xe2\x80\x9cWe were laughing and crying in awe at the size of the moon,\xe2\x80\x9d he recalls in one of the band\xe2\x80\x99s most impassioned anthems. It\xe2\x80\x99s a simple, near-precious thought that\xe2\x80\x99s immediately elevated with a more sobering question: \xe2\x80\x9cDo you want to die?\xe2\x80\x9d' b'\xe2\x80\x9cSize of the Moon\xe2\x80\x9d is the penultimate track on Elsewhere, a 30-minute offering following a banner year of touring in support of their breakout debut,\xc2\xa0Cardinal. The eight songs on the collection are not reinventions: there\xe2\x80\x99s no extended jamming, no gratuitous stage banter. But like the already-legendary video of Pinegrove\xe2\x80\x99s AudioTree set last year, *Elsewhere *seems tailor-made for introducing new fans to the band. The recordings on *Elsewhere *are, in fact, a good deal more polished than the intentionally-messy Cardinal. Nandi Rose Plunkett, who also performs as Half Waif, glides through the album with a graceful shimmer, using her keyboard to fill in gaps that might have otherwise been accentuated with feedback squalls or background noise; it\xe2\x80\x99s a crucial\xc2\xa0element\xc2\xa0in their toughening sound. On Elsewhere, all of Pinegrove\xe2\x80\x99s songs feel\xc2\xa0bigger, tighter, and more controlled, without losing the edge that made them stand out in the first place.' b'More than anything, *Elsewhere *is a testament to just how good a live band Pinegrove has become. These are mostly flawless renditions of not-so-easy-to-replicate songs. Hall\xe2\x80\x99s voice is weathered and raw, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not careless: he knows exactly which lines to shout, which to whisper, which to leave out entirely and let the audience sing. The rest of the band is similarly proficient, evolving in subtle ways that build on on their various touchstones, from the American Football layered guitars in \xe2\x80\x9cVisiting\xe2\x80\x9d through rootsier territory in \xe2\x80\x9cAngelina\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAphasia.\xe2\x80\x9d In \xe2\x80\x9cAphasia,\xe2\x80\x9d a lonesome slide guitar\xe2\x80\x94a sound that hid in the background of Cardinal, suggesting its presence without asserting itself\xe2\x80\x94comes to the forefront, highlighting the band\xe2\x80\x99s ability to evolve into a modern, alt-country act.' b'In a closing rendition of \xe2\x80\x9cNew Friends,\xe2\x80\x9d Hall\xe2\x80\x99s voice even resembles a young Ryan Adams, before his days of breaking hearts, when he drank like a river. What the band does next will reveal where *Elsewhere *stands in their discography\xe2\x80\x94a spirited appendix to a strong debut or a Wide Awake in America before a Joshua Tree. For now, it\xe2\x80\x99s just another dose of good karma for a band who\xc2\xa0feels\xc2\xa0like an increasingly noble cause to support.'

column7: b'Minneapolis rapper\xc2\xa0P.O.S is still all about his consciousness, and usefully motivated by anger. But on\xc2\xa0Chill,\xc2\xa0d**ummy, he embraces a freed-up feel,\xc2\xa0with some\xc2\xa0grooves you might hear in a club.'
column8: b'Focusing on trauma has always been a central plank in P.O.S\xe2\x80\x99s artistic platform. He comes by the obsession honestly. That same instinct\xc2\xa0is a hallmark of the punk tradition, long cited as an inspiration by the Minneapolis rapper. Whether you prefer to apply sub-genre labels like \xe2\x80\x9cconscious\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbackpack\xe2\x80\x9d to the art of rhyming, it\xe2\x80\x99s obvious that engagement with uncomfortable concepts has been key for a rich lineage of idiosyncratic MCs (both popular and not). P.O.S has called Aesop Rock his favorite rapper; the latter\xe2\x80\x99s mix of emotional vulnerability and technical confidence is a clear influence.' b'When P.O.S approaches a mood of raw celebration, the route often runs through a hardcore group chant, premised on some opposition to the zeitgeist. This aesthetic has a way of pushing uncomplicated exuberance so deep into the background that it disappears from view. And that demotion of one of hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s most expressive, universal modes creates a tension with rap\xe2\x80\x99s mainstream, no matter the season.' b'On his last record, 2012\xe2\x80\x99s We Don\xe2\x80\x99t Even Live Here, P.O.S took shots at a wide array of then-current trends in rap. The disses were on-brand, but the synth-heavy instrumentation sounded less distinct than the punk-rap style that made 2009\xe2\x80\x99s Never Better such an energizing listen. Frivolity can be pretty easy to call out. Creating a suitably attractive alternative tends to be more difficult.' b'With Chill, dummy, P.O.S avoids retreating into the program of Never Better, while also one-upping his prior outing. His own production\xe2\x80\x94and that of his collaborators\xe2\x80\x94pushes more decisively into some grooves that you might actually hear in a club. There\xe2\x80\x99s even a hint of sensuality, thanks to the slinky, bass-heavy motif that drives \xe2\x80\x9cFaded.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s new-enough ground for P.O.S that you can hear a bit of a giggle in the mix, right after the first appearance of \xe2\x80\x9cI want your body on me.\xe2\x80\x9d Though for the balance of the track, the seduction is played for real\xe2\x80\x94Justin Vernon\xe2\x80\x99s guest vocals are some of his best, too.' b'The lyricism remains captivating throughout. Rapping from the post-op vantage of a harrowing, ultimately successful\xc2\xa0kidney transplant, P.O.S is still all about his consciousness. But his latest internal critiques prove far more interesting than his evergreen complaints about meme culture. The sometimes prideful concept of \xe2\x80\x9cstaying in your lane\xe2\x80\x9d gets a healthy kick during the chorus of \xe2\x80\x9cLanes,\xe2\x80\x9d as P.O.S wonders whether staying true to his style may have stunted his growth. (\xe2\x80\x9cI been doin my own thing so long/Or is it/I been in my own way so long.\xe2\x80\x9d) This line of thinking leads to one of the most experimental tracks P.O.S has ever created: the eight-minute-plus album finale \xe2\x80\x9csleepdrone/superposition.\xe2\x80\x9d He covers a lot of ground here, with grim, sustained synth tones as well as a Kathleen Hanna feature: \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re supposed to be happy to be alive,\xe2\x80\x9d she sings. \xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re supposed to be lucky to be alive.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Other topics include the killings of Mike Brown and Eric Garner, a general sense of futility, and the concept of \xe2\x80\x9csuperposition\xe2\x80\x9d in quantum physics. That last idea\xc2\xa0is obviously\xc2\xa0fairly complicated. But at root, it has to do with multiple, simultaneous potentials for particles of matter: a discovery with clear poetic implications for an artist focused on states of development. The track itself can become almost anything, at any time\xe2\x80\x94courtesy of pivots in rhythm and vocal cadence. In the end, it\xe2\x80\x99s as rousing as P.O.S\xe2\x80\x99s best work, even though it sounds little like anything he\xe2\x80\x99s given us before.' b'Not everything on the album works on this high level. A couple of the guest-heavy tracks (like \xe2\x80\x9cBully\xe2\x80\x9d) feel more muddled in their intent. But the overall tenor of the album has a satisfying, freed-up quality. As P.O.S raps on \xe2\x80\x9cPieces/Ruins\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cSame dude new guts/Literal and figurative lost a couple fucks.\xe2\x80\x9d And\xc2\xa0while he\xe2\x80\x99s openly experimenting with his ideal resting heart-rate, P.O.S is still usefully motivated by anger\xe2\x80\x94a reality you hear clearly on the industrial-tinged opening track \xe2\x80\x9cBorn a Snake.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s healthy to try out new patterns and engage in self-critique, but not everything needs changing.'

column7: b'The D.C. rapper Shy Glizzy\xe2\x80\x94here rebranded as Jefe\xe2\x80\x94offers \xc2\xa0another tough-minded collection of street rap anthems, addressed to people struggling through poverty and the criminal-justice system.'
column8: b'As Shy Glizzy, D.C. native Marquis King has become the face of the rap crew Glizzy Gang, and one of the most consistent artists in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s capital. He raps in a needling\xc2\xa0whine about gunfights and authority and the spaces where they intersect: neighborhood turf wars, exchanges with law enforcement, being strapped as a symbol of manhood, and using gunmanship as a means to gain control over one\xe2\x80\x99s own life, to overcome poverty and unbalanced systems. Last year, he released his most compelling work yet, Young Jefe 2, a blueprint for his particular brand of confessional tough talk, half chest-beating bravado, half emotional plea for understanding (\xe2\x80\x9cI promise you that you gon\xe2\x80\x99 feel my pain bitch\xe2\x80\x9d). The tape was the most comfortable he\xe2\x80\x99s ever been, proudly taking up the mantle of local street benefactor and willing brand ambassador for his crew. Perhaps sensing a shift, King has dropped the Shy Glizzy moniker in favor of the mixtape persona: Jefe, which is Spanish for \xe2\x80\x98boss.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m just rebranding myself. Reinventing on a whole higher level,\xe2\x80\x9d he told the Fader. \xe2\x80\x9cI earned the title Jefe ... From the get go I\xe2\x80\x99ve been putting on for the city.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'His first offering under the new name is an EP called The World Is Yours. The eight-track project continues to explore the same ongoing themes in King\xe2\x80\x99s music\xe2\x80\x94using success as a window through which to reflect on humbler beginnings. Its message is encapsulated in the hook on \xe2\x80\x9cLove Me\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cHow the fuck could you hate me when I came up from nothing?/I just want you to love me.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'This isn\xe2\x80\x99t King at the peak of his powers. When he\xe2\x80\x99s at his best, he can string several devastating phrases together to create complex models of what he\xe2\x80\x99s seeing and feeling. Here, he mostly seems content to roll leisurely through verses, as on \xe2\x80\x9cOver the Hills.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s no sense of urgency, and, outside of declaring his city a war zone, the stakes are generally lower for Jefe than they are in most Shy Glizzy songs. But that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean the songs are without consequence. On \xe2\x80\x9cCongratulations,\xe2\x80\x9d he assesses the envy of those close to his success. The cautionary tale \xe2\x80\x9cGive It Up\xe2\x80\x9d is an instruction manual for young street soldiers, ending with an inspirational testimonial, tracing a bleak journey from\xc2\xa0juvenile corrections to six-figure tours: \xe2\x80\x9c14 years old, I went to juvie for an O/16 years old, I stuck my dick in my PO/18 years old, I was whipping up the dope/ By 20 years old, I was getting 20 for a show.\xe2\x80\x9d The World Is Yours seems as much a personal memo as it is a Nas-ian aphorism.' b'For much of the EP\xe2\x80\x99s running time, Jefe provides glimpses of what can, at times, make him a truly special rapper\xe2\x80\x94as has been exhibited in the past on songs like \xe2\x80\x9cFuneral\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cAwwsome.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99ll go through an entire verse only using one scheme (as he does on \xe2\x80\x9cCongratulations\xe2\x80\x9d), but other times he\xe2\x80\x99ll take big cuts at syllables, at one point rhyming \xe2\x80\x9cfuck,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNew York,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMarshall Faulk.\xe2\x80\x9d Over one of the most vibrant Zaytoven beats in years, on \xe2\x80\x9cOne,\xe2\x80\x9d he mixes off-balance slant rhymes with brief moments of criminal introspection. It\xe2\x80\x99s a reminder of what he\xe2\x80\x99s capable of. The World Is Yours is a fine introduction to Jefe. But it\xe2\x80\x99s still worth getting to know Shy Glizzy first.'

column7: b'Life Without Sound is\xc2\xa0the most contemplative Cloud Nothings album yet.'
column8: b'With every album, Cloud Nothings have bailed on their past and re-shaped themselves into something more vital. Over their first three\xc2\xa0albums, Cleveland native Dylan Baldi seemed to be flooring the pedal in search of inspiration, from the lo-fi indie of singles collection\xc2\xa0Turning On\xc2\xa0to the pop-punk indebted self-titled\xc2\xa0debut to the increasingly serrated and howling peaks of Attack on Memory\xc2\xa0and Here and Nowhere Else. Somewhere in the long-gestating creation of their new album, however, Baldi stopped sprinting and briefly stalled out. Unsatisfactory demos piled up. Unproductive recording sessions and frustrations mounted, and a year of recording stretched on, the longest time Baldi had ever spent making one record. (Here and Nowhere Else was written after slamming some bad coffee and writing songs the day before.) Finally he broke through, and Life Without Sound, the result, is the most contemplative Cloud Nothings album yet.' b'This time, instead of becoming faster or more volatile, they pump the brakes and smooth out some of their more coarse edges. Baldi was inspired by the chaotic, freeform improvisations of \xc2\xa0New York composer Malcolm Goldstein, and the album boasts an open-ended, impressionist feel that\xe2\x80\x99s new for them. The quiet, almost mournful piano solo of \xe2\x80\x9cUp to the Surface\xe2\x80\x9d opens the album, and when Baldi\xe2\x80\x99s voice appears, his singing is subtle and restrained. Displaced, disoriented, and alone, he paints a portrait of fire on the horizon and a planet frozen over. The narrator of Life Without Sound has a lot of this kind of stuff in his back pocket\xe2\x80\x94poetry about isolation, desperation, self-evaluation, and trying to find a place in the world. The drama is rich, so when the lyrics temporarily fall away and the sound suddenly becomes massive, the payoff feels huge.' b'Producer John Goodmanson (whose pedigree includes records by Sleater-Kinney, Bikini Kill, Death Cab, and Unwound) recorded the band for three weeks, and in that time, he helped build moments like the climax of \xe2\x80\x9cUp to the Surface\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a big whorl of sound where TJ Duke\xe2\x80\x99s bass lines become massive, threatening to eclipse Jayson Gerycz\xe2\x80\x99s point-perfect drum fills and some dependably catchy riff work from Baldi. The album regularly oscillates between calm and upheaval, and with Goodmanson\xe2\x80\x99s help, Cloud Nothings ride valleys into peaks effortlessly.' b'Baldi\xe2\x80\x99s vocals were the final element to be recorded on the album, and he delivers his most emotionally complex performance to date. There\xe2\x80\x99s a bruised quality to his delivery on \xe2\x80\x9cSurface\xe2\x80\x9d and an assertive resolve when he sings about moving on (and looking back) on \xe2\x80\x9cEnter Entirely.\xe2\x80\x9d You can hear both confidence and fragility on \xe2\x80\x9cModern Act.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s always been good, but the album provides the best showcase for Baldi\xe2\x80\x99s voice yet.' b'The biggest knock against Life Without Sound\xc2\xa0is that it comes up short on\xc2\xa0hooks. Historically, the most powerful Cloud Nothings tracks bob and weave in search of new melodies, turning up new earworms to replace the ones from moments earlier. Look at \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Not Part of Me\xe2\x80\x9d (maybe their best song)\xe2\x80\x94each new hook somehow manages to dunk on the one that came before until the chorus reaches a shout-along fever pitch. There are scattered examples of this songwriting on Life Without Sound, but some songs just spin in place. \xe2\x80\x9cDarkened Rings\xe2\x80\x9d begins with momentum, but beyond its initial rush, it\xe2\x80\x99s short on ideas. \xe2\x80\x9cRealize My Fate\xe2\x80\x9d becomes repetitive and stagnant even when the band turns the screws on the tension. Screams, massive guitar tone, and a muscular performance, it turns out, can only go so far.' b'Baldi has called Life Without Sound the band\xe2\x80\x99s version of new age music. (Warning: Do not attempt to meditate to this loud guitar music.) The songs come with uplifting mantras (\xe2\x80\x9cfeel right, feel lighter\xe2\x80\x9d) and encourage reflection in tumultuous times (\xe2\x80\x9cI knew\xc2\xa0peace in the terror of the mind\xe2\x80\x9d). Baldi declares his intentions to move past the heaviness, though he knows full well that\xe2\x80\x99s easier said than done. \xe2\x80\x9cMoving on but I still feel it/You\xe2\x80\x99re just a light in me now,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings, repeatedly, on \xe2\x80\x9cEnter Entirely.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a powerful message, but it takes more than words to make this kind of music feel inspirational. They\xe2\x80\x99ve eased back from their most breakneck inclinations, and while Life Without Sound isn\xe2\x80\x99t their strongest work, it\xe2\x80\x99s got the seeds that could lead to their next definitive statement. History shows, anyway, that Baldi\xe2\x80\x99s not going to make the same record twice.'

column7: b'Hey Mr Ferryman is Mark Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s heaviest album, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also, in a peculiar way, his sweetest\xe2\x80\x94like Phil Spector orchestrating a George Saunders story.'
column8: b'So much of Mark Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s music exists in spite of itself. Sung in a husky register between a whisper and a croon, his songs are filled with characters willing themselves to disappear, transmitting from a translucent state between existence and nothingness. At the beginning of his last album, 2012\xe2\x80\x99s Don\xe2\x80\x99t Be a Stranger, a woman approached Eitzel to say, \xe2\x80\x9cI love you, but you\xe2\x80\x99re dead,\xe2\x80\x9d a six-word phrase that sums up the tension in Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s body of work, both in his seminal band American Music Club and throughout his fruitful solo career. His songs don\xe2\x80\x99t confront mortality; they drift in and out if it like subway stops.' b'So when the reaper himself comes to take Eitzel away in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Last Ten Years,\xe2\x80\x9d the opening number of his latest album Hey Mr Ferryman, Eitzel is not particularly bothered. As he begins his descent to the netherworld, he\xe2\x80\x99s actually more concerned that they get his drink order right: \xe2\x80\x9cSo, mister ferryman,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings over a smooth, lite-rock groove, \xe2\x80\x9cDo you party where you\xe2\x80\x99re from?\xe2\x80\x9d While Mark Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s songs have always been stately, with his moody fingerpicking standing as one of the saddest, most immediately identifiable sounds in indie rock, they\xe2\x80\x99ve never been so ornate. The eleven tracks on Hey Mr Ferryman are adorned with codas and false-endings, strings and bells, backing vocals and auxiliary percussion. If Don\xe2\x80\x99t Be a Stranger, with its stark ballads and haunting production, felt like a vulnerable return-to-form, this is the moment where the stakes heighten and the urgency increases: the Skeleton Tree to Stranger\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0Push the Sky Away.' b'All the production on *Ferryman *might seem over-the-top (more than one song ends with an on-the-knees-at-the-edge-of-the-stage guitar solo), if his lyrics weren\xe2\x80\x99t so crushing. In a standout track called \xe2\x80\x9cIn My Role as a Professional Singer and Ham,\xe2\x80\x9d Eitzel wails in the chorus, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you look at me, I look away.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s a sentiment that\xe2\x80\x99s often rung true for Eitzel. For all his years as a working songwriter\xe2\x80\x94with even a major label deal thrown in the mix for a little bit in the \xe2\x80\x9990s\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s never armed himself for a proper breakthrough: his work always felt too quiet, too insular, too strange. But on Ferryman, Eitzel is staring right back out at you. Notice in that line in \xe2\x80\x9cMy Role\xe2\x80\x9d how he holds out the second syllable of \xe2\x80\x9caway\xe2\x80\x9d to make sure he\xe2\x80\x99s got your attention (while also making the self-deprecating song title feel a little less ironic). In this context, the orchestration feels less ornamental and more like a reflection of Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s own confidence and catharsis.' b'As always, Eitzel populates *Ferryman *with a myriad of stories and characters, taking the focus off of himself and onto his word choice and the thematic links between songs. Sometimes, he takes on a literal character, like in the Joni Mitchell-style showbiz tragicomedy \xe2\x80\x9cMr Humphries\xe2\x80\x9d or the repurposed folklore of \xe2\x80\x9cLa Llorona.\xe2\x80\x9d Other times, he uses his subjects as a foil for his own fatalistic tendencies. \xe2\x80\x9cAn Answer\xe2\x80\x9d is one of Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s finest love songs and one that finds him questioning his entire belief system: \xe2\x80\x9cYou make me want to stick around and find if there\xe2\x80\x99s an answer,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings. It\xe2\x80\x99s crucial that he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say, \xe2\x80\x9cYou make me believe that there\xe2\x80\x99s an answer\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s still a Mark Eitzel song, after all. But the idea that someone can open him up to the possibility of permanence feels like a revelation.' b'That sentiment forms the underlying message\xc2\xa0of Ferryman\xe2\x80\x94that optimism doesn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily mean knowing that things will be okay, but simply having a reason to wait and find out if they could be. It\xe2\x80\x99s Eitzel\xe2\x80\x99s heaviest album, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also, in a peculiar way, his sweetest\xe2\x80\x94like Phil Spector orchestrating a George Saunders story. \xe2\x80\x9cIf that was death, it\xe2\x80\x99s not so bad,\xe2\x80\x9d Eitzel sings in \xe2\x80\x9cAn Angel\xe2\x80\x99s Wing Brushed the Penny Slot,\xe2\x80\x9d from the perspective of a dead woman haunting her gambling-addict widow. Visiting him in the hotel where she died, she leaves him with a pithy message: \xe2\x80\x9cThe El Cortez still welcomes me/Guess if you die on their floor, the drinks are all free.\xe2\x80\x9d After all, Eitzel implies, seeing a light at the end of the tunnel is just another way to\xc2\xa0look on the bright side.'

column7: b"There are glimpses of Vitalic's old energy on Voyager, but he's dialed back on the maximalist energy that made his dancefloor anthems radiate."
column8: b'Pascal Arbez-Nicolas has spent years trying to wriggle free of Vitalic\xe2\x80\x99s 2001 breakthrough debut *Poney EP. It still casts a long shadow; the chain-driven turbo-fluttering hiss of \xe2\x80\x9cLa Rock 01\xe2\x80\x9d and the horror/euphoria grind of \xe2\x80\x9cPoney Part 1\xe2\x80\x9d were the early alley-oops to the monster jams of Ed Banger\xe2\x80\x99s mid-\xe2\x80\x9900s heyday. But after OK Cowboy\xc2\xa0fleshed out his geeked-out aggro electro-house and Flashmob\xc2\xa0let it grow even wilder, Rave Age\xc2\xa0*revealed the limits of his overblown attack: sooner or later, like any powerful drug, all you get from ramping up the dosage is a baseline feel of familiar getting-by normality.' b'*Voyager\xc2\xa0*comes more than a decade after *OK Cowboy *amplified Vitalic\xe2\x80\x99s thrilling role in the French Touch scene, and it feels like it. There are glimpses of the old feverish energy on the record\xe2\x80\x94Arbez can still bring the no-fucking-around 4/4 with big stompy kicks\xe2\x80\x94but to what end, it\xe2\x80\x99s never entirely clear. The one thing you could definitely expect from a Vitalic record, good or bad, was abrasion. But\xc2\xa0*Voyager\xc2\xa0*power-washes all the distortion away, leaving a\xc2\xa0shiny surface that feels anonymous in its spotlessness.' b'Without that leviathan hum, a lot of *Voyager\xe2\x80\x99*s cuts stall out at \xe2\x80\x9cmildly exciting.\xe2\x80\x9d Most of the music\xe2\x80\x99s your standard uptempo placeholder dance, detached from\xc2\xa0fleeting trends but also uninterested in finding a new niche. It\xe2\x80\x99s not like Vitalic-Goes-Synthwave would be a guaranteed improvement over the water-treading stasis of tracks like \xe2\x80\x9cLevitation\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cUse It or Lose It,\xe2\x80\x9d but it\xe2\x80\x99d at least hint at something besides an effort to carry a torch for blog house when everyone else has moved to different platforms.' b'The ostensible anthems on *Voyager *range from meaningless sincerity (the downtempo loneliness-cliche checklist \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Leave Me Now\xe2\x80\x9d) to meaningless goofiness (\xe2\x80\x9cSweet Cigarette\xe2\x80\x9d is more or less what would happen if \xe2\x80\x9cWarm Leatherette\xe2\x80\x9d was about Christopher Buckley\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThank You for Smoking\xe2\x80\x9d instead of JG Ballard\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCrash\xe2\x80\x9d). And the closest things get to an engagingly scuzzy headfirst dive into the weirder corners Vitalic used to skulk around in is \xe2\x80\x9cHans Is Driving,\xe2\x80\x9d another downtempo navelgazer that sounds like a cruel parody of Drive-chic and features Miss Kittin evoking Euro-club aimlessness. It\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of stuff that really works when there\xe2\x80\x99s no shame and no half-measures, but *Voyager\xe2\x80\x99*s attempts to pay homage to disco ancestors while paring his maximalism way back make it all feel like a dance night in an unfurnished room, all speakers and no lighting.'

column7: b'The sound\xc2\xa0of Puerto Rican-born, NYC-based duo Buscabulla\xc2\xa0is post-chillwave but\xc2\xa0decidedly Caribbean, with nods\xc2\xa0to salsa, reggaeton, and bachata. Their\xc2\xa0sophomore\xc2\xa0EP\xc2\xa0features a duet\xc2\xa0with Helado Negro.'
column8: b'In many ways, the Buscabulla story is indicative of the new paradigm in independent music: an indie spirit buttressed by corporate sponsorship. The Puerto Rican-born, Brooklyn-based couple of Raquel Berrios and Luis Alfredo Del Valle won a Guitar Center contest for the privilege of having Dev Hynes produce their first EP, which was recorded with help from Converse, and released by the hybrid clothing/record label Kitsun\xc3\xa9. Berrios still holds down a day job as a designer, while raising her two-year-old with Del Valle.' b'Their breaks are representative of the kind of opportunity that millions of American citizens in Puerto Rico have sought out as they\xe2\x80\x99ve left their homes on the island to pursue new lives in the states. But the exchange runs both ways. Just as NYC\xe2\x80\x99s global market and culture has shaped their lives, they help ingrain Boricua culture into America\xe2\x80\x99s, bringing the sounds and stories of the islands to mainland and, often, to English-speaking audiences.' b'You can count the recorded Buscabulla songs on two hands, and they all sound like love songs to their homeland; Berrios\xe2\x80\x99 lyrics convey a longing, distant gaze that buffers out the island\xe2\x80\x99s rough edges, a magical oasis that exists only in dreams. These themes permeate Buscabulla\xe2\x80\x99s self-released second EP, a continuation of the first, both in concept and aesthetic. \xe2\x80\x9cFr\xc3\xado\xe2\x80\x9d is\xc2\xa0a\xc2\xa0duet with Helado Negro\xe2\x80\x99s Roberto Carlos Lange, in which the \xe2\x80\x9cYoung, Latin, and Proud\xe2\x80\x9d singer tries to comfort\xc2\xa0Berrios\xc2\xa0as they weather the winter\xe2\x80\x99s biting cold, yearning\xc2\xa0for the warm embrace of their hometowns. \xe2\x80\x9cEl fr\xc3\xado \xc3\xa9ste duele/(Duele en tu mente),\xe2\x80\x9d they sing, or \xe2\x80\x9cThis cold hurts/(The pain is in your mind.)\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cPerd\xc3\xb3n\xe2\x80\x9d considers the closure of leaving things, and people, behind. And \xe2\x80\x9cT\xc3\xa1rtaro,\xe2\x80\x9d the ode to \xe2\x80\x9csalsa erotica\xe2\x80\x9d legend Frankie Ruiz, romanticizes the island\xe2\x80\x99s seedier corners with a nostalgic fondness for sleaze that can quickly be punctured by the grimness of reality (like when the band found used towels and condom wrappers in the room they booked at an infamous Puerto Rican love hotel\xc2\xa0to shoot the video).' b'But Ruiz is an excellent analogue to the vibe that Buscabulla seeks to create. He sings about adultery and promiscuity, but with a croon that sounds too pretty to be wrong. While Buscabulla\xe2\x80\x99s live shows are considerably more high-energy than the lounge vibes on the records, they still draw from the same the sonic palette. Their aesthetic is post-chillwave but\xc2\xa0decidedly Caribbean, with percussion that skews towards salsa, and\xc2\xa0there are discernible nods to reggaeton, bachata, and even hints of Sade\xe2\x80\x99s new age soul (if she was an alto). Del Valle has admitted to being drawn to the \xe2\x80\x9cpeculiar type of charm\xe2\x80\x9d of Ruiz\xe2\x80\x99s music, a kitschiness wrapped in a beautiful voice, reminding us it\xe2\x80\x99s still fun to be naughty.'

column7: b"Segall\xe2\x80\x99s new album feels like a sampler of what he\xe2\x80\x99s been up to in the last\xc2\xa0half-decade. It's an easy entry point into his imposing catalog, and a complete portrait of his many capabilities."
column8: b'Back in the \xe2\x80\x9960s, when bands like the Rolling Stones were averaging three new albums a year, they\xe2\x80\x99d also drop quickie compilations along the way\xe2\x80\x94like High Tides and Green Grass and Through the Past, Darkly\xe2\x80\x94to summarize a particularly prolific period (or just cash-in on more casual fans). As someone who aspires to a \xe2\x80\x9960s Stones ideal\xe2\x80\x94in terms of both his sheer level of output and his ever-evolving garage-rock aesthetic\xe2\x80\x94Ty Segall is also wont to drop the occasional summary collection that allows the average listener to play catch-up. Except Segall is so restless and relentless, of course, that these compilations actually comprise all new material.' b'In the fall of 2012, Segall dropped Twins, an eclectic album that took a tasting-menu approach to the three\xc2\xa0aesthetically discrete albums that immediately preceded it. Likewise, Segall\xe2\x80\x99s new album feels like a sampler of what he\xe2\x80\x99s been up to in the half-decade since: the melancholic acoustic meditations of Sleeper, the classicist craftsmanship of Manipulator, the Marc Bolan s\xc3\xa9ances of Ty Rex, the diseased, dementoid psych-punk of last year\xe2\x80\x99s Emotional Mugger. Ty Segall is the second self-titled album in his discography (after his 2008 eponymous debut), seemingly because its 10 tracks offer a complete portrait of his many capabilities. But Ty Segall is more than just an easy entry point into his imposing catalog. The new album shows Segall has not only mastered several, stylistically divergent strains of rock\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s becoming ever more adept at seamlessly stitching them together.' b'For someone with roots in a genre\xe2\x80\x94garage-punk\xe2\x80\x94that puts a premium on gritty authenticity, Segall has become increasingly fond of artifice, be it the Bolan-via-Barrett faux British accent that\xe2\x80\x99s become his default vocal tic, the silver-lipstick vamping, or his use of Emotional Mugger as a vehicle to masquerade as a surrogate band and terrorize morning news programs. And that mischievous zeal is the glue that ultimately holds this album\xe2\x80\x99s disparate pieces together, particularly when they collide in the same song. Bulldozing opener \xe2\x80\x9cBreak a Guitar\xe2\x80\x9d forges a holy communion between Big Star melody and Black Sabbath brawn, and its cocksure attitude spills over to the stripped-down follow-up, \xe2\x80\x9cFreedom,\xe2\x80\x9d a scrappy, acoustic-powered number that recalls John Lennon\xe2\x80\x99s frantic Abbey Road curio \xe2\x80\x9cPolythene Pam.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'But that\xe2\x80\x99s not the only move Segall has cribbed from the second side of that Beatles classic. \xe2\x80\x9cFreedom\xe2\x80\x9d immediately gives way to an epic sequel, \xe2\x80\x9cWarm Hands (Freedom Returned),\xe2\x80\x9d a 10-minute multi-sectional suite that ricochets between warped glam-folk, proto-metal ferocity, sneering British Invasion swagger, overdriven fuzz-punk, and a jazzy guitar jam that attempts to out-Santana the Stones\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cCan\xe2\x80\x99t You Hear Me Knocking.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s the most ambitious, audacious piece of music Segall has ever produced, but he whisks through the song\xe2\x80\x99s train-like structure with such manic glee that this colossal track ultimately feels as brisk and economical as a seven-inch single.' b'Given that it\xe2\x80\x99s dropped early on in the No. 3 slot, \xe2\x80\x9cWarm Hands (Freedom Returned)\xe2\x80\x9d casts a long shadow over the rest of the album\xe2\x80\x94in its wake, even the sludgy stomper \xe2\x80\x9cThe Only One\xe2\x80\x9d and the wild, glass-smashing roadhouse rave-up \xe2\x80\x9cThank You Mr. K\xe2\x80\x9d feel a bit rote in comparison. But Segall wisely balances his most epic gestures to date with his most intimate, as Ty Segall\xe2\x80\x99s back half yields the prettiest, most pristine pop songs he\xe2\x80\x99s ever written: \xe2\x80\x9cOrange Color Queen\xe2\x80\x9d is a mash note to his girlfriend rendered in T. Rex\xe2\x80\x99s mystic-lady language; the piano-rolled \xe2\x80\x9cPapers\xe2\x80\x9d wraps the album\xe2\x80\x99s catchiest chorus around a cluttered-desk scene straight out of a late-\xe2\x80\x9960s Kinks album. And on \xe2\x80\x9cTake Care (to Comb Your Hair),\xe2\x80\x9d Segall shrewdly builds a deceptively hippy-dippy folk song into a Who-sized barrage of finger-slicing windmill strums and kit-toppling drum rolls, effortlessly bridging the troubadour and trouble-maker sides of his personality.' b'Of course, Segall can\xe2\x80\x99t help but follow up these handsomely packaged songs with \xe2\x80\x9cUntitled,\xe2\x80\x9d which is really just a four-second blurt of guitar noise that closes the album with all the subtlety of a fart let out in the most crucial moment of a wedding ceremony. But that throwaway gag nonetheless serves as a reminder of Segall\xe2\x80\x99s most essential quality: his refusal to settle. Rather than chart a typically linear course from raw to refined, Segall has constructed a discography more like a zig-zagging thrill ride liable to careen off into any direction. And whether it\xe2\x80\x99s the jarring track-to-track juxtapositions or within the shape-shifting songs themselves, Ty Segall shows that, nearly a decade into the game, the only predictable thing about Segall is his ability to continually surprise.'

column7: b'Though not her best work, Big Trouble Little Jupiter showcases why Kodie Shane is one of rap\xe2\x80\x99s most promising prospects: she\xe2\x80\x99s resourceful and she\xe2\x80\x99s fearless.'
column8: b'Atlanta artist (by way of Chicago) Kodie Shane is a young jack-of-all-trades, the Swiss army knife of Lil Yachty\xe2\x80\x99s Sailing Team. She\xe2\x80\x99s already mastered a few of them: rapper-singer\xc2\xa0alchemist, hook-making\xc2\xa0savant, bittersweet ballad scribe, intergenerational R&B translator, and (much like Yachty himself) effortless transmitter of communicable joy. She\xe2\x80\x99s at her best when she fills rap cadences with R&B melodies and when her verses blend into her hooks, sometimes because the verses themselves are hooks, too. After releasing her breakout EP, Zero Gravity, in December, which showcased all of her skills in a sampler, she has quickly delivered a new 10-track mixtape called Big Trouble Little Jupiter. The tape ventures even further beyond genre limits\xe2\x80\x94moving erratically from belligerent pop trap to vintage new jack swing. What it lacks in flow and consistency, it makes up for with big transitions and sheer ambition.' b'Big Trouble Little Jupiter, billed to be \xe2\x80\x9cstarring\xe2\x80\x9d Kodie Shane, is at least loosely related to the 1986 Kurt Russell film Big Trouble in Little China. Thematically, the tape is mostly about rescuing a lover from a boring boyfriend only to lure her into a short-term, noncommittal relationship while-jet setting across the globe. (Not exactly the plot of the film, but close.)\xc2\xa0Much of Kodie Shane\xe2\x80\x99s strength lies in her ability to generate earworms out of thin air, and that\xe2\x80\x99s still in play on Big Trouble Little Jupiter, especially on cuts like \xe2\x80\x9cBe With or Without.\xe2\x80\x9d But some song\xc2\xa0drag, or never get going: Woozy opener \xe2\x80\x9c2 Minute\xe2\x80\x9d is subdued and nearly sedated. The boxy confines of the slow-trotting, En Vogue-featuring \xe2\x80\x9cYour Side\xe2\x80\x9d minimizes open space, forcing Shane to maneuver through pockets with more traditional flows. The trap screecher \xe2\x80\x9cLike a Rockstar\xe2\x80\x9d forces her to over-exert\xc2\xa0her voice. When she presses too hard, the difference is palpable.' b'The best songs on Big Trouble Little Jupiter\xc2\xa0are as soothing and infectious as her strongest work. Songs pivot dramatically from stunt anthems to emotional pleas to personal profiles. On \xe2\x80\x9cTwins,\xe2\x80\x9d she declares herself a hustler and a pimp in the lineage of Jeezy, Jay Z, and Meek Mill. Over bunched synth strings on \xe2\x80\x9cNa Na Naa,\xe2\x80\x9d she reassesses her surroundings: \xe2\x80\x9cThese niggas is my sons, but I ain\xe2\x80\x99t raise \xe2\x80\x98em like this/And these hoes they not the one, but they swear that they is.\xe2\x80\x9d Her writing is as sharp as ever, producing subtle double entendres like \xe2\x80\x9cThey all want my swag but they just can\xe2\x80\x99t grasp it\xe2\x80\x9d along with scathing reads: \xe2\x80\x9cSo keep it real with me/And you don\xe2\x80\x99t have me now cause you can\xe2\x80\x99t deal me/I know your man don\xe2\x80\x99t know you here, you know I know you babe.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s in these moments, where she examines those around her, that she invites listeners to know her.' b'Production-wise, she continues to build a rapport with longtime collaborators Matty P and D.Clax here. They have credits on every song on Big Trouble Little Jupiter, and while the songs sometimes seem to come from different decades,\xc2\xa0Shane almost always pairs them with the appropriate melody and rhythm, finding a precise balance, ripping through some and drifting through others. As they continue to work together, they\xe2\x80\x99re getting a feel for what works through trial and error, scanning the entire hip-hop/R&B spectrum in the process. Though not her best work, Big Trouble Little Jupiter showcases why Kodie Shane is one of rap\xe2\x80\x99s most promising prospects: she\xe2\x80\x99s resourceful and she\xe2\x80\x99s fearless.'

column7: b'*Brokenlegged *is a rich and multifaceted emo record, exploring\xc2\xa0not only the expected moments of catharsis, but the hangovers that arise in their aftermath.'
column8: b'The title of *Labor Pains *was wasted on Sinai Vessel\xe2\x80\x99s debut. Frontman Caleb Cordes joked that the process of making the follow-up had become a full-blown \xe2\x80\x9cDIY Frank Ocean sort of thing\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94writing, recording, ditching the original mixes and re-recording has put five and a half years worth of distance between *Brokenlegged and its predecessor (three and change\xc2\xa0if you include the Profanity\xc2\xa0*EP). It\xe2\x80\x99s an odd position for an emo band to be in\xe2\x80\x94perfectionism is about\xc2\xa0the exact opposite of what its devotees ask for. After all, this music thrives on unsteady vocals, careening aggression and the immediacy of desperation and epiphany. Listeners and artists tend to age fast, distancing themselves from their dearly beheld truths of two years prior. When Labor Pains dropped in 2011, today\xe2\x80\x99s conscientious scene leaders Modern Baseball and the Hotelier were still teenage pop-punk bands.\xc2\xa0Fortunately, Cordes has made the most out of the\xc2\xa0protracted wait:\xc2\xa0Brokenlegged is a rich and multifaceted emo record, exploring\xc2\xa0not only the expected moments of catharsis, but the complicated hangovers that arise in their aftermath.' b'It makes for a logical follow-up to the gnarled, strident *Profanity, *which used mewithoutYou and Pedro the Lion as both sonic and lyrical guidance in how to extricate oneself from an evangelical upbringing. Reaffirming North Carolina as home\xc2\xa0after college, Cordes described the main theme of *Brokenlegged *as, \xe2\x80\x9ctrying to figure out how to live among people who haven\xe2\x80\x99t come to the same realizations of truth as you...who just take the status quo as being the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d Whatever that meant for him during the creation of *Brokenlegged, *it\xe2\x80\x99s a loaded statement that\xe2\x80\x99s going to be interpreted a very specific way in January of 2017. Red-state living isn\xe2\x80\x99t addressed all that much in indie rock (or *any *genre) and as we\xe2\x80\x99ve all seen on our Facebook feeds and family gatherings in the past few months, even well-intentioned attempts to breach this topic easily fall victim to either barely concealed anger or condescension.' b'Lead single \xe2\x80\x9cDogs\xe2\x80\x9d (a presumptive sequel to Profanity\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cCats\xe2\x80\x9d) could have fell victim to\xc2\xa0both, as a loftily-worded worded indictment of religious zealots.\xc2\xa0The general theme is familiar, exposing the hypocrisy of fundamentalists *othering *those who live in their same community in the name of love, and Cordes doesn\xe2\x80\x99t fall into the same trap. There\xe2\x80\x99s a \xe2\x80\x9cwrite what you know\xe2\x80\x9d/\xe2\x80\x9cknow your enemy\xe2\x80\x9d wisdom in \xe2\x80\x9cDogs\xe2\x80\x9d that puts it in a league with Modest Mouse\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cTrailer Trash\xe2\x80\x9d or the Mountain Goats\xe2\x80\x99 *Tallahassee**, *rare examples of indie rock that look directly at this kind of pathology rather than simply looking down on it.' b'\xe2\x80\x9cDogs\xe2\x80\x9d is something of an outlier; most of\xc2\xa0Brokenlegged isn\xe2\x80\x99t as overt about its spiritual and political leanings.\xc2\xa0The few immediately understandable\xc2\xa0lyrics\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt gets better every day, move along,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI used to be scared/I used to be just like you\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94are crucial guideposts through Cordes\xe2\x80\x99 occasionally impenetrable thickets of allusive imagery.' b"Often times, it's easier and just as rewarding to derive the meaning from the clenched intensity of Sinai Vessel's hardworking and exceedingly\xc2\xa0dense arrangements. \xc2\xa0The songs have sturdy, solid cores, and intriguing details at the edges justifying the band's exacting craftsmanship. Grace notes, like\xc2\xa0the vibraphone ringing through the pregnant atmosphere of \xe2\x80\x9cRamekin\xe2\x80\x9d or the caustic yells that interrupt \xe2\x80\x9cLaughlin,\xe2\x80\x9d push\xc2\xa0Sinai Vessel outside of the swaying, ocean-sprayed sound that defines the bulk of Brokenlegged.\xc2\xa0Though the eight songs here barely take up a half hour, they assume the heft of a record twice its length." b"Ironically,\xc2\xa0Cordes\xe2\x80\x99 painstaking songwriting only comes off as\xc2\xa0ostentatious on the album's sparest song.\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cDied on My Birthday\xe2\x80\x9d is a solo acoustic number performed as grave and solemnly\xc2\xa0as it's titled, its immediacy sapped by counterintuitive\xc2\xa0word choices: cacophonous phrases like \xe2\x80\x9crattles our lentil bowls\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ccruel lunch\xe2\x80\x9d land like sprained ankles, while\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9carbiter\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cfortnight\xe2\x80\x9d become distractions in the way \xe2\x80\x9cjudge\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9ctwo weeks\xe2\x80\x9d wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xc2\xa0Some might\xc2\xa0hear it as *Brokenlegged\xe2\x80\x99*s answer to the Hotelier\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHousebroken,\xe2\x80\x9d a brief tailspin on a record with an otherwise masterfully controlled trajectory. It just also just\xc2\xa0as easily have an \xe2\x80\x9cI Will Follow You Into the Dark\xe2\x80\x9d-like life outside of Brokenlegged, the breakout on an otherwise glistening, depressive and cohesive record. Either way, the manner in which Cordes puts himself out there with his\xc2\xa0superhumanly earnest delivery ensures it truly belongs.\xc2\xa0Brokenlegged\xc2\xa0isn't perfection\xe2\x80\x94could it be trusted if it was?\xe2\x80\x94but every second sounds like it earned its right to exist."

column7: b'On their sophomore album, the Los Angeles rock trio fronted by\xc2\xa0Clementine Creevy\xc2\xa0have offered their fiercest recordings yet,\xc2\xa0full of shredding jams, furious howls, and self-aware swagger.'
column8: b'Four years ago,\xc2\xa0Los Angeles rock outfit Cherry Glazerr began with then-15-year-old singer/guitarist Clementine Creevy recording bedroom demos under the name Clembutt. These tracks were soon discovered on Soundcloud by Burger Records co-founder Sean Bohrman, who released them as a tape titled *Papa Cremp *in 2013. Cherry Glazerr\xe2\x80\x99s lineup soon solidified with the addition of bassist Sean Redman and drummer Hannah Uribe. Around this time, Cherry Glazerr caught the eye of Saint Laurent\xe2\x80\x99s ex-creative director Hedi Slimane, who embraced Creevy as a model and muse, and enlisted the band to soundtrack his debut film and a\xc2\xa0Fall 2014 Ready-to-Wear show. Then there\xe2\x80\x99s Creevy\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0work in the Amazon series \xe2\x80\x9cTransparent,\xe2\x80\x9d in which she performs in a band called Glitterish (and later Fussy Puss). By the time Cherry Glazerr released their debut LP, 2014\xe2\x80\x99s Haxel Princess, Creevy\xe2\x80\x99s reputation preceded them. All of this was done while she was in high school.' b'But Creevy has been clear that Cherry Glazerr is her\xc2\xa0primary passion and the group\xe2\x80\x99s sophomore record (and Secretly Canadian debut), Apocalipstick, confirms this more fiercely than ever. While Haxel Princess was full of goofy and relatable teenage dispatches, *Apocalipstick *shoots daggers. Now 19, Creevy sounds wizened and ready for battle\xe2\x80\x94and it\xe2\x80\x99s not just because she recorded \xe2\x80\x9cGiving Bad People Good Ideas\xe2\x80\x9d for Death Grips\xe2\x80\x99 Bottomless Pit. Thanks in part to the production of Joe Chiccarelli (the Strokes) and Carlos De La Garza (Bleached), Creevy and new bandmates Sasami Ashworth (keys/guitar) and Tabor Allen (drums) are a powerful rock trio. But for all this swagger, there\xe2\x80\x99s still the acknowledgement that Cherry Glazerr are \xe2\x80\x9cActing professional/When I\xe2\x80\x99m nothing but a self-conscious child.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Opener \xe2\x80\x9cTold You I\xe2\x80\x99d Be With the Guys\xe2\x80\x9d recounts Creevy\xe2\x80\x99s shift from lone wolf to supportive sister, but rather than being an anthem of empowerment, the track feels mournful as it recounts lost time. \xe2\x80\x9cI told you, I told you I\xe2\x80\x99d be with the guys,\xe2\x80\x9d she howls before doubling back into murmured regret, \xe2\x80\x9cBut I know better now/Than to be with the guys.\xe2\x80\x9d Cherry Glazerr tend to see-saw between extremes of expression: Moments of softness quickly give way to fiery yowls, and one can imagine a packed house of beer-swigging\xc2\xa0fans losing their minds to it. \xe2\x80\x9cSip O\xe2\x80\x99 Poison\xe2\x80\x9d has all the furious drums of No Age. Creevy\xe2\x80\x99s voice, combined with Ashworth\xe2\x80\x99s keys, create a piercing effect like Avey Tare\xe2\x80\x99s clipped yelps on Animal Collective\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cGrass.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'Even the\xc2\xa0lighter tracks\xc2\xa0remain rollicking. The re-recorded \xe2\x80\x9cNurse Ratched\xe2\x80\x9d offers a brief respite after \xe2\x80\x9cSip O\xe2\x80\x99 Poison\xe2\x80\x9d with a\xc2\xa0steady, shredding\xc2\xa0jam. \xe2\x80\x9cTrash People\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMoon Dust\xe2\x80\x9d are all bubbly synths and\xc2\xa0incessant drumming__,__\xc2\xa0presenting an idea of what the Go-Go\xe2\x80\x99s could have sounded like if Kim Gordon joined their ranks. \xe2\x80\x9cNuclear Bomb\xe2\x80\x9d is perhaps Apocalipstick\xe2\x80\x99s mellowest track (you might expect it to be the more appropriately titled \xe2\x80\x9cLucid Dreams\xe2\x80\x9d). Creevy takes the sadness from \xe2\x80\x9cTold You I\xe2\x80\x99d...\xe2\x80\x9d and opens the wound even deeper, digging into the pain of loss with a scalpel and a smile.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s been over 30 years since Cherie Currie of the Runaways boasted, \xe2\x80\x9cHello, world! I\xe2\x80\x99m your wild girl/I\xe2\x80\x99m your ch-ch-ch-cherry bomb!,\xe2\x80\x9d giving young women control of a provocative firecracker: themselves. All fruit-related similarities aside, Cherry Glazerr are here to offer a 2017 version of the same energy, one that is sexy, juvenile, catchy, and above all, simply great rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll. While some argue that guitar music is pass\xc3\xa9, Cherry Glazerr promise to make you remember how awesome a sick riff can be, how nostalgia can be captured in a single shred, and how anyone can start a band. Always.'

column3: b'Near to the Wild Heart of Life'
column7: b'For the most part, Near to the Wild Heart of Life sticks to the Japandroids M.O., but the end results are less enticing.'
column8: b'Listening to Japandroids makes me think about Jenga. You have the most basic elements (guitar, drums, and vocals, in this case) delicately stacked on top of each other. The raw materials\xc2\xa0are so simple,\xc2\xa0but the more it builds in increments, the higher the stakes become; each move ratchets up the tension partly because you know the whole thing is constantly in danger of buckling under itself at any time.' b'Likewise, the best Japandroids songs are always threatening to topple over; singer/guitarist Brian King struggles to reach his highest notes, and drummer David Prowse pounds the drums frantically, like they might be running away from him. They teeter\xc2\xa0forever on a precipice\xc2\xa0separating transcendence\xc2\xa0from pure cheese\xe2\x80\x94one of their best songs turns on the cathartic refrain \xe2\x80\x9cI just wanna worry about those sunshine girls\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s sold with life-changing intensity. As a lyricist, King takes you to that precipice, invites you to look over, even gives you the smallest nudge\xe2\x80\x94and then he catches you.' b'Which is why the advance single to their latest record \xe2\x80\x9cNear to the Wild Heart of Life\xe2\x80\x9d is so disappointing. \xe2\x80\x9cNear to the Wild Heart of Life\xe2\x80\x9d is too perfect. The grit on King\xe2\x80\x99s voice is gone; the guitar is too cleanly mixed; the drums don\xe2\x80\x99t hit as hard. This is a band whose second album is literally titled Celebration Rock, but this song\xe2\x80\x99s version of a lyrical clincher\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI used to be good but now I\xe2\x80\x99m bad\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94clunks off the ear like a tennis ball against a wall.' b'For the most part, Near to the Wild Heart of Life sticks to the Japandroids M.O. King still writes about drinking, about girls, about the love-hate relationship between himself and the idea of a hometown. King claims Vancouver, although things have gotten slightly more complicated as the band has\xc2\xa0tacked between Toronto, New Orleans, and Mexico City, taking a three-year hiatus of touring beginning in 2013. This much is reflected in the rollicking autobiographical travelogue \xe2\x80\x9cNorth East South West,\xe2\x80\x9d which is one of King\xe2\x80\x99s sharpest songs on the album lyrically. But the mix is too pristine, the acoustic guitar too loud, and it lacks the bite of their best songs.' b'More disheartening is the sapping of King\xe2\x80\x99s sense of humor. He was often funny in a straightforward way, like Jonathan Richman if he weren\xe2\x80\x99t a teetotaler: \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t we have anything to live for?/Well of course we do/But \xe2\x80\x98til they come true/We\xe2\x80\x99re drinking,\xe2\x80\x9d went a highlight from \xe2\x80\x9cThe Nights of Wine and Roses.\xe2\x80\x9d On \xe2\x80\x9cWet Hair\xe2\x80\x9d he gave us the magnificent\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cMust get to France so we can French kiss some French girls.\xe2\x80\x9d There are no similar laugh lines on\xc2\xa0Near to the Wild Heart of Life, which relies heavily on cliches and platitudes minus the wink or the grin.' b'Take \xe2\x80\x9cArc of Bar,\xe2\x80\x9d a seven-minute story song that is the centerpiece of the record and defiantly unlike anything else in the band\xe2\x80\x99s catalog. But it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t build to a hearty climax, a hallmark of the band. It just lumbers around, as King places hoary clich\xc3\xa9 on top of hoary clich\xc3\xa9 about \xe2\x80\x9chustlers, whores\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe jokers doing the dealing\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ca mistress, to some a muse\xe2\x80\xa6for her love, I would help the devil.\xe2\x80\x9d For a band that lives by its ability to slam-dunk a moment of catharsis, this song is the ultimate heat-check.' b'The spruced up modern-rock sound of a song like \xe2\x80\x9cTrue Love and a Free Life of Free Will\xe2\x80\x9d has the hollow appeal of \xe2\x80\x9creal\xe2\x80\x9d rock and roll bands like Foo Fighters or the Black Keys. (King sounds awfully like Dave Grohl on \xe2\x80\x9cMidnight to Morning.\xe2\x80\x9d) The band that playfully riffed on Thin Lizzy or sustained one riff\xc2\xa0for five minutes while proclaiming \xe2\x80\x9cafter her/I quit girls,\xe2\x80\x9d now sounds like MOR. It\xe2\x80\x99s a testament to King\xe2\x80\x99s inherent likability and the band\xe2\x80\x99s still-effortless knack for\xc2\xa0memorable melodies that this album isn\xe2\x80\x99t as big a disappointment\xc2\xa0as it may\xc2\xa0seem. They still have the discipline to keep things at eight songs only, and they can still reel off a sparkler like \xe2\x80\x9cNo Known Drink or Drug,\xe2\x80\x9d an incandescent song that flares with the ending \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6could ever hold a candle to your love.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'King and Prowse have sustained critical and fan love for eight years now. Both seem to be comfortable in their roles as rock\xc2\xa0veterans, with a loyal fanbase, a label that allows them years between records. Who am I to begrudge artists who\xe2\x80\x99ve matured?\xc2\xa0Perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s age, experience, a new record label, the inevitable artistic instinct to want to switch things up a little, but whatever the reason, Near to the Wild Heart of Life ultimately lacks the urgency of the band\xe2\x80\x99s best music. The tower hasn\xe2\x80\x99t collapsed, but it\xe2\x80\x99s starting to wobble.'

column7: b'Matthew Dear\xe2\x80\x99s contribution to the\xc2\xa0DJ-Kicks series is his most engaging\xc2\xa0commercial mix yet. Intricately and intuitively mixed, it incorporates a handful of his own unreleased tracks.'
column8: b'Multiple identities are common in dance music, but Matthew Dear has taken his ego-altering further than most. In the early years, his aliases\xe2\x80\x94False, Jabberjaw, and Audion, along with his real name\xe2\x80\x94served as proving grounds for subtle tweaks on a single, overarching vision of techno in which texture, groove, and hook all held equal weight. But the gulf between the different aspects of his personality has steadily widened, particularly as he has settled on two main projects situated at opposite poles. As Audion, he makes cavernous, big-room techno that trades in weaponized euphoria and supersized sensation. Under his own name, he has become a singer/songwriter of knotty, nuanced electronic pop\xe2\x80\x94the possessor of a sultry, Bowie-indebted baritone and a bandleader with the swaggering stance to match.' b'His DJ-Kicks mix is credited simply to Matthew Dear, but it actually represents a third aspect of his musical persona: the DJ. It is not his first commercial mix CD. As Audion, he recorded Fabric 27 in 2006, and as Dear, he delivered the seventh installment in Get Physical\xe2\x80\x99s Body Language series in 2008. Like those mixes, DJ-Kicks focuses heavily on the present moment: Nothing is more than two years old, with the exception of a 1980 synth-pop rarity that turns up in a newly edited form. Given the ways that dance music has changed in the past decade, there\xe2\x80\x99s a temptation to read the new mix as survey of its moment, much in the same way that Fabric 27 represented the minimal scene at its mid-\xe2\x80\x9900s peak and *Body Language Volume 7 *captured a snapshot of the EasyJet-set\xe2\x80\x94the tech-house axis of London, Berlin, and Ibiza\xe2\x80\x94at the end of the decade. But Dear\xe2\x80\x99s DJ-Kicks feels less like a cross-section of a scene or a snapshot of a moment in time than a core sample of his own idiosyncratic sensibility. There\xe2\x80\x99s more character in this mix than in the previous two; it\xe2\x80\x99s weirder and more engaging. The others could sometimes get tripped up by their own linearity, but this one is more charged, more unhinged, and riskier; it\xe2\x80\x99s also more intricately and intuitively mixed. It\xe2\x80\x99s a vision of house and techno that\xe2\x80\x99s sleazy, druggy, and disorienting\xe2\x80\x94also sneaky, whip-smart, and fun.' b'Dear\xe2\x80\x99s specialty is the controlled urgency of the peak time, and that\xe2\x80\x99s precisely where the bulk of the set dwells: deep in the chugging, roiling murk, with blunt machine grooves stirring up melodies the color of bruise blood. He opens on a more contemplative note, though, with an elegiac solo-piano piece from Nils Frahm that launches us into a new, previously unreleased song of his own: \xe2\x80\x9cWrong With Us,\xe2\x80\x9d a bittersweet, Koze-like vocal number that neatly captures the weariness of a relationship going off the rails. It\xe2\x80\x99s the only time we\xe2\x80\x99re treated to Dear\xe2\x80\x99s singing voice in the mix, but voices actually constitute a crucial through-line. Across\xc2\xa0the set he has scattered snippets of dialogue with his friends and family\xe2\x80\x94off-the-cuff fragments, slowed to a narcotic (and largely incomprehensible) crawl, that serve as sinewy connective tissue from track to track. They lend the impression of moving through a crowded dancefloor where scraps of truncated conversations whip around your head as you move\xe2\x80\x94a kind of Nightclub of Babel.' b'While few songs here foreground sung melodies, nearly every track uses vocals as a textural or rhythmic element: the cut-up, head-turning double entendres of Markus Enochson\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHot Juice Box\xe2\x80\x9d; the choppy, panned, and filtered gurgles of Kreon\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSilo Sol\xe2\x80\x9d; the booming, crowd-stoking commandments of Italojohnson\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cITJ10B1.\xe2\x80\x9d As a singer, Dear has always been as interested in the heft of the voice as he is in lyrical meaning, so it makes sense that he\xe2\x80\x99d gravitate toward club cuts that work in the same way. And for listeners, his varied selections\xe2\x80\x94juggling high voices and low, rough and smooth, garbled and clean\xe2\x80\x94carve out an unusual space in between vocal and instrumental dance music. These aren\xe2\x80\x99t voices we sing along with, necessarily; they aren\xe2\x80\x99t the garish \xe2\x80\x9ctoplines\xe2\x80\x9d garnishing commercial EDM. But they add nuance and mystery, drawing you in past the stern, occasionally forbidding contours of the rhythms Dear favors\xe2\x80\x94snapping, mechanical vortexes full of sharp edges and jutting angles.' b'Dear\xe2\x80\x99s mixing is a treat. Unless you know the tracks inside and out, it\xe2\x80\x99s virtually impossible to tell where they begin and end; he favors long, careful blends, and rarely leaves a given track to play out by itself for long. His selections benefit from the hands-on style. Pay attention to the way energy pulses between two cuts running in parallel, and you imagine the motion of a pinball as it ricochets off bouncers and flippers: wildly kinetic and keenly controlled.' b'The smartly paced set switchbacks between minimalist drum tracks and deeper, more atmospheric house, and it climaxes with two\xc2\xa0previously unreleased Audion cuts and an interlude. Following the \xe2\x80\x9cFlat Eric\xe2\x80\x9d-like bassline of Soulphiction\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSky So High,\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cLive Breakdown\xe2\x80\x9d wipes the slate clean with an extended stretch of granular vocal processing drawn out into a gravelly fit of pique. \xe2\x80\x9cStarfucker\xe2\x80\x9d rebuilds momentum with a rolling groove and a sharply syncopated hook, and it all comes to a head with the unhinged \xe2\x80\x9cBrines,\xe2\x80\x9d an improvised modular-synth workout playing rapid-fire snare rolls off dial-tone squeal. The set\xe2\x80\x99s real highpoint, though, comes a few tracks earlier, when Dear mixes Simian Mobile Disco\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cStaring at All This Handle\xe2\x80\x9d into Pearson Sound\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cXLB,\xe2\x80\x9d one of 2016\xe2\x80\x99s biggest techno tracks. As Resident Advisor\xe2\x80\x99s No. 2 track of the year, it\xe2\x80\x99s by far the highest-profile selection in the mix, but its notoriety isn\xe2\x80\x99t the operating factor here; it\xe2\x80\x99s the way Dear plays the two tracks\xe2\x80\x99 hooks off each other.' b'Each one is considerably powerful on its own. Simian Mobile Disco\xe2\x80\x99s sounds like a Foley artist\xe2\x80\x99s thunder sheet being suddenly liquefied, as if by some arcane chemical process; Pearson Sound\xe2\x80\x99s is a barrage of neon tracers cutting through darkness. Together, they evoke an image like something out of a John Woo film\xe2\x80\x94a hail of bullets in an actual hailstorm. It\xe2\x80\x99s such an intuitive pairing that you wonder why all DJs don\xe2\x80\x99t always play these two tunes together. But it goes deeper than that. With the two descending sequences snapped into a kind of double helix formation, we\xe2\x80\x99re presented with a schema of what Dear listens for when he\xe2\x80\x99s putting together a mix: an X-ray of the structural underpinnings of his DJ sets. DJing is often characterized as an active, even athletic undertaking, whether that means rapid cross-cutting or vulgar fist-pumping. But in Dear\xe2\x80\x99s hands, it can also be a more contemplative one: a case of setting up two tracks and letting them play out in a way that allows\xc2\xa0us to hear them anew. Locked into his listening, we let his ears guide ours.'

column7: b'The new EP is a retreat, another Of Montreal release where the standout track is the one that most sounds like Ziggy Stardust.'
column8: b"People would appreciate Kevin Barnes\xe2\x80\x99 music more if he released less of it. Two decades into his Of Montreal project, Barnes continues to average about an album a year, and far more if you count compilations and EPs. That Stephen King-like prolificacy may work for\xc2\xa0rappers who aren't concerned if you listen to their latest mixtape or wait for the next one, or guys like Robert Pollard, whose records ask almost\xc2\xa0nothing of the listener. But even Of Montreal\xe2\x80\x99s best albums don\xe2\x80\x99t exactly go down easy; they\xe2\x80\x99re a serious investment of time, energy, and patience. We all only get so much time on this earth, and we can only devote so much of it listening to Kevin Barnes. And so since False Priest Of Montreal albums have piled up like unread issues of The New Yorker on a coffee table, guilt tripping you for failing to keep up with them." b'For those who checked out after the band\xe2\x80\x99s third consecutive Georgie Fruit album, or those who could no longer keep all of the group\xe2\x80\x99s Seussian record titles straight, here\xe2\x80\x99s what you\xe2\x80\x99ve missed: a further bottoming out, followed by a run of decent full-lengths that felt a bit like apologies for the headaches that preceded them, including a kind of folky record, a more rocking one and, last year, a semi-EDM inspired one called Innocence Reaches. While by no means one of the group\xe2\x80\x99s best records\xe2\x80\x94it probably doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even crack the 50th percentile\xe2\x80\x94that last album seemed to outline a promising path forward for the band: Stay relevant by engaging with contemporary sounds instead of returning to the usual Beatles/Bowie/Prince triptych. But this is Of Montreal we\xe2\x80\x99re talking about, and they\xe2\x80\x99ve never been ones to follow a linear progression, so here we have their latest EP, Rune Husk, which ret-cons away the last record\xe2\x80\x99s raved-up synths. It\xe2\x80\x99s a retreat, another Of Montreal release where the standout track is the one that most sounds like Ziggy Stardust.' b"\xe2\x80\x9cStag to the Stable,\xe2\x80\x9d with its punchy, Mick Ronson-esque riff, is the EP\xe2\x80\x99s most purely fun moment, especially during a loopy bridge that riffs on one of Barnes\xe2\x80\x99 go-to themes, transformation (\xe2\x80\x9cDisappearing is eerie when you don't even care to maintain a physical form/Or give voice to the pariah plaintiff in adjudication rooms.\xe2\x80\x9d) Unfortunately, the limp tracks bookending it feel like leftovers, possibly ones that predate Innocence Reaches by quite a while. Two are low-energy psychedelic sketches in need of a hook. The third is a slightly livelier one with the same problem." b'Credit Barnes this, though: He may have made some misguided albums, but he\xe2\x80\x99s never made a cynical one. Even on his lesser material, he digs in with gonzo determination, and that conviction can go a long way. \xe2\x80\x9cIsland Life\xe2\x80\x9d almost coasts on his vividly grotesque beat poetry alone: \xe2\x80\x9cKing Derelict outed shifty ranges and kinky drones/No fetal sex traumas without revenge, a boring execution climax of trinity maggot.\xe2\x80\x9d And when on the otherwise aimless \xe2\x80\x9cWidowsucking\xe2\x80\x9d Barnes enthuses \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m wicked \xe2\x80\x99cause I have not peaked!\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99s so confident that you truly want to give him the benefit of the doubt. It\xe2\x80\x99s possible he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t peaked. Mostly, though, Rune Husk reaffirms what we already know: Barnes has some more good music in him, and possibly even some great music, but he\xe2\x80\x99s going to make us keep digging for it.'

column7: b'The dynamic Atlanta rapper Trouble\xe2\x80\x99s year-in-review mixtape is a smart flex, featuring collaborations with Young Thug, Fetty Wap, Quavo, and others.'
column8: b'The Atlanta rapper Mariel Semonte Orr, aka Trouble, released his first mixtape in 2011, aligning himself with the nascent locals of Duct Tape Entertainment, a label founded by rappers from the same Edgewood Court section of East Atlanta. DTE hasn\xe2\x80\x99t launched a full-fledged star from its roster, but over the last couple years, Trouble\xe2\x80\x99s name has been popping up a bit more conspicuously. Trouble now\xc2\xa0seems like the imprint\xe2\x80\x99s best chance at a resurgence;\xc2\xa0he\xc2\xa0has been earning the attention with some of the most interesting music of his career.
