His latest mixtape, Year in 2016, is a hasty year-in-review project, and functions as a fan-service document as well as an\xc2\xa0open invitation to catch up.' b'In 2015, Trouble made the best of an appearance on Young Thug\xe2\x80\x99s Slime Season 2*\xc2\xa0*mixtape: He slunk\xc2\xa0into bar-trading stride with one of hip-hop\xe2\x80\x99s squirrelliest vocalists and helped to slur out the \xe2\x80\x9cThief in the Night\xe2\x80\x9d hook, which propelled that\xc2\xa0banger in the first place. The appearance wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an exhaustive come-up, but it suddenly cast Trouble\xc2\xa0in a newly capable, vital light. Trouble has been nurturing that collaborative spirit for years, and he\xe2\x80\x99s become an increasingly reliable Atlanta team-player. Accordingly, *Year in 2016 *hosts enough Atlanta rappers to scan like a local studio sampler. The posse cut \xe2\x80\x9cWatchu Doin,\xe2\x80\x9d one of several here\xc2\xa0culled from Trouble\xe2\x80\x99s 2016 mixtape Skoobzilla, corners him with\xc2\xa0Quavo, Young Thug, and Skippa Da Flippa. Quavo and Trouble co-pilot a tumbling, charged-up hook; on a busy beat with some\xc2\xa0big personalities, Trouble sounds indispensable, never like an add-on. It\xe2\x80\x99s not an isolated occurrence:\xc2\xa0Trouble holds his own through a handful of other crowded tracks here, too.' b'More than ever, Trouble has opened up as a rapper, having long since retired the slow-talk flow he barked out on clunky\xc2\xa0early songs. Trouble is now more likely\xc2\xa0to channel the audacity and emotion of his bars in\xc2\xa0snappier ways. There\xe2\x80\x99s still something endearingly awkward about the way he ladles his voice: sometimes shouty and yelping, others mumbling or singing a slur.' b'Lyrically, \xe2\x80\x9cAhh Man\xe2\x80\x9d may be Trouble\xe2\x80\x99s most depressing banger ever, in which he sours a piano loop with downright gloom. He moans about not wanting to answer his phone, justifies drinking because of his father\xe2\x80\x99s health, and cops to copping pills for his grandmother in legitimate need. (\xe2\x80\x9cI guess the system just ain\xe2\x80\x99t showing no love/I got her a pack off the street though,\xe2\x80\x9d he fesses.) He contemplates his uncertainties: \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes I be blaming myself/For the doubt I brought down on myself.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'On \xe2\x80\x9cShe in Love Wit Trouble,\xe2\x80\x9d another solo track\xc2\xa0with some wonky trap synths dancing in the background, Semonte plays the boastful homewrecker; he flips his own name into an easy pun for a playful melody. If there\xe2\x80\x99s a lasting effect of this tape, and Trouble\xe2\x80\x99s recent success, it\xe2\x80\x99s that he\xe2\x80\x99s become an increasingly adept hook slinger\xe2\x80\x94prone to staying in pocket melodically, but versatile and daring in every other sense.' b'Not all the songs on Year in 2016\xc2\xa0originally belonged to the headliner, but when Trouble plays the featured artist, he\xe2\x80\x99s dynamic enough to make an impression. Still, a pair of Fetty Wap collaborations fall flat, not for lack of chemistry so much as a missed mark to begin with. And only one of Young Thug\xe2\x80\x99s three appearances marks\xc2\xa0a return to their banger\xe2\x80\x99s duet style. That track, the Goose-produced \xe2\x80\x9cRespect,\xe2\x80\x9d stands out early in the tape: Thug\xe2\x80\x99s no-filler second verse might be the attention grabber, but the song belongs to Trouble from the moment he lists his bonafides in the hook.' b'Year in 2016 rounds up the best of Trouble\xe2\x80\x99s best year yet, but it\xc2\xa0presses too much into a single compilation\xc2\xa0for a gratifying continuous listen. Still, an overloaded comp\xc2\xa0feels like a smart flex for Trouble, ample proof that he\xe2\x80\x99s suddenly, quietly launched an urgent second act. If you haven\xe2\x80\x99t been keeping up, Trouble is the type to remind you he\xe2\x80\x99s been here all along.'

column7: b'This collaboration between experimental guitarist Richard Pinhas and Oren Ambarchi, Merzbow, and others\xc2\xa0sounds like rock music echoed out into the stratosphere.'
column8: b'Save for a brief hiatus in the \xe2\x80\x9980s when he became disillusioned with music, guitarist Richard Pinhas has\xc2\xa0spent the last five decades making records, both solo and with many groups including \xe2\x80\x9970s French space-rock innovators Heldon. Lately he\xe2\x80\x99s been more productive, and collaborative, than ever: Reverse is his 14th release this decade, and like most of the others it features a fine supporting cast of accomplished players.' b'That cast began with Oren Ambarchi,\xc2\xa0a partner with Pinhas on their excellent 2014 album Tikkun. The pair recorded guitar drones in an initial session, stripped away the parts that they felt didn\xe2\x80\x99t work, and then added contributions from five collaborators including noise legend Merzbow, percussion master William Winant, and Pinhas\xe2\x80\x99s own son Duncan on synths. That\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of large personalities to fit into one space, but *Reverse *never feels crowded or dominated. Its expansive mix of sounds comes off as democratic.' b'In fact, if there is such a thing as a star of Reverse, it\xe2\x80\x99s one of its lesser-known participants, drummer Arthur Narcy. On three of the four tracks in an album-length suite called \xe2\x80\x9cDronz,\xe2\x80\x9d Narcy\xe2\x80\x99s playing creates a sturdy spine for his colleagues to wrap tones around, while also being agile enough to respond to their amorphous improvisations. In some spots, as during the gradual climb of \xe2\x80\x9cDronz 2 - End,\xe2\x80\x9d he starts with a steady beat and tweaks it into abnormal shapes to match the guitars\xe2\x80\x99 thickening clouds. He takes the opposite tack on opener \xe2\x80\x9cDronz 1 - Ketter,\xe2\x80\x9d coagulating jazzy sounds\xc2\xa0until they become metronomic.' b'The textures that Pinhas and company surround Narcy with are in constant motion, and are dense enough that something new is revealed with each listen. The sound the\xc2\xa0group conjures is too spacey to be called noise and too busy to be called drone. Its base is\xc2\xa0rock\xe2\x80\x99n\xe2\x80\x99roll, though there\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0little in the way of riffs or single, discrete notes. *Reverse *sounds more like rock music echoed out into the stratosphere, extracting the essence of guitar chords the way the shining light of a star distills\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0core of something long gone.' b'Pinhas has called\xc2\xa0making *Reverse *a healing process, coming as it did during a stressful period\xc2\xa0in his personal life, including the passing of both of his parents. There\xc2\xa0is a therapeutic aspect to the way the music\xc2\xa0continually opens up the world, suggesting that looking forward can help alleviate the past. That\xe2\x80\x99s true even in the album\xe2\x80\x99s only drum-less track, \xe2\x80\x9cDronz 4 - V2,\xe2\x80\x9d whose whirring treble feels more like a cathartic scream than a medicinal potion. In the sure hands of Pinhas and his comrades, *Reverse *is big enough to contain emotional multitudes.'

column7: b'The R&B singer offers the third installment of his sexually charged mixtape series, featuring his latest proteg\xc3\xa9\xc2\xa0Mike x Angel on eight of its 11 tracks.'
column8: b"At the end of last December, videos surfaced of Trey Songz destroying a stage at Joe Louis Arena in Detroit during a mini-temper tantrum. The event staff who prevented Trigga from performing past the venue\xe2\x80\x99s 11:30 pm curfew presented him a golden opportunity for free promo\xe2\x80\x94the smirk on the singer\xe2\x80\x99s mugshot, which went viral, all but announced\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cnew music is dropping soon.\xe2\x80\x9d Sure enough, Trey Songz and his frequent collaborator, Fabolous, surprised fans with their joint EP *Trappy New Years *on New Year's Eve. \xc2\xa0Eleven days later (and fittingly on a \xe2\x80\x9chump day\xe2\x80\x9d Wednesday), the singer released the third installment of his sexually charged Anticipation mix-tape series." b'Interestingly, Anticipation 3 is a collaborative effort, not a solo turn. Although the cover highlights Trey mid-performance, roaring and ripped,\xc2\xa0(possibly a screengrab from the Joe Louis Arena incident???), the\xc2\xa0smaller print reads \xe2\x80\x9cFEAT. MIKE X ANGEL.\xe2\x80\x9d But\xc2\xa0Mike x Angel, Trey Songz\xe2\x80\x99s latest proteg\xc3\xa9, is more than just a featured act: \xc2\xa0he\xe2\x80\x99s on eight of the 11 tracks. The singer is Virginia\xe2\x80\x99s answer to Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s Tory Lanez, with hints of R&B cult fave Pleasure P from Pretty Ricky. Trey\xe2\x80\x99s guest opens up the mixtape on the slow, loopy jaunt \xe2\x80\x9cA3\xe2\x80\x9d promising \xe2\x80\x9cparty favors, party favors.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"With the assistance of his pupil, Trey Songz delivers on his usual dimpled-grin bedroom talk, but this time around he's consistently upstaged by other featured guests. New York\xe2\x80\x99s Justine Darcenne breathes new life into *Anticipation 3 *as the female antagonist of \xe2\x80\x9cFind My Love,\xe2\x80\x9d and the frank voice on the excellent \xe2\x80\x9cVibrator.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cVibrator\xe2\x80\x9d also includes a great turn by Chicago rapper Chisanity, whose sounds like a deeper-voiced 21 Savage crossed with\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cAtlanta\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d fictional character Paper Boi. On the other hand, \xe2\x80\x9c93 Unleaded\xe2\x80\x9d could have worked without Dave East, whose\xc2\xa0bars and flow overwhelm the simplistic beat." b'Like Trigga, Anticipation 3 dabbles with trap&b atmospherics, a la Bryson Tiller\xe2\x80\x99s TRAPSOUL. But Trey\xe2\x80\x99s voice is a little too powerful to blend into the background of the wispy production, and he is too much of an old-school star to disappear from the foreground for long.\xc2\xa0The best is saved for last: \xe2\x80\x9cSho Nuff,\xe2\x80\x9d a slow jam suited for the \xe2\x80\x9cQuiet Storm\xe2\x80\x9d segments of late-night urban radio. \xc2\xa0The electric guitar chords and eager hook of \xe2\x80\x9cis you still my baby, she say sho\xe2\x80\x99 you right\xe2\x80\x9d is Trey at his freshest, throwing all the way back to the vibe of\xc2\xa0his 2005 debut I Gotta Make It.' b'Surprisingly enough, the other show stealer comes from Mike x Angel on closing bonus track, \xe2\x80\x9cAnxious.\xe2\x80\x9d Trey Songz is nowhere to be found as Angel tenderly asks a lover \xe2\x80\x9cWhat are we doing? What should I call this?\xe2\x80\x9d. Instead, we\xe2\x80\x99re held to anticipate new music from an up and coming talent, wondering if this could be a sign of an Aaron Hall being usurped by his Kellz. Only time will tell, but based on recent events, it seems highly unlikely Trigga would allow that to become a reality.'

column7: b"On their fourteenth studio album, thrash legends Kreator give us more of the same jackhammer style they built the band's name on\xe2\x80\x94only without quite as much personality or edge."
column8: b"Kreator\xe2\x80\x99s 1985 debut Endless Pain arrived two years after Metallica fired thrash metal's first shot with *Kill 'Em All\xe2\x80\x94*something of an eternity in the formative stages of a genre. Kreator immediately stood out, though, with their static-y guitars, frontman/guitarist Mille Petrozza's inimitable bark, and drummer J\xc3\xbcrgen \xe2\x80\x9cVentor\xe2\x80\x9d Reil\xe2\x80\x99s distinct combination of precision and primal savagery. So it didn\xe2\x80\x99t take long for the German thrash outfit to gain ground on their elite predecessors with landmark albums like 1989\xe2\x80\x99s Extreme Aggression, 1990\xe2\x80\x99s Coma of Souls, and 1992\xe2\x80\x99s Renewal." b'Of course, if you measure the energy level of those titles next to their new album Gods of Violence, there\xe2\x80\x99s just no comparison. By the same token, it would be too easy to dismiss the band\xe2\x80\x99s latter-day work as just an excuse to tour. After a run of four experimental, industrial-tinged albums in the \xe2\x80\x9990s, Kreator re-dedicated themselves to straight thrash on 2001\xe2\x80\x99s *Violent Revolution\xe2\x80\x94a\xc2\xa0*move that might have signified a\xc2\xa0surrender to heritage-act status if the band hadn\xe2\x80\x99t sounded so revitalized at the time.' b'Some of that vitality was on display as recently as last year\xe2\x80\x99s Violence Unleashed EP, but Gods of Violence suggests that it might be time for another shake-up. The band\xe2\x80\x99s fourteenth full-length, Gods of Violence does contain some noteworthy deviations from form. Album opener \xe2\x80\x9cApocalypticon,\xe2\x80\x9d an orchestral piece courtesy of Fleshgod Apocalypse members Francesco Paoli and Francesco Ferrini, bears more than a passing resemblance to both the Star Wars theme and the \xe2\x80\x9cMars\xe2\x80\x9d movement of Holst\xe2\x80\x99s iconic suite The Planets.' b'Bagpipes appear on the Celtic-flavored \xe2\x80\x9cHail to the Hordes,\xe2\x80\x9d while the title track intro features a solo from a 12 year-old harpist. And, for better or worse, the bright melody in the chorus section of \xe2\x80\x9cTotalitarian Terror\xe2\x80\x9d wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t sound out of place in the hands of pop-punk acts like Against Me! or Anti-Flag. Mostly, though, Petrozza and Reil give us more of the same jackhammer style they built the band\xe2\x80\x99s name on\xe2\x80\x94only without quite as much personality or edge. Case in point: the verse riff on \xe2\x80\x9cTotalitarian Terror,\xe2\x80\x9d which sees Petrozza coming dangerously close to re-treading Slayer when Slayer have been most guilty of re-treading themselves.' b"At times, Gods of Violence plays like an unresolved tug of war between quintessential Kreator and grandiose symphonic metal\xe2\x80\x94often in the same song. If you like both styles, you can expect to be in hog heaven. But if you prefer one over the other, you're left to skip over certain sections of songs. \xe2\x80\x9cArmy of Storms,\xe2\x80\x9d for example, hearkens back to signature riffs from the back-catalog staples \xe2\x80\x9cBetrayer\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRenewal\xe2\x80\x9d in the verse but then abruptly switches to an operatic chorus. In general, when Gods of Violence hews towards outsized melody, it feels watered-down rather than stretched out." b'Lyrically, Gods of Violence suffers in a similar way. Perhaps more than any other genre, part of the job requirement of being a heavy metal musician is the ability to come up with song titles and lyrics that look badass scrawled across the pages of high schoolers\xe2\x80\x99 notebooks. If we ranked bands based on that criterion, Kreator would surely land near the top of the list. For the last 30-plus years, Petrozza has penned gem after lyrical gem, amassing a string of fist-waving catchphrases that rival anyone in metal. So it\xe2\x80\x99s no surprise that Petrozza doesn\xe2\x80\x99t disappoint on Gods of Violence.' b"Petrozza has a way of distilling a song\xe2\x80\x99s chorus down to a punchline he delivers in single syllables, as if he wanted to ensure that even a child or non-English speaker could imagine a bouncing dot in their heads as they follow along. You have to be willing to indulge a little boneheadedness to get behind classic back-catalog nuggets like \xe2\x80\x9cTime/to/raise/your/flag/of/hate\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cUn-/der/the/gui-/llo-/tine.\xe2\x80\x9d But a trademark Kreator chorus makes it irresistible to sing along. You haven't lived, for example, until you\xe2\x80\x99ve sung the titular chorus of the new song \xe2\x80\x9cSatan Is Real\xe2\x80\x9d at an inappropriate volume in a setting where you\xe2\x80\x99re bound to raise eyebrows.(Attention ad execs: this is the song you need for your seitan ad!)" b'That said, despite Petrozza\xe2\x80\x99s gift for communicating directly to the angsty teenager at the core of every metalhead\xe2\x80\x99s soul, his subject matter speaks to a thoughtful way of observing the world. Petrozza also has a knack for using his words to convey the opposite of what they seem to indicate on first (or even second) glance. The new material exemplifies this technique: For Petrozza, Satan is a fictitious concept that becomes \xe2\x80\x9creal\xe2\x80\x9d because people invest it with belief. \xe2\x80\x9cDeath Becomes My Light,\xe2\x80\x9d meanwhile, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t glamorize death in stereotypically \xe2\x80\x9cmetal\xe2\x80\x9d fashion but instead looks at dying through the lens of a near-death experience. And the title track, with its chorus of \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall kill,\xe2\x80\x9d is actually a life-affirming call to evolve past (and thus \xe2\x80\x9ckill\xe2\x80\x9d) antiquated modes of thinking that no longer serve humanity\xe2\x80\x99s forward progress.' b'Petrozza even delves into utopian reverie with \xe2\x80\x9cHail to the Hordes\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94basically a heavy metal buddy anthem that offers solace and solidarity as \xe2\x80\x9cthe failed, the outcasts... carry each other through the darkest moments in life.\xe2\x80\x9d But this wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be a Kreator album if it didn\xe2\x80\x99t go to dark places. Originally conceived as a concept album rooted in Greek mythology, Gods of Violence frames modern warfare as a remnant of an ancient evil that has resided in the psyche for as long as our species has existed. Petrozza\xe2\x80\x99s original idea was to present our predilection for viciousness as something that was \xe2\x80\x9cborn\xe2\x80\x9d into our world after the gods decided to have an orgy.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a rich premise\xe2\x80\x94unfortunately, Petrozza doesn\xe2\x80\x99t flesh it out very much in the actual songs. G**ods of Violence could have used more of Petrozza\xe2\x80\x99s warped take. He\xc2\xa0has renounced the audacious moves the band made during its experimental period, but at least those moves were charged with a sense of creative risk. After several albums\xe2\x80\x99 worth of proving they can still recapture their classic sound, it\xe2\x80\x99s high time Kreator took more risks, come what may. They\xe2\x80\x99ve earned the right.'

column7: b'The legendary New Jack Swing trio reunites for a new album, right as fellow alumni New Edition hit the charts for the first time in over a decade.'
column8: b'Few anticipated the trio Bell Biv Devoe\xe2\x80\x99s sensational 1990 debut. All three members were in the important and longstanding R&B vocal group New Edition, but none were ever a central focus of the ensemble. They were consistently overshadowed by Ralph Tresvant, who provided lead vocals on most New Edition tracks; Johnny Gill, who joined the group in 1988 for their most fully realized album, Heart Break, but already had hits of his own; and even by former member Bobby Brown, who left New Edition in 1985 and hit No. 1 on the Hot 100 three years later. While Ricky Bell, Michael Bivins, and Ronnie Devoe were essential to the success of the group as a whole, they almost always served to support their more prominent co-stars.' b"Until they didn't: heeding advice from the world-class production duo Jam & Lewis, Bell Biv Devoe formed a trio and released an album that was eventually certified quadruple platinum. Of the New Edition diaspora, Brown enjoyed the most sales and notoriety, Tresvant approached one-note perfection with \xe2\x80\x9cSensitivity,\xe2\x80\x9d and Gill built an enviable collection of ballads, but it was the underdogs in Bell Biv Devoe who came up with that elusive thing, a crossover standard which everyone will know for eternity: \xe2\x80\x9cPoison.\xe2\x80\x9d President Obama recently invited the group to the White House to perform the track, confirming its designation as a piece of universal American pop culture." b"That honor makes it a fine time for Bell Biv Devoe to reemerge with Three Stripes. They're also likely to benefit from New Edition\xe2\x80\x99s high level of visibility at the moment: the group returned to the radio for the first time in over a decade last year, credited as featured vocalists on Johnny Gill\xe2\x80\x99s No. 1 R&B hit \xe2\x80\x9cThis One\xe2\x80\x99s For Me And You,\xe2\x80\x9d and a three-part New Edition biopic is slated to air on BET the same week that Three Stripes hits the shelves." b"This is the first Bell Biv Devoe album in 16 years, and early on, it feels like the trio is stepping gingerly, with continuity in mind above all else. Despite their time away from the studio, Bivins and Devoe still rap in the end-rhyme-heavy style of the late \xe2\x80\x9980s. And since the majority of the group's early hits were smutty accounts of the group's interactions with the opposite sex, similar narratives guide several songs on Three Stripes. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll say a bunch of slick shit to get between your thighs,\xe2\x80\x9d Devoe promises in \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m Betta,\xe2\x80\x9d a pushy, hurry-up-and-leave-him-number which reminds listeners that 49 year-olds have the right to be juvenile, too." b"But despite these allusions, Three Stripes rarely crackles in the manner of early Bell Biv Devoe\xe2\x80\x94the Poison album is resiliently pesky, like an especially pugnacious welterweight, but there's little of that scrappy spirit here. As they did in 1990, the trio calls on hip-hop producers for help: Erick Sermon of the famous New York hip-hop duo EPMD crafted \xe2\x80\x9cRun,\xe2\x80\x9d and other beat makers here include DJ Battlecat (Snoop Dogg, Xzibit) and Doug E. Fresh. But the tracks are mostly either pedestrian and unmemorable, or memorable for the wrong reasons. This is exemplified by the lead single, \xe2\x80\x9cRun,\xe2\x80\x9d which redundantly interpolates Notorious B.I.G.\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHypnotize,\xe2\x80\x9d a song too molded to Biggie to provide a favorable look for anyone else." b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a pair of the least energetic moments, though, which turn out to be the richest on the record. While Bell Biv Devoe classics mostly eschewed harmony, a New Edition hallmark, in favor of skeletal thwack, the trio embraces the full-group approach on the back half of Three Stripes. When Bell trades verses with SWV\xe2\x80\x99s scene-stealing Coko on the ballad \xe2\x80\x9cFinally,\xe2\x80\x9d her full, trembling tone nourishes his lancing falsetto. And Boyz II Men, who owe their name to a New Edition song, appear on \xe2\x80\x9cOne More Try,\xe2\x80\x9d helping create a benign, slender number based around Jerry Butler\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cI Could Write A Book\xe2\x80\x9d from 1970.' b"Plummy as these tracks are, they make you wonder why Bell Biv Devoe didn\xe2\x80\x99t recruit from the crack platoon of contemporary songwriters most adept at balancing R&B tradition with the requirements of today's production practices. This coterie includes Babyface, who writes nearly as well as he did two decades ago (see 2015\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cLove and Devotion\xe2\x80\x9d); Gregg Pagani, who helped pen Gill\xe2\x80\x99s No. 1 last year; and the duo of Pop & Oak, who gifted the world with Usher\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cGood Kisser\xe2\x80\x9d and Tamia\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSandwich and a Soda.\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0But Bell Biv Devoe aren\xe2\x80\x99t looking for that kind of help, and who says they need it? \xe2\x80\x9cRun\xe2\x80\x9d is currently a top ten record at Urban AC radio: once again, this underdog trio is enjoying unexpected success."

column7: b'Philly artist PnB broke out last year with an appealing rapper-turned-singer swagger. His major label debut carefully balances his malleable take\xc2\xa0on R&B and street rap.'
column8: b'Philadelphia rap is undergoing a generational shift. Despite all the tabloid drama, Meek Mill remains the city\xe2\x80\x99s biggest star, rapping with the emotional intensity of hometown legend Beanie Sigel, but with a honed ability to land crossover hits. Yet the city\xe2\x80\x99s two up-and-coming stars operate completely outside the street-vs.-pop divide that Meek observes so carefully.\xc2\xa0Lil Uzi Vert is a bratty rockstar that cannot write a bad hook and and PnB Rock wields a rapper-turned-singer swagger. Meek Mill rapped on Philly street corners and committed years to the mixtape grind, where this new wave was scooped up early by major labels, landing on success that took years for Meek to achieve.' b'PnB Rock went from catching regional buzz with\xc2\xa0post-prison freestyles in 2014 to signing with Atlantic Records the following year. In that short time, Fetty Wap, another rapper-turned-singer from the Tri-State area, emerged and crossed over with numerous Top 40 pop hits (\xe2\x80\x9cTrap Queen,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9c679\xe2\x80\x9d). Last year they released a joint mixtape, Money, Hoes, and Flows that highlighted Fetty Wap\xe2\x80\x99s charming vocal quirks set against\xc2\xa0PnB Rock\xe2\x80\x99s more conventional singing voice.' b'*GTTM: Going Through The Motions, *PnB Rock\xe2\x80\x99s major-label debut, carefully balances his malleable interpretations of both R&B and street rap. \xe2\x80\x9cRange Rover\xe2\x80\x9d fits a boastful trap mold (\xe2\x80\x9cRollie all on my wrist/Bitch I ball no assist/Smoking weed by the zip/Whole squad yeah we lit\xe2\x80\x9d), but his smooth delivery pushes the song closer to acoustic Ty Dolla $ign than Migos. On the other side of the spectrum is \xe2\x80\x9cNotice Me,\xe2\x80\x9d where Rock pines for a second of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s time, whose attention is buried in social media. The sentiment can feel like Drake-style shaming, but his words are empathetic when he wistfully sings: \xe2\x80\x9cIn your hand all day, on the \xe2\x80\x99gram all day/You been tweeting, snapchatting/And I feel like I just got to ask you/Do you notice me?\xe2\x80\x9d PnB Rock\xe2\x80\x99s delivery convey a simple a desire to find a romantic middle ground more than chauvinistic condemnation.' b'Song-by-song, *GTTM is a charming debut, but when viewed as complete album it falls fairly flat. It opens on a sour note with the Wiz Khalifa-featuring \xe2\x80\x9cAttention.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet instead of the suave Kush and OJ\xc2\xa0*Wiz, we get the\xc2\xa0boastful *Cabin Fever *version, full of to turgid go-nowhere cliches (\xe2\x80\x9cWhole lotta weed getting rolled in a paper plane/Whole lotta bitches scream my name\xe2\x80\x9d). Either of the following tracks\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThere She Go,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cPlaya No More,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSelfish\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94would have been\xc2\xa0stronger introductions, potential hits that also offer clear introductions to PnB Rock\xe2\x80\x99s worldview.' b"Unfortunately, tracklisting issues dog the album to its closing seconds. \xe2\x80\x9cNew Day,\xe2\x80\x9d produced by frequent Lil Uzi Vert collaborator Maaly Raw, is buried as the penultimate track, where it could\xe2\x80\x99ve added a bit of energy to the album\xe2\x80\x99s tepid middle section. The album closes with \xe2\x80\x9cStand Back,\xe2\x80\x9d an aggressive, calculated classic piece of East Coast street rap featuring Bronx up-and-comer A-Boogie Wit Da Hoodie. The pair share a natural chemistry, but there are no sparks here as the two jockey to see who can act the hardest. Fans in a post-iTunes streaming world can easily cull the best songs, \xc2\xa0but it\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate the album places that burden on them. Still,PnB Rock shows more than enough heart and talent; pick through the missteps, and there's still a good new artist here, someone capable of more."

column7: b'Phil Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 second album is a work of long-steeped fury at his country\xe2\x80\x99s sins, naked in its scorn for a system showing its many fissures; still, it guards a flickering, tenacious hope.'
column8: b'Though the cover shot of I Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore is a graveyard of grim political rhetoric\xe2\x80\x94Phil Ochs slumped against a wall of torn Barry Goldwater and Kenneth Keating posters, their slogans shredded and inscrutable\xe2\x80\x94the back cover essays comprise\xc2\xa0a beatnik rhapsody for the ages. Written by Ochs and the critic Bruce Jackson, they deliver the sort of earnest, overly verbose salvo\xc2\xa0only a Greenwich Village protest-folk record could deliver: a dense scrum of cheers to the Movement, jeers at the invertebrates in Congress, and navel-gazings on the quest for truth in art, with a track listing and credits seemingly wedged in as afterthought.' b'Midway through all the eager pulpit-pounding, though, the 24-year-old Ochs takes a turn both petulant and self-effacing, listing the most frequent complains that have been lobbed at him in his short career:' b'There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing as dull as yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s headlines.' b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t be so ambitious.' b'Sure it\xe2\x80\x99s good, but who\xe2\x80\x99s gonna care next year?' b'I bet you don\xe2\x80\x99t go to church.' b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t be so negative.' b'I came to be entertained, not preached to.' b'That\xe2\x80\x99s nice but it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t really go far enough.' b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not folk music.' b'Why don\xe2\x80\x99t you move to Russia?' b'Which is what you got in 1965 for leaping up onto a bench in Washington Square Park and warbling your dismay at the morning\xe2\x80\x99s New York Times: you were branded an ally of the communist kleptocracy, back when that sort of charge might actually end your career. (Simpler times.) But Ochs didn\xe2\x80\x99t argue these accusations; he reveled in them as proof of concept, his confirmation that he was hitting the establishment where it hurt. He labeled himself a \xe2\x80\x9csinging journalist,\xe2\x80\x9d not a folk singer like the rest of his Bleecker Street fraternity (Bob Dylan, Dave Van Ronk__,__ Tom Paxton), and stuffed his lyrics with the up-to-the-minute topicality and op-ed lambasting of a newsman\xe2\x80\x94championing a coal miners\xe2\x80\x99 strike in Kentucky one verse__,__ decrying Marines landing at Santo Domingo the next. He called the front pages like a guerrilla newsie, merging the sardonic wit of Woody Guthrie, the chatty candor of Pete Seeger, and the lone-gunslinger bravado of Hank Williams.' b'And in the troubled arc of Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 career\xe2\x80\x94in which he began as the voice of the antiwar movement and heir apparent to Dylan, then cooled into his also-ran, then sank a bitter and penniless outcast\xe2\x80\x94these cries of unpatriotism were a rare constant. He died not even knowing their extent; decades after he committed suicide in 1976, at age 35, the Freedom of Information Act unearthed a FBI monitoring dossier on him, thick as a novel.' b'But only a true American idealist could have written I Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore. Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 second album is a work of long-steeped fury at his country\xe2\x80\x99s sins, naked in its scorn for a system showing its many fissures; still, it guards a flickering, tenacious hope that the nation can reach its potential to embrace, to empathize. It is a work of nationalistic heartbreak, the deploring of a terrible fate: the requiem of a romantic with nowhere to love. It is zealously leftist, so unequivocal as to smack of propaganda over poetry, almost wholly dependent on Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 inculcating wordplay: with his twangy, octave-at-best vocal range, stevedore coffee shop strumming, and modest melodies, this album grabs your throat entirely on lyrical ferocity.' b'But to Ochs, there was no time for subtlety. The Lyndon B. Johnson administration was escalating involvement in Vietnam, ignoring countrywide demonstrations of dissent and returning body bags by the thousands; the racial friction of the South was exploding in bombings and riots; young Americans were still rudderless from the assassination of President Kennedy, mourning that era of profound hope and their purpose within it. Ochs absorbed it all and was a true believer in tuneful social reform; as he quipped in the program notes of the 1964 Newport Folk Festival, \xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised to see an album called Elvis Presley Sings Songs of the Spanish Civil War or The Beatles with the Best of the Chinese Border Dispute Songs.\xe2\x80\x9d But until the day that happened, Ochs was here for us, offering 14 brisk tracks of fingerpicked guitar and unvarnished tenor, distilling the world\xe2\x80\x99s chaos into a frightening thesis: An era of optimism and social promise was not only ending, but taking alarming leaps backward. But, he stressed, there was still time to reverse course.' b"He sets his agenda firmly in the title track\xe2\x80\x94an opener that rouses and incites despite a pallor of exhaustion, regret, and fear. Over a simple acoustic strum with a subtly agitated back-trill, Ochs travels the bloody scope of American warfare, gazing wearily through the eyes of a soldier whose obedience has cost him his humanity. He begins at the War of 1812, where \xe2\x80\x9cthe young land started growing/The young blood started flowing\xe2\x80\x9d; then he grips a glinting bayonet in the Civil War, pilots a plane through Japanese skies that sets off \xe2\x80\x9cthe mighty mushroom roar.\xe2\x80\x9d When Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 warrior reaches the \xe2\x80\x9cCuban shore,\xe2\x80\x9d and sees the missiles looming overhead, he grinds down his heels at last. \xe2\x80\x9cIt's always the old to lead us to the wars/Always the young to fall,\xe2\x80\x9d he laments__.__ \xe2\x80\x9cNow look at all we've won/With a saber and a gun/Tell me is it worth it all?\xe2\x80\x9d In a few breaths, Ochs not only decries the cyclical carnage of war, he explores the individual in bloodshed with clear-eyed empathy and lays a wrenching argument for ethical subversion. \xe2\x80\x9cCall it peace, or call it treason/Call it love, or call it reason,\xe2\x80\x9d he quavers, \xe2\x80\x9cBut I ain't marching anymore.\xe2\x80\x9d Here, his oft-nasal voice betrays a slight Scottish lilt, the result of his Queens-based family\xe2\x80\x99s brief stint in Edinburgh when he was a child\xe2\x80\x94a warm, global topnote to his treaty. Upon its release, \xe2\x80\x9cI Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore\xe2\x80\x9d became a ubiquitous anthem of the antiwar movement, and Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 signature tune; when he performed it outside the Democratic National Convention in 1968, hundreds of young men burned their draft cards." b"Ochs may have dropped out of journalism school (at Ohio State, where his fervent political columns got him demoted from the school paper), but he retained a penchant for interviewing strangers whenever he performed, from uptown street corners to dirt roads in the deep South. Early into Side A, on \xe2\x80\x9cIn the Heat of the Summer,\xe2\x80\x9d Ochs recalls scenes from the Harlem riot of 1964, his reporter\xe2\x80\x99s eye for detail gleaming in the \xe2\x80\x9cloudspeaker drowned like a whisperin' sound\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cuniforms shoving with their sticks/Asking, \xe2\x80\x98Are you looking for trouble?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d While touring the summer folk festival circuit, he passed through Mississippi shortly after the abductions and murders of three civil rights workers\xe2\x80\x94James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner\xe2\x80\x94as they registered African Americans to vote. Ochs marched up to their neighbors, pen and paper in hand; their unease and obstinance informs \xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s to the State of Mississippi,\xe2\x80\x9d a scorched-earth screed that implicates rural communities for resisting social progress and denounces the lack of education and options that perpetuate the spiral of intolerance." b'\xe2\x80\x9cTalking Birmingham Jam\xe2\x80\x9d is a brutal lament of the violence in Birmingham, Alabama in 1963, when black residents demonstrated in opposition of the city\xe2\x80\x99s Jim Crow racial segregation laws__.__ In response, President Kennedy sent the National Guard to enforce integration in its schools, catalyzing the Civil Rights Act\xe2\x80\x94and the city\xe2\x80\x99s public safety commissioner, Eugene \xe2\x80\x9cBull\xe2\x80\x9d Connor, replied with attack dogs, high-pressure water hoses, and club-wielding cops. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, all the signs said \xe2\x80\x98Welcome In\xe2\x80\x99/Signed by Governor Wallace and Rin Tin Tin/They said come along and watch the fights/While we feed our dogs on civil rights,\xe2\x80\x9d Ochs seethes in a conversational sing-song lifted from Guthrie, excoriating Connor and George Wallace. \xe2\x80\x9cYou see Alabama is a sovereign state/With sovereign dogs and sovereign hate.\xe2\x80\x9d His words echo powerful ones Martin Luther King, Jr. penned the year before, though it\xe2\x80\x99s not known how deliberately. \xe2\x80\x9cThe silent password was fear. It was a fear not only on the part of the black oppressed, but also in the hearts of the white oppressors,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. King wrote of Birmingham in Why We Can\xe2\x80\x99t Wait. \xe2\x80\x9cThere was also the dread of change, that all too prevalent fear which hounds those whose attitudes have been hardened by the long winter of reaction.\xe2\x80\x9d' b'While I Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore arrived at a fractious moment in American history, it also landed at a strong pivot for Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 beloved Greenwich Village protest-folk microcosm: it was the beginning of the end for this bohemian idyll. Ochs had moved to New York three years earlier, where the same liberal ire that made him an outcast in Ohio ingratiated him instantly with the other young troubadours at the Bitter End and the Gaslight. He played peace rallies at Carnegie Hall with Dylan and palling around with Van Ronk and Paxton afterward at dimly lit poker tables, sprawling in shoddy apartments to tease out new songs. He crashed on the couch of Jim Glover, his college roommate, with whom he\xe2\x80\x99d once formed a band called the Singing Socialists; Glover was now half of the sweetheart folk duo Jim and Jean. (If they sound familiar, their name and saccharine charisma\xe2\x80\x94plus Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 frequent irascibility toward them\xe2\x80\x94were imported wholesale into Inside Llewyn Davis.)' b"Dylan and Ochs were the heaviest hitters in the New York scene, and their reputations preceded them; in this time, they were described by *Melody Maker *in England as the \xe2\x80\x9cking of protest\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthe president,\xe2\x80\x9d respectively. They shared a mostly cordial rivalry, one with the hierarchy firmly apparent. As the Ochs biography Death of a Rebel details, Ochs revered Dylan openly, but Dylan was mercurial in return; he once raved of Ochs, \xe2\x80\x9cI just can't keep up with Phil. And he's getting better and better and better,\xe2\x80\x9d but was also quick to call him a \xe2\x80\x9cturncoat\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9copportunist\xe2\x80\x9d for wanting fame as nakedly as he did. (Once, Dylan allegedly kicked Ochs out of a limousine, hurling the \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99re just a singing journalist\xe2\x80\x9d epithet back in his face as the final indignity.) But for several years, both musicians coexisted in the same topical nexus. They both flourished at the landmark 1963 Newport Folk Festival; Pete Seeger, upon hearing them perform at a counterculture newspaper office, predicted vast fame for both. In one of many overlapping lyrical examples, they both bemoaned the death of civil rights activist Medgar Evers in 1964: Dylan on \xe2\x80\x9cOnly A Pawn in Their Game\xe2\x80\x9d (from The Times They Are a-Changin\xe2\x80\x99), Ochs on \xe2\x80\x9cToo Many Martyrs\xe2\x80\x9d (from his debut, All the News That\xe2\x80\x99s Fit to Sing). And both were well-known volatiles; Dylan was the imperious prodigy simultaneously enjoying and bemoaning society\xe2\x80\x99s quick deification of him. Ochs, one year older, envied his recognition openly and had a likewise-sticky reputation as a hothead alcoholic, a handsome narcissist who\xe2\x80\x99d beaten girlfriends and alienated friends." b'By 1965, Greenwich Village folk had begun splintering into their separate schools of folk ideology: Ochs believed folk songwriting should affect reactionary change in politics via blunt broadcasting of information and resistance, while Dylan teased out philosophical truths through personal ruminations, and daubing that canvas with larger social metaphor. That year, as Ochs continued to file his topical acoustic briefs sourced from *Newsweek *and The Village Voice, Dylan fully sniffed at it, \xe2\x80\x9cgoing electric\xe2\x80\x9d at the Newport Folk Festival and releasing Bringing It All Back Home and Highway 61 Revisited. (Consider the former\xe2\x80\x99s oblique Side A protest, \xe2\x80\x9cMaggie\xe2\x80\x99s Farm,\xe2\x80\x9d a rollicking yet not-so-dissimilar bray of sedition as \xe2\x80\x9cI Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94though, in this case, Dylan was protesting against protest folk.) Commercial favor tipped to Dylan\xe2\x80\x99s rock rancor; it would not bend back toward Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 bleeding headlines. As Christopher Hitchens summarized in the Ochs documentary There But for Fortune, \xe2\x80\x9cPhil\xe2\x80\x99s very tough, grainy songs\xe2\x80\xa6were far more political and tough-minded than the much more generalized, accessible \xe2\x80\x98Blowin\xe2\x80\x99 in the Wind.\xe2\x80\x99 There was a difference between people who liked Bob Dylan\xe2\x80\x94anyone could like Bob Dylan, everybody did\xe2\x80\x94and those who even knew about Phil Ochs.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"But serious-minded as Ochs was, he was not without his gallows humor\xe2\x80\x94the secret weapon of I Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore. \xe2\x80\x9cDraft Dodger Rag\xe2\x80\x9d is a droll riff on shirking the call to Vietnam, spry with the impishness of a boy claiming fang marks on his homework. Ochs spits out any and every excuse that will get him discharged from duty: \xe2\x80\x9cI've got a dislocated disc and a wracked-up back/I'm allergic to flowers and bugs,\xe2\x80\x9d he wheedles. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd when the bombshell hits, I get epileptic fits/And I'm addicted to a thousand drugs.\xe2\x80\x9d Not all his cop-outs have aged well, exactly, by progressive standards (\xe2\x80\x9cI always carry a purse\xe2\x80\x9d sets off a modern air-raid siren), but it\xe2\x80\x99s an endearing novelty. And as with all Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 songs, there is a galvanizing point staked into the sand: the draft fell disproportionately to the poor, the uneducated, and minorities. Another lighter offering, comparatively, is \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s What I Want to Hear,\xe2\x80\x9d a call to arms for the exploited and whiny (inert liberals being a favored punching bag of Ochs\xe2\x80\x99). \xe2\x80\x9cYou tell me that your last good dollar is gone/And you say that your pockets are bare,\xe2\x80\x9d he sings at a sharp but not-unkind clip. Soon enough, \xe2\x80\x9cNow don't tell me your troubles/No, I don't have the time to spare/But if you want to get together and fight/Good buddy, that's what I want to hear.\xe2\x80\x9d It is a call to action but, notably, not to knee-jerk jingoism; mobilization is easy in the first flush of fear but resistance, if taken to conclusion, will always be a pyrrhic victory. Here, Ochs tapers one of his core, conclusively patriotic theses: that he, and his listeners, should be willing to lose some comforts to keep the world turning." b"The most affecting moment of the album is \xe2\x80\x9cThat Was the President,\xe2\x80\x9d Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 eulogy to President Kennedy that speaks to the shattered disillusionment of his generation. It\xe2\x80\x99s sung as softly as an echo across wooden pews. \xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s a memory to share, here's a memory to save/Of the sudden early ending of command,\xe2\x80\x9d he sighs. \xe2\x80\x9cYet a part of you and a part of me is buried in his grave/That was the President and that was the man.\xe2\x80\x9d It aches with lack of resolution; it\xe2\x80\x99s a memorial to the idealism the president fostered, whose administration itself shuttered in unfulfilled promise of its progressive agenda. (There is more than a wisp of the paternal here; Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 father also died in 1963.)" b'Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 music after I Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore would be pocked by outside influences; he jealously watched less overtly political colleagues like Dylan and Peter, Paul and Mary reach national fame, and struggled to reconcile his ardency for social reform with his craving to be a star. He watched artists advance on his back; Joan Baez\xe2\x80\x99s cover of his compassionate tune \xe2\x80\x9cThere But for Fortune\xe2\x80\x9d charted in the Top 50 in both America and the UK, higher than he\xe2\x80\x99d ever managed. Frustrated, he retreated from earnest topicality; his next full studio album, Pleasures of the Harbor, folded in lush, Sinatra-strings and ragtime piano, adding a poppier bend to his dour character studies of empty socialites and downtrodden flower vendors. He became disillusioned with demonstrating; he and his Yippie party cohorts staged a protest at 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, during which they nominated an actual pig for president (name: Pigasus), but the mirth ended in a massive, era-defining riot between protesters and police. He retreated from New York, his wife, and his daughter, drinking heavily, heaped his flagging idealism on the communist uprisings of Fidel Castro and the Marxist Chilean revolutionary Salvador Allende. His erratic creative path onward included self-funded, unsuccessful tours through South America and Africa (where he was arrested for performing at a political rally in Uruguay, robbed and strangled in Tanzania), and attempting to replicate Elvis Presley\xe2\x80\x99s 1969 comeback show in Las Vegas with his own mystifying performance in gold lam\xc3\xa9 at Carnegie Hall. He dabbled more in symphonic pop and recruited Van Dyke Parks for a country-western turn (sarcastically called Phil Ochs\xe2\x80\x99 Greatest Hits), all of which fell flat commercially.' b'Abetted by his rampant alcoholism and persistent writer\xe2\x80\x99s block, Ochs slid into a bipolar breakdown; not even the end of the Vietnam War, and its ensuing celebratory concerts, could rouse him from his nosedive. He adopted an alternate identity called \xe2\x80\x9cJohn Train\xe2\x80\x9d and went on paranoid rants onstage, insisting he had murdered Phil Ochs and the CIA was after him. (The miserable irony of the FBI\xe2\x80\x99s monitoring.) He slept on the streets, got arrested, attacked friends. On April 9, 1976, amid the gaudy patriotism of the Bicentennial Celebration, he hanged himself at his sister\xe2\x80\x99s home in Queens.' b'But for a moment, Phil Ochs existed in pure conviction. I Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Marching Anymore reminds us to resist the dangers of acquiescence, to take to the streets to demand the country that still persists in our hearts, even if it\xe2\x80\x99s not before to our eyes anymore. It would be easy to stop marching in apathy or in defeat, but Ochs pushed for something greater: a righteous, excruciating, beautiful reclamation. Small wonder his powerful polemics have been covered and updated by the Clash, Neil Young, Jello Biafra: His fight was never just his, never just of his time. And in the right hands, it will never die.'

column7: b'With a newly pared down sound, Austra\xe2\x80\x99s latest\xc2\xa0synth-pop record concerns itself primarily with the dark side of \xe2\x80\x9cthe personal is political.\xe2\x80\x9d But it is essentially optimistic, and presents solutions.'
column8: b'The past year has seen a wider\xc2\xa0move towards\xc2\xa0the\xc2\xa0genre of \xe2\x80\x9ctiny utopias\xe2\x80\x9d: small, invented idylls that, unlike the colossal world reconfigurations common in speculative fiction, are built to human scale. Whether polemic or meditative, they share a vision: a world better than our own and also within reach. It is, of course, obvious why one might want this now, might long to crawl out of this orange apocalypse and into a utopia. Art might not, as the myth goes, get better during bleak times, but bleak times do make people cling harder to the art they\xe2\x80\x99ve got.' b'Electronic artist Katie Stelmanis has always made political art, blatantly or subtly, from her time with riot grrl band Galaxy to her more muted project, Austra. But since 2013\xe2\x80\x99s Olympia, politics have gotten more, well, urgent. Stelmanis is Canadian and wrote *Future Politics *before the election results and before fascism started winning, but the album\xe2\x80\x99s Inauguration Day release is now looming, inescapable subtext. \xe2\x80\x9cI was kind of worried it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be something that people would be interested in, or connect to... [but it\xe2\x80\x99s] become more relevant than I could\xe2\x80\x99ve ever imagined,\xe2\x80\x9d she told CBC.' b'Future Politics doesn\xe2\x80\x99t depart from Austra\xe2\x80\x99s sound so much as filter it. Stelmanis\xe2\x80\x99 band, and its sound, are pared down, producing straightforward, minimal music akin to club artists like\xc2\xa0Marie Davidson or Kate Wax, or perhaps Bj\xc3\xb6rk\xe2\x80\x99s electronic work. Even Stelmanis\xe2\x80\x99 voice, capable of great force, sounds less operatic than deliberately hollowed-out, as in the tentative melodies of \xe2\x80\x9cBeyond a\xc2\xa0Mortal\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cGaia\xe2\x80\x9d or the collapsing coloratura of \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a Monster.\xe2\x80\x9d' b"Austra fills the extra space by surfacing the themes formerly held in the band\xe2\x80\x99s subtext, though\xc2\xa0occasionally stated, like *Olympia\xe2\x80\x99*s \xe2\x80\x9cI Don't Care (I\xe2\x80\x99m a Man).\xe2\x80\x9d While writing this album, Stelmanis was into science fiction and political manifestos\xe2\x80\x94in particular, the Accelerationist Manifesto and Marge Piercy\xe2\x80\x99s canonical Woman on the Edge of Time, a novel whose utopian visions reach its main character amid abuse and institutional detention. \xe2\x80\x9cIt needed to have a purpose other than just my own ego,\xe2\x80\x9d Stelmanis said. And while Future Politics isn\xe2\x80\x99t impersonal\xe2\x80\x94throughout it\xc2\xa0runs an undercurrent of loss, partly the result of personal and professional departures in Stelmanis\xe2\x80\x99 life\xe2\x80\x94the album concerns itself primarily with the dark side of \xe2\x80\x9cthe personal is political,\xe2\x80\x9d the slow parallel rot of self-contained\xc2\xa0depression and political turmoil. When the definition of disordered thinking resembles, so closely and measurably, a world increasingly disordered and unmoored from fact, what do you even do? How do you think? How do you begin to conceive a way out?" b'It\xe2\x80\x99s fitting that the first track of the album is a question: \xe2\x80\x9cWhat if we were alive?\xe2\x80\x9d Stelmanis sings over synth pads and unsettled chords, like closing credits for a bittersweet ending. \xe2\x80\x9cFreepower,\xe2\x80\x9d like its near-namesake, presents a twitchy, unsettled mix and a plea for the personal. The title track is a driving sequencer track shaped like an anthem, but gets only as far as a battle cry: \xe2\x80\x9cfuture politics.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s still mourning in the present to get past, after all, and the midsection of the album dwells upon it. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a Monster\xe2\x80\x9d begins like the bridge of a club track, the sort with tears-on-the-dancefloor and throbbing backing vocals, but where that track would provide release, there\xe2\x80\x99s only hollowness: \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t feel nothing anymore.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cGaia\xe2\x80\x9d dwells upon loss as well; the track most reminiscent of Bj\xc3\xb6rk, it\xe2\x80\x99s like a cut from a less optimistic *Biophilia**, *where the environment\xe2\x80\x99s full of more death than life.' b'Despite all this, *Future Politics *is essentially an optimistic album, and presents solutions. First: self-care is important. \xe2\x80\x9cDeep Thought,\xe2\x80\x9d a minute-long, a cappella harp palpitation at the end of the record, is reminiscent of dream pop or chillout, or even ASMR\xe2\x80\x94soothing genres. Second: make connections. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\xe2\x80\x99s possible for me to write in a major key,\xe2\x80\x9d Stelmanis said (partly in jest) while touring Olympia, but \xe2\x80\x9cI Love You More Than You Love Yourself\xe2\x80\x9d accomplishes this musically and metaphorically, taking an idea last seen in dull dance backfill and turning it into an ode to redemptive love. \xe2\x80\x9cUtopia\xe2\x80\x9d has the album\xe2\x80\x99s lushest arrangement, a whirlwind of chiming trance synths, cheery octaves and airy background vocals, and its most indomitably romantic lyric: \xe2\x80\x9cI only want to hold your hand my own damn life/I can picture a place where everyone feels it too.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s got the highest notes and most triumphant melodies of the album. It\xe2\x80\x99s music to be escaped into, whether on dance floors or alone somewhere, filled with a little less despair.'

column7: b'Real Ting is the first project of the impressive rising young London MC Stefanie Allen (aka Stefflon Don). The mixtape is a slightly rocky intro, but her raw talent shines through.'
column8: b'In late 2015, then-ascendant South London rappers Section Boyz made their presence felt with \xe2\x80\x9cLock Arff,\xe2\x80\x9d the breakout single that netted them a place on BBC\xe2\x80\x99s Sound of 2016 longlist at the end of that year. It\xe2\x80\x99s usually an indicator of success when a song gets remixed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLock Arff,\xe2\x80\x9d a sprawling opus that boasts contributions from each member of the six-person crew, left little room for anyone else to get a look-in between verses. But a version with two new verses by Stefanie Allen (aka Stefflon Don), stripped of everything but the original beat and chorus, impressed the Section Boyz enough that they cosigned its official video treatment. The remix and video in turn raised Stefflon Don\xe2\x80\x99s profile enough to land her on the 2017\xc2\xa0Sound of\xe2\x80\xa6 longlist at the end of last year.' b'In between, the young London MC stayed busy\xe2\x80\x94churning out more remixes or hopping on songs by compatriots like Angel and grime veteran Lethal Bizzle. All of that that momentum culminated in Real Ting, her first full length solo project, released just before 2016 drew to a close.' b'With a running time of under 40 minutes, the tape\xe2\x80\x99s rocky start is acutely felt, taking up more space than it should in proportion to the remaining nine tracks. \xe2\x80\x9cIntro\xe2\x80\x9d is a somewhat cartoonish announcement of Allen\xe2\x80\x99s formal arrival on the scene (\xe2\x80\x9cLook to the sky, it\xe2\x80\x99s a bird, it\xe2\x80\x99s a plane, it\xe2\x80\x99s a Don!\xe2\x80\x9d) set to an excerpt from Nile Rodgers\xe2\x80\x99 Coming To America score. The melody plays during the scene in which King Jaffe Joffer tracks Prince Akeem down in Queens; from the eastern borough Allen bears south for inspiration on \xe2\x80\x9cReal Ting.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s startlingly derivative of Brooklynite Young M.A\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cOOOUUU\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94from the punchline delivery to the ad libs.' b'Comparison to established artists can be a boon or a blight for an emerging talent, foreshadowing similar levels of success in the former case or inviting dismissal in the latter. Since \xe2\x80\x9cLock Arff\xe2\x80\x9d went viral, discussion of Stefflon Don has often touched on the parallels between her and Nicki Minaj: owing to her cadence, a penchant for brightly-colored hairstyles and a tendency to slip back in and out of Jamaican patois, which can resemble Minaj\xe2\x80\x99s Trinidadian Creole to the untrained ear. Thankfully in Allen\xe2\x80\x99s case the similarities seem both incidental and positive; no rapper could or should corner the market for bravado, and Stefflon Don clearly possesses a lot of it.' b'Real Ting picks up steam by track three \xe2\x80\x9cTight Nooki,\xe2\x80\x9d an upbeat dancehall jaunt featuring Jeremih. It capitalizes on the unstoppable \xe2\x80\x9cBam Bam\xe2\x80\x9d riddim, made famous by Chaka Demus & Pliers in the early \xe2\x80\x9990s, and complements the pair\xe2\x80\x99s previous collaboration on Jeremih\xe2\x80\x99s Late Nights: Europe mixtape. \xe2\x80\x9cFamily Ties\xe2\x80\x9d is deeply personal, touching on a childhood marked by violence and her mother\xe2\x80\x99s legal troubles (\xe2\x80\x9cShe was looking at ten but the lawyer beat the case/By the grace and the power or the mercy of the state.\xe2\x80\x9d) The family affair is rounded out by her brother Dutch, who goes into detail about his own run-ins with the law, and UK House star Donae\xe2\x80\x99o. \xe2\x80\x9cEnvy Us,\xe2\x80\x9d another dancehall-tinged standout with an assist from Tottenham upstart Abra Cadabra, is a good example of the rhythmic space for which Stefflon Don\xe2\x80\x99s voice is well-suited. But the tape\xe2\x80\x99s overall scattered quality positions it as a teaser of things to come rather than a cohesive collection.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to tell if or where the line between a mixtape and an album should be drawn\xe2\x80\x94in 2017 a mixtape can be the vehicle for an artist\xe2\x80\x99s unpolished experiments, or be in with a serious chance of winning a Grammy. On *Real Ting, *listeners get a proper introduction to Stefflon Don and a fuller understanding of her artistry. She sings as well as she raps, is a scholar of many genres (trap, dancehall, house and more) and has wide-ranging influences; the outtake from a Margaret Thatcher interview on \xe2\x80\x9cLik Down\xe2\x80\x9d and even the antics of \xe2\x80\x9cIntro\xe2\x80\x9d are revelatory of her cultural interests beyond the music. So if Real Ting is her CV, it\xe2\x80\x99ll be fun to watch her find her footing at work.'

column7: b'The\xc2\xa0debut EP from cryptic\xc2\xa0London artist Naaahhh offers\xc2\xa0five tracks of murky electronic ambience, though\xc2\xa0it contains\xc2\xa0unmistakable traces of UK rave culture.'
column8: b'Kiran Sande, the shadowy figure pulling the strings behind London electronic outpost\xc2\xa0Blackest Ever Black, is one of those label bosses who\xc2\xa0can make a record sound essential through sheer turn of phrase. The debut release by Naaahhh comes with next to zero biographical information\xe2\x80\x94just the promise that he, she, or they hail from \xe2\x80\x9cunder London,\xe2\x80\x9d plus a found photo of a hippy raver, cross-legged and grinning on an Afghan rug, with a half-rolled joint laid out in front of her. Luckily, Sande\xe2\x80\x99s liner-notes make up for some of\xc2\xa0the gaps in the narrative, promising \xe2\x80\x9csidereal downers for all hardcore ravers\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cparanoid street music meets the cosmic disturbances of musique concr\xc3\xa8te, the MDMA spine-freeze of isolationism and England\xe2\x80\x99s hidden reverse.\xe2\x80\x9d With a billing like that, it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to resist.' b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not that Naaahhh\xe2\x80\x99s music struggles to live up to the accompanying prose, exactly. But Themes\xc2\xa0has you squinting into its depths in search of the promised ingredients, like a fortune-teller sifting through tea leaves. Here we have five tracks of murky ambience, devoid of anything you might recognize as a beat, but rhythmic nonetheless\xe2\x80\x94an ooze of sound with dark, rippling tides mottling its surface. Casting around for antecedents, you might compare \xe2\x80\x9cEmpty Rituals\xe2\x80\x9d to the more haunted and abstract works of Coil or Nurse With Wound, veteran British industrial units for whom sound was a carrier for occult or spiritual currents; or \xe2\x80\x9cNeck Devour\xe2\x80\x9d to the blasted, Gristle-y dub of Wolf Eyes circa Dead Hills.' b'True to Sande\xe2\x80\x99s description, though, there are unmistakable traces of UK rave culture buried in Themes\xe2\x80\x99 fabric. The throbbing, faintly seasick synth washes of \xe2\x80\x9cBlooz\xe2\x80\x9d imagine some ancient jungle or hardcore 12\xe2\x80\x9d\xc2\xa0with the beats and bass peeled away, leaving just floating, faintly toxic atmosphere. \xe2\x80\x9cMy Theme\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cTheme 2,\xe2\x80\x9d meanwhile, could be club music as viewed from the \xe2\x80\x9cStranger Things\xe2\x80\x9d alternate dimension of Upside Down. Muffled rhythms pulse interminably, gooey bass notes affect a dismal plod, and high quavering melody lines ghost around in the higher registers\xe2\x80\x94a grotesque parody of rave\xe2\x80\x99s ecstatic euphoria.' b'Over and out in 28 minutes, Themes draws to a close before your first impressions have quite had time to coalesce. This is neither uncommon nor necessarily unwelcome for a label that deals in the cryptic. But there is the sense that this is a project still finding its form. Whether Naaahhh follows on the heels of former Blackest Ever Black\xc2\xa0groups like Dalhous and Raime in\xc2\xa0blossoming into something dimly\xc2\xa0beautiful, or Themes remains a one-off emission from the dark side, remains to be seen.'
